English = answer.; (As a Noun) What you say or write to someone as a result of what they have said or written to you. English = answer, reply, response.; (As a Noun) A possible solution to a problem. English = answer.

answering%20machine.description: (As a Noun) A device which you connect to your telephone so that it records telephone calls while you are out. English = answering machine.

answer%20telephone.description: (As a Noun) The act of telephoning someone. English = telephone call.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To pick up the telephone when it rings or because you want to make a telephone call. English = answer the telephone.

anthropology.description: (As a Noun) The scientific study of people, society, and culture. English = anthropology.

enjoy.description: (As a Noun) The feeling of pleasure that you have when you do or experience something you like. English = enjoyment.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To get a lot of enjoyment from something. English = relish.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have that feeling of pleasure  when you do or experience something you like. English = enjoy, (be) enjoyable.

eagerness.description: (As a Noun) The desire to do something very much or the display of the feeling of being excited about doing something or liking something very much. English = eagerness, enthusiasm, zeal.; (As a Noun) Great enthusiasm, especially in connection to work, religion or politics. English = zeal.; (As a Noun) The feeling of looking forward to some pleasant or exciting event. English =  anticipation.

anticoagulant.description: (As a Noun) An ANTICOAGULANT is a drug/medication that reduces blood clotting.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ANTICOAGULANT. If you know a sign for ANTICOAGULANT used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

antiemetic.description: (As a Noun) An ANTIEMETIC drug/medication that reduces nausea, i.e. If you are sea sick you can have an antiemetic.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ANTIEMETIC. If you know a sign for ANTIEMETIC used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

anti-inflammatory.description: (As a Noun) An ANTI-INFLAMMATORY drug/medication reduces inflammation (swelling, red etc); (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ANTI-INFLAMMATORY. If you know a sign for ANTI-INFLAMMATORY used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

anti-psychotic.description: (As Modifier) ANTI-PSYCHOTIC medication is used to treat 'psychotic' mental health conditions such as schizophrenia; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ANTI-PSYCHOTIC. If you know a sign for ANTI-PSYCHOTIC used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

antiseptic.description: (As a Noun) The action of putting (or removing) a substance onto (or from) a surface with quick, light, strokes using something like cotton wool.; (As a Noun) A substance which is regularly dabbed onto cuts and wounds and which kills germs and harmful bacteria. English = antiseptic.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put or remove a substance onto or from a surface with quick, light, strokes using something like cotton wool. English = dab.

antlers.description: (As a Noun) The branched horns on the head of a male deer. English = antlers.; (As a Noun) A large wild animal that eats grass and leaves. Male ones usually have large, branching horns. English = deer.; (As a Noun) A deer with large antlers that lives in northern areas of Europe, Asia, and America. English = reindeer.

opposite.description: (As a Noun) A thing which is completely different from another thing of the same kind in one particular way. English = opposite.; (As a Noun) Of signs and words, to be a word or sign which is completely different in meaning from another word or sign in one particular way. English = opposite, antonym.; (As a Noun) In mathematics, the negative of a number; numbers that, when added, the answer is zero. English = opposite.

anus.description: (As a Noun) The hole between a person's buttocks, from which faeces leave the body. Formal English = anus  (a polite or medical word). Vulgar English = arse, arsehole.

frustration.description: (As a Noun) The feeling of being upset and angry because you are unable to do what you would like to do. English = frustration.; (As a Noun) A feeling of nervousness or worry. English = anxiety.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To feel angry and upset because you are unable to do what you would like to do. English = (be) frustrated.

whatever.description: (As a Noun) A thing, an event, or an idea which is not a particular one of its kind. English = anything.; (As a Noun) A person who is not any particular person. English = anyone, anybody.; (As a Noun) A place which is not any particular or exact place. English = anywhere.

turn over.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To make something, usually a flat object, reverse its orientation so that the side that was up is now down and vice versa. English = turn, turn over.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of flat objects, to reverse orientation so that the side that was up is now down and vice versa. English = turn, turn over.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning of a sign sentence to give further information (to your partner or to your own previous statements) which is at variance to what has been said before. English = on the other hand, anyhow, in any case.

any%20time.description: (As a Noun) A thing, an event, or an idea which is not a particular one of its kind. English = anything.; (As a Noun) A person who is not any particular person. English = anyone, anybody.; (As a Noun) A place which is not any particular or exact place. English = anywhere.

matter (not matter).description: (Interactive) Used to try to reassure your addressee when they are worried or concerned about something. English = 'Never mind', 'Don't worry', 'It's not important', and so on.; (Interactive) Used in response to your addressee's questions expressing concern for you when you want them to stop worrying or tell them everything is okay. English = 'It doesn't matter', 'No problems', 'Forget about it'; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of the first of two sign phrases to mean that what you say in the second phrase is surprising given the first phrase. English = despite, despite that.

separate.description: (As a Noun) The movement of two or more things away from each other so that they are no longer connected. English = separation.; (As a Noun) Of a married or de facto couple, the act of living apart and deciding to end the relationship. English = separation. Idiomatic English = break up.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move apart from each other and no longer be connected. English = separate.

apartment%20(building).description: (As a Noun) A tall structure or a high rise building such as an office building or a large hotel. English = high rise.; (As a Noun) A set of rooms for living in, usually on one floor of a large building. English = flat, apartment, home unit.

apology.description: (As a Noun) Something that you say or write in order to tell someone that you are sorry that you have hurt them or caused trouble for them.  English = apology.; (As a Noun) The act of forgiving someone. English = forgiveness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say to someone that you are sorry that you have hurt them or caused trouble for them. English = apologise.

apostrophe.description: (As a Noun) A symbol written before or after an 's' at the end of a word to indicate that what follows belongs to or relates to the word, as in 'the cat's whiskers'. English = apostrophe.; (As a Noun) A mark written to indicate that one or more letters have been omitted from a word, as in 'can't and 'he'll'. English = apostrophe.

terrible.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) A situation or experience which is very serious and unpleasant. English = (be) terrible.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cause you to feel great shock, fear, and disgust. English = (be) horrible, (be) shocking, (be) dreadful, (be) appalling.; (Interactive) Used alone to show that you feel very unpleasant, shocked, frightened, or disgusted. English = 'Terrible!', 'How awful!', 'Shocking!', 'Appalling!'

clothes.description: (As a Noun) The things that people wear, such as shirts, coats, trousers, and dresses. English = clothes, clothing. Formal English = garments.; (As a Noun) Clothes that people wear, especially on a formal occasion. Formal English = apparel.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put a piece of clothing or clothes on your body. English = wear (something), get dressed, clothe.

face.description: (As a Noun) The front of your head from your chin to your forehead. English = face.; (As a Noun) The shape of your eyes, nose, mouth and other parts of your face, particularly in terms of how beautiful or how handsome you are. English = features, looks, appearance.

appendix.description: (As a Noun) Your APPENDIX is a small closed tube inside your body which is attached to your digestive system.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for APPENDIX. If you know a sign for APPENDIX used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

applause.description: (As a Noun) The sound or action of people bringing their hands together to make a noise in order to show approval, for example when they have enjoyed a play or a concert. English = applause, clapping.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To bring your hands together and make a noise in order to show approval, for example when you have enjoyed a play or a concert. English = applaud, clap.; (Interactive) Used alone to show your appreciation of what someone has done or to encourage them to continue. English = 'Good on you', 'Good work!'

apple.description: (As a Noun) A round fruit with a smooth skin and firm white flesh. English = apple.; (As a Noun) Something which grows on a tree or a bush and which contains seeds or a stone covered by a substance that you can eat. Apples, oranges, grapes, and bananas are examples. English = fruit.; (Note) Most Auslan signers use this sign for APPLE only and use another sign, found in this dictionary, for FRUIT.

touch.description: (As a Noun) The act of putting you fingertips gently on something. English = touch, tap.; (As a Noun) A request, usually written, to ask formally to be allowed to have something or do something. English = application.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To gently put your fingertips on something. English = touch, tap.

apply.description: (As a Noun) The practical use to which something, especially a theory or subject of study, can be put. English = application.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be relevant to a particular person or situation. English = apply.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a rule, system, or skill, to use it in a particular situation or activity. English = apply.

letter.description: (As a Noun) A message written on a piece of paper and which has been sent to someone, usually through the post. English = letter, missive, correspondence.; (As a Noun) A formal written request to someone to ask to have something, especially a job from an employer. English = application.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To send a written message on a piece of paper to someone, usually through the post. English = correspond.

slice.description: (As a Noun) A triangular piece of a pie or cake. English = slice, segment, portion.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cut a triangular piece out of a pie or cake; to slice a cake; to segment a cake; to cut into portions; to apportion.

increase.description: (As a Noun) A rise in the number, level, or amount of something. English = increase.; (As a Noun) An increase in the height of something; or an increase in your wages or salary.  English = rise; raise.; (As a Noun) Money you have put aside (usually in a bank or a building society) for another time when you may need it, or an increase in that money. English = savings.

thanks.description: (As a Noun) The friendly feelings you have towards someone and the wish to thank them because they have given you something or done something for you. English = appreciation, gratefulness, thanks.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have friendly feelings towards someone and to wish to thank them because they have given you something or done something for you. English = (be) grateful, (be) appreciative, (be) thankful; appreciate, give thanks, show your appreciation.

arrest.description: (As a Noun) The chasing and catching of someone who is then put somewhere where they cannot get out until it is decided what to do with them. Used especially for the activities of the police or soldiers in war. English = arrest, capture, apprehension.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To chase and catch someone and then put them somewhere where they cannot get out. Used especially for the activities of the police or soldiers in war. English = arrest, capture. Formal English = apprehend.

apprentice.description: (As a Noun) A young person who works with someone in order to learn their skill. English = apprentice.; (As a Noun) A fixed period of time in which someone works with a person who has a particular skill in order to learn the skill. English = apprenticeship.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be under the power of an employer for a fixed period of time during which the employer is obliged to teach you a skill. English = (be) apprenticed, (be) bonded.

approach.description: (General Definition) Of a person or an entity, to go closer or nearer to someone or something, or any action or any thing directly or indirectly associated with this.; (As a Noun) The act of moving closer to a thing or person. English = approach.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of things or people, to go closer or nearer to someone or something. English = approach.

scavenge.description: (As a Noun) The act of taking a child into your own family and making it legally your son or daughter. English = adoption.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make something yours which is not properly yours (e.g., if you accidentally find it, tell yourself it is lost or discarded, and then decide to keep it). English = appropriate, scavenge, keep. Idiomatic English = come across, pocket.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To take a child into your own family and to make it legally your own son or daughter. English = adopt.

proper.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be real and satisfactory rather than inadequate in some way; to be correct or the most suitable; to be socially acceptable and right. English = (be) proper, (be) appropriate.; (As Modifier) Used next to a verb to mean that the action was done in the most correct or suitable way or in a way is socially acceptable. English = properly, appropriately.

pass (test).description: (As a Noun) A mark you get in an exam or test which means you have got an acceptable standard, usually by getting more than half of the answers right. English = pass.; (As a Noun) Agreement which is given to a plan or a request, particularly because it meets official or formal standards. English = approval.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To do a test or an exam and to be judged to have an acceptable standard, usually getting more than half of the answers right. English = pass an exam.

certify.description: (As a Noun) Formal acceptance of a document by the government or by someone in authority, especially if that is shown by a stamp or mark on it. English = certification, approval.; (As a Noun) Formal acceptance of a policy or action by the government or by someone in authority. English = approval.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a document, to be formally accepted by the government or by someone in authority, especially by having been stamped or marked in some way. English = (be) official, (be) certified, (be) approved.

approximation.description: (As a Noun) A statement of the number, time or position of something which is close to the correct amount but which is not exact. The exact figures may or may not be know. English = approximation.; (As a Noun) A statement of the number, time or position of something which is a reasoned guess based on evidence when the exact answer is not known. English = estimate.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say or give a number, time, or position for something which is close to the correct number, time, or position but is not exact. The exact figures may or may not be known. English = approximate.

apricot.description: (As a Noun) A small, soft, round fruit with yellowish-orange flesh and a stone inside. English = apricot.

apron.description: (As a Noun) A piece of clothing that you put on over the front of your normal clothes and tie round your waist, especially when you are cooking, in order to prevent your clothes from getting dirty. English = apron.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put on an apron.

aquarius.description: (General Definition) The action of tilting a container that is being held at shoulder height, or any action or any thing directly or indirectly associated with this, especially Aquarius.; (As a Noun) A constellation and a star of the Zodiac (the water bearer). English = Aquarius.

arbitrary.description:
(As a Verb or Adjective) In linguistics, the lack of a clear relationship between the form of a word or sign and its meaning. 
English = arbitrary; (Note) The signer in the video is giving a definition in Auslan for the English term ARBITRARY as it is used in an academic or educational context, especially when talking or writing about linguistics.; (Note) This is not published because there is no Auslan video explaining it.

bow (archery).description: (As a Noun) A weapon for shooting arrows. It consists of a long piece of wood bent into a curve by a string attached to both its ends. English = bow.; (As a Noun) A sport in which people shoot at a target with a bow and arrow. English = archery.; (As a Noun) Someone who shoots with a bow and arrow. English = archer.

architect.description: (As a Noun) The preparation of technical drawings. English = drafting, draughting.; (As a Noun) A person whose job it is to prepare technical drawings. English = draftsman, draughtsman.; (As a Noun) A person who designs buildings. English = architect.

ruler.description: (As a Noun) A long, narrow, flat  piece of wood, metal, or plastic with straight edges marked in inches or centimetres, which you use to measure things or to draw straight lines. English = ruler.; (As a Noun) A person whose job is to prepare technical drawings and plans. English = draftsman, draughtsman.; (As a Noun) The ability to draw and prepare technical drawings and plans. English = draftsmanship, draughtsmanship.

difficulty.description: (As a Noun) The degree or amount to which something requires effort to do. English = difficulty.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To involve a lot of effort or energy and to be not easy to do, understand, or solve. English = (be) difficult, (be) hard.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be tiring and involving a lot of effort. English = (be) arduous, (be) strenuous.

are.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) The plural and the second person singular of the present tense of the verb 'be'.; (Note) Used in Sign English systems to represent the English word “are”. Representing English words that do not normally occur in Auslan is sometimes necessary, e.g., when someone is “reading out” in signs to a group of people the contents of something written in English, or when someone is quoting “word for word” in signs what someone else said or wrote in English.; (Note) Some younger signers accept this as the usual way to represent the English word “are”, but the majority of signers, especially older signers, or much more likely to fingerspell A-R-E if they have a need to do this.

area.description: (As a Noun) A particular bit of some space (such as a room, building, city, country, or the world). English = part, area, district, region, place, locality.; (As a Noun) A particular subject or area of activity or interest. English = field.; (As a Noun) The place where a person or thing is located or to be found. English = whereabouts.

area%20(surface%20area).description: (As a Noun) In mathematics, geometry and surveying, the measurement of the size of the surface of a geometric shape or a piece of land. English = area, surface area.; (Note) Originally only an alternative Australasian Signed English sign for the Auslan sign ‘area’. Now this variant is used by some teachers in maths and geometry specifically for ‘surface area’.

argument.description: (As a Noun) A disagreement with someone about something, sometimes resulting in speaking or signing angrily. English = argument.; (As a Noun) A disagreement with someone about something. English = dispute.; (As a Noun) A discussion in which people express different opinions about a subject. English = debate.

ram.description: (As a Noun) An adult male sheep. English = ram.; (As a Noun) A farm animal with a thick woolly coat. They are kept for their wool or for their meat. English = sheep.; (As a Noun) A constellation and sign of the Zodiac (the ram). English = Aries.

arm.description: (As a Noun) The long part of your body that is attached to your shoulder and has a hand at the end. You have two of them. English = arm.

lounge chair.description: (As a Noun) A comfortable chair which has a support on each side for your arms. English = lounge chair, armchair.

army.description: (As a Noun) A large organised group of people who are armed and trained to fight on land in a war. English = army.

around.description: (General Definition) Of any two things (real or imaginary, abstract or concrete), for one thing to go around the other thing, or any thing or activity that can be directly or metaphorically associated with this in context.; (As a Noun) The path or places around something.; (As a Noun) A journey around a circular path or course. English = circuit, lap.

around%20(approximately).description: (As a Noun) A statement of the number, time or position of something which is a reasoned guess based on evidence when the exact answer is not known. English = estimate.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be close to the correct number of something, but not to be exact. English = (be) around, (be) about, (be) approximate.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say or give a number, time, or position for something which is only a reasoned guess based on evidence because the exact answer is not known. English = estimate.

around%20the%20clock.description: (As a Noun) Time that you spend at your job in addition to your normal working hours. English = overtime.; (As Modifier) Used after a verb (action) sign to mean the action takes place over several hours making it take longer than is usual. Idiomatic English = hour by hour, round the clock, around the clock.; (As Modifier) Used after the sign work to mean the work is in addition to your normal working hours. English = overtime.

plan.description: (As a Noun) A method of achieving something that you have worked out in detail beforehand. English = plan.; (As a Noun) The plans and preparations which you make so that something will happen or be possible. English = arrangements.; (As a Noun) The story of a film, novel, or play and the way in which it evolves. English = plot.

management.description: (As a Noun) The responsibility for and actions involved in controlling an organisation, business, or system. English = management.; (As a Noun) The person or people responsible for controlling an organisation, business, or system. English = manager, management; (As a Noun) The plans for an event or meeting to happen. English = arrangement, arrangements.

arrival.description: (As a Noun) The act of coming to or ending up at a place, which is high or important, after a journey. English = arrival, reaching.; (As a Noun) The achieving of some goal, usually after a lot of effort. English = attainment.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To reach a place which is high or important at the end of a journey. English = arrive at, reach, get to.

arrow.description: (As a Noun) A long thin weapon which is sharp and pointed at one end. It is shot from a bow. English = arrow.

engraving.description: (As a Noun) A picture or design that has been either cut into a surface with a sharp object or acid and/or printed from a plate which has been cut. English = engraving,  etching.; (As a Noun) The creation of drawings, paintings, and sculpture, when these things are considered to be beautiful or to express a particular idea. English = art.; (As a Noun) Objects, such as paintings or pieces of sculpture, which are considered to be beautiful and which are part of a society's culture. English = art.

artery.description: (As a Noun) Tube carrying blood away from the heart. English = artery.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ARTERY. If you know a sign for ARTERY used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

arthritis.description: (As a Noun) ARTHRITIS is a medical condition in which the joints in someone's body are swollen and painful.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ARTHRITIS. If you know a sign for ARTHRITIS used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

arthroscopy.description: (As a Noun) An ARTHROSCOPY is when a tube is inserted into a joint (the knee, for example) to inspect or repair the joint tissue.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ARTHROSCOPY. If you know a sign for ARTHROSCOPY used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

secretary.description: (As a Noun) A person who is employed to do office work, such as typing letters, answering phone calls, and arranging meetings; a person whose job in a club or other organisation involves keeping records and writing letters. English = secretary.; (As a Noun) A room or a part of a building where people work sitting at desks. English = office.; (As a Noun) A person who works in an office, bank, or law court, and whose job is to look after the records or accounts. English = clerk, office worker.

pronunciation.description: (As a Noun) The way in which you say a particular word. English = pronunciation, articulation.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say in words what you feel and think. English = articulate.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say a word in a particular way. English = pronounce, articulate.

joke.description: (As a Noun) Something which is said or done in order to make people laugh. English = joke.; (As a Noun) An object which has been make to look like something valuable or real, often in order to deceive people. English = fake.; (As a Noun) An attempt to make someone believe you will do something when you do not really intend to do it. English = bluff.

artillery.description: (As a Noun) Large, powerful guns which are transported on wheels and used by an army. English = artillery.

why.description: (As a Noun) The thing that makes an event happen. English = cause.; (As a Noun) The fact or situation which explains why something happens or exists. English = reason.; (As Modifier) Used to link or join two sentences of which the second is the reason or cause of the event or events described in the first. English = because.

asbestos.description: (As a Noun) ASBESTOS is a grey material which does not burn and which has been used in building as a protection against fire or heat. It can be found in old buildings. It has to be handled carefully because it can cause serious illness including cancer if dust or particles are inhaled.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term ASBESTOS. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ASBESTOS (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for ASBESTOS used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

ascension.description: (As a Noun) Of a person, the act of moving up into the air. English = ascension.; (As a Noun) Of a person or soul, the act of going up into heaven. English = ascension.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to move up into the air. English = ascend.

ashtray.description: (As a Noun) A small dish in which people can put the ash from their cigarettes and cigars. English = ashtray.; (As a Noun) The grey or back powdery substance that is left after a cigarette or cigar is burnt. English = ash.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To flick the ash off the end of a cigarette or cigar by tapping your finger on it, usually into an ashtray. English = ash.

shame.description: (As a Noun) An uncomfortable feeling you have when you know you have done something wrong. English = shame, embarrassment.; (As a Noun) The act of going redder in your face than usual because you are ashamed or embarrassed. English = blushing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To feel uncomfortable because you know you have done something wrong or stupid; or to cause someone to feel that way. English = (be) ashamed, (be) embarrassed; shame, embarrass.

asia.description: (As a Noun) The eastern and south-eastern parts of the Eurasian continent, especially those parts including China and Japan. English = Asia, East-Asia, South East Asia, the Orient.; (As a Noun) A person who comes from East Asia or the Orient and/or has the physical and racial features of the majority of the population in that area of the world. English = Oriental, Asian.; (As a Noun) A country in East Asia south of the Russian Federation and north of Vietnam. English = China.

digression.description: (As a Noun) A move away from the subject you are talking or writing about. English = digression, aside.; (As a Noun) A route which is not the shortest way from one place to another. You often do this because you want to avoid a traffic jam, because the direct route is closed for some reason, or because you want to see the sights. English = detour.; (As a Noun) A change in the course or destination of something, especially a telephone call. English = diversion.

ask.description: (As a Noun) Something you have said to someone in the form of a question because you want to know something, or because you want them to do something for you. English = request.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say something to someone in the form of a question because you want to know something, or because you want them to do something. English = ask, request.

ask%20around.description: (As a Noun) The process of informally asking a number of people questions in order to find out information about something. English = enquiry, inquiry.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say something to a number of people in the form of a question because you want to know something, or because you want them to do something. English = ask around, enquire, inquire.; (Augmented Meaning) This is actually a modified form of the sign ASK. The movement in an arc or spiral strongly suggests asking many people over a period of time in a deliberate way.

asleep.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be sleeping deeply. Idiomatic English = (be) sound asleep, (be) dead to the world, sleep soundly; (As a Verb or Adjective) To fall asleep quickly and completely and then to sleep very deeply because you are very tired.

aspect.description:
(As a Noun) In grammar, the way verbs are modified to show whether an activity is ongoing or complete. 
For example, compare ‘had eaten’ (completed) in “I had eaten dinner, when they arrived last night” with “was eating” (ongoing) in “I was eating dinner, when they arrived last night”. English = aspect; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan definition of the English term ASPECT as it is used in an educational or academic context, particularly when talking or writing about language and grammar.; (Note) There appear to be no Auslan signs associated with this term (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for ASPECT used by yourself or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

aspiration.description: (As a Noun) ASPIRATION is the removal of fluid or tissue (i.e. with a syringe) for testing.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ASPIRATION. If you know a sign for ASPIRATION used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

attendance.description: (As a Noun) The number of people who are present at a meeting or a performance. English = attendance.; (As a Noun) A large gathering or meeting of people. English = assembly, crowd.; (As a Noun) The gathering of people in one place.

assembly%20line.description: (As a Noun) An arrangement of workers and machines in a factory where the product passes from one worker to another until it is finished. English = assembly line.

assertiveness.description: (As a Noun) The ability to say or do exactly what you want to or what you think without getting angry or embarrassed. English = assertiveness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To speak or act in a forceful way so that people take notice of you. English = assert oneself, assert yourself, (be) assertive.

assessment.description: (General Definition) The action of one person looking at another or at a relatively tall and thin object, or any action or thing directly or indirectly associated with this.; (As a Noun) A judgement made about the quality of a student and their work. English = assessment.; (As a Noun) [With a negative facial expression] a feeling of dislike for someone because you think they are of little value or importance. English = disdain.

assignment.description: (As a Noun) A task or a piece of work that you are given to do, especially as part of your job or studies. English = assignment.

association.description: (As a Noun) An official group of people with a common occupation, aim, or interest. English = association.

differences.description: (As a Noun) The ways in which a whole lot of otherwise similar things are actually different from each other. English = differences.; (As a Noun) A range of different conditions, qualities, or types. English = diversity, assortment.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of several things, to have lots of different types of properties or qualities. English = (be) diverse, (be) disparate, (be) various.

suppose.description: (As a Noun) The idea that something is true, sometimes wrongly, e.g., for no good reason or without strong evidence. English = assumption.; (As a Noun) An action or way of behaving that is intended to make people believe something that is not true. English = pretence.; (As a Noun) An approximate calculation, or the result obtained by such a calculation; a judgement which you make about a person or situation, without very good evidence or reason. English = estimate, estimation.

asthma.description: (As a Noun) A chest disease which makes breathing difficult. English = asthma.; (As a Noun) A person who suffers from asthma. English = asthmatic.; (As a Noun) Breathing which is quick and loud and made with your mouth open, because you have been doing something energetic. English = panting.

wonder.description: (As a Noun) A feeling of surprise and amazement. English = wonder.; (As a Noun) A feeling of surprise and pleasure. English = delight.; (As a Noun) Something which surprises, pleases and amazes; something that is quite unbelievable because it is so surprising, pleasing or amazing. English = wonder, marvel, miracle.

telescope.description: (As a Noun) A long, tube-shaped instrument with lenses inside it which you look through in order to make distant things appear larger and nearer. English = telescope.; (As a Noun) The scientific study of the stars, planets, and other natural objects in space. English = astronomy.; (As a Noun) A scientist who studies the stars, planets, and other natural objects in space. English = astronomer.

asymptote.description: (As a Noun) In geometry, a straight line that continually approaches a curve but does not ever meet it. English = asymptote.

on.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be located on a surface. English = (be) on.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put something on a surface; to lay something on a surface; to place something on a surface.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be located or situated at a place. English = (be) at.

at%20heart.description: (As a Noun) The way a person behaves and thinks that makes them unique or of a particular type. English = character,  personality.; (As a Noun) Things which are thought to be related to or inside the heart. English = emotion.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very much your own and related to your feelings and emotions. English = (be) personal.

disbelief.description: (As a Noun) The thought that something is not true, or false. English = disbelief.; (As a Noun) A person who does not believe something; a person who has doubts about the truth of something. English = disbeliever, sceptic.; (As a Noun) A person who does not believe that there is a God and/or does not believe in a religion. English = atheist, non-believer.

atherosclerosis.description: (As a Noun) ATHEROSCLEROSIS is when fatty deposits in the arteries cause them to become narrower and harder.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ATHEROSCLEROSIS. If you know a sign for ATHEROSCLEROSIS used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

sprint.description: (As a Noun) A short race in which runners race very fast. English = sprint.; (As a Noun) Various field and track sports, such as running, the high jump, and the javelin. English = athletics.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To run as fast as you can over a short distance. English = sprint.

atm%20(automatic%20teller%20machine).description: (As a Noun) A machine in a shop, pub, or restaurant that is used to add up and record how much money people pay, and in which the money is kept. English = cash register, till.; (As a Noun) A person customers pay money to or get money from in a shop, bank, or garage. English = cashier.; (As a Noun) A machine that is used to withdraw and deposit money from one's bank account. English = automatic teller machine, ATM.

attempt.description: (As a Noun) An effort you make to do something because you want to do it even if you are not sure you are able to do it. English = try, attempt.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make the effort to do something because you want to do it even if you are not sure you are able to do it. English = try, attempt.

attend%20(pay%20attention).description: (As a Noun) The act of looking at, listening to, or thinking about something carefully. English = attention.; (As a Noun) Two pieces of leather which are placed at the side of a horse's eyes so that it can only see straight ahead. English = blinkers.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To look at, listen to, or think about something carefully. English = attend to, pay attention to

attention.description: (As a Noun) The act of looking at, listening to, or thinking about something carefully. English = attention.; (As a Noun) Two pieces of leather which are placed at the side of a horse's eyes so that it can only see straight ahead. English = blinkers.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To look at, listen to, or think about something carefully. English = attend to, pay attention to

attention%20(get%20attention).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To get the attention of all the people around you, especially by tapping them on the shoulder and getting others to do likewise, in order to talk (sign) to them.; (Interactive) Used alone to tell those people in a group of deaf people who are already looking at you to tap their neighbours on the shoulder so that everyone is looking at you and you can talk to them all at once. English = 'Can I have everyone's attention?!'

attitude.description: (As a Noun) The way you think or feel about something or the way you behave when you deal with other people. English = attitude.

attract.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To have features that cause people or animals to come close. English = attract.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of an organization or a group, to attract people to join or become part of it. English = recruit.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To catch someone's attention or affections.

thirst.description: (As a Noun) The need to drink something. English = thirst.; (As a Noun) The feeling of wanting something very much. English = desire.; (As a Noun) The strong feeling of wanting to have sex with someone. English = desire, randiness, attraction. Idiomatic English = the hots.

prettiness.description: (As a Noun) The condition or state of being nice to look at or being good-looking. English = prettiness, attractiveness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be nice to look at; to look good. English = (be) pretty, (be) good-looking, (be) attractive.; (Interactive) Used alone to give mild approval to some thing or some idea. English = 'It seems okay.', 'Looks good.', 'That's fine.', and so on.

auction.description: (As a Noun) A public sale of goods where the goods are sold to the person who offers the highest price. English = auction.; (As a Noun) A person in charge of an auction. English = auctioneer.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To sell goods at a public sale to the person who offers the highest price. English = auction.

audience.description: (As a Noun) The group of people who are watching or listening to something such as a play, concert, or film. English = audience.

audience%20(excited).description: (As a Noun) A group of people, especially children, who are restless with excitement and interest in something, or anticipation of something happening; a restless crowd or audience.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a group of people, to jump up and down or to be restless in excitement or interest in something, or anticipation of something happening.

graph.description: (General Definition) A wavy or irregular line drawn on a flat surface, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a graph or an audiogram.; (As a Noun) A mathematical diagram, usually a line or curve, which shows how two or more sets of numbers or measurements are related. English = graph.; (As a Noun) A graphic representation of the acuteness of someone's hearing in a range of sound frequencies. English = audiogram.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

head-set.description: (As a Noun) A pair of speakers inside pads which you wear over your ears in order to listen to a radio, record player, or tape recorder without other people hearing it. English = headphone, headphones, head-set.; (As a Noun) A medically trained person whose job is to test people's hearing, especially for any evidence of hearing loss. English = audiologist.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Noun) The study of people's hearing, especially the testing of people's hearing for any evidence of hearing loss. English = audiology.

selection.description: (As a Noun) The choosing of one or more things from a group. English = selection.; (As a Noun) A short performance that someone gives so that a director can decide if they are good enough to be in a play, film, or orchestra. English = audition.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To choose one or more things from a group. English = select.

auditory-verbal.description: (As a Noun) An educational philosophy and technique used in the education of some deaf children which stresses speech and listening without the reliance any visual clues, including lip patterns. English = auditory-verbal technique.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of an educator, to practise the auditory-verbal technique.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a deaf child, to be subjected to the auditory-verbal technique.

aunt.description: (As a Noun) The sister of your mother or father, or the wife of the brother of your mother or father. English = aunt, auntie, aunty.

auslan.description: (As a Noun) The sign language used by the Australian Deaf community. English = Auslan, Australian Sign Language.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To talk or sign in an informal and friendly way with someone. English = chat. Informal English = chinwag.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use Australian Sign Language.

aussie%20rules.description: (As a Noun) A code of football which originated in Australia and which is most popular in the southern and western States. It has its origins in Gaelic football. English = Australian Rules football. Informal English = Aussie Rules.

australia.description: (As a Noun) The island continent between south east Asia and Antarctica. English = Australia.; (As a Noun) The country which occupies the entire island continent between south east Asia and Antarctica. English = Australia.; (As a Verb or Adjective) From or relating to Australia. English = (be) Australian.

australian%20rules.description: (As a Noun) A team ball game played in Australia, called Australian rules football (AFL).; (As a Verb or Adjective) To prepare to kick or pass a ball in Australian rules football.

australian%20sign%20language.description: (As a Noun) The sign language used by the Australian Deaf community. English = Auslan, Australian Sign Language.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To talk or sign in an informal and friendly way with someone. English = chat. Informal English = chinwag.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use Australian Sign Language.

austria.description: (As a Noun) A country in central Europe between Germany and Hungary. English = Austria.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To relate to or come from Austria. English = (be) Austrian.

genuine.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be real and exactly what it appears to be, and not a copy. English = (be) genuine, (be) original, (be) authentic.

author.description: (As a Noun) The person who wrote a piece of writing, especially a book. English = author.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be the author of a piece of writing, especially a book.

authority.description: (As a Noun) The right to have command and control over other people; a quality that someone has which makes other people take notice of what they say; official permission to do something. English = authority.

autism.description: (As a Noun) A developmental condition characterized by difficulties with social communication and interaction, and restricted and repetitive behaviours and interests. English = autism.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Verb or Adjective) About or with reference to the condition of autism. English = autistic.

automatic.description: (As a Noun) A machine that can perform a task without needing to be operated by a person. English = automatic.; (As a Noun) A car or a vehicle in which the driver does not need to change the gears manually. English = automatic.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a machine, to be able to perform a task without needing to be operated by a person. English = (be) automatic.

automatic%20doors.description: (As a Noun) A set of automatic doors.

car.description: (As a Noun) A motor vehicle with room for a small number of passengers. English = car. American English = automobile.

autumn.description: (As a Noun) The time of year when the weather becomes cooler. English = autumn.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be low in temperature, but not cold. English = (be) cool, (be) fresh.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To become a low or lower temperature, but not cold. English = cool, cool down, freshen.

availability.description: (As a Noun) The state of being free to be used or obtained. English = availability.; (As a Noun) A job that is not being done by anyone and which people can apply for; a room at a hotel or guest house that is not occupied and is available for people to stay in. English = vacancy.; (As a Noun) Of a person, the state of not being busy so that you can do something or meet someone. English = availability.

grudge.description: (As a Noun) An unfriendly feeling towards someone because they have upset you or harmed you in the past. English = grudge.; (As a Noun) The act of hurting or doing something bad to someone who has hurt or harmed you in some way before. English = revenge, vengeance.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have an unfriendly feeling towards someone because they have upset you or harmed you in the past; to bear a grudge; have it in for someone.

avenue.description: (General Definition) A long wide way between two places, lined with something, such as trees or buildings, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially an avenue or boulevard, or a fairway.; (As a Noun) A wide road, often lined with trees. English = avenue, boulevard.; (As a Noun) The long strip of short grass between every tee and green on a golf course. English = fairway.

average.description: (As a Noun) The result that you get when you add two or more numbers together and divide the total by the number of numbers you added together. English = average.; (As a Noun) A number, time, or position for something that is correct but not exact. English = approximation.; (As a Noun) The feeling you have when you are not sure about the details of something. English = doubt.

distasteful.description: (As a Noun) The feeling of not liking something and thinking it is unpleasant, especially types of food. English = dislike, distaste.; (As a Noun) The avoiding of something very unpleasant; or the rejection of food you find unpleasant. English = aversion.; (As a Noun) The things that you do not like, especially types of food. English = dislikes.

avocado.description:
(As a Noun) AVOCADO is a fruit with leathery skin and soft flesh. It has a high unsaturated fat content and is usually eaten raw served in salads or in guacamole.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English keywords AVOCADO. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for AVOCADO for most signers (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic).

If you know a sign for AVOCADO used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

avoid.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To keep away from something. English = avoid.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To keep something away from you; to keep something at bay.

resistance.description: (As a Noun) The act of keeping away or refusing someone or something which has the potential to cause you harm or damage, especially if you could be tempted. English = resistance, avoidance.; (As a Noun) The ability of something to withstand various pressures.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To keep away from or to say no to someone or something which has the potential to cause you harm or damage, especially if you could be tempted. English = avoid, resist.

wakefulness.description: (As a Noun) The state of not being asleep. English = wakefulness, consciousness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To become conscious again after being asleep. English = wake, wake up, awaken.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To not be asleep. English = (be) awake, (be) conscious.

prize.description: (As a Noun) Something of value, for example a certificate, money or a trophy, that is given to someone who has the best results in a competition or game, or as a reward for doing good work. English = prize, award.; (As a Noun) Something which you buy or keep to remind you of a holiday, place, or event. English = souvenir.; (As a Noun) The ability to remember things. (This sense is becoming obsolete and is used in this way mostly by older members of the deaf community.) English = memory.

awful.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be not very good or very nice; to be unpleasant, shocking, or bad. English = (be) awful, (be) dreadful.; (Note) This sign is based on a gesture shared with the spoken language community. The gesture is made when dismissing something as unimportant or trivial or rejecting something because it is no good or awful.

floundering.description: (As a Noun) The action of moving in an energetic, uncontrolled way when you are in water in order to try not to sink. English = floundering.; (As a Noun) The feeling that you are unable to do anything to protect or save yourself, or to do the right thing in a situation. English = helplessness, floundering.; (As a Noun) A state of confusion, disorder, or great anxiety; a state of complete disorder and confusion. English = turmoil; chaos.

ceiling.description: (As a Noun) The horizontal surface that forms the top part inside a room . English = ceiling.; (As a Noun) A horizontal surface above head height used for protecting people and objects from the elements. English = awning, covering.; (As a Noun) Protection from the sun caused by something, usually horizontal, above head height. English = shade.

axe.description: (As a Noun) A tool used for cutting wood. It consists of a blade attached to the end of a long handle, at the side. English = axe.; (As a Noun) A small axe. English = hatchet.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cut something into pieces by hitting it with an axe, hatchet or knife. English = axe, chop.

axis.description: (General Definition) The intersection of a vertical line or surface and a horizontal line or surface, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially an axis.; (As a Noun) One of two lines on a graph on which the scales of measurement are marked. English = axis.

b.description: (As a Noun) The letter B in the one handed alphabet.

strange.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be unusual or unexpected and likely to make you feel uneasy, afraid, or even amused. English = (be) strange, (be) weird, (be) odd, (be) peculiar.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very odd and strange. English = (be) bizarre.; (Interactive) Used alone to mean you think that what has just been said or what has just happened is bizarre, strange, unusual or peculiar. English = 'Well, I'll be ...'

baby.description: (As a Noun) A very young child, especially one that cannot yet walk or talk. English = baby, infant.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To nurse a baby; to hold a baby in your arms; to cradle a baby in your arms.

scenery.description: (As a Noun) The painted cloth and boards at the back of a stage which are made to look like a place, for example a room or a place outside. English = scenery.; (As a Noun) A large piece of cloth, often with scenery or buildings painted on it, that is hung at the back of a stage while a play is being performed. English = backdrop.

background.description: (As a Noun) The kind of family you come from and the kind of education and work experience you have had. English = background.; (As a Noun) The things, shapes, or colours in a picture or scene that are less noticeable or less important and are often partly hidden by the main things or people in it. English = background.; (As a Noun) The pictures, lights, furniture and so on at the back of a stage in the theatre. English = scenery.

backing%20(support).description: (As a Noun) The agreement you have with someone and the help you might give them; the money and things you give to someone to help them do something. English = support, backing.; (As a Noun) Things added to something else to make it stronger, especially soldiers which are sent to join an army in order to make it stronger. English = reinforcement, reinforcements.; (As a Noun) Money, equipment, or services that are provided to people in need. English = aid, assistance.

back%20(of%20body).description: (As a Noun) The part of your body that is behind you, from your neck to the top of your legs. English = back.; (Note) The hand can be moved to touch the shoulder, further down the back, the neck or the head to mean "back of shoulder", "on the back", "back of neck" or "back of head" respectively.

suspect.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To think about something on and off for a long period of time. Idiomatic English = to have an idea or thought in the back of your mind.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To think that something is likely or is probably true. English = suspect.; (Interactive) Used alone in response to being told something that you already thought or suspected was the case to mean "Oh, I thought as much!", "Oh, I suspected as much!".

hiker.description: (As a Noun) A long walk in the country made for pleasure. English = hike, hiking.; (As a Noun) A person who goes for a long walk in the country for pleasure. English = hiker.; (As a Noun) A bag with straps that go over your shoulders, so that you can carry things on your back, for example when you are walking, hiking or climbing. English = backpack, rucksack.

backstroke.description: (As a Noun) A kind of swimming stroke that you do floating on your back. English = backstroke.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To swim floating on your back. English = backstroke.

back%20(support).description: (As a Noun) The agreement you have with someone and the help you might give them; the money and things you give to someone to help them do something. English = support, backing.; (As a Noun) Things added to something else to make it stronger, especially soldiers which are sent to join an army in order to make it stronger. English = reinforcement, reinforcements.; (As a Noun) Money, equipment, or services that are provided to people in need. English = aid, assistance.

back%20up%20(reverse).description: (As a Noun) The side or part of something that is towards the rear or farthest from the front. It is normally not used or seen as much as the front. English = back.; (As a Noun) Thinking of the future as a time which is in front of you, used to point to that period of time which is before the present and thus ‘behind’ you. English = past.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move in a direction which is the opposite direction to the one in which you normally face or in which you normally go when walking or driving. English = go backwards, back up, reverse.

backward.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To move in the direction that your back is facing. English = go backward.

bacon.description: (As a Noun) Salted or smoked meat which comes from the back or sides of a pig. English = bacon.; (As a Noun) A thin slice of bacon. English = rasher.

bacteria.description: (As a Noun) BACTERIA are very small organisms which can cause disease.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for BACTERIA. If you know a sign for BACTERIA used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

bad.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be unpleasant, harmful, undesirable, or to be of an unacceptable quality, amount or standard. English = (be) bad.; (Interactive) Used alone to express your feelings that something you have been told is harmful, undesirable, or of an unacceptable quality. English = 'How dreadful!', 'Oh no, that's awful!' and so on.

bad%20breath.description: (As a Noun) The small round white bulb of an onion-like plant. It has a very strong smell and taste and is used in cooking. English = garlic.; (As a Noun) Breath which smells bad, bad breath.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a strong or foul-smelling breath, to have bad breath.

badge.description: (As a Noun) A small, usually circular, piece of metal or cloth which you attach to your clothes. It often has messages or designs on it. English = badge.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wear small, usually circular, piece of metal or cloth which you attach to your clothes. It often has messages or designs on it.

bad%20luck.description: (As a Noun) A lack of success or bad things that happen to you, that have not been caused by yourself or other people. English = bad luck. Formal English = misfortune.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have bad luck. English = unlucky. Formal English = unfortunate.; (Interactive) Used to express sympathy for someone who has failed to do something or failed to get something. English = 'Bad luck!', 'Hard luck!', 'Shame!', 'What a pity!' and so on.

badminton.description: (As a Noun) A game in which you use a racket to hit a small, feathered object called a shuttlecock over a high net to your opponent. English = badminton.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To play badminton.

bag.description: (As a Noun) A strong enclosed container with a handle or handles, used to carry things in. English = bag, case.; (As a Noun) A usually open container, made of thin strips of cane woven together, with a large handle, used to carry things in. English = basket.; (As a Noun) A case in which you carry your clothes when you are travelling. English = suitcase. Australian (Queensland) English = port.

bagpipes.description: (General Definition) The action of playing the bagpipes (squeezing the bag with your elbow and playing the attached flute), or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially Scotland and the Scots.; (As a Noun) A musical instrument which you play by blowing air through a pipe into a leather bag, and then squeezing the bag to force the air out through other pipes. English = bagpipes.; (As a Noun) The country to the north of England. English = Scotland.

bain%20marie.description: (General Definition) A container with a wide uncovered top, repeated multiple times to show many containers.; (As a Noun) A food container that is placed over a bath of boiling water. Used for keeping prepared food warm, or for slow cooking. English = bain marie.; (As a Noun) A food container that has a pan of boiling water to keep the food slow cooking. English = bain marie.

bake.description: (As a Noun) A cooker or part of a cooker that is like a box with a door. You put food inside the oven in order to cook it. English = oven.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put inside an oven in order to cook.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cook in an oven without extra liquid or fat. English = bake.

balance.description: (As a Noun) The act of remaining steady and upright and not falling over when you are standing or walking on a narrow spot. English = balancing.; (As a Noun) The score in a game of tennis when both players have forty points. English = deuce.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To remain steady and upright and not fall over when you are standing or walking on a narrow spot. English = balance, keep your balance.

bald.description: (As a Noun) Of a person, the state of having little or no hair on the top of their head. English = baldness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to have little or no hair on the top of their head. English = (be) bald.

bald%20tyre.description: (As a Noun) A tyre which is very smooth and no longer safe to use. English = bald tyre.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a tyre, to be very smooth and no longer safe to use. English = (be) bald.

bali.description: (As a Noun) One of the islands of the country of Indonesia, between the islands of Java and Lombok, called Bali.

ball.description: (As a Noun) A round object that is used in games such as tennis, cricket, and football. English = ball.; (As a Noun) A small, soft, red fruit that you can eat raw in salads, or cooked as a vegetable or in a sauce. English = tomato.

ballet.description: (As a Noun) A type of very skilled and artistic dancing with carefully planned movements. English = ballet.; (As a Noun) An artistic work that is performed by ballet dancers. English = ballet.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To leap or jump up in the air, especially as part of a ballet.

ball%20joint.description: (General Definition) A visual deptiction using hands to represent a ball being encased by a rounded object and portraying the movement of the ball within the object.; (As a Noun) The place in a machine where two parts of the machine (for example the wheels of a car) are connected to each other. The end of the first part is rounded and fits into a rounded space in the second part. English = ball joint.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for BALL JOINT for most signers (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic).  If you know a sign for BALL JOINT used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

ball%20of%20string.description: (General Definition) The action of pulling something small or long and thin out of a round object or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this.; (As a Noun) A thin rope made of twisted threads. English = string.; (As a Noun) A long piece of string rolled into a ball. English = ball of string.

balloon.description: (As a Noun) A small, thin, rubber bag that you blow air into so that it becomes larger and rounder or longer. They are used for toys or for decorations, especially at parties. English = balloon.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To blow up or inflate a balloon.

balls%20(testicles).description: (As a Noun) The two sex glands of a man that produce sperm. They are egg shaped and hang in sacks under his penis. English = testicles. Informal slang English = balls.

ball-up%20(australian%20rules%20football.description: (As a Noun) In Australian rules football, the bouncing of the ball by the field umpire to restart play after the ball has been smothered in a pack. English = ball-up.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In Australian rules football, to restart play by bouncing the ball after the ball has been smothered in a pack. English = ball-up.

ban.description: (As a Noun) A law, decree or public statement that says you cannot do something. English = ban, prohibition.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say publicly by decree or to make a law that says you cannot do something; to be officially not allowed. English = ban, prohibit; (be) banned, (be) prohibited, (be) illegal.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To order someone not to do something; to be not allowed. English = forbid; (be) forbidden.

banana.description: (As a Noun) A long curved fruit with a yellow skin and cream-coloured flesh. English = banana.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To peel the skin off a banana.

orchestra.description: (As a Noun) A large group of musicians who play a variety of different instruments together, usually playing classical music. English = orchestra.; (As a Noun) A person who stands in front of an orchestra or choir and direct its performance. English = conductor.; (As a Noun) A group of musicians, especially who play brass or percussion instruments. English = band.

bandage.description: (As a Noun) A long strip of cloth which is wrapped around a wounded part of someone's body to protect it. English = bandage.; (As a Noun) A covering which is put on a wound to protect it while it heals. English = dressing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To tie a long strip of cloth around a wounded part of someone's body to protect it. English = bandage.

tape (adhesive).description: (As a Noun) Sticky strips of plastic which you use for sticking things together. English = tape, adhesive tape.; (As a Noun) A strip of sticky material used for covering small cuts or sores on your body. English = band-aid. British English = plaster.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use sticky strips of plastic to stick things together. English = apply adhesive tape.

explosion.description: (As a Noun) A sudden violent burst of energy. English = explosion.; (As a Noun) A loud noise such as the noise of an explosion. English = bang.; (As a Noun) A device which explodes and damages or destroys a large area. English = bomb.

bracelet.description: (As a Noun) A chain or band, usually made of metal, which you wear around your wrist as jewellery. English = bracelet, bangle.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wear a bracelet, bangle.

bank.description: (As a Noun) A place where you can keep your money in an account. English = bank.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put your money in an account at a bank. English = bank, deposit.

banknote.description: (As a Noun) A unit of money used in the USA, Australia and some other countries. It is made up of one hundred smaller units, called cents. English = dollar. Idiomatic English = buck.; (As a Noun) A piece of printed paper or plastic that is used as money. English = note, bill.

bankruptcy.description: (As a Noun) The failure of a person or a business to pay their debts. English = bankruptcy.; (As a Noun) A person who has failed in business and is unable to pay their debts. English = bankrupt.; (As a Noun) A lack of success in doing or achieving something; a person who has not succeeded at something or anything. English = failure.

bank%20(shore).description: (As a Noun) A place where land or some other solid surface is found right next to a body of water.; (As a Noun) The land along the edge of a sea, lake, or wide river, where water and land come together. English = shore.; (As a Noun) The raised ground along the edge of a river or lake. English = bank.

banquet.description: (As a Noun) A very formal, grand or lavish dinner. English = banquet, feast.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To eat a very formal, grand or lavish dinner. English = have a banquet, feast.

baptism.description: (As a Noun) The ceremony in which a person is immersed in water as a sign that they have become a member of a Christian Church. English = baptism.; (As a Noun) A person who is a Christian who believes that baptism is necessary for a Christian, and that it should happen only to someone who is old enough to understand what they are doing. English = Baptist.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To immerse someone in water as a sign that they have become a member of a Christian Church. English = baptise.

christening.description: (As a Noun) A Christian ceremony in which a baby is made a member of the Christian church by being anointed with water and is officially given his or her name. English = christening, (Catholic) baptism.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a baby, to be made a member of the Christian church by being anointed with water and to be officially given his or her name. English = (be) christened, (Catholic) (be) baptised.

barber.description: (As a Noun) A man who cuts men's hair. English = barber.; (As a Noun) A shop or a place where a barber works. English = barber's.; (As a Noun) A very short haircut, especially on a man.

blank.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a surface or object, to have nothing on it, or to not be covered or decorated with anything. English = (be) blank, (be) bare.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a place, to have no people in it. English = (be) empty, (be) deserted.

bargain.description: (As a Noun) Something which is low in price and affordable. English = bargain.; (As a Noun) A reduction in the normal price of something. English = discount.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be low in price and be affordable; or to make low in price. English = (be) cheap; cheapen.

barman.description: (As a Noun) A person who serves drinks in a bar or pub. English = barman (male), barmaid (female).; (As a Verb or Adjective) To work behind a bar making and serving drinks, especially filling glasses with beer from taps.

bartender.description: (As a Noun) A person who serves drinks in a bar or pub. English = bartender, barperson. Old-fashioned English = barman (male), barmaid (female).; (As a Verb or Adjective) To work behind a bar making and serving drinks, especially filling glasses with beer from taps.

bar%20(pub).description: (As a Noun) A bitter alcoholic drink made from grain. English = beer.; (As a Noun) Alcoholic drinks of any sort. English = booze.; (As a Noun) A building where people can have drinks, especially alcoholic drinks, and talk to their friends. English = pub, bar, hotel.

barracker.description: (As a Noun) A person who shouts out to show they like someone, especially a sports team, and wants them to do well or win. English = barracker, supporter, fan.; (As a Noun) Something that prevents people or things from being harmed or damaged. English = protection, defence.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To shout out to show you like someone, especially a sports team, and want them to do well or win. English = barrack for, support, (be) a fan of.

barrier.description: (General Definition) Some kind of vertical surface or line of things in front of and to the sides of you or the person, place or thing you represent, such as a barrier or fence, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To resolve that you will no longer consider or talk about someone else's concerns or affairs because you consider it to be none of your business.; (Interactive) Used alone to mean that something is none of one's business or concern and you have no intention of getting involved. English = 'I'm keeping right out of that. It's got nothing to do with me.'

court (law).description: (As a Noun) A place where legal matters are decided by a judge and jury or by a magistrate. English = court.; (As a Noun) The person in a court of law who decides how the law should be applied to people, for example how criminals should be punished. English = judge.; (As a Noun) The legal process in which a judge and jury decide whether a person is guilty of a particular crime after listening to evidence relating to it. English = trial.

bar%20(rod).description: (General Definition) Any medium-sized, horizontal cylindrical object, such as a pipe, pole, bar, or rod, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, such as a degree or diploma.; (As a Noun) A long, round, hollow object, usually made of metal or plastic, through which a liquid or gas can flow. English = pipe.; (As a Noun) A long, thin, straight object made of metal, wood, or some other hard substance. English =  pole, bar, rod.

wheelbarrow.description: (As a Noun) A small cart that is used in the garden for carrying things. It is usually shaped like an open box, with one wheel at the front, two legs at the back, and two handles to lift and push it with. English = wheelbarrow, barrow.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To push a wheelbarrow.

base.description: (As a Noun) The creating or starting of a new building or organisation. English = foundation, establishment.; (As a Noun) A position or thing from which something can be developed or achieved; the main place from which you work; or the place from which the main part of an army is from. English = base, camp.; (As a Noun) The action or statement by which you say you have a right to something or interest in something. English = claim, stake.

baseball.description: (As a Noun) A game played by two teams of nine players. Each player from one team hits a ball with a bat and then tries to run round all four bases before the other team can get the ball back. English = baseball.; (As a Noun) A form of baseball played with a larger and softer ball. English = softball.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To play baseball, or softball.

based%20on.description: (As a Noun) The smallest amount or number of something that is possible or allowed. English = minimum, limit, lower limit.; (As a Noun) The furthest extent you can go downwards. English = the end of, the bottom of.; (As a Noun) The most central and important part of something from which it can be further developed. English = basis.

base%20(of%20triangle).description: (As a Noun) In mathematics and geometry, the lowest edge or part of a triangle, as in the English expression ‘the base of a triangle’. English = base.; (Note) Originally only an alternative Australasian Signed English sign for the other Auslan sign for ‘base’. Now this variant is used by some teachers in maths and geometry specifically for ‘base of a triangle’.; (Note) Apologies for the missing video. The line drawing will be replaced as soon as possible.

shyness.description: (As a Noun) The quality of being nervous and uncomfortable in the company of other people. English = shyness.; (As a Noun) The quality of being nervous and uncomfortable in the company of other people and having no courage or self-confidence. English = timidity.; (As a Noun) The quality of being nervous and uncomfortable in the company of other people and to be easily embarrassed. English = bashfulness.

primary.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Used to describe something that is extremely important, or most important for someone or something. English = (be) primary, (be) fundamental, (be) basic.

basin.description: (General Definition) An object, particularly a container, with a flat bottom, relatively straight sides and a wide, uncovered top, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, such as a basin, washbasin, sink or tub.; (As a Noun) A deep bowl that you can use for mixing or storing food. English = basin.; (As a Noun) A large basin with taps that supply water which is used for washing your hands and face. English = washbasin.

minimum.description: (As a Noun) The smallest amount or number of something that is possible or allowed. English = minimum, limit, lower limit.; (As a Noun) The furthest extent you can go downwards. English = the end of, the bottom of.; (As a Noun) The most central and important part of something from which it can be further developed. English = basis.

basket.description: (As a Noun) An open container made of thin strips of cane woven together, or of thin metal wire, with a round base and a handle on top. English = basket.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To carry a basket.

basketball.description: (As a Noun) A game in which two teams of five players each try to score goals by throwing a large ball through a circular net fixed to a metal ring at each end of the court. English = basketball.; (As a Noun) A game in which two teams of seven players, usually women, each try to score goals by throwing a large ball through a net which is at the top of a pole at each end of the court. English = netball.; (As a Noun) The act of hitting down repeatedly on a ball. English = bounce.

bugger (bastard).description: (As a Noun) A person you dislike or have contempt for. Vulgar English = bugger, bastard.; (As a Noun) A person who you pretend to dislike or be annoyed with (because they do naughty things or play tricks on you) but whom you are actually fond of and whose antics you enjoy. English = bugger, bastard.; (Interactive) Used alone to express anger, annoyance, or contempt with someone or something. A vulgar sign. Vulgar English = 'You bugger!', 'Bugger you!', 'Bugger that!', 'You bastard!'

baste.description:
(As a Verb or Adjective) To BASTE means to spoon the cooking juices over meat while it is roasting to prevent the meat drying out.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English keywords BASTE. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for BASTE for most signers (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic).
