If you know a sign for BASTE used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

bat.description: (As a Noun) A specially shaped piece of wood that is used for hitting the ball in games such as cricket, baseball, rounders, table-tennis, etc. English = bat.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a turn at hitting the ball in a game such as cricket, baseball, rounders, table-tennis, etc; to hit a ball with specially shaped piece of wood. English = bat.

bat%20(animal).description: (General Definition) The action of beating or flapping wings, or any real or imagined creature that is able to fly or, especially, the body parts with which they fly.; (As a Noun) The two parts of the body of some animals, insects and birds that are used for flying. English = wings.; (As a Noun) In football or hockey, an attacking player who plays mainly on the far left or the far right of the pitch. English = winger.

bath.description: (As a Noun) A long, rectangular container which you fill with water and sit or lie in while you wash your body. English = bath, bathtub.; (As a Noun) The act of washing your body while sitting or lying in a bath filled with water. English = bath.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To sit or lie in a bath and wash your body. English = have a bath, bathe.

swimming costume.description: (As a Noun) A small piece of clothing worn over and around your buttocks and groin which has two holes to put your legs through and is quite narrow at the sides of the waist. You wear it for swimming. English = swimming costume, swimming briefs, bathers.; (As a Noun) A small piece of underwear worn around your buttocks and groin which has two holes to put your legs through and elastic around the top. English = (men and women) briefs, bikini briefs, underpants; (women) panties, knickers.

bathing%20suit.description: (As a Noun) A tight-fitting piece of clothing that a woman wears when she goes swimming. English = swimsuit, bathing suit, one-piece.

stick.description: (General Definition) The action of holding something and using it to hit something or someone, or any action or any thing directly or indirectly associated with this.; (As a Noun) Something that you hold in your hand and use to hit something or someone. English = baton, stick, club.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To hit someone or something with an instrument such as a baton, stick or club. English = beat, strike, club.

batter.description:
(As a Noun) A BATTER is a mixture of flour and liquid, used for baking or to coat food prior to frying.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To BATTER means to coat an ingredient with batter.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English keywords BATTER. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for BATTER for most signers (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic).

If you know a sign for BATTER used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

battery.description: (As a Noun) A device that produces the electricity in something such as a torch, radio, watch or hearing-aid. English = battery; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be operated by a battery rather than mechanically or by mains power.

battery%20(car).description: (As a Noun) Two thick wires with clamps at each end that can be used when a car will not start because its battery does not have enough power. They are used to connect the battery to the battery of another car. English = jumper leads.; (As a Noun) A device that produces electricity in a car. English = car battery.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Verb or Adjective) To attach jumper leads to a car battery.

war.description: (As a Noun) A period of fighting between countries or states. English = war.; (As a Noun) A fight between armies or between groups of ships or planes. English = battle.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of two countries, to fight each other. English = fight a war, war, (be) at war.

bawl%20out.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To scold someone angrily for doing something wrong. Informal English = bawl out, tell off.

beach.description: (As a Noun) The area of sand or pebbles beside the sea. English = beach.; (As a Noun) A meal eaten out of doors, usually in a field, wood, park or at the beach. English = picnic.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go the area of sand or pebbles beside the sea for an outing in order to swim, relax or eat a meal.

knob.description: (General Definition) Any thing which is long and thin with a small sphere-like protrusion at one end, or any thing or any action that is directly or indirectly associated with this, such as a knob or berry, or the action of chalking a snooker cue.; (As a Noun) A rounded lump on the end of a stick or post. English = knob.; (As a Noun) A small piece of rock. English = stone.

beaded%20necklace.description: (General Definition) Any thing worn around the neck or going around the neck, such as a necklace or the collar or neck line of a garment; or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, particularly if made of beads.; (As a Noun) Small, often round, pieces of coloured glass, wood, or plastic with a hole through the middle and put together on a piece of string or wire to make a necklace. English = beads, beaded necklace.; (As a Noun) A piece of jewellery worn around the neck. English = necklace.

beaded necklace.description: (General Definition) Any thing worn around the neck or going around the neck, such as a necklace or the collar or neck line of a garment; or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, particularly if made of beads.; (As a Noun) Small, often round, pieces of coloured glass, wood, or plastic with a hole through the middle and put together on a piece of string or wire to make a necklace. English = beads, beaded necklace.; (As a Noun) A piece of jewellery worn around the neck. English = necklace.

duck.description: (As a Noun) A very common water bird with short legs, webbed feet, a short neck, and a large flat beak. English = duck.; (As a Noun) The hard, flat mouth of a duck. English = beak, bill.; (As a Noun) A large bird, like a duck, but with a long neck. English = goose (singular), geese (plural).

beans.description: (General Definition) The act of cutting along a long thin object, such as splitting open a stick or slicing a vegetable, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially beans or peas.; (As a Noun) The pods of a climbing plant, or the seeds that the pods contain, which are eaten as a vegetable. English = beans.; (As a Noun) Small, round, green seeds which are eaten as a vegetable. English = peas.

bear.description: (As a Noun) A large strong animal with thick fur and sharp claws. English = bear.; (As a Noun) An Australian animal which looks like a small bear with grey fur and small tufted ears. It lives in trees and eats leaves. English = koala.

beard.description: (As a Noun) The hair that grows on a man's chin and cheeks. English = beard.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a beard. English = (be) bearded

beat%20(defeat).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To win a victory over someone in a battle, game, or contest. English = beat, defeat.

beat%20(heart).description: (As a Noun) The regular movement of the heart as it pumps blood around the body. English = heartbeat.; (As a Noun) A very strong feeling of affection for someone who you are romantically or sexually attracted to. English = love.; (As a Noun) Someone you love or any lovable or endearing person. English = darling, sweetheart.

beat%20(hit).description: (General Definition) The action of holding something and using it to hit something or someone, or any action or any thing directly or indirectly associated with this.; (As a Noun) Something that you hold in your hand and use to hit something or someone. English = baton, stick, club.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To hit someone or something with an instrument such as a baton, stick or club. English = beat, strike, club.

beat%20(mix).description: (As a Noun) A kitchen tool with rotating blades used for beating eggs or whipping cream. English = egg-beater.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To stir cream or eggs very fast until they are thick and frothy or stiff, especially using an egg-beater. English = whip.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use an egg-beater. English = whip, beat.

beat%20(music).description: (As a Noun) The pattern of regular changes in different kinds of movements and sounds, especially in music. English = rhythm, beat.; (As a Noun) The hitting of a surface with finger or a stick. English = tap.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To hit a surface with your finger or a stick to get someone's attention or to show the rhythm of speech or music. English = tap, tap out; beat, beat out.

beauty.description: (As a Noun) The quality of being attractive, pleasant and pleasing to the eye and other senses.  English = beauty, loveliness, prettiness.; (As a Noun) (When speaking of people) the quality of attractiveness found in women. English = beauty, loveliness, prettiness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be attractive, pleasant and pleasing to the eye and other senses. English = (be) beautiful, (be) lovely, (be) pretty.

because.description: (As Modifier) Used to introduce a statement that is the reason for something. English = because.

come here.description: (As a Noun) The act of calling or signalling someone to come closer to you. English = beckoning.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To ask someone to come over from where they are to where you are; to ask someone to come closer to you. English = beckon.; (Interactive) Used alone to tell someone to come over to where you are. English = 'Come here!'

become.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To start being something. English = become.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To stop being one thing and start being another thing. English = change into.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To completely change into something else. English = transform.

bedframe.description: (As a Noun) The wooden or metal frame that holds up a bed. English = bedframe.; (As a Noun) A piece of furniture that you lie on when you sleep. English = bed.; (As a Noun) A large old-fashioned bed that has a tall post at each corner and curtains that can be drawn around it. English = four-poster bed.

bedbugs.description: (As a Noun) BEDBUGS have no wings and smell really bad.  The live inside people's beds (espcially in unclean houses) and suck on people's blood.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for BEDBUGS. If you know a sign for BEDBUGS used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

bed%20(riverbed).description: (As a Noun) The lowest part of something; the lowest layer or thing in a series; the least powerful or important level in an organisation; the worst student in a class. English = bottom.; (As a Noun) The ground at the bottom of the sea or a river. English = sea bed, river bed.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be or be located at the lowest part of something; to be the lowest layer or thing in a series; to have the least powerful or least important level in an organisation; to be the worst student in a class. English = (be) bottom.

bedroom.description: (As a Noun) A room which is used for sleeping in. English = bedroom.

bed%20(seabed).description: (As a Noun) The lowest part of something; the lowest layer or thing in a series; the least powerful or important level in an organisation; the worst student in a class. English = bottom.; (As a Noun) The ground at the bottom of the sea or a river. English = sea bed, river bed.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be or be located at the lowest part of something; to be the lowest layer or thing in a series; to have the least powerful or least important level in an organisation; to be the worst student in a class. English = (be) bottom.

insect.description: (As a Noun) A small animal which has six legs and which flies. English  = (flying) insect.; (As a Noun) An insect which usually has a yellow and black striped body, makes honey and lives in large groups.  English = bee.; (As a Noun) A small insect which lives in damp places and bites people in order to suck their blood. English = mosquito.

meat.description: (As a Noun) The flesh of a dead animal that people cook and eat. English = meat, flesh.; (As a Noun) The meat of a cow, bull or ox. English = beef.; (As a Noun) A piece of beef without much fat on it. English = steak.

touch finish (been-there-done-that).description: (Interactive) Used alone to mean that you have been to a place or know about or have experienced something already, especially when your addressee thinks you have not. English = 'Been there, done that!'

beer.description: (As a Noun) A bitter alcoholic drink made from grain. English = beer.; (As a Noun) Alcoholic drinks of any sort. English = booze.; (As a Noun) A building where people can have drinks, especially alcoholic drinks, and talk to their friends. English = pub, bar, hotel.

beer%20gut.description: (As a Noun) The front part of someone's body below their waist, especially when it is very large. English = (large) stomach, (big) belly.; (As a Noun) A large stomach, especially one due to drinking excess alcohol or beer. English = beer gut.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a large stomach, to have a big belly, to have a beer gut.

spider.description: (As a Noun) A small creature with eight legs, many types of which make webs. English = spider.; (As a Noun) A small animal that has six legs, many types of which have wings. Examples include, ants, flies, butterflies and beetles. English = insect. Informal English = bug.; (As a Noun) An insect with a hard covering on its body. English = beetle.

before.description: (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of the first of two phrases to mean that the action in the first happens earlier than the action of the second phrase (which is signed after the first). English = before.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sign phrase, or immediately next to a verb (action) sign, to mean that the action took place at a time earlier than the time of speaking or time of point of reference. English = before.

before%20(long%20before).description: (As a Noun) The side or part of something that is towards the rear or farthest from the front. It is normally not used or seen as much as the front. English = back.; (As a Noun) Thinking of the future as a time which is in front of you, used to point to that period of time which is before the present and thus ‘behind’ you. English = past.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move in a direction which is the opposite direction to the one in which you normally face or in which you normally go when walking or driving. English = go backwards, back up, reverse.

before%20that.description: (As Modifier) Used to mean that an action happens at some time and also happened before that time. It involved either many actors, many entities of some kind, or many units of time (days, weeks, etc.).; (As Modifier) Used to mean that an action happened at some time in the past and also happened before that time. It involved either many actors, many entities of some kind, or many units of time (days, weeks, etc.).

before%20that%20(not%20before%20that).description: (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb to mean that the action did not occur at some time in the past before some other action. English =  nothing previously, not prior to that, not before that.

before%20then.description: (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb to mean that the action began at some time in the past (or at a time which has already been mentioned) and continued up to the present (or another nominated time). English =  from then to now, from then up to now; prior to and up to now, until now, until a specific point in time.

before%20then%20(not%20before%20then).description: (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb to mean that the action did not occur at some time in the past (or at a time which has already been mentioned) and did not happen up to the present (or another nominated time). English = nothing up to now/then, nothing before now/then, and so on.

befuddlement.description: (As a Noun) Extreme confusion. English = befuddlement, disorientation.; (As a Noun) The state of no longer knowing in what direction anything is, including the direction that you have come from. English = disorientation.; (As a Noun) Behaviour which is wild, strange, and sometimes violent, often as a result of mental illness. English = derangement, craziness, dementia.

beg.description: (As a Noun) The act of asking people to give you food or money because you are very poor. English = begging.; (As a Noun) A person who asks other people for money or food because they are very poor. English = beggar.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To ask people to give you food or money because you are very poor. English = beg.

pleading.description: (As a Noun) The act of asking someone in an intense and emotional way, often repeatedly, to do something. English = pleading, begging.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To ask someone in an intense and emotional way, often repeatedly, to do something. English = plead, beg.; (Interactive) Used alone to express the anxious feeling you have when you do not want something to happen, especially something unpleasant. English = 'Oh, please (God), no! Let it not be/happen!'

launch.description: (As a Noun) The start of a large and important activity or organisation, for example an art show or a political movement. English = launch, opening, start.; (As a Noun) The official introduction of a new product or service by an organisation, or the celebration associated with this. English = launch.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To start a large and important activity or organisation, for example an art show or a political movement. English = launch, open, start, begin.

start.description: (As a Noun) The first part of some activity. English = start, commencement, beginning.; (As a Noun) The first part of a race or competition. English = start.; (As a Noun) The beginning or cause of something. English = origin.

beginning%20directional.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a sign, to belong to a class of signs in which the location of the starting point of the sign can be changed to show the relationship between two people or things and the action of the verb. English = (be) beginning directional.

patient (calm).description: (As a Noun) The ability to stay calm and not get annoyed, for example when you are waiting for something. English = patience.; (As a Noun) The ability to bear a painful or difficult situation calmly and patiently. English = endurance.; (As a Noun) A state of quiet and peacefulness without excitement or stress. English = calmness.

behave%20well.description: (As a Noun) The way someone acts which people think is correct and proper. English = good behaviour.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To act in a way that people think is correct and proper. English = behave well.

behaviour.description: (As a Noun) The way someone acts. English =  behaviour, conduct.; (As a Noun) The typical way that people, animals or even things act, function, or change. English = behaviour.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To act in a particular way. English = behave.

behaviour%20(good%20behaviour).description: (As a Noun) The way someone acts which people think is correct and proper. English = good behaviour.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To act in a way that people think is correct and proper. English = behave well.

behind.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be located so that the back of a thing or person is facing you. English = (be) behind.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go or move so that you are facing the back of a thing or person, or so that something or someone is between you and another thing or person. English = go behind.

behind%20(afl).description: (As a Noun) A kind of goal scored in Australian rules football. English = behind.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To score a behind in Australian rules football.

belief.description: (As a Noun) The idea or feeling that something is true. English = belief.; (As a Noun) A strong belief that something is true, especially something religious. English = conviction, faith.; (As a Noun) The belief and confidence that you have that someone is honest and will not deliberately do anything to harm you. English = trust.

believe%20in.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To adopt the beliefs or opinions of another person or group of people after a period of doubt followed by consideration, reflection and ultimately agreement.

believe%20(not%20believe).description: (As a Noun) The thought that something is not true, or false. English = disbelief.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To not think that something is true; to think that something is false. English = not believe, disbelieve.

mortification.description: (General Definition) Of the height of something (or the level of something in a container), to become less and less until there is nothing left, or any thing or any action literally or metaphorically related to this, such as the time available to do something or personal self-confidence or self-worth.; (As a Noun) The feeling that you have when you are belittled, humiliated or offended. English = humiliation, mortification.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make someone feel unimportant or not very good. English = belittle.

belt.description: (As a Noun) A strip of leather or cloth that you fasten around your waist. English = belt.

bend.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To use force to make something which is flat or straight become curved or angular. English = bend.

beneath.description: (General Definition) An area or a flat extended object located below a long, usually thin, object, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be located beneath a long object; (be) beneath a long object.

benefit.description: (As a Noun) The amount of money that you gain when you are paid more for something than it cost you to make it, get it, or do it. English = profit; (As a Verb or Adjective) To benefit or gain from something. English = profit, make a profit.

benign.description: (As Modifier) A BENIGN substance or process does not have any harmful effects.  A benign tumour will not cause death or serious harm.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for BENIGN. If you know a sign for BENIGN used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

be%20(not%20be).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of something or someone, to not be here or there, to not exist in a place.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To not own or possess something. English = not have any, have not got any, have none of.

bequest.description: (As a Noun) Money or property that someone gives to someone else after they die, or money  or property that someone receives after someone else has died.; (As a Noun) Money or property that someone gives to someone else after they die. Formal English = bequest.; (As a Noun) Money or property that someone is given by someone who dies. English = inheritance.

demand.description: (As a Noun) A firm request or series of requests for something. English = demand, demands.; (As a Noun) A list of demands or claims made by someone or a group of people on another person or group, for example a list of demands of workers to their employers.; (As a Noun) A statement in which you express your dissatisfaction with a particular situation. English = complaint.

beret.description: (As a Noun) A circular, flat hat this is made of soft material and has no brim. English = beret.

berlin.description: (As a Noun) The capital city of Germany, called Berlin.

berry.description: (General Definition) Something small and round which is typically found at the end of something thin and long, such as a berry on the end of a twig, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this.; (As a Noun) A kind of small, round fruit that grows on a bush or tree, some of which you can eat. English = berry.

wharf.description: (As a Noun) A platform built of stone or wood along the side of a river or sea, where ships can be tied up for the purposes of loading and unloading goods or passengers. English = wharf, berth, pier, jetty, dock.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To pull up in a ship next to a wharf, pier, or jetty. English = berth, dock.

beside.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be located at the side of something or next to it. English = (be) beside.; (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb and a following noun to mean the action takes place at the side of or next to the thing. English = beside, next to.

best.description: (As a Noun) A thing which is very good indeed-more so than all the other things of its type you can compare it to. English = the best.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very good indeed-more so than all the other things of its type you can compare it to. English = (be) best.; (As Modifier) Used before or after a verb (action) sign to mean that the action is done by someone or something in a very good way indeed-more so than all others you can compare it with. English = best.

best%20friends.description: (As a Noun) Two people, especially school children, who are each others best friends. English = buddies, chums.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be best friends with someone, especially while at school, if not ever since school. English = (be) buddies, (be) best friends, (be) mates.; (Interactive) Used alone to mean that you and your addressee have done something exactly alike (like order something in a restaurant) or think alike in some way. English = 'Hey, we're the same!', 'Great minds think alike!', and so on.

bet.description: (As a Noun) The act of betting on something, or the amount of money you agree to give. English = bet. Formal, archaic English = wager.; (As a Noun) A suggestion from someone that you should compete or argue with them. English = challenge, dare.; (As a Noun) A challenge which one person makes to another to do something dangerous or frightening. English = dare.

beta.description: (As a Noun) The second letter of the Greek alphabet, written β in lower case, called “beta”. It is used as a symbol in mathematics and scientific notation, often to mean the second in a series of items or categories. English = beta.

be%20there.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of events and happenings, to take place and unfold over a period of time in a particular place; for events to go on over time. English = do, take place, carry on, continue.

deception.description: (As a Noun) Something that you say or do which is intended to deceive someone. English = deception.; (As a Noun) Behaviour that is intended to make people believe something which is not true. English = deceit, duplicity.; (As a Noun) The action of betraying someone. English = betrayal.

better.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be one of two things which you like more than the other thing. The one you like is very good; more so than the other thing you can compare it to. English = (be) better.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be not as ill as you were before; to be less sick. English = (be) better, get better.; (As Modifier) Used before or after a verb (action) sign to mean that the action is done by someone or something in a good way -more so than another one you are thinking of and comparing it to. English = better.

between.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) With reference to two other things, to be located so that one thing is on one side of you and another thing is on the other side of you. English = (be) between, (be) in between.; (As a Verb or Adjective) With reference to two other events, to be located in time so that now or some third event is after one event and before the other event. English = (be) between, (be) in between.

between%20(two%20clock%20times).description: (As a Noun) A time period described with reference to two clock times.; (As Modifier) Usually used immediately next to two time signs to mean precisely between these two times.

care.description: (As a Noun) Attention and thought you give to something. English = care.; (As a Noun) Attention and help you give to someone who needs help, for example because they are sick. English = care.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To do something with a lot of attention and thought or to do it thoroughly and make sure that all the details are correct. English = (be) careful.

misunderstanding.description: (As a Noun) The failure to understand something such as a situation or a person's remarks. English = misunderstanding.; (As a Noun) A foolish mistake based on a misunderstanding.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To fail to understand something such as a situation or a person's remarks without realising the mistake immediately; to talk at cross purposes.

simpleton.description: (As a Noun) A person with very low intelligence. English = simpleton.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very confused by something, especially something you see; to find something incomprehensible, especially something you see. English = (be) bewildered.

biased.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be unfair in your judgements or decisions, because you allow yourself to be influenced by your own opinions, rather than considering the facts. English = (be) biased.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a strong bias in favour of someone or something. Idiomatic English = (be) one-eyed.

serviette.description: (As a Noun) A square of cloth or paper that you use to protect your clothes or to wipe your mouth when you are eating. English = serviette. American English = napkin.

bible.description: (As a Noun) The sacred book on which the Jewish and Christian religions are based. English = Bible.

bibliography.description: (As a Noun) A list of books on a particular subject. English = bibliography.; (As a Noun) A list of books and articles that are referred to in a particular book. English = bibliography.

bicycle.description: (As a Noun) A vehicle with two wheels which you ride by sitting on it and pushing two pedals with your feet. English = bicycle.; (As a Noun) A sport in which people race each other riding bicycles. English = cycling.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To ride a bicycle, to cycle; to pedal.

bicycle%20pump.description: (As a Noun) A hand held device for forcing air into the tyre of a bicycle. English = pump, bicycle pump.; (As a Noun) The act of forcing air into a bicycle tyre by using a hand held pump. English = pumping.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To force air into a bicycle tyre using a hand held pump. English = pump, pump up.

bid%20(auction).description: (As a Noun) An offer to pay a particular amount of money to buy something, especially at an auction. English = bid.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To offer to pay a particular amount of money for something, especially at an auction. English = bid.

bid%20(bet).description: (As a Noun) An offer to pay a particular amount of money for something, especially at an auction. English = bid.; (As a Noun) An amount of money you agree to give on the chance of a future event happening (like a horse winning a race). English = bet, wager; (As a Verb or Adjective) To offer to pay a particular amount of money for something, especially at an auction. English = bid.

bikini.description: (As a Noun) A two-piece swimming costume worn by women.  English = bikini.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wear a bikini.

English = (men and women) briefs, bikini briefs, underpants; (women) panties, knickers.

English = smoke.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have lots of dust or smoke particles in the air. English = (be) dusty, (be) hazy.

bin.description: (General Definition) A large cylindrical object, such as a drum or bucket, if hollow, or a column, telegraph pole, tree trunk or pylon, if solid, or any object or action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a bin or wastepaper basket.

biopsy.description:
(As a Noun) A BIOPSY is the removal of a sample of tissue for diagnosis.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for BIOPSY. If you know a sign for BIOPSY used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details.
Thank you.

bi-polar%20disorder.description: (As a Noun) BI-POLAR DISORDER is a type of depression that involves mood swings, i.e. really happy then normal then really sad, grumpy etc.; (As a Noun) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for BI-POLAR DISORDER.; (As a Noun) If you know a sign for BI-POLAR DISORDER used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

bird.description: (As a Noun) A creature with feathers and wings. Most of them can fly. The females lay eggs. English = chickens, fowl; chicken, poultry.; (As a Noun) A person who is afraid to do something. Informal English = chicken.

English = breeding.

bishop.description: (As a Noun) A clergyman of high rank, especially in the Roman Catholic, Anglican, and Orthodox churches. English = bishop.

pimp.description: (As a Noun) A person who betrays the trust of others by telling people in authority about the goings on of their peers when they involve either secrets or wrong-doings such as the breaking of rules, regulations or laws. English = pimp, blab, tell tales, inform on.

black.description: (As a Noun) The darkest colour that there is, the colour of the sky at night when there is no light at all. English = black.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be or have the darkest colour that there is, the colour of the sky at night when there is no light at all. English = (be) black.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make something black. English = blacken.

black%20eye.description: (As a Noun) An eye which has been injured and has a dark-coloured bruise around it. English = black eye.

black%20(person).description: (As a Noun) A person who is black. English = black, Negro.; (As a Noun) A person who belongs to the indigenous, black population of Australia. blacktown.description: (As a Noun) A suburb of Sydney, Australia, called Blacktown.

bladder.description: (As a Noun) Your BLADDER is the part of your body where urine is stored until it leaves your body.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for BLADDER. blanket.description: (As a Noun) A square or rectangular piece of thick cloth, especially one which you put on a bed to keep you warm. English = blanket.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To pull a blanket up over yourself.

blank%20mind.description: (As a Noun) A mind which has no ideas or thoughts in it at all; a mind which is empty. Formal English = tabula rasa.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have no ideas or thoughts at all; to have a blank mind.

blast%20(tell%20off).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To speak or sign to someone in an angry or serious way because they have done something wrong. Idiomatic English = tell off, blast.

blaze%20(sun).description: (As a Noun) A blazing sun, on a hot and cloudless day.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of the sun, to be shining very brightly and intensely, like on a hot, cloudless day; to blaze.

spinning.description: (General Definition) Of any two things (real or imaginary, concrete or abstract), for both to go around or circle each other, or any action or any thing directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a child's top, a blender, a spin-drier, or a cyclone.; (As a Noun) The action of turning quickly around a central point. English = bless.; (Interactive) Used alone just after someone has sneezed as a mild expression of concern. You hope that it does not mean they are very sick, or will get very sick. English = 'Bless you!', 'God bless you!'

blind.description: (As a Noun) People who are unable to see. English = the blind.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be unable to see because your eyes are damaged. English = (be) blind.

blind%20(screen).description: (General Definition) Any large flat object extending over one’s head or over one’s head and down in front of the eyes that give shelter or protection from water, sunlight, or any other type of hazard (like particles or dust to one’s eyes), such as an awning, a blind, a screen or an eye-guard.; (As a Noun) Protection for the eyes made by something vertical or diagonal in front of the eyes. flame (cooking).description: (General Definition) Any device with a nozzle and a thumb trigger that can be used to emit compressed gas, liquid or flame onto a surface, or any thing or any action that can be easily associated with this in context.; (As a Noun) A device with a nozzle and a thumb trigger that can be used to emit burning gas. English = blush.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To hold back the tears.

With minimal or no context, signers will assume you mean a wall.; (As a Noun) One of the vertical sides of a building or room; a long narrow vertical structure made of stone or brick that surrounds or divides an area of land. English = wall.; (As a Noun) A barrier made of wood or wire supported by posts. English = fence.

English = boarder.

board%20(get%20on).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To stand up after lying down, especially after sleeping in a bed. English = get up.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To stand up after sitting. body.description: (As a Noun) All the main physical parts of a person, including the head, arms and legs. English = body.; (As a Noun) A person who is dead. English = body.; (As a Noun) The main central part of your body, but not your neck, head, legs, or arms. English = trunk.

protector.description: (As a Noun) A person or thing that protects or defends anything. English = protector, defender, guard.; (As a Noun) A person who protects famous or important people. English = bodyguard.; (As a Noun) A person or thing that protects patrons inside a nightclub or party from unwanted or uninvited guests. English = bouncer.

body%20parts%20(pointing%20to).description: (As a Pointing Sign) The video at this entry shows someone pointing to different parts of their body. Some of these body-parts have their own Auslan sign (and if you do a keyword search for them you will find a match).; (Note) Most body parts do not have special signs in Auslan and they are signed simply by pointing to them. However, some body parts both external (’eyebrows’) and internal (’heart’) have their own Auslan signs. You will find them by searching for the keyword. If a body part is inside you and has no sign, e.g. ‘liver’, then you can point to the general area where it is located, and then describe it (say what it does or show how it is shaped using depicting signs). You can also fingerspell the English word for it.; (Note) Pointing signs are used when the body part can be easily and appropriately pointed at, with due regard to the situation and the audience. For example, some sexual body parts should not be pointed to in polite/formal situations, in mixed groups, or in the presence of children. Some of them also have their own Auslan signs (and if you do a keyword search for the them you will find a match).

shithouse.description: (As a Noun) The solid waste that people get rid of from their body when they go to the toilet. English = faeces. English (especially with children) = poo. Informal crude English = shit, crap.; (As a Noun) A small room containing a large bowl with a seat which you use when you want to get rid of urine or faeces from the body. An informal sign. Colloquial Australian English = shithouse, dunny, bog.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To get rid of faeces from the body. Crude informal English = shit, crap. Formal English = defecate.

bubbles.description: (As a Noun) Small balls of air that form in a liquid and then rise to the surface, either because it is very hot and boiling or because it is fizzy. English = bubbles.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a hot liquid, to start to change into steam and vapour as bubbles appear in it. English = boil.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a liquid, to have small balls of air forming in it and then rising to the surface. English = bubble, (be) bubbling, (be) bubbly, (be) effervescent.

boil%20(blister).description: (General Definition) A round protrusion or swelling on the body, such as a cyst or boil, or anything or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a blister.; (As a Noun) A painful swelling containing clear liquid on the surface of your skin, often the result of burning or rubbing. English = blister, cyst, abscess.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have blisters.

boiler%20suit.description: (As a Noun) A piece of clothing consisting of trousers and a top that are joined together in one piece, which people wear when they are working in order to keep their ordinary clothes clean. English = overalls, boiler suit.

relationship.description: (As a Noun) A close friendship between two people, especially one involving romantic or sexual feelings. English = relationship, connection, link.; (As a Noun) A strong feeling of friendship, love, or shared belief that unites two people. English = bond.

bone.description: (As a Noun) The hard parts inside your body which together form your skeleton. English = bone.

erection.description: (As a Noun) The state of a man's penis being stiff, swollen, and sticking up. For some Auslan users this is a vulgar sign. Formal English = erection. Vulgar English = stiff, boner. Idiomatic English = hard on.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a man's penis, to become stiff, swollen, and sticking up. For some Auslan users this is a vulgar sign. Formal English = become erect, get an erection. Vulgar English = become stiff, get a stiff, get a boner. Idiomatic English = get a hard on.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a man's penis, to be stiff, swollen, and sticking up. For some Auslan users this is a vulgar sign. Formal English = (be) erect. Vulgar English = (be) stiff. Idiomatic English = have a hard on.

bonnet%20(car).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of the boot/trunk or hood/bonnet of a car, to open or be open.

boo-boo.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To make a slight mistake, especially overlooking or forgetting something. Idiomatic English = boo-boo, make a boo-boo.; (Interactive) Used alone to indicate that there has been a slight accident or mistake. English = 'Oops!'

boobs.description: (As a Noun) The two soft round pieces of flesh on a woman's chest that can produce milk to feed a baby. Used especially to describe a woman who is well endowed with large breasts. book.description: (As a Noun) A number of pieces of paper, usually with words printed on them, which are fastened together and fixed inside a cover of stronger paper or cardboard. It contains information, stories, pictures, or poetry. English = book.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To open a book.

library.description: (As a Noun) An institution or part of an institution which keeps books and newspapers for people to read. Most of them allow people to borrow books for certain periods of time. English = library.; (As a Noun) A room in which books are kept. English = library.; (As a Noun) The shelves on which books are stored. English = bookshelf, bookshelves, bookcase.

reserve (book).description: (As a Noun) An arrangement that you make when you book something such as a theatre seat or a hotel room. English = reservation, booking.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To arrange to have or use something (such as a hotel room, or a ticket for something) at a particular time. English = reserve, book.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of things such as a hotel room, a seat at the theatre, or a table at a restaurant, to be taken or claimed by someone else for future use. English = (be) reserved, (be) booked.

book%20(reserve).description: (As a Noun) An arrangement that you make when you book something such as a theatre seat or a hotel room. English = reservation, booking.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To arrange to have or use something (such as a hotel room, or a ticket for something) at a particular time. English = reserve, book.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of things such as a hotel room, a seat at the theatre, or a table at a restaurant, to be taken or claimed by someone else for future use. English = (be) reserved, (be) booked.

boomerang.description: (As a Noun) A curved piece of wood which comes back to you if you throw it the correct way. It was first used by Australian Aborigines as a weapon. English = boomerang.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To throw a boomerang.

boot%20(car).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of the boot/trunk or hood/bonnet of a car, to open or be open.

bootmaker.description: (As a Noun) Someone who makes or repairs shoes. English = bootmaker.

boot%20(shoe).description: (As a Noun) A piece of clothing which covers your foot and ankle and is worn inside a shoe. English = boots.; (As a Noun) Loose, soft shoes that you wear in the house. English = slippers.

boundary.description: (As a Noun) An imaginary line or a real barrier (such as a fence) that separates one area of land from another. English = boundary.; (As a Noun) The dividing line between two countries or regions. English = border.

brush%20aside.description: (As a Noun) The act of getting rid of an employee. English = dismissal. Informal English = sacking.; (As a Noun) The act of getting rid of something or someone because it is not good enough or not wanted. English = rejection.; (As a Noun) The action of telling someone to go because you have decided that someone or something is not important or good enough to stay. English = dismissal.

brush%20(hair).description: (As a Noun) A brush that you use to brush your hair. English = hairbrush, brush.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To untangle your hair by using a hairbrush. English = brush (one's hair).

brush%20off.description: (As a Noun) The act of getting rid of an employee. English = dismissal. Informal English = sacking.; (As a Noun) The act of getting rid of something or someone because it is not good enough or not wanted. English = rejection.; (As a Noun) The action of telling someone to go because you have decided that someone or something is not important or good enough to stay. English = dismissal.

brush%20(teeth).description: (As a Noun) A small brush with a long handle which you use for cleaning your teeth. English = toothbrush.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To brush your teeth, to clean your teeth, to clean your teeth with a toothbrush.

chewing gum.description: (As a Noun) A kind of sweet which you chew for a long time but do not swallow. English = chewing gum.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To chew gum.

dollar.description: (As a Noun) A unit of money used in Australia, the USA, Canada, and some other countries. It is equal to 100 cents. English = dollar. Informal English = buck.

bucket.description: (General Definition) A container of some sort with a semi-circular handle on the top of it, such as a basket or bucket, an object with a curved top or covering, such as a button mushroom or ice-cream, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this.

seat belt (plane).description: (As a Noun) A strap attached to a seat in a car or an aeroplane. You fasten it across your body in order to prevent yourself being thrown out of the seat if there is a sudden movement. English = seat belt.; (As a Noun) A piece of metal or plastic attached to one end of a belt or strap, which is used to fasten it. English = buckle.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put on a belt, to fasten a belt, to buckle up a belt.

clam.description: (General Definition) Any object of a circular or elliptical shape, as described, or any object or action directly or indirectly associated with such an object, such as a clam, oyster, mussel and other shellfish, or a bud on a plant.

buddies.description: (As a Noun) Two people, especially school children, who are each others best friends. English = buddies, chums.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be best friends with someone, especially while at school, if not ever since school. English = (be) buddies, (be) best friends, (be) mates.; (Interactive) Used alone to mean that you and your addressee have done something exactly alike (like order something in a restaurant) or think alike in some way. English = 'Hey, we're the same!', 'Great minds think alike!', and so on.

mate.description: (As a Noun) A person you know well and like to spend time with. English = mate, pal, chum.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To know a person well and to like spending time with them. English = (be) mates, (be) pals, (be) chums.

budgerigar.description: (As a Noun) A small, brightly-coloured bird that people keep in their houses as pets. It has a small, hard, curved beak. English = budgerigar.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To nibble and peck at something like a budgerigar.

frugality.description: (As a Noun) The spending of as little money as possible by living cheaply, mainly because of difficult economic circumstances. English = frugality, sparingness, scrimping, economising.; (As a Noun) A plan showing how much money a person or organisation has available and how it should be spent. English = budget.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To live cheaply and spend as little money as possible; to use severe economy; to manage under difficult economic circumstances. English = scrimp, scrimp and save, (be) frugal, (be) sparing, make ends meet.

budget.description: (As a Noun) A plan showing how much money a person or organisation has available and how it should be spent, or the design of such a plan. English = budget, budgeting.; (As a Noun) In a particular country or region, the system according to which money, industry, and trade are organised there, as well as the wealth that it gets from this system. English = economy.; (As a Noun) The study of the way in which money, industry, and trade are organised in a particular country. English = economics.

buffer.description: (As a Noun) A device for polishing. English = buffer.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To polish metal, especially the metal of a car body, using a special mechanical polisher. English = buff.

feast.description: (As a Noun) A large and special meal. English = feast.; (As a Noun) Various hot and cold foods arranged on a table. English = smorgasbord, buffet.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To spread food out on a table.

bugger%20(bastard).description: (As a Noun) A person you dislike or have contempt for. Vulgar English = bugger, bastard.; (As a Noun) A person who you pretend to dislike or be annoyed with (because they do naughty things or play tricks on you) but whom you are actually fond of and whose antics you enjoy. English = bugger, bastard.; (Interactive) Used alone to express anger, annoyance, or contempt with someone or something. A vulgar sign. Vulgar English = 'You bugger!', 'Bugger you!', 'Bugger that!', 'You bastard!'

bugger%20off.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To leave a place, especially a room, suddenly and quickly because you do not want to be there any longer. English = get out.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To leave a place where you are normally obliged to stay because of responsibilities (eg work or home) without regard to the consequences or without permission. You would do this because you are angry, irritated or irresponsible.; (As a Verb or Adjective) English = walk out. Informal English = nick off, bugger off.

build.description: (As a Noun) A structure which has a roof and walls, for example a house or a factory. English = building.; (As a Noun) A person whose job is to build houses and other buildings. English = builder.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make a structure which has a roof and walls, such as a house or a factory. English = build, construct, erect.

build%20up.description: (As a Noun) The gradual increase, growth or improvement in something, especially after it had been damaged. English = build up.; (As a Noun) The rebuilding of something that has been destroyed or badly damaged. English = reconstruction.; (As a Noun) The carrying out of a plan, system or policy. English = implementation.

light bulb.description: (As a Noun) The glass part of an electric lamp, which gives out light when electricity passes through it. English = light bulb, bulb.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To remove a light bulb from a light socket.

bulk%20bill.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) When your doctor or health care provider BULK BILLS it means he or she charges the government directly for the medical service they have given to you and your appointment is free; you do not have to pay any money.

horns.description: (As a Noun) The hard pointed things that stick out of the heads of cows, deer, and some other animals. English = horns.; (As a Noun) A male animal of the cow family. English = bull.; (As a Noun) In Christianity, the most powerful evil spirit who is often depicted as having horns. English = devil.

bulldozer.description: (As a Noun) A large, powerful tractor with a broad metal blade at the front, which is used for knocking down buildings or moving large amounts of earth. English = bulldozer.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To knock something down or move something using a bulldozer. English = bulldoze.

bullet.description: (General Definition) Something that comes out of the end of a gun or gun-like object, such as a stream of water out of a water pistol, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a bullet.; (As a Noun) A small piece of metal with a pointed or rounded end, which is fired out of a gun. English = bullet.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a bullet, to be fired out of a gun.

bull's-eye.description: (As a Noun) The small circular area at the centre of a target. English = bull's-eye.; (As a Noun) A throw of a dart or shot of an arrow or bullet that hits the bull's-eye. English = bull's-eye.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To throw a dart, shoot an arrow, or shoot a bullet so that it hits the bull's-eye; to score a bull's-eye.

doublespeak.description: (As a Noun) Talk or gossip which is inaccurate, vague or ambiguous, in order to brag or to smear someone. English = doublespeak, double-talk. Informal English = bullshit, bull.; (As a Noun) Talk or gossip which is obscure, vague, euphemistic, ambiguous or evasive so as to avoid saying the truth directly, e.g., like a politician. It is sometimes done to deliberately deceive. English = doublespeak, double-talk.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To talk or gossip in a way which is inaccurate, vague or ambiguous, in order to brag or to smear someone. English = use doublespeak, use double-talk. Informal English = bullshit.

bullshit%20(nonsense).description: (As a Noun) Something which is nonsense, completely untrue, or not worth taking seriously. English = bullshit, rubbish.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To dislike something quite strongly. English = hate, loathe.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To reject, refuse or dismiss something because you do not like it.

bully.description: (As a Noun) A person who uses their strength or power to hurt or frighten other people. English = bully.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use your strength or power to hurt or frighten other people and make them do things. English = bully.

bum.description: (As a Noun) The part of your body that you sit on. English = bum, bottom, buttocks. Informal English = cheeks.  Informal vulgar English = arse. Informal slang English = buns (especially of a man).

lump.description: (General Definition) Something of this general shape (an arc or a hemisphere) lying on a flat surface, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a lump on the body.; (As a Noun) A small, hard piece of flesh that is formed on someone's body as a result of an injury or an illness. English = lump.; (As a Noun) A swollen shape on your body which is there as a result of a blow. English = bump.

bump%20into.description: (As a Noun) The accidental meeting of someone.; (As a Verb or Adjective) For one person or thing to go to and meet another unexpectedly. Formal English = encounter. Idiomatic English = run into, bump into.

rough.description: (As a Noun) A surface which is sloping or curved, and has raised parts; an uneven surface, a rough surface.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have lots of bumps and raised parts on a surface. English = (be) rough, (be) bumpy, (be) uneven.

bundle.description: (As a Noun) A number of things tied together or wrapped in a cloth so that they can be carried or stored. English = bundle.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To tie a number of things together or wrap them in cloth so that they can be carried or stored. English = bundle.

bun%20(hair).description: (As a Noun) A style of wearing long hair in which your hair is fastened into a round shape at the back of your head. English = bun, hair bun.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wear your hear in a bun.

bunk.description: (As a Noun) Two beds, one above the other, held in a frame. English = bunk, bunk beds.

bunker.description: (General Definition) A surface with a curved depression in it, such as a hollow or valley, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a bunker.; (As a Noun) In golf, a shallow excavation, usually at the side of a green, which has been nearly filled with sand and which serves as a hazard. English = bunker.

rabbit.description: (As a Noun) A small furry animal with long ears. It lives in holes in the ground. English = rabbit. Informal English (especially for small children) = bunny, bunny rabbit.; (As a Noun) An animal like a large rabbit with long ears, long legs, and a small tail. English = hare.

bunny%20rabbit.description: (As a Noun) A small furry animal with long ears. It lives in holes in the ground. English = rabbit. Informal English (especially for small children) = bunny, bunny rabbit.; (As a Noun) An animal like a large rabbit with long ears, long legs, and a small tail. English = hare.

buns%20(buttocks).description: (As a Noun) The part of your body that you sit on. English = bum, bottom, buttocks. Informal English = cheeks.  Informal vulgar English = arse. Informal slang English = buns (especially of a man).

buoy.description: (As a Noun) A placeholder or an anchor sign that helps keep ideas ordered or the events in a story in sequence. English = buoy.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving a definition in Auslan for the English term BUOY, as it would be used in an academic context, especially when discussing the linguistics of signed languages. If you know an Auslan sign used in this context by yourself or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters), please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

burden.description: (As a Noun) Something which causes you a lot of worry or hard work. English = burden.; (As a Noun) A heavy load that is difficult to carry. English = burden.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have something which causes you a lot of worry or hard work; to be burdened with something.

bureaucracy.description: (As a Noun) An administrative system operated by a large number of officials following rules and procedures. English = bureaucracy.

burger.description: (As a Noun) Minced meat which has been shaped into a flat disc or round flat ball and which is fried. English = burger, patty, rissole.; (As a Noun) A bread roll which contains minced meat that has been shaped into a flat disc and which may also contain lettuce, tomato, cheese and so on. English = hamburger.; (As a Noun) A ball of snow. Children often throw them at each other. English = snowball.

thief.description: (As a Noun) A person who steals something from another person, especially without using violence and often wearing a mask to hide their identity. English = thief, burglar.

stealing.description: (As a Noun) The act of taking things away from people without their permission and without intending to return them. English = stealing, robbery, theft, burglary.; (As a Noun) A person who steals things. English = robber.; (As a Noun) The removal of money from a bank account. English = withdrawal.

funeral.description: (As a Noun) The ceremony that takes place when a dead body is put into the ground and covered or burnt. English = funeral.; (As a Noun) The ceremony that takes place when a dead body is put into the ground and covered. English = burial.; (As a Noun) The place where a dead body is put into the ground and covered. English = grave.

fire.description: (As a Noun) The hot, bright flames produced by things that are burning. English = fire.; (As a Noun) A quantity of hot, bright, burning gas that comes in a pointed stream from something that is burning. English = flame, flames.; (As a Noun) The burning of a dead body at a funeral. English = cremation.

burrow.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person or animal, especially a dog, to dig a hole using your hands or claws. English = burrow.

burst%20into%20flames.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of something flammable, to suddenly catch fire. English = ignite. Idiomatic English = burst into flames.

bus.description: (As a Noun) A large motor vehicle that carries passengers from one place to another. English = bus.; (As a Noun) A comfortable bus that carries passengers on long journeys. English = coach.; (As a Noun) A vehicle like a large car that is used for carrying goods. English = van.

bus%20driver.description: (As a Noun) A large vehicle, such as a bus, truck, lorry, or tractor which has a large, almost horizontal, steering wheel.; (As a Noun) A large motor vehicle that carries passengers from one place to another. English = bus.; (As a Noun) A large vehicle that is used to transport goods by road. English = truck, lorry.

shrub.description: (As a Noun) A low plant like a small tree with several woody stems instead of a trunk. English = shrub, bush.

business.description: (As a Noun) Work relating to the production, buying, and selling of goods and services. English = business, firm.; (As a Noun) An organisation which produces and sells goods or which provides a service. English = business.

business%20card.description: (General Definition) The action of outlining something which is small and rectangular, or any thing or any action which is directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a ticket or a card.; (As a Noun) An official piece of paper or card which shows that you have paid for a journey or have paid to enter a place of entertainment such as a sports ground or cinema. English = ticket.; (As a Noun) A small piece of stiff paper that you write information on. English = card.

business%20(none%20of%20my%20business).description: (General Definition) Some kind of vertical surface or line of things in front of and to the sides of you or the person, place or thing you represent, such as a barrier or fence, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To resolve that you will no longer consider or talk about someone else's concerns or affairs because you consider it to be none of your business.; (Interactive) Used alone to mean that something is none of one's business or concern and you have no intention of getting involved. English = 'I'm keeping right out of that. It's got nothing to do with me.'

business%20(none%20of%20your%20business).description: (Interactive) Used alone in response to someone's question when you believe they have no right to ask you that or know the answer. Abrupt and offensive if used with strangers. English = '(It's) none of your business!', 'Butt out!', 'Mind your own business!'

statue.description: (As a Noun) A large sculpture of a person or an animal, made of stone or metal. English = statue.

breasts (large).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a woman, to have large breasts. Informal English = busty.

busybody.description: (As a Noun) A person who is very inquisitive and always wants to know everything that is happening, especially about other people's affairs. Informal English = busybody, sticky-beak.

busy%20(road).description: (As a Noun) The movement of vehicles along a road. English = traffic, flow of traffic.; (As a Noun) Multiple lanes for cars on a wide road. English = traffic lanes.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a road, to be full of moving vehicles. English = (be) busy.

but.description: (As Modifier) You use this sign to introduce a statement which contrasts with what you have just said. English = but.; (As Modifier) You also use this sign when you are about to add something further in a discussion or to change the subject. English = but.

butcher.description: (As a Noun) A shopkeeper who sells meat, or the shop in which meat is sold. English = butcher, butcher's.; (As a Noun) The flesh of a dead animal that people cook and eat. English = meat.; (As a Noun) The meat of a cow, bull or ox. English = beef.

butter.description: (As a Noun) A yellowish substance made from cream which you spread on bread or use in cooking. English = butter.; (As a Noun) A substitute spread for butter made from vegetable oils. English =  margarine.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To spread butter or margarine on bread or toast. English = butter.

butterfly.description: (As a Noun) A type of insect with large colourful wings and a thin body. English = butterfly.; (As a Noun) An insect like a butterfly but without colourful wings, which usually flies about at night. English = moth.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a butterfly or moth, to fly about, to flutter its wings.

butterfly%20needle.description: (As a Noun) A BUTTERFLY NEEDLE is a type of needle used for drawing blood from parts of the body where blood vessels are close to the skin, i.e. the hand or wrist.  It has plastic "wings" like a butterfly.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for BUTTERFLY NEEDLE. If you know a sign for BUTTERFLY NEEDLE used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

butterfly%20stroke.description: (As a Noun) A kind of swimming stroke which you do lying on your front, bringing your arms over your head together. English = butterfly stroke.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To swim using the butterfly stroke. English = butterfly.

button%20(clothing).description: (As a Noun) A small hard object sewn on to shirts, coats, or other pieces of clothing. You fasten the clothing by pushing it through a hole (called a buttonhole). English = button.

button%20mushroom.description: (General Definition) A container of some sort with a semi-circular handle on the top of it, such as a basket or bucket, an object with a curved top or covering, such as a button mushroom or ice-cream, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this.

buttons%20(clothing).description: (As a Noun) A small hard object sewn on to shirts, coats, or other pieces of clothing. You fasten the clothing by pushing it through a hole (called a buttonhole). English = button.

button%20up.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To fasten the buttons on an item of clothing, especially a shirt. Idiomatic English = do up buttons, button up

purchase.description: (As a Noun) Something you have obtained by paying money for it. English = purchase.; (As a Noun) A person who buys things, usually for other people. English = buyer, purchaser.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To obtain something by paying money for it. English = buy. Formal English = purchase.

buy%20for.description: (As a Noun) A person or organisation who pays some or all of the expenses connected with an event or someone's training, often in order to get publicity for themselves. English = sponsor.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To pay the cost of something for someone, or to buy something for someone, e.g., as a gift.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person or organisation, to pay some or all of the expenses connected with an event or someone's training, often in order to get publicity for themselves. English = sponsor.

wave hand.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To move your hand side to side in the air, usually in order to say hello or goodbye to someone.  English = wave.; (Interactive) Used alone when greeting someone. English = 'Hello!', 'Hi!'; (Interactive) Used alone when taking leave of someone. English = 'Good-bye', 'Bye.' Formal English = 'Farewell'.

bypass.description: (As a Noun) A BYPASS is an operation performed on or near the heart.  The flow of blood is redirected so that it does not flow through a part of the heart which is blocked or diseased.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for BYPASS. If you know a sign for BYPASS used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

c.description: (As a Noun) The letter C in the one-handed manual alphabets.; (Augmented Meaning) A single letter sign can be used alone (often with a slight outward repeated movement) to represent any word (especially proper names for people and places). When this occurs the signer often silently mouthes the word. Some letters are very commonly associated with particular words. In Auslan, the letter C from the one-handed alphabet is strongly assoicated with Canberra (the capital city of Australia).

taxi.description: (As a Noun) A car driven by someone whose job is to take you where you want to go in return for money. English = taxi, cab

cabbage.description: (General Definition) The action of chopping or shredding something, usually food, rapidly and finely, such as vegetables or meat, or any action or any thing directly or indirectly associated with this, especially cabbage or mince.; (As a Noun) A vegetable which looks like a ball of green, pale green and white leaves which is often chopped up finely or shredded before it is cooked and eaten. English = cabbage.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cut an object up into lots of small pieces. English = chop, chop up, shred.

cupboard.description: (As a Noun) A piece of furniture which has one or two doors at the front and usually shelves inside it. It is used for keeping things in. English = cupboard, cabinet.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To open and close a cupboard.

cable%20stitch.description: (As a Noun) A knitting pattern whereby one set of stiches is crossed over another so that a rope-like effect is produced. English = cable stitch.

stash.description: (As a Noun) Something put into a secret place. Informal English = stash. Formal English = cache.; (As a Noun) The act of collecting money by not spending it, or the money itself. English = saving, savings.; (As a Noun) A collection of gold or silver objects, jewels or other valuable things, which has been hidden. English = treasure.

caddie.description: (General Definition) The act of carrying something heavy slung over your shoulder, or any object or action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a caddie.; (As a Noun) A person who carries a bag of golf clubs. English = caddie.

cadge.description: (As a Noun) A person who constantly or repeatedly asks other people for things, food or money (especially cigarettes or drinks), rather than buying or getting them him or herself. He or she always takes advantage of other people to get or do things they want. English = user, cadger, scrounger. Informal Australian English = bludger.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To constantly or repeatedly ask other people for things, food or money (especially cigarettes or drinks), rather than buying or getting them yourself. To treat someone unfairly for your own benefit, to use someone, to make use of someone. English = take advantage of, scrounge, cadge. Informal Australian English = bludge.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use something or someone at hand, even though the thing or the person is not what or who you wanted in the first place. English = make do.

user.description: (As a Noun) A person who always takes advantage of other people to get or do things they want. English = user, cadger, scrounger, bludger.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use someone, to make use of someone, to take advantage of someone. English = use, cadge, scrounge, bludge.

caesarean.description: (General Definition) An operation performed on the stomach area of the body, or any action or any thing directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a Caesarean or a hysterectomy.; (As a Noun) An operation in which a baby is lifted out of a woman's womb through an opening cut in her abdomen. English = Caesarean, Caesarean section.; (As a Noun) A surgical operation to remove a woman's womb. English = hysterectomy.

cafe.description: (As a Noun) A place where you can buy drinks, especially coffee, and light meals or snacks. English = cafe.; (As a Noun) A restaurant where you choose your food from a counter and carry it to your table yourself after paying for it. English = cafeteria.; (As a Noun) A place in a factory or other place of work where the people who work there can eat. English = canteen.

caffeine.description: (As a Noun) CAFFEINE is a chemical substance found in coffee, tea, and cocoa, which affects your brain and body and makes you more active.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for CAFFEINE. If you know a sign for CAFFEINE used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

cage.description: (General Definition) Any box-like object which is covered with stripes or made up of long and thin things, such as wires, bars, or beams, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a frame or a cage.; (As a Noun) An arrangement of bars that gives an object its shape and strength. English = frame, framework.; (As a Noun) A structure of wire or metal bars in which birds or animals are kept. English = cage.

cairns.description: (As a Noun) A coastal city in the north of the Australian state of Queensland, called Cairns.

cake.description: (As a Noun) A sweet food made by baking a mixture of flour, eggs, sugar, and fat in an oven. It is usually flat and round. English = cake.

calcification.description: (As a Noun) CALCIFICATION is when calcium builds up in the soft tissue of the body, and causes it to harden.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for CALCIFICATION. If you know a sign for CALCIFICATION used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

calculator.description: (General Definition) A small hand-held device which is operated by pushing buttons, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a calculator or mobile phone.; (As a Noun) A small electronic device that you use for doing mathematical calculations. English = calculator.; (As a Noun) A small portable telecommunications device that you use for making phone calls. You dial the number by pushing on buttons. English = mobile phone.

calculus.description: (As a Noun) A branch of advanced mathematics which deals with variable quantities. English = calculus.

calendar.description: (As a Noun) A chart which shows a particular year divided up into months, weeks, and days, and shows what the date of each day is in that year. English = calendar.

called%20(entitled).description: (As a Noun) The name of a book, play, film or piece of music. English = title.; (As a Noun) The thing, person, or idea that is being discussed or written about. English = topic, subject, theme.; (As a Noun) A word or phrase that is usually used in a particular situation or by particular people, and that you are quoting, explaining, or commenting on. English = expression.

called%20(named).description: (As a Noun) A name given to someone which is not their real name. English = nickname, sobriquet.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To give a name to someone or something; or to be given a particular name and to be known by that name. English = call, name; (be) called, (be) named.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To describe a thing or a person by using a particular word, sign or phrase. English = call.

callisthenics.description: (As a Noun) Energetic movements which you do in order to become fit or remain healthy. English = callisthenics, gymnastics, exercise.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To do energetic movements in order to become fit or to remain healthy. English = do exercises, do callisthenics, do gymnastics.

call%20(name).description: (As a Noun) A name given to someone which is not their real name. English = nickname, sobriquet.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To give a name to someone or something; or to be given a particular name and to be known by that name. English = call, name; (be) called, (be) named.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To describe a thing or a person by using a particular word, sign or phrase. English = call.

canberra.description: (As a Noun) The capital city of the Commonwealth of Australia, called Canberra.

cash%20register.description: (As a Noun) A machine in a shop, pub, or restaurant that is used to add up and record how much money people pay, and in which the money is kept. caught%20out.description: (As a Noun) The act of seizing an object which is moving through the air with your hands.
