English = debriefing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) After a meeting, a presentation or an event of importance to a group of people, to get together with the participants and discuss what happened. English = debrief.

lousy.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be of very bad quality and not to be liked at all; to be worth nothing at all. English = (be) lousy, (be) rotten; (be) worthless.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To severely harm, damage or spoil something; to damage something so that it no longer works. English = ruin.; (As a Verb or Adjective) (When talking of food, wood or the bodies of animals) to become no good because they are getting old, dying, or are dead and are being attacked by micro-organisms or insects. English = rot, decay, go off.

slow down.description: (As a Noun) Reduction in speed or rate. English = deceleration.; (As a Noun) In mathematics and physics, the rate at which the speed of an object is decreasing. English = deceleration.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To take your foot off the accelerator in order to make a vehicle go slower. English = slow down, decelerate. Idiomatic English = ease up, take one's foot off the brake.

decide.description: (As a Noun) A choice that you make about what should be done or about which is the best of various alternatives. English = decision.; (As a Noun) The act of deciding something. English = decision, decision making.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To choose to do something, usually after you have thought carefully about the other possibilities. English = decide.

decimal.description: (As a Noun) A fraction that is written in the form of a dot followed by one or more numbers which represents tenths, hundreds, and so on. English = decimal.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In mathematics, a system of counting based in units of ten. English = decimal.

decimal%20point.description: (General Definition) Indicate by pointing, or mark with your finger, a small defined thing or location somewhere in space or on a surface, or any thing or any action that can be associated with this in context.; (As a Noun) A mark on a piece of paper or on a display screen (or any surface which can be drawn or written on) which is small, round and completely filled in. English = point, dot, spot.; (As a Noun) A mark in writing that is small, round and completely filled in which marks the end of a sentence. English = full stop, stop, period.

decision.description: (As a Noun) The act of choosing to do something, usually after you have thought carefully about the other possibilities. English = decision.; (As a Noun) A firm decision to do something or the determination to do something. English = resolution.; (As a Noun) A formal decision to do something which is passed at a meeting by means of a vote. English = resolution.

decision%20making.description: (As a Noun) A choice that you make about what should be done or about which is the best of various alternatives. English = decision.; (As a Noun) The act of deciding something. English = decision, decision making.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To choose to do something, usually after you have thought carefully about the other possibilities. English = decide.

declare%20(cricket).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) In cricket, to close an innings voluntarily before all ten wickets have fallen. English = declare.

decline%20(refuse).description: (As a Noun) The action of someone who says firmly that they will not do or accept something. English = refusal.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say firmly that you will not do or accept something. English = refuse, decline.

decoration.description: (As a Noun) Something that is added to something else in order to make it look more attractive. English = decoration, decorations.; (As a Noun) Ribbons, balloons and other brightly colored objects hung around a room to make it look more attractive as part of a celebration. English = decorations.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To add something to something else in order to make it look more attractive. English = decorate.

subtraction.description: (As a Noun) The calculation in which you take one number away from another number. English = subtraction, deduction.; (As a Noun) The removal or crossing out of something that has been written down. English = deletion.; (As a Noun) The act of taking one thing away from another thing.

de%20facto.description: (As a Noun) A relationship in which two people live together in a sexual and domestic relationship without there being any act of marriage (legal, civil, or religious) between them. English = de facto relationship.; (As a Noun) A person who lives with another person in a sexual and domestic relationship (as husband or wife) without there being any act of marriage (legal, civil, or religious) between them. English = de facto.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To live with someone in a sexual and domestic relationship without there being any act of marriage (legal, civil, or religious) between you. English = (be) de facto. Idiomatic English = shack up with/together, live together.

defeat.description: (As a Noun) The state of being beaten in a battle, game, or contest. English = defeat.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To win a victory over someone in a battle, game, or contest. English = defeat, beat.

prevention.description: (As a Noun) The stopping of something from happening, or the stopping of someone from doing something. English = prevention.; (As a Noun) The prevention of someone or something from being harmed or damaged. English = protection.; (As a Noun) Action taken to protect someone or something from attack. English = defence.

avoidance.description: (General Definition) Of two people, for one person to suddenly change direction and to move away from the other person, or any action or any thing directly or indirectly associated with this, especially avoid.; (As a Noun) The act of keeping away from someone so that you do not meet them. English = avoidance.; (As a Noun) A quick movement or a sudden change in direction so as to avoid meeting or being seen by someone, or to avoid being hit or caught by someone or something.

explanation.description: (As a Noun) Facts, details and ideas which say why something happened or is the way it is. English = explanation.; (As a Noun) An account of what a person, thing or event is like, especially what it looks like. English = description.; (As a Noun) A statement giving the meaning of a word or a sign, especially in a dictionary. English = definition

definite%20integral.description: (As a Noun) All the facts about something, rather than things that are imagined or invented. English = truth.; (As a Noun) A piece of information that is true. English = fact.; (As a Noun) The world around us as it is rather than the way someone imagines it to be. English = reality.

degree%20(temperature).description: (As a Noun) The degree symbol, written as a small superscript zero after a number.; (As a Noun) A unit of measurement that is used when expressing temperatures. English = degree.; (As a Noun) A unit of measurement that is used when expressing angles and also latitude and longitude. English = degree.

de-identify.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To remove identifying particulars or details from data sets such as medical records or test results, social research results, or government records typically for statistical or other purposes. English = de-identify, anonymize.; (Note) Suggested sign #1×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (Note) Suggested sign #2×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

depression.description: (As a Noun) The feeling of great sadness and disappointment. English = depression, despondency, dejection, gloom.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Verb or Adjective) To feel great sadness and disappointment. English = (be) depressed, (be) dejected, (be) despondent, (be) downcast, (be) sad, (be) unhappy.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make someone feel great sadness and disappointment. English = depress, sadden.

wilfulness.description: (As a Noun) The determination to get what you want and to do things in your own way, often knowing you may hurt someone else. English = wilfulness.; (As a Noun) The strong determination that someone has to do exactly what they want and not to change their mind or be persuaded to do anything else. English = obstinacy.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of actions, to be done with intention or with a plan, that is after having thought about it first. English = (be) deliberate, (be) intentional, (be) done on purpose.

delicious.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a very pleasant taste, to taste good. English = (be) delicious. Informal English = (be) yummy.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have an extremely pleasant taste, to taste extremely good. English = (be) scrumptious.; (Interactive) Used alone to indicate that you like the food you are eating very much, especially to the person who made it or is responsible for it. English = 'Yummy!'

thrill.description: (As a Noun) A sudden feeling of great excitement or pleasure. English = thrill.; (As a Noun) An event or experience that gives you a thrill. English = thrill.; (As a Noun) An apparatus on which you can do acrobatic jumps. It consists of a large piece of strong cloth held by springs in a frame. English = trampoline.

exquisite.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be extremely beautiful in appearance, or very pleasant or satisfying. English = (be) exquisite, (be) magnificent, (be) delightful.

free (liberate).description: (As a Noun) The setting free of a person or animal, especially a person from gaol. English = release, freeing, liberation.; (As a Noun) The escape of someone from bondage, or the saving of someone. Formal English = deliverance.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To no longer be a prisoner or a slave, and to be unrestricted, uncontrolled, or unlimited in what you can do; of a person, to be released from gaol. English = (be) freed, (be) released, (be) liberated.

delusion.description: (As a Noun) A DELUSION is a false belief.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DELUSION. If you know a sign for DELUSION used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

go blank (forget).description: (As a Noun) [Especially when made with two hands] a chronic or persistent brain disease that causes memory loss, personality changes, and difficulty in reasoning (thinking). English = dementia.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To completely forget to do something that you should have remembered.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be unable to remember things you have learnt (such as your part in a play, or information for an exam) or to be unable to think of anything to say. English = go blank.

demister.description: (As a Noun) In a vehicle, a device that blows air onto a windscreen to reduce condensation. English = demister.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DEMISTER for most signers (but some signers represent this visually using these depicting signs, once they have established the topic). This suggested sign is a combination of the Auslan signs WINDOW RECTANGULAR EMIT to represent air moving up the windscreen of a car. Source of this recommended sign: Victorian College for the Deaf.

democracy.description: (As a Noun) The system of government or organisation in which people choose leaders or make important decisions by voting. English = democracy.; (As a Noun) A country in which the people choose their government by voting for it. English = democracy.

demolition.description: (As a Noun) The act of knocking down a building, often because it is old or dangerous. English = demolition.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To knock down a building, often because it is old or dangerous. English = demolish. Idiomatic English = pull down.

demonstration.description: (As a Noun) A public meeting or march which is held by people to show their opposition to something or their support for it. English = demonstration, protest.; (As a Noun) A group of people, usually trade union members, who stand outside a place of work in order to protest about something, to prevent people from going in, or to persuade the workers to join a strike. English = picket.; (As a Noun) A large notice that is carried in a march or demonstration or is displayed in a public place. English = placard.

demotion.description: (As a Noun) The change from a more important to a less important job or position in an organisation. English = demotion.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To reduce someone's rank; to give them a less important job in an organisation. English = demote.; (Interactive) Used alone, especially in the context of a meeting or lecture, to suggest or tell people to move on to the next item on the agenda. English = 'Okay, let's move on to the next item’; ‘Okay, next.’

denial.description: (As a Noun) A statement in which you say something is not true, usually be shaking you head side to side.; (As a Noun) A statement in which you say something is not true, especially when it has been claimed to be true of you. English = denial.; (As a Noun) A rejection of an offer. English = refusal, rejection.

denomination%20(religion).description: (As a Noun) A building in which Christians worship. English = church.; (As a Noun) A building used for the worship of a god or gods in some religions. English = temple.; (As a Noun) One of the groups of people within the Christian religion, for example Catholics. English = church, denomination, religion.

denominator.description: (As a Noun) The number below the line in a fraction. English = denominator.

denotation.description: (As a Noun) In linguistics, the literal (narrow) meaning or "dictionary definition" of a word or sign. English = denotation; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term DENOTATION as it is used in an educational or academic context, especially when talking or writing about linguistics.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DENOTATION (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for DENOTATION used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

dentist.description: (As a Noun) A person who is qualified to treat people's teeth. English = dentist.; (As a Noun) The removal of a tooth out of someone's mouth by a dentist. English = extraction.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a dentist, to pull a tooth out of someone's mouth. English = extract (a tooth).

false teeth.description: (As a Noun) Artificial teeth used by people who no longer have all their own teeth. English = false teeth, dentures.

deny.description: (As a Noun) A statement in which someone says that something is not true or that they did not do something. English = denial.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say that something is not true, especially to say that it is not you who did something. English = deny.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be not guilty or not responsible for a crime, misdemeanour, or wrong-doing. English = (be) innocent.

deny%20responsibility.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To not have the duty to deal with, make decision about, or accept the blame for something; (be) not responsible for; to have no responsibility.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say that you did not do something after others claim or assume that you did do it. English = deny responsibility.; (Interactive) Used alone to mean you have no interest or connection with what someone is talking about, especially because they mistakenly think you have done something or are someway involved in it. English = 'It's got nothing to do with me!', 'It's not my responsibility!', 'Damned if I know or care!', and so on.

deodorant.description: (As a Noun) A pleasant-smelling spray that you put on your body, especially under your arms, in order to reduce the smell of perspiration. English = deodorant, underarm deodorant, spray deodorant.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To apply underarm spray deodorant.

exit.description: (As a Noun) The act of leaving or going out of or from a confined space (such as a room or a building). English = exit, departure.; (As a Noun) A door in a public building through which you can leave; the path you follow to get out of a building or group of buildings. English = exit, way out.; (As a Noun) A person who has escaped from a prison. English = escapee.

gone.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To have moved or travelled away from a place. English = gone, went, left, departed.

region.description: (As a Noun) One of, or a number of, large areas of land that are different from other areas of land, for example because they are different parts of a country or because they have a particular geographical features. English = region, regions; district, districts.; (As a Noun) One of, or a number of, the parts of an organisation, institution or some other entity which together make up the whole. English = division, divisions, department, departments.; (As a Noun) One of, or a number of, the separate areas of a large town or city that are not close to the centre. People often work in the centre and live in one of these areas. English = suburb, suburbs.

departure.description: (As a Noun) The act of moving away or travelling away from the place where you are now. English = going, leaving, going away, departure.; (As a Noun) A social event in which you go away from your own house to be with other people or, particularly, to visit outdoor sites. English = outing.; (As a Noun) The approval of someone else to do something. English = permission, go ahead.

depend on.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) For one thing to happen only if the circumstances are right (ie if something else happens first); to be determined by something else. English = depend on.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Used to describe something which is dependent on another thing. English = (be) dependent.; (Interactive) Used alone to mean you are not sure what will happen or what the best answer to give is. English = 'It depends.'

dependent%20variable.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) For one thing to happen only if the circumstances are right (ie if something else happens first); to be determined by something else. English = depend on.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Used to describe something which is dependent on another thing. English = (be) dependent.; (Interactive) Used alone to mean you are not sure what will happen or what the best answer to give is. English = 'It depends.'

depend%20on.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) For one thing to happen only if the circumstances are right (ie if something else happens first); to be determined by something else. English = depend on.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Used to describe something which is dependent on another thing. English = (be) dependent.; (Interactive) Used alone to mean you are not sure what will happen or what the best answer to give is. English = 'It depends.'

depends.description: (Interactive) Used alone to mean that you are not sure what will happen or what is the best answer to give. English = 'It depends.'; (As Modifier) Used before a signed sentence (usually followed by fingerspelt IF or signed ON) to mean that the topic under discussion will only happen if special conditions, relating to the sentence after this sign, are met. English = depends.

deposit.description: (As a Noun) An amount of money put into a bank account. English = deposit.; (As a Noun) The amount of money you put into a bank or buy shares with. English = investment.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put something somewhere, especially money into a bank, so that it is safe until it is needed again. English = deposit.

descale.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To remove the scales from a fish. English = descale; (Note) The following signs or sign expressions are suggested for 'descale'.  Source: DeafConnectED, Melbourne Polytechnic.; (Note) Suggested sign #1×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

generation.description: (As a Noun) The period of time, usually considered to be about thirty years, that it takes for children to grow up and become adults and have children of their own. English = generation.; (As a Noun) All the children, grandchildren, great grandchildren and so on of any particular couple or community of people. English = descendants.; (As a Noun) The children or grandchildren of a particular couple. English = offspring.

information.description: (As a Noun) Facts, details and ideas which are communicated or received about something or someone. English = information.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Noun) The act of saying what someone or something is like or an account of what someone or something is like. English = description.; (As a Noun) Facts, details and ideas which say why something happened or is the way it is. English = explanation.

desk.description: (As a Noun) A table, often with drawers, which you sit at in order to write or work. English = desk.; (As a Noun) A piece of furniture with drawers. English = drawers, chest of drawers

loathing.description: (As a Noun) An extremely strong dislike for something. English = hate, hatred, loathing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have an extremely strong dislike for something. English = hate, detest, loathe.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be disliked very much. English = (be) hated, (be) loathsome, (be) detested, (be) detestable.

disconnect.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of two things or people, to suddenly become apart from each other after having been attached or joined in some way. English = disconnect, unfasten, detach.

detail%20(in%20detail).description: (As a Noun) The distance between the top and bottom surfaces of something. English = depth.; (As a Noun) The great intensity or seriousness of a situation, emotion, thought, etc. English = depth, profundity.; (As a Noun) The degree or amount to which something is serious or important. English = depth.

detective.description: (As a Noun) Someone whose job is to discover what has happened in a crime or other situation and to find the people involved. English = detective.

worsen.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To get worse. English = worsen, deteriorate.

deterioration.description: (General Definition) A flat surface, a quantity of something, or the top of something which is and/or becomes lower, shorter or smaller, or any thing or any object that can be associated with this in context.; (As a Noun) The height of something which is low or small.; (As a Noun) The state of getting worse and worse in condition (especially in illness), or to become more difficult or unpleasant. English = deterioration.

determination.description: (As a Noun) The quality that you show when you have decided to do something and you will not let anything stop you. English = determination.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make a firm decision to do something and not let anything or anyone else stop you. English = (be) determined.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make a great effort to do something. English = strive.

used to.description: (As a Noun) The condition of two things being exactly alike in all respects. English = identity.; (As a Noun) In a match or competition, an equal score between two people or two teams so that nobody wins. English = draw, tie; deuce (in tennis).; (As a Noun) The result when two competitors in a race both cross the finishing line at exactly the same time. English = dead heat.

deuce%20(tennis).description: (As a Noun) The act of remaining steady and upright and not falling over when you are standing or walking on a narrow spot. English = balancing.; (As a Noun) The score in a game of tennis when both players have forty points. English = deuce.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To remain steady and upright and not fall over when you are standing or walking on a narrow spot. English = balance, keep your balance.

improvement.description: (As a Noun) A change for the better. English = improvement.; (As a Noun) The act or process of becoming more advanced, skilful, or higher in rank over a period of time. English = progress.; (As a Noun) The process of growing or changing over a period of time into a better or more complete form. English = development.

sugar.description: (As a Noun) A sweet substance, often in the form of white or brown crystals, which is used to sweeten food and drink. English = sugar.; (As a Noun) [Only some signers, especially when they say the word "diabetes" with their lips] a medical condition in which someone has too much sugar in their blood. English = diabetes.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Noun) [Only some signers, especially when they say the word "diabetic" with their lips] a person who has diabetes. English = diabetic.

diagnosis.description: (As a Noun) Identifying what is wrong with someone who is ill. English = diagnosis.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To identify what is wrong with someone who is ill. English = diagnose.

diagonal.description: (As a Noun) A line that goes in a slanting direction. English = diagonal.; (As a Noun) A diagonal line that separates letters, words, or numbers, especially a flat or apartment number from the building number. English = slash, stroke.; (As a Noun) A slanting straight line that joins two opposite corners of a straight-sided shape such as a square or cube. English = diagonal.

diagram.description: (As a Noun) A simple drawing consisting mainly of lines, often one which is used to explain how something works. English = diagram.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To draw a picture or diagram.

diameter.description: (As a Noun) In geometry, a straight line passing from side to side through the centre of a body or figure, especially a circle or square. English = diameter.

diamond.description: (As a Noun) A hard, bright, precious stone that consists of pure carbon. It is used especially in jewellery and rings. English = diamond.; (As a Noun) A small circle of metal that you wear on your finger as an ornament or to show that you are engaged or married. It often has a diamond in it. English = ring, diamond ring, engagement ring, wedding ring.

diamond%20ring.description: (As a Noun) A hard, bright, precious stone that consists of pure carbon. It is used especially in jewellery and rings. English = diamond.; (As a Noun) A small circle of metal that you wear on your finger as an ornament or to show that you are engaged or married. It often has a diamond in it. English = ring, diamond ring, engagement ring, wedding ring.

diarrhoea.description: (As a Noun) An illness in which people get rid of lot of faeces that are much more liquid than usual. English = diarrhoea.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To rid waste matter from your body through your anus. Formal English = defecate. Informal English = shit.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have diarrhoea. Idiomatic English = have the runs.

diathermy.description: (As a Noun) DIATHERMY is a type of physical therapy which uses high-frequency electrical current to produce heat and treat tissue.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DIATHERMY. If you know a sign for DIATHERMY used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

dice.description: (As a Noun) A small cube made of wood or plastic, which has from one to six spots on each of its six sides. You throw it in games to decide, for example, who will start the game first or how many moves you can make. English = dice.; (As a Noun) Games of chance in which people use dice and make bets. English = gambling.; (As a Noun) A building or a room where people play gambling games such as roulette. English = casino.

dice%20(chop%20up).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To cut food into small cubes to create uniformly sized pieces, ensuring even cooking. The term usually applies to vegetables.  English = dice.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DICE (but some signers represent this visually using these depicting signs, once they have established the topic).  If you know a sign for DICE used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

dickhead.description: (As a Noun) A fool or an idiot. Informal vulgar English = dickhead.

dictionary.description: (As a Noun) A book in which the words of a language are listed one after the other and their meanings are explained in the same language or in another language. English = dictionary. Technical English = lexicon.

did.description: (As Modifier) As with the English auxiliary 'did', this sign is used to refer back to or substitute for a verb sign or signs in the past tense. It is especially used in this way when the signer wishes to affirm an action which has been denied.; (As Modifier) As with the English auxiliary 'did', this sign is used before a verb sign to emphasise it or to affirm it (especially where the negative has been previously implied). It is reserved for actions in the past.; (As Modifier) As with the English auxiliary 'did', this sign can be used in forming a question about an action in the past.

did%20(did%20not).description: (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb or adjective to mean the action or the quality does not happen or exist at the time specified or understood. English = not, don't, doesn't, didn't.

not.description: (Interactive) Used alone to say that something is not true, to refuse an offer, or to refuse permission. English = 'No!'; (Interactive) Used alone, when directed as someone you are talking to, to tell them to no do or stop doing something. English = "Don't", "Don't do that", "Stop that", and so on.; (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb or adjective to negate it (i.e., that the action does not happen, or that something does not have that quality). English = not, don't, doesn't, didn't.

die%20out.description: (General Definition) Of some thing or process, to no longer be able to be seen or be detected because it has either gone somewhere else or because it has ceased to exist entirely, or any thing or any action that can be associated with this in a given context.; (As a Noun) The act of becoming unable to be seen or experienced by going somewhere else, by changing in some way, or by becoming smaller and smaller or less and less. English = disappearance, vanishing.; (As a Noun) The end of existence of things of a particular type, especially species of animals, after they have become less and less common. English = extinction.

slim.description: (As a Noun) The special kind of food that you eat if you want to lose weight. English = diet.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To eat special kinds of food because you want to lose weight. English = (be) on a diet, diet.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have an attractively thin and well-shaped body, especially narrow waists. English = (be) slim.

difference.description: (As a Noun) The way in which two thing are unlike each other. English = difference.; (As a Noun) The thing that makes one thing different from another. English = distinction.; (As a Noun) The process of finding a derivative in mathematics. English = differentiation.

differential.description: (As a Noun) In a vehicle, a part that allows one wheel to rotate faster than the other wheel when turning corners, for example. English - differential.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DIFFERENTIAL for most signers (but some signers represent this visually using these depicting signs, once they have established the topic). This suggested sign is a visual representation of the turning action of a round component rotating faster around another one. Source of this recommended sign: Victorian College for the Deaf.

differentiate%20(mathematics).description: (As a Noun) The way in which two thing are unlike each other. English = difference.; (As a Noun) The thing that makes one thing different from another. English = distinction.; (As a Noun) The process of finding a derivative in mathematics. English = differentiation.

differentiation%20(mathematics).description: (As a Noun) The way in which two thing are unlike each other. English = difference.; (As a Noun) The thing that makes one thing different from another. English = distinction.; (As a Noun) The process of finding a derivative in mathematics. English = differentiation.

digestion.description: (As a Noun) When food passes through your body to your stomach, DIGESTION is the process of your stomach removing the substances that you need, and your body getting rid of the rest.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DIGESTION. If you know a sign for DIGESTION used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

digging.description: (As a Noun) The act of making a hole in the ground, especially by using a spade. English = digging.; (As a Noun) A tool used for digging, with a flat metal blade and a long handle. English = spade, shovel.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make a hole in the ground, especially by using a spade. English = dig.

digital%20display.description: (As a Noun) A small light or flame that shines unsteadily, with sudden changes in strength and brightness. English = flicker.; (As a Noun) A small light or series of lights which display numerical and other information on a small screen. The numbers change often according to the time or the amount of some thing being measured. English = digital display.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a light or a flame, to shine unsteadily, with sudden changes in strength and brightness. English = flicker.

digital%20watch.description: (General Definition) Something attached to your wrist which glitters or flickers, such as bracelet, bangle or watch, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a digital watch.; (As a Noun) A small clock that you wear on a strap on your wrist that shows the time by displaying numbers rather than by using hands as on a traditional clock face. English = digital watch.

dilation.description: (As a Noun) Of a pupil, the process of becoming wider and bigger. English = dilation.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a pupil, to become wider and bigger. English = dilate.

ignorance.description: (As a Noun) A person who cannot learn what someone is trying to teach them. English = dimwit, dunce.; (As a Noun) The lack of knowledge about something. English = ignorance.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To not know anything about something. English = (be) ignorant.

dim%20witted.description: (As a Noun) The inability to understand or learn things easily or be unable to plans things well. English =  ignorance.; (As a Noun) The inability to use your experience and knowledge in order to make sensible decisions and judgements. English = inexperience, immaturity.; (As a Noun) A person who is unable to understand or learn things easily, or to use their experience and knowledge in order to make sensible decisions and judgements. English = simpleton, ignoramus.

dinner.description: (As a Noun) The main meal of the day, especially when that meal is in the middle of the day. English = dinner.; (As a Noun) A formal social event in the evening at which a meal is served. English = dinner.; (As a Noun) An occasion when people eat. English = meal.

muzzle.description: (As a Noun) That part of the face of many animals, such as dogs, wolves and foxes, that sticks out a long way and contains its nose and mouth. English = muzzle.; (As a Noun) That part of the face of many animals, such as pigs, that sticks out a long way and contains its nose. English = snout.; (Note) For signers in the Northern Territory (especially in the area around Darwin) this signs specifically means "dingo".  A dingo is a native species of dog found in Australia.

dining%20room.description: (As a Noun) The room in a house where people have their meals, or a room in a hotel where meals are served. English = dining room.

dinosaur.description: (As a Noun) A type of large reptile that lived in prehistoric times and which is now extinct. English = dinosaur.

dip.description: (General Definition) The act of scooping up a soft paste-like substance with something held with your hand, or any thing or action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a savoury-dip.; (As a Noun) A thick, creamy mixture which you can eat by scooping it up with raw vegetables or biscuits. English = dip, savoury-dip.

director.description: (As a Noun) Someone who is responsible for organising and leading a group of people who are working together. English = director.; (As a Noun) Someone who is on the board of a company or in charge of a government organisation. English = director.; (As a Noun) Someone who decides how a film, play, or television program is made or performed. English = director.

direct%20contact.description: (As a Noun) In relation to infectious diseases (especially COVID-19), a person who has been face-to-face or very close to a person who has covid for a long period of time so that they are at a very high risk of catching the infection. English = direct contact.

directional.description: (As a Noun) A class of signs in which the direction of the movement of the sign can be reversed or changed from the citation form to show the relationship between two people or things and the action of the verb. English = directional verb.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a sign, to belong to a class of signs in which the direction of the movement of the sign can be reversed or changed from the citation form to show the relationship between two people or things and the action of the verb. English = (be) directional.

directional%20verb.description: (As a Noun) A class of signs in which the direction of the movement of the sign can be reversed or changed from the citation form to show the relationship between two people or things and the action of the verb. English = directional verb.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a sign, to belong to a class of signs in which the direction of the movement of the sign can be reversed or changed from the citation form to show the relationship between two people or things and the action of the verb. English = (be) directional.

straight.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be or go in a path of movement which is all in one direction, without bending, curving or straying. English = (be) straight, go straight.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be or go in a path of movement which is always in one direction and always in front of you. English = (be) straight ahead, go straight ahead.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go from one place to another directly, without stopping, and immediately, without delay. English = go straight, (be) direct.

dirt.description: (As a Noun) Dust or mud on something which is usually kept clean. English = dirt.; (As a Noun) Stains, bodily fluids (such as blood) and other things on something which is usually kept clean. English = grime, filth.; (As a Noun) References to sex in jokes, books, magazines and films that many people find offensive. English = smut, obscenity.

disability.description: (As a Noun) A physical or mental condition which prevents you from living a totally normal life. English = disability.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a physical or mental condition that prevents you from living a totally normal life. English = (be) disabled.

fall back.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) In a competition or race, to be behind your rival(s) and for your position to get worse. English = fall behind, fall back, drop back, be losing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have progressed less quickly at something than had been planned. English = (be) behind.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move in a direction opposite to that intended. English = go backward.

disagreement.description: (As a Noun) An opinion about what is true or correct that is different to the opinion of other people. English = disagreement.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a different opinion to other people about what is true or correct. English = disagree.

disallow.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To not accept or not approve of something. English = disallow.

disappear%20(into%20distance).description: (As a Noun) The process of something becoming unable to be seen and disappearing by moving away into the distance at speed.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To disappear by moving away into the distance at speed. Idomatic English = disappear from sight, vanish from sight.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To leave a place quickly or suddenly. Idiomatic English = dash off, zoom off.

disappointment.description: (As a Noun) The state of feeling disappointed. English = disappointment.; (As a Noun) Something which makes you feel disappointed. English = disappointment.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of people, places or things, to not satisfy you because they are not as good as you had hoped, or they do not do what you want. English = disappoint.

lousiness.description: (As a Noun) The state of being no good. English = lousiness, rottenness.; (As a Noun) The feeling that you do not like someone or something and that you think it or they are wrong. English = disapproval.; (As a Noun) The state of getting worse and worse in condition (especially in illness), or to become more difficult or unpleasant. English = deterioration.

believe (not believe).description: (As a Noun) The thought that something is not true, or false. English = disbelief.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To not think that something is true; to think that something is false. English = not believe, disbelieve.

disk.description: (As a Noun) A circular, flat object used for storing information in computers or for use in computers. English = disc, disk.

discharge.description: (As a Noun) When there is a DISCHARGE of a substance, the substance comes out from inside somewhere.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DISCHARGE. If you know a sign for DISCHARGE used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

discipline.description: (As a Noun) The practice of making people obey rules by lecturing or punishing them when they do not. English = discipline.; (As a Noun) The practice of moral instruction.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To train people to behave or work in a controlled way, especially by punishing them for behaving badly or breaking a rule or lecturing to them seriously about their behaviour. English = discipline.

disconnection.description: (As a Noun) The pulling apart of two things that are joined. English = disconnection.; (As a Noun) The detachment of a piece of equipment from its source of power. English = disconnection.; (As a Noun) The act of setting a person or animal that has been in captivity free. English = release.

confidence (lose confidence).description: (As a Noun) The feeling of losing confidence in yourself. English = discouragement.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To lose your confidence in yourself; to make someone feel that way. English = (be) discouraged; discourage.

discouragement.description: (As a Noun) Something that makes you unwilling to do something because you are afraid of the consequences or because you have lost your enthusiasm. English = discouragement.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To lose your enthusiasm or to become unwilling to do something. English = (be) discouraged.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be sad because something you wanted has not happened or because it is not as good as you hoped it would be. English = (be) disappointed. Idiomatic English = (be) let down.

find.description: (As a Noun) A thing or idea which has been seen, located or understood. Usually something which is good, interesting or useful. English = find.; (As a Noun) The information or the conclusions that someone gets as a result of doing an investigation or some research. English = findings.; (As a Noun) The fact or object that someone sees, locates or knows about for the first time (which no one else knew about before). English = discovery.

found out.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be discovered doing something dishonest or secretly. English = (be) found out, (be) discovered.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To suddenly realise, discover or find out about something.

discrimination.description: (As a Noun) The practice of unfairly treating someone worse or better than other people. Usually used in the negative sense only. English = discrimination.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To unfairly treat someone worse or better than other people. Usually used in the negative sense only. English = discriminate.

discus.description: (As a Noun) A heavy, flat circular object that is thrown as a sport. English = discus.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To throw a discus.

illness.description: (As a Noun) A health problem which makes you unable to work or live normally. English = illness, sickness, disease.; (As a Noun) The experience of being ill for a period of time. English = illness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be suffering from a disease or health problem which makes you unable to work or live normally. English = (be) sick, (be) ill.

dish.description: (General Definition) Any thing which is relatively large and circular or elliptical in shape and with raised sides, such as a dish, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this.; (As a Noun) A shallow container used for cooking or serving food. English = dish.

dislike.description: (As a Noun) The feeling of not liking someone or something. English = dislike.; (As a Noun) The strong feeling of not liking someone or something at all. English = hate, detest.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To not like someone or something and to think that they are unpleasant. English = dislike.

dislocation.description: (As a Noun) A DISLOCATION is an injury where a bone slips out of a joint.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term DISLOCATION. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DISLOCATION (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for DISLOCATION used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

dismemberment.description: (As a Noun) The separating of something into the different parts that it is made of.; (As a Noun) The pulling off or the cutting off of the arms or legs of a person or animal. English = dismemberment.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To separate something in to the different parts that it is made of. English = take apart.

sacking.description: (As a Noun) The act of telling an employee that they can no longer work for you, or being told that you can no longer work for someone else. English = sacking, firing, dismissal.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of an employer, to say to someone (an employee) that they can no longer work for you, often because their work is not good enough. English = sack, fire, dismiss.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of an employee, to be told by your boss (your employer) that you can no longer work for them. English = (be) sacked, get sacked, (be) fired, get fired. Idiomatic English = get the sack, (be) given the sack, get the push.

dismissive.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To pay no real attention to what someone is saying or doing and to attach no importance to it. English = (be) dismissive, ignore, neglect.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To appear to pay attention to someone or to say you agree or approve when in fact you do not just in order to please them or to avoid a confrontation. English = humour someone. Idiomatic English = pay lip service to someone.; (Interactive) Used alone in response to something your conversational partner has said to appear to agree (when really you either don't agree or don't care one way or the other) or to actually mean "Yes... but so what?", "Yes, of course that's true..." and so on.

dismiss%20(sport).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) In sports, to tell a player to leave the playing field because they have broken the rules of the game in some way. English = send off, dismiss.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In sports and games, to have done something which means you can no longer participate. English = (be) out.; (As Modifier) A Signed English sign for the English word 'out' used in all its senses.

disorder.description: (As a Noun) A DISORDER is a problem or illness which affects a person's mind or body.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DISORDER. If you know a sign for DISORDER used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

dispatch.description: (As a Noun) The act of sending something to someone.; (As a Noun) A load of goods that is being sent from one place and delivered to another. English = consignment, dispatch.; (As a Noun) The delivery of something to several people or locations. English = distribution.

spill.description: (General Definition) Of anything, to go from being in one place or being in one piece to then being in many places or in many pieces over a larger area.; (As a Noun) The act of causing a liquid to flow over the edge of a container. English = spill, spillage.; (As a Noun) The spreading of people or objects over a wide area or of ideas and objects amongst a large number of people. English = dispersal, dissemination.

show.description: (As a Noun) A form of entertainment at the theatre or on television that usually consists of several items. English = show.; (As a Noun) An arrangement of things that is intended to attract people's attention. English = display, exhibition.; (As a Noun) A public event that is intended to entertain people. English = display, spectacle, performance.

prohibition.description: (As a Noun) A law or rule forbidding something. English = prohibition.; (As a Noun) The act of stopping someone from taking part in an event, activity, or competition because they have broken a law or rule. English = disqualification.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be unable to do something because you do not have permission to do it; to be not allowed to so something by some authority, especially the law. English = (be) forbidden, (be) prohibited, (be) illegal.

disregard.description: (As a Noun) The act of not paying attention to or ignoring something or someone, especially orders and instructions. English = disregard.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To act as if something or someone you have seen, heard, or experienced did not or does not exist. Used especially in the sense of not following orders or instructions. English = ignore, disregard.

spread.description: (As a Noun) The spreading out of information or ideas or the spreading out of the affects of information and ideas to more and more people. English = spread. Formal English = dissemination.; (As a Verb or Adjective) For something to gradually reach or affect a larger and larger area or more and more people. English = spread.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a number of things, to be located everywhere and far apart. English = (be) spread out.

dissimulate.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To pretend to feel a certain way about something, especially interest or amusement. English = dissimulate, humour someone, feign interest.; (Interactive) Used alone to tease or mock your addressee. You express a kind of mock disdain at them because you do not think they have been as clever, witty or original as they assume, especially if they are getting at you in some way.

dissolving.description: (As a Noun) The disappearance of a solid in a liquid after they have been mixed. English = dissolving.; (As a Noun) The change in colour of an object from strong to pale. English = fading.; (As a Noun) The way of dealing with a difficult situation so that the difficulty is removed; something that makes an illness disappear. English = solution; cure.

far.description: (As a Noun) The amount of space between two places. English = distance.; (As a Noun) The distance between two places, especially when that distance is considerable; a long way.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be located at a great distance away. English = (be) far, (be) far away, (be) distant.

distraction.description: (As a Noun) A lack of attention to what is being said or done. English = inattention.; (As a Noun) Something that takes you attention away from something. English = distraction.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of someone, to be made by something or someone else to stop concentrating on what they are doing. English = (be) distracted

ditch%20(someone).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To end a relationship with someone, especially a casual sexual relationship or a defacto relationship. English = separate. Idiomatic English = break up, split up, dump, ditch, give someone the flick, tell someone it's over, (be) finished with.

diuretic.description: (As a Noun) A DIURETIC is a substance which makes your body increase its production of waste fluids, with the result that you need to urinate more often than usual.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DIURETIC. If you know a sign for DIURETIC used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

diving.description: (As a Noun) The activity in which you go under water, usually in the sea, using special breathing equipment for pleasure or work.; (As a Noun) A person who goes deep sea diving for pleasure or work. English = diver, deep sea diver, scuba diver.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go under water, usually in the sea, using special breathing equipment for pleasure or work. English = dive, go deep sea diving, go scuba diving.

divergence.description: (As a Noun) The moving apart of two edges, sides or surfaces of something; or the separating in some way of two things that were once one. English = divergence.; (As a Verb or Adjective) For two edges, sides or surfaces of something to move further and further apart from a central point. English = diverge.

diverticulitis.description: (As a Noun) DIVERTICULITIS is a colon disease.  It happens when pouches on the colon become inflamed or infected.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DIVERTICULITIS. If you know a sign for DIVERTICULITIS used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

share.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To separate, cut, break, etc, something up into smaller parts so that a little piece or small amount can be given to each of several people. English = share, divide, divide up.

divide%20(mathematics).description: (As a Noun) The act of separating something into two or more different parts; the mathematical process of dividing one number by another. English = division.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To separate something into two or more different parts; in mathematics, to calculate how many times a small number can go into a large number. English = divide.

diving%20board.description: (As a Noun) The act of jumping head first into water. English = dive.; (As a Noun) A person who jumps head first into water as a sport. English = diver.; (As a Noun) A board high above a swimming pool from which people can dive into the water. English = diving board.

division%20(mathematics).description: (As a Noun) The act of separating something into two or more different parts; the mathematical process of dividing one number by another. English = division.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To separate something into two or more different parts; in mathematics, to calculate how many times a small number can go into a large number. English = divide.

divorce.description: (As a Noun) The formal ending of a marriage by law. English = divorce.; (As a Noun) A person, particularly a woman, who is divorced. English = divorcee.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To formally end a marriage by law. English = divorce.

dizziness.description: (As a Noun) A feeling of losing your balance and being about to fall over. English = dizziness, giddiness.; (As a Noun) A confused feeling and a feeling of losing your balance and being about to fall over because you have drunk too much alcohol.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To feel that you are losing your balance and are about to fall over. English = (be) dizzy, (be) giddy.

gene.description: (As a Noun) The part of a cell in a living thing which controls its physical characteristics, growth, and development. English = gene.; (As a Noun) The study of heredity and how qualities and characteristics are passed on from one generation to another by means of genes. English = genetics.; (As a Noun) An abbreviation for `deoxyribonucleic acid'. DNA is found in the chromosomes of the cells of living things. DNA determines the particular structure and functions of every cell and is responsible for characteristics being passed on from parents to their children. English = DNA, deoxyribonucleic acid.

do.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of events and happenings, to take place and unfold over a period of time in a particular place; for events to go on over time. English = do, take place, carry on, continue.

doctor.description: (As a Noun) Someone who is qualified in medicine and treats people who are ill. English = doctor.

document.description: (As a Noun) A sheet of paper or a document that has a lot of writing, printing or information on it. English = document, text, written information.; (As a Noun) Instructions for preparing any type of food. It will have a list of ingredients, and describe the steps to prepare and combine them. English = recipe.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put a large amount of written information onto a document. English = write down, type.

do%20(do%20not).description: (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb or adjective to mean the action or the quality does not happen or exist at the time specified or understood. English = not, don't, doesn't, didn't.

does.description: (As Modifier) As with the English auxiliary 'does', this sign is used to refer back to or substitute for a verb sign or signs involving the third person singular. It is especially used in this way when the signer wishes to affirm an action which has been denied.; (As Modifier) As with the English auxiliary 'does', this sign is used before a verb sign to emphasise it or to affirm it (especially where the negative has been previously implied). Used with the third person singular.; (As Modifier) As with the English auxiliary 'does', this sign can be used in forming a question.

doesn't%20matter.description: (Interactive) A gesture of rejection or dismissal made towards the person or thing that is rejected or dismissed, saying that it is not worth bothering about or is no longer important. English = doesn't matter. Colloquial English interjection = "Phooey!". "Forget it!"; (Interactive) A gesture used to reject an invitation or suggestion, dismissively. English = no way.

doff.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To lift your hat off in greeting, or to show respect, honour or recognition of a person's achievements; to doff one's hat.; (Interactive) Used alone as a means of greeting, or of showing respect and recognition of someone's achievements. English = 'Good on you!'

dog.description: (As a Noun) An animal that is often kept as a pet or used to guard or hunt things. English = dog.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a four leg animal (especially a dog), to sit on your hind legs and raise your forelegs. English = beg, sit on haunches.

doll.description: (As a Noun) A child's toy that looks like a small person or a baby. English = doll. Children's English = dolly.

dolphin.description: (As a Noun) A mammal that lives in the sea and looks like a large fish. English = dolphin.

domino.description: (As a Noun) Small rectangular blocks marked with two groups of spots on one side, used for playing games. English = domino (singular), dominoes (plural).; (As a Noun) A game played using dominoes. English = dominoes.

finish.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To make or do the last part of something so that there is no more for you to do. English = finish, complete.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have made or done the last part of something so that there is no more for you to do. English = (be) finished, (be) complete, (be) done.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cease to be involved or interested in something. Idiomatic English = (be) done with.

done%20(not%20done).description: (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb or adjective to mean the action or the quality does not happen or exist at the time specified or understood. English = not, don't, doesn't, didn't.

donkey.description: (As a Noun) An animal which is like a horse, but smaller and with longer ears. English = donkey.

don't%20(do%20that).description: (Interactive) Used alone to say that something is not true, to refuse an offer, or to refuse permission. English = 'No!'; (Interactive) Used alone, when directed as someone you are talking to, to tell them to no do or stop doing something. English = "Don't", "Don't do that", "Stop that", and so on.; (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb or adjective to negate it (i.e., that the action does not happen, or that something does not have that quality). English = not, don't, doesn't, didn't.

don't%20know.description: (Interactive) Used alone in response to a question to mean that you have absolutely no idea of what the correct answer is. English = 'I don't have a clue.', 'I wouldn't have the foggiest', 'Well?', and so on.; (Interactive) Used alone in response to an accusation that you have done something to mean that either you did not do it or that you did not do it and know nothing about it whatsoever. English = 'It's got nothing to do with me.'; (Note) The manual part of this sign (the hands placed in neutral space with the palms up) is a form of the ‘palms up’ sign found in this dictionary (it can be found by searching for ‘well’ as a keyword). This variant has a negative facial expression as well as shrugged shoulders and is identical to a gesture made with the same meaning as hearing people in Australia and in many other cultures. It is given its own separate entry here.

doona.description: (As a Noun) A cover filled with feathers or some other warm, soft material, which you put over yourself when you are in bed. English = doona, quilt, duvet, eiderdown.

door.description: (As a Noun) A swinging piece of wood, glass, or metal, which is used to open and close the entrance to a building, room, or vehicle. English = door.; (As a Noun) A swinging piece of wood or metal which is used at the entrance to a field, a garden, or the grounds of a building. English = gate.

doorbell.description: (General Definition) A button like object which is located on a surface, such as a wall, which you press with your thumb, such as a call button for a lift etc., or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a doorbell.; (As a Noun) A button like object located next to the front door of houses which rings (or causes lights to flash) when pressed and lets the people inside know you are at the door. English = doorbell.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Verb or Adjective) To press a button like object located at the front door of a house to let the people inside know you are at the door by ringing a bell or flashing lights. English = ring doorbell.

doorbell%20(flashing%20light).description: (General Definition) The repeated pulsing of a source of light or sound energy which is located above the signer's head, such as a light or a speaker; or any thing or any action which is directly or indirectly associated with this.; (As a Noun) An electrical system connected to lights inside a deaf person's home that causes them to flash when the doorbell is pressed. English = flashing-light doorbell.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

door%20(close).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To close the entrance to a building, room, or vehicle by swinging a piece of wood, glass, or metal across the entrance; to close a door. English = close, shut.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To close the opening on any kind of object.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a door, to close or be closed.

doorknob.description: (As a Noun) A round handle on a door. English = doorknob.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To open a door using a doorknob.

door%20knock.description: (As a Noun) The sound of someone hitting a door, window or wall with the knuckles of their closed fist. English = knock, knocking, door knock.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To hit a door, window or a wall several times with the knuckles of your closed fist in order to attract someone's attention. English = knock, rap.

door%20lock.description: (As a Noun) In a vehicle, a device that secures the doors. English = door lock.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DOOR LOCK for most signers (but some signers represent this visually using these depicting signs, once they have established the topic). This suggested sign is a combination of the Auslan sign DOOR and the action of turning a key in a lock. Source of this recommended sign: Victorian College for the Deaf.

door%20lock%20(remote).description: (As a Noun) In a vehicle, a device that secures the doors. English = door lock remote.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DOOR LOCK for most signers (but some signers represent this visually using these depicting signs, once they have established the topic). This suggested sign is a combination of the Auslan sign REMOTE and a depiction of two flat objects moving down or two flat objects clamping back towards the signer. Source of this recommended sign: Victorian College for the Deaf.

door%20(open).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To open the entrance to a building, room, cupboard, or vehicle by swinging a piece of wood, glass, or metal across the entrance; to open a door. English = open.; (As a Verb or Adjective) About businesses, offices, shops, etc., to be in a period when work is happening and there is access to the premises. English = (be) open.

dope%20(marijuana).description: (As a Noun) A type of drug which is smoked in cigarettes and which is illegal in most countries. English = marijuana. Informal English = pot, grass, weed, dope.; (As a Noun) A cigarette made of marijuana. Informal English = joint.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put a marijuana cigarette in your mouth, suck the smoke into your lungs and blow it out again. English = smoke marijuana, smoke a marijuana cigarette. Informal English = smoke dope, smoke pot, smoke a joint.

dormitory.description: (As a Noun) A large bedroom where several people sleep in many different beds, for example in a boarding school. English = dormitory.

dorsal%20fin.description: (As a Noun) A very large fish with sharp teeth. It sometimes attacks people. English = shark.; (As a Noun) A flat object that sticks out the back of some fish. It helps the fish swim and keep its balance. English = dorsal fin.; (As a Verb or Adjective) (Of fish with dorsal fins) to travel through water close to the surface with the dorsal fin sticking out of the water.

dosage.description: (As a Noun) A DOSAGE is the amount of a medicine or drug that someone takes or should take.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DOSAGE. If you know a sign for DOSAGE used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

point (dot).description: (General Definition) Indicate by pointing, or mark with your finger, a small defined thing or location somewhere in space or on a surface, or any thing or any action that can be associated with this in context.; (As a Noun) A mark on a piece of paper or on a display screen (or any surface which can be drawn or written on) which is small, round and completely filled in. English = point, dot, spot.; (As a Noun) A mark in writing that is small, round and completely filled in which marks the end of a sentence. English = full stop, stop, period.

do%20there.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of events and happenings, to take place and unfold over a period of time in a particular place; for events to go on over time. English = do, take place, carry on, continue.

specks.description: (As a Noun) Lots of tiny little marks on a surface. English = specks, speckles.; (As a Noun) Lots of tiny little round marks or shapes on a surface. English = spots, dots.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have lots of little marks or shapes on a surface. English = (be) speckled.

double.description: (As a Noun) Two things that are the same size and shape and are intended to be used together. English = pair.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of something, to become twice as large as it was before. English = double.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of something, to be twice its normal size. English = (be) double.

double%20adaptor.description: (As a Noun) A plug-in connector by which two electrical appliances may be operated simultaneously from a single power-point. English = double adaptor.

double-breasted%20suit.description: (As a Noun) A suit in which the jacket or coat has two very wide sections at the front which overlap when you button them up. English = double-breasted jacket, double-breasted suit.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wear or put on a double-breasted suit or jacket.

doubles.description: (As a Noun) A game of tennis, badminton, or any other game, when two people play against two other people. English = doubles, pairs.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make the amount or size of something twice as large. English = double.

doubles%20(tennis).description: (As a Noun) In a game of tennis or badminton, a competition in which two people play against two other people. English = doubles.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To play doubles.

double%20talk.description: (As a Noun) Talk or gossip which is inaccurate, vague or ambiguous, in order to brag or to smear someone. English = doublespeak, double-talk. Informal English = bullshit, bull.; (As a Noun) Talk or gossip which is obscure, vague, euphemistic, ambiguous or evasive so as to avoid saying the truth directly, e.g., like a politician. It is sometimes done to deliberately deceive. English = doublespeak, double-talk.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To talk or gossip in a way which is inaccurate, vague or ambiguous, in order to brag or to smear someone. English = use doublespeak, use double-talk. Informal English = bullshit.

doubt.description: (As a Noun) The feeling of uncertainty you have about something, especially wondering if it is true or false, good or bad, or possible or impossible. English = doubt, uncertainty.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To feel some uncertainty about something, especially to wonder if it is true or false, good or bad, or possible or impossible. English = doubt; (be) doubtful, (be) unsure, (be) uncertain.; (Interactive) Used alone in response to a question to show your uncertainty and your desire to know more about the situation before you can give an answer. English = 'Not sure', 'It depends' and so on.

down.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To go down, to go downwards.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In a building, to go down to or be located at a lower floor. English = downwards.

rain.description: (As a Noun) Water that falls from the clouds in small drops. English = rain.; (As a Noun) [With stress] a fast and heavy rain. English = downpour.; (As a Verb or Adjective) For water to fall from the clouds in small drops. English = rain.

downward.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To move from a higher position to a lower position. English = go downwards, go lower.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move something from a high position to a low position. English = lower.

dozen.description: (As a Noun) A quantity in which many things are sold, such as eggs, which consists of twelve items or units. English = dozen.; (As a Noun) The number 12, between 11 and 13. English = twelve.

draft%20(conscript).description: (As a Noun) An order to come towards you, to approach you, or to come inside. draft%20(draw).description: (As a Noun) The preparation of technical drawings. English = drafting, draughting.; (As a Noun) A person who prepares technical drawings. English = draftsman, draughtsman.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To prepare technical drawings; prepare a draft. English = draft, draught.

drafting%20(draw).description: (As a Noun) The preparation of technical drawings. English = drafting, draughting.; (As a Noun) A person who prepares technical drawings. English = draftsman, draughtsman.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To prepare technical drawings; prepare a draft. English = draft, draught.

drag%20artist%20(female%20impersonator).description: (As a Noun) The act of a man, especially an entertainer, wearing women's clothes. English = drag.; (As a Noun) A man, particularly an entertainer, who wears women's clothes. drag%20(female%20impersonation).description: (As a Noun) The act of a man, especially an entertainer, wearing women's clothes. English = drag, drag artist.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a man, especially an entertainer, to put on or be wearing women's clothes. English = (be) in drag.

dragon.description: (As a Noun) An animal found in stories and legends that is like a big lizard. It has wings and claws, and breathes out fire. English = dragon

drain.description: (As a Noun) A metal grid in a road, through which rainwater can flow away into pipes. English = drain.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of water, to flow over and through a metal grid away to somewhere else (usually through pipes). English = drain, drain away.

theatre.description: (As a Noun) A building with a stage on which plays and other entertainments are performed. English = theatre.; (As a Noun) The activity of acting in, producing, and writing plays. English = theatre.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To belong to or relate to the theatre. English = (be) theatrical.

draught%20(draw).description: (As a Noun) The preparation of technical drawings. English = drafting, draughting.; (As a Noun) A person who prepares technical drawings. English = draftsman, draughtsman.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To prepare technical drawings; prepare a draft. English = draft, draught.

draughting%20(draw).description: (As a Noun) The preparation of technical drawings. English = drafting, draughting.; (As a Noun) A person who prepares technical drawings. English = draftsman, draughtsman.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To prepare technical drawings; prepare a draft. English = draft, draught.

drawing.description: (As a Noun) A picture which someone has made with a pencil, pen or crayon. English = drawing.; (As a Noun) A drawing that is done quickly without a lot of details. English = sketch.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make a picture, pattern, or diagram using a pencil, pen or crayon. English = draw.

draw%20circle.description: (As a Noun) A long thin object which you use to write in ink. English = pen.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To draw a circle.

drawer.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To close a drawer.

drawing%20pins.description: (As a Noun) A written announcement which is put in a place, usually a wall or vertical surface, where it can be read by everyone. English = notice.; (As a Noun) Short nails with broad, fat tops, which you use for attaching papers to a wall or vertical surface. English = drawing pins, thumb tacks.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put up a written announcement, usually on a wall or vertical surface, where it can be read by everyone.

draw%20line.description: (As a Noun) A line which has been drawn on a vertical surface or a board.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To draw a line, especially on a vertical surface or a board.

draw%20(lottery).description: (As a Noun) The act of extracting, pulling or taking out one thing (ticket, ball, stick, etc) from many such things in a container as part of a competition. The thing chosen tells you who has won. English = draw.; (As a Noun) An organised process in which people vote to choose a person or group of people to hold an official position or to represent them in government. English = election.; (As a Noun) The actual success and selection of a person in an election. English = election.

draw%20out.description: (General Definition) Something being extracted and concentrated, or anything or any action that can be associated with this in context, such as a fuel pump.; (As a Noun) [Especially the two handed variant] the device in a vehicle that moves petrol from the petrol tank to the engine. English = fuel pump.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To take a substance out of another substance so that there is more of it than the other substance; or to take a weak sources of energy (light, heat, sound, etc.) and bring them together into a smaller space so that it is stronger and more intense. English = draw out, extract, concentrate.

draw%20(tie).description: (As a Noun) The condition of two things being exactly alike in all respects. English = draw, tie; deuce (in tennis).; (As a Noun) The result when two competitors in a race both cross the finishing line at exactly the same time. English = dead heat.

dream.description: (As a Noun) An imaginary series of events that you experience in your mind while you are asleep. English = dream.; (As a Noun) A situation or event which you often think about because you would very much like it to happen. English = dream, day-dream.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To see imaginary pictures or events in your mind while you are asleep. English = dream.

dress.description: (As a Noun) A piece of clothing worn by a woman or a girl. It covers her body and extends down over her legs. English = dress.

dress%20(bandage).description: (As a Noun) A long strip of cloth which is wrapped around a wounded part of someone's body to protect it. English = bandage.; (As a Noun) A covering which is put on a wound to protect it while it heals. English = dressing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To tie a long strip of cloth around a wounded part of someone's body to protect it. English = bandage.

dressing%20gown.description: (As a Noun) A loose-fitting coat which you wear over pyjamas or a nightdress when you are not in bed. English = dressing gown.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put on or wear a dressing gown.
