dress%20(skirt).description: (As a Noun) A piece of clothing worn by women and girls which fastens at the waist and hangs down to above or below the knees. English = skirt.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wear a skirt.

dress%20up.description: (As a Noun) The things that people wear, such as shirts, coats, trousers, and dresses. English = clothes, clothing. saliva.description: (As a Noun) The watery liquid that forms in your mouth and helps you to chew and digest food. English = saliva.; (As a Noun) A small stream of saliva that trickles down from your mouth often involuntarily or unconsciously, as happens to a baby. English = dribble.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To produce a lot of saliva in your mouth, often as a result of seeing or smelling food. English = salivate.

dribble%20(ball).description: (As a Noun) A game in which two teams of five players each try to score goals by throwing a large ball through a circular net fixed to a metal ring at each end of the court. English = basketball.; (As a Noun) A game in which two teams of seven players, usually women, each try to score goals by throwing a large ball through a net which is at the top of a pole at each end of the court. English = netball.; (As a Noun) The act of hitting down repeatedly on a ball. English = bounce.

dryer.description: (As a Noun) An electric machine that dries washing quickly. You put the wet clothes inside it and it turns them over slowly while blowing hot air onto them. English = drier, dryer, tumble drier, tumble dryer.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To dry clothes in a tumble drier.

drill.description: (As a Noun) A tool or machine that you use for making holes. English = drill.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make a hole in something using a drill. English = drill.

drink%20tea.description: (As a Noun) A drink made with hot water and the chopped, dried leaves of a particular bush. Milk and sugar are often added to the drink. English = tea.; (As a Noun) A cup of tea, or a cup of any other drinks made with hot water and leaves or flowers.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To drink tea.

drops.description: (As a Noun) Small ball shaped quantities of a liquid. English = drops.; (As a Noun) A crack or a small hole in a container through which a liquid is passing. English = leak.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a liquid, to fall in small drops. English = drip.

dripolator.description: (General Definition) The act of liquid dripping into a container, such as a tap dripping into a bucket, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a coffee dripolator.; (As a Noun) A coffee-making machine in which boiling water is allowed to pass down slowly through ground coffee beans. English = dripolator.

drive.description: (As a Noun) The wheel in a car or truck which the driver holds when he or she is steering the vehicle. English = steering wheel.; (As a Noun) The act of operating and controlling a vehicle so that it goes where you want it to go. English = driving.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To control a car to make it go in the direction you want by turning the steering wheel. English = steer.

drive%20belt.description: (As a Noun) In a vehicle, a flat rubber ring that is used to turn other parts of an engine. English = drive belt.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DRIVE BELT for most signers (but some signers represent this visually using these depicting signs, once they have established the topic). This suggested sign is a combination of the Auslan sign CAR and depiction of a flat object that is circular. Source of this recommended sign: Victorian College for the Deaf.

drive%20in.description: (As a Noun) A cinema where people can stay in their cars while they watch the movie. English = drive in cinema, drive in.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To park your car in a drive in cinema in preparation for watching a film.

drivers.description: (General Definition) Some thing or many things that push something forward or any thing or action associated with this in context.; (As a Noun) The things which cause a particular phenomenon to happen or develop. English = drivers, factors, reasons.

driver's%20licence.description: (As a Noun) An official document which gives you permission to do, use, or own something. English = licence, permit.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Noun) A official document which gives you permission to drive a car. English = driver's licence.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have an official document which gives you permission to do, use, or own something. English = (be) licensed.

drizzle.description: (As a Noun) A light rain that falls in very small drops. English = drizzle.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To rain lightly in very small drops. English = drizzle.

drop.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To let something fall deliberately or by mistake. English = drop.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In a sports team, to get rid of a player because they are not needed or because they are not good enough. English = drop.

drop%20out.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To stop doing something, especially being a member or participant in some organisation or activity. English = quit, withdraw, resign. Idiomatic English = drop out, pull out.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To not become involved in something. English = stay aloof, keep aloof, remain aloof.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To like to be alone and not talk much to other people. English = (be) aloof.

drowning.description: (As a Noun) Death caused by going under water where you cannot breathe. English = drowning.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go under water and die because you cannot breathe. English = drown.

drug.description: (As a Noun) A chemical which is given to people in order to treat or prevent an illness or disease. English = drug.; (As a Noun) Substances that some people smoke or inject into their blood because of their stimulating effects. In most countries, these uses are illegal. English = drugs.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To give a chemical substance to a person or animal. English = drug.

drug%20addict.description: (As a Noun) A small tube with a plunger and a fine hollow needle or pointed end. It is used for putting liquids into something and taking them out, for example drugs into a person's body or for taking blood samples from them. English = syringe, hypodermic needle.; (As a Noun) The act of using a syringe to put liquids into a person's body. English = injection. Informal English = jab.; (As a Noun) The act of injecting someone with a weak form of a disease as a way of protecting them from it. English = immunisation, inoculation, vaccination.

drum.description: (As a Noun) A musical instrument consisting of a skin stretched tightly over a round frame. You play it by beating it rhythmically with sticks. English = drum.; (As a Noun) A person who plays a drum or drums in a band or group. English = drummer.; (As a Noun) The sticks you hold on to when you beat a drum. English = drumstick.

xylophone.description: (General Definition) To hit something rhythmically with something else, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, such as a row of drums, and especially a xylophone.; (As a Noun) A musical instrument made of a row of wooden bars of different lengths that you hit with a special hammer. English = xylophone.

drunkard.description: (As a Noun) Someone who often gets drunk. English = drunkard.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have drunk enough to make you behave a little different from normally, usually friendlier or sillier than usual. English = (be) tipsy, (be) merry.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have drunk so much alcohol that you cannot speak or sign clearly or behave sensibly. English = (be) drunk. Formal English = (be) inebriated. Informal English = (be) sloshed, (be) pissed.

dryness.description: (As a Noun) The lack of water or moisture. English = dryness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have no liquid or water on something or in something. English = (be) dry.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To become completely dry, to dry out.

dry%20clean.description: (General Definition) The action of holding onto something in front of you and moving it up and down repeatedly, such as dunking clothes in water and rubbing them against a washboard or operating a hand held pump, or any thing or any action which can be easily associated with this when given enough context.; (As a Noun) A board or frame with corrugated metallic or other surface, on which clothes are scrubbed in the process of washing. English = washboard.; (As a Noun) A room in a house or hotel where clothes, sheets, and towels are washed; or a business that does this for people. English = laundry.

dry%20cleaner.description: (General Definition) The action of holding onto something in front of you and moving it up and down repeatedly, such as dunking clothes in water and rubbing them against a washboard or operating a hand held pump, or any thing or any action which can be easily associated with this when given enough context.; (As a Noun) A board or frame with corrugated metallic or other surface, on which clothes are scrubbed in the process of washing. English = washboard.; (As a Noun) A room in a house or hotel where clothes, sheets, and towels are washed; or a business that does this for people. English = laundry.

drying%20up.description: (As a Noun) The act of rubbing the surface of something lightly in order to remove dirt or liquid from it. English = wiping.; (As a Noun) The drying of plates, knives, forks, and other things with a cloth when they have been washed after a meal. English = wiping up, drying up.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To rub the surface of something lightly in order to remove dirt or liquid from it. English = wipe.

dry%20out.description: (As a Noun) The lack of water or moisture. English = dryness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have no liquid or water on something or in something. English = (be) dry.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To become completely dry, to dry out.

dry%20up.description: (As a Noun) The lack of water or moisture. English = dryness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have no liquid or water on something or in something. English = (be) dry.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To become completely dry, to dry out.

dublin.description: (As a Noun) The capital city of the Irish Republic, called Dublin.

duckling.description: (As a Noun) A baby duck. English = duckling.

duck%20(lower%20head).description: (As a Noun) The movement of your head quickly downwards to avoid being seen or hit by something.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move your head quickly downwards to avoid being seen or hit by something. English = duck, duck your head.

owe.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To tell someone to give you something, especially money, that they owe you; to call on a debt.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a some of money which has been lent to someone else, to have the right to have it paid back to you. English = (be) due, (be) owed.

dues.description: (As a Noun) A sum of money you pay regularly to an organisation you belong to. English = dues, membership, subscription.; (As a Noun) A person who belongs to an organisation, especially one in which they are required to pay dues. English = member.; (As a Noun) A person who pays for a magazine or newspaper to be regularly sent to them or for a service (gas, electricity, telephone, pay television, etc.) to be provided to them. English = subscriber.

dullness.description: (As a Noun) The condition of colours or lights being not bright. English = dullness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a colour or light, to be not bright. English = (be) dull.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a colour or light, to become less bright. English = dull.

gibberish.description: (As a Noun) For deaf or hearing impaired people, the speech of a hearing person which is impossible to follow through listening or lip reading.; (As a Noun) Language (speech or signed) that does not make any sense. English = gibberish.; (As a Noun) A concept or proposition that is not clear.

dumb%20(mute).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to be silent and not speak. English = (be) mute.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to be silent and not speak because you are unable to, especially because you are deaf. English = (be) mute, (be) dumb.

dummy.description: (General Definition) Something small that is held or placed at the mouth, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a baby's dummy.; (As a Noun) A rubber or plastic object that you give to a baby to suck so that it feels comforted and stays quiet. English = dummy, (rubber) teat, pacifier.

dump.description: (As a Noun) A place where rubbish is left. English = dump, rubbish dump, tip.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put unwanted waste matter somewhere with the intention of leaving it there for ever. English = dump.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To carelessly and quickly put or throw something (usually something unwanted) somewhere. English = throw away, dump.

dump%20(someone).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To end a relationship with someone, especially a casual sexual relationship or a defacto relationship. English = separate. Idiomatic English = break up, split up, dump, ditch, give someone the flick, tell someone it's over, (be) finished with.

dunce.description: (As a Noun) A slow or lazy student who cannot learn what someone is trying to teach them and is punished by being made to sit in the corner of the classroom or by wearing a silly hat. English = dunce.; (As a Noun) A tall paper cone, formerly put on the head of a slow or lazy student. English = dunce's cap.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be a dunce or to be punished as a dunce.

dye.description: (General Definition) The action of holding onto something delicately and lowering it repeatedly into something, or any thing or any action that can be associated with this in context.; (As a Noun) A substance which is mixed into a liquid and is used to change the colour of something such as clothing or hair. English = dye.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To change the colour of something, such as your hair or a piece of cloth, by soaking or putting it into a coloured liquid. English = dye.

don't know.description: (Interactive) Used alone in response to a question to mean that you have absolutely no idea of what the correct answer is. English = 'I don't have a clue.', 'I wouldn't have the foggiest', 'Well?', and so on.; (Interactive) Used alone in response to an accusation that you have done something to mean that either you did not do it or that you did not do it and know nothing about it whatsoever. English = 'It's got nothing to do with me.'; (Note) The manual part of this sign (the hands placed in neutral space with the palms up) is a form of the ‘palms up’ sign found in this dictionary (it can be found by searching for ‘well’ as a keyword). This variant has a negative facial expression as well as shrugged shoulders and is identical to a gesture made with the same meaning as hearing people in Australia and in many other cultures. It is given its own separate entry here.

duodenum.description: (As a Noun) The DUODENUM is the first part of the small intestine, which is part of the digestive system.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DUODENUM. If you know a sign for DUODENUM used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

length.description: (As a Noun) The distance something measures from one end to the other. English = length.; (As a Noun) The amount of time that it takes for something to happen. English = duration.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To measure a large distance from one end of an object to another. English = (be) long.

when.description: (As Modifier) Used to introduce an expression of time that specifies the time at which something happens. English = when, while, during.; (As Question) Used to ask questions about the time at which things happen. Found at the beginning, end or at both the beginning and end of the question. English = when.

dust%20mask.description: (As a Noun) A DUST MASK is a flexible pad held over the nose and mouth by elastic or rubber straps to protect against dust for example, in construction or cleaning activities.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term DUST MASK. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for DUST MASK (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for DUST MASK used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

netherlands.description: (As a Noun) A country in north western Europe, east of Germany and north of Belgium. English = the Netherlands, Holland.; (As a Verb or Adjective) A person or thing from or relating to the Netherlands. English = Dutch.

responsibility.description: (As a Noun) The obligation that a person has to deal with something or make decisions relating to something and not ignore it or give the work to someone else. English = responsibility, duty.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be obliged to deal with something and make decisions about it. English = (be) responsible.

e.description: (As a Noun) The letter E in the one-handed manual alphabets.; (Note) Apologies for the poor quality of this video. It will be replaced as soon as possible.

each.description: (As a Noun) An individual who is part of a group, but considered separately, and who is equal to all the others in some way, such as receiving something, undergoing something or being located relative to others in a similar way. English = each thing, each person.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be or to refer to every single member of a group, but considered individually and not as a whole. English = (be) each.; (As Modifier) Used immediately after plain verbs to mean the action is spread across to, or located equally at, a number of recipients, objects or places.

each%20other.description: (As Modifier) Used to say that each member of a group does something to the others or has a particular connection with the others. English = each other.

keenness.description: (As a Noun) A strong desire and interest in doing something. English = keenness, eagerness, enthusiasm.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be enthusiastic and interested in what you are doing or will do, or to want to do something very much. English = (be) keen, (be) eager.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have interest in something. English = (be) interested in.

parrot.description: (As a Noun) A bird with a curved beak.; (As a Noun) A tropical bird with a curved beak and often brightly-colored feathers. It can be kept as a pet and sometimes copies what people say. English = parrot.; (As a Noun) A large bird with a curved beak that lives by eating small animals and other birds. English = eagle.

ear.description: (As a Noun) The two parts of your body, one on each side of your head, with which most people hear sounds. English = ear, ears.; (As a Noun) The soft part at the bottom  of your ears. English = ear lobe.

earache.description: (As a Noun) An ache in the ear. English = earache.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have an ache in the ear.

eardrum.description: (As a Noun) The EARDRUM is a thin membrane between the external ear and the middle ear.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for EARDRUM. If you know a sign for EARDRUM used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

ear%20lobe.description: (As a Noun) The two parts of your body, one on each side of your head, with which most people hear sounds. English = ear, ears.; (As a Noun) The soft part at the bottom  of your ears. English = ear lobe.

early.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be near the beginning of a period of time, a process, or a piece of work. English = (be) early.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To happen or arrive before the time that was arranged or expected. The sign is placed after signs that specify how many units of time the action is 'in advance' (eg, 10 seconds, 3 minutes, 5 hours, 1 day, 2 weeks, etc.).; (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb to mean the action of the verb happens near the beginning of a period of time, a process, or a piece of work. English = early.

early%20childhood%20intervention.description: (As a Noun) The practice of intervening with special support, education and rehabilitation in the lives of children from a very early age to lessen the impact of any disadvantage or disability that they may otherwise experience as they grow older. English = early childhood intervention.

salary.description: (As a Noun) The money that you are paid for your job, usually each month, especially when you have a professional job and the money paid is considerable. English = salary, (good) salary.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be paid money for your work, usually each month, especially when you have a professional job and the money paid is considerable. English = receive a salary, earn a good income.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To earn lots of money. Idiomatic English = earn money hand over fist.

income.description: (As a Noun) The money that you earn or that you get from other sources such as investments or pensions. English = income, earnings, interest.; (As a Noun) The money that is regularly paid to you for working, especially for manual or unskilled work. English = wage, pay.; (As a Noun) The money that you are paid each month for your job, especially when you have a professional job. English = salary.

earring.description: (As a Noun) A piece of jewellery which you attach to your earlobe. English = earring.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wear an earring.

ears%20(animal).description: (General Definition) Of an animal with upright or large ears, like a dog, to have them flap in the wind or retract downwards because the animal is frightened or on guard.; (As a Noun) The feeling of being ashamed or stupid. English = humiliation.; (As a Noun) The ears of some animals.

soil.description: (As a Noun) The substance on the land surface of the earth in which plants grow. English = soil, earth, dirt.

earthquake.description: (As a Noun) A shaking of the ground caused by movement of the earth's crust. English = earthquake.; (As a Noun) A small earthquake. English = tremor.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of the ground, to shake because of movement of the earth's crust.

ease.description: (As a Noun) The lack of any difficulty. English = ease.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be able to be done without effort or difficulty. English = (be) easy, simple.; (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb to mean that the action of the verb is done without effort or without difficulty. English = easily, simply.

ease%20up.description: (As a Noun) Reduction in speed or rate. English = deceleration.; (As a Noun) In mathematics and physics, the rate at which the speed of an object is decreasing. English = deceleration.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To take your foot off the accelerator in order to make a vehicle go slower. English = slow down, decelerate. Idiomatic English = ease up, take one's foot off the brake.

east.description: (As a Noun) The direction which you look towards in order to see the sun rise. English = east.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be located in or associated with the east. English = (be) eastern, (be) easterly.; (As Modifier) Used next to a verb to mean the direction of movement is towards the east. English = eastwards.

easter.description: (As a Noun) A religious festival in March or April when Christians celebrate the death and resurrection of Christ. English = Easter.

simplicity.description: (As a Noun) The fact that something is not complicated but is easily understood or easily done. English = simplicity.; (As a Noun) A person who has very low intelligence. English = simpleton.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be not complicated; to be easy to understand or to do. English = (be) simple, (be) easy.

easy-peasy.description: (Interactive) Used alone to mean that some action or task is very easy to do and you don't mind doing it. Informal English = 'easy-peasy', 'no worries', 'no problems'.

eat%20(round).description: (General Definition) The action of holding and eating something small, round and flat, such as small pie or tart, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a biscuit or a cookie.; (As a Noun) A small sweet cake that is crisp and usually sweet. English = biscuit, cookie, tart.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To eat a biscuit, cookie or tart.

ecg%20(electrocardiogram).description: (As a Noun) ECG is an abbreviation for electrocardiogram. If someone has an ECG, doctors use special equipment to measure the electric currents produced by that person's heart in order to see whether it is working normally.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ECG. If you know a sign for ECG used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report a missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

echidna.description: (As a Noun) An animal with a long spiny coat, a long snout, and claws. It lays eggs in burrows on the ground, and eats ants and insects. It lives in Australia and New Zealand. English = echidna.

eczema.description: (As a Noun) ECZEMA is a skin condition which makes your skin itch and become sore and broken.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ECZEMA. If you know a sign for ECZEMA used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

edit.description: (General Definition) The action of bringing two strip-like objects together, or any action or any thing directly or indirectly associated with this, such as joining streamers and, particularly, splicing film together in order to edit it.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To choose some material that has been filmed or recorded and arrange it in a particular order. English = edit.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To join two pieces of film or tape together neatly at the ends so that they make one long continuous piece. English = splice.

labour.description: (As a Noun) An action or job that requires an unusual amount of physical or mental energy to do it. English = effort.; (As a Noun) Physical or mental work which is difficult and very hard, even painful. English = labour, toil, exertion. Formal English = travail.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To work hard or a lot, to make an effort.

egg.description: (As a Noun) The rounded object produced by a female bird from which a baby bird emerges. English = egg.; (As a Noun) A hen's egg which is considered as food and farmed for that very purpose. English = egg.

egg-beater.description: (As a Noun) A kitchen tool with rotating blades used for beating eggs or whipping cream. English = egg-beater.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To stir cream or eggs very fast until they are thick and frothy or stiff, especially using an egg-beater. English = whip.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use an egg-beater. English = whip, beat.

selfishness.description: (As a Noun) The quality of only caring about yourself, and not about other people. English = selfishness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To care only about yourself, and not about other people. English = (be) selfish.

egypt.description: (As a Noun) A country in North Africa, on the shores of the Mediterranean, between Israel and Libya. English = Egypt.

egypt%20(ancient%20egypt).description: (As a Noun) The country in North Africa, along the valley of the river Nile, when it was ruled by Pharaohs and the pyramids were build, thousands of years ago; Ancient Egypt.

eight.description: (As a Noun) The number 8, between 7 and 9. English = eight.

eighteen.description: (As a Noun) The number 18, between 17 and 18. English = eighteen.

eighth.description: (As Modifier) Of a sequence of numbers or things, the one which is between seven (seventh) and nine (nineth) in that sequence. English = eighth.

either.description: (As a Noun) Each of two things. English = either one.; (As Modifier) Used in front of the first of two alternatives, when you are stating the only possibilities or choices that there are. English = either, whether.

either%20way.description: (Interactive) Used in response to a suggestion to do something in two different ways or a question about which of two ways of doing something to mean one is just as good as the other. English = either way.; (As Modifier) Used to modify a verb, especially a verb of movement, to say it could go in one of two possible directions or ways. English = either way, left or right, this way or that way.

ejaculation.description: (As a Noun) Of a man, the act of discharging semen through the penis. English = ejaculation.; (As a Noun) For a man, the moment of greatest pleasure and excitement during sexual activity. English = orgasm.; (As a Noun) The liquid containing sperm that is produced by the sex organs of men and male animals. English = semen.

elan.description: (As a Noun) Elan is the name of a computer program used for analysis and annotation of video and/or audio recordings. It is used by many sign language researchers.

elastic.description: (As a Noun) A rubber material that stretches when you pull it and returns to its original size and shape when you let it go. English = elastic.; (As a Noun) A thin circle of rubber that you put around things in order to hold them together. English = rubber band, elastic band.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be able to be stretched easily and then return to its original shape; to be made of elastic. English = (be) elastic.

elastic%20band.description: (As a Noun) A rubber material that stretches when you pull it and returns to its original size and shape when you let it go. English = elastic.; (As a Noun) A thin circle of rubber that you put around things in order to hold them together. English = rubber band, elastic band.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be able to be stretched easily and then return to its original shape; to be made of elastic. English = (be) elastic.

elbow.description: (As a Noun) The part in the middle of your arm where your arm bends. English = elbow.

eldest.description: (As a Noun) In a family, the child who was born before all the others; the eldest child.

vote.description: (As a Noun) The choice you make at an election, or at a meeting where decisions are made. English = vote; (As a Noun) An organised process in which people vote to choose a person or group of people to hold an official position or to represent them in government. English  = election.; (As a Noun) A vote in which all the people in a country or region are asked whether they agree or disagree with a particular policy. English = referendum.

electric.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of various devices and machines, to depend on electricity as a source of power. English = (be) electric, (be) electrical.

electrical%20wire.description: (As a Noun) A flexible cable, often made of copper and covered with plastic insulation which carries an electrical current. English = electrical wire.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ELECTRICAL WIRE for most signers (but some signers represent this visually using these depicting signs, once they have established the topic). This suggested sign is a combination of the Auslan sign ELECTRICITY and a depiction of a thin cable made of twisted threads. Source of this recommended sign: Victorian College for the Deaf

electrical%20wiring.description: (As a Noun) In a vehicle, the system of wires that carries electricity around between different parts, including the battery, engine and electrical accessories. English = electrical wiring.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ELECTRICAL WIRING for most signers (but some signers represent this visually using these depicting signs, once they have established the topic). Source of this recommended sign: Victorian College for the Deaf.; (Note) A combination of the Auslan signs ELECTRICITY and SPREAD, or ELECTRICITY and a depiction of long thin things (wires) moving outwards.

spanner.description: (As a Noun) A metal tool with a specially shaped end that fits around a nut so that you can loose or tighten the nut. English = spanner, wrench.; (As a Noun) Someone whose job is to repair and maintain machines and engines. English = mechanic.; (As a Noun) A person whose job is to connect and repair things, such as water and drainage pipes, baths, and toilets. English = plumber.

electricity.description: (As a Noun) A form of energy which is transmitted through wires that is used for heating and lighting, and to provide power for machines in houses and factories. English = electricity, power.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of various devices and machines, to depend on electricity as a source of power. English = (be) electric, (be) electrical.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a device, to have transistors, silicon chips, or valves which control and change the electric current passing through it. English = (be) electronic.

electric%20shock.description: (As a Noun) A sudden painful feeling that you get when you touch something which is connected to a supply of electricity. English = shock, electric shock.

elephant.description: (As a Noun) A very large animal with a long trunk. They are found in Africa and India. English = elephant.; (As a Noun) The very long nose of an elephant that it uses to lift food and water. English = trunk.

eleven.description: (As a Noun) The number 11, between 10 and 12. English = eleven.

eliminate.description: (As a Noun) The complete removal of something, especially when it is something that you do not want or need. English = elimination, eradication.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To remove something completely, especially when it is something that you do not want or need. English = eliminate, eradicate.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To remove an item from a surface, especially something written on a page, a name from a list, or information on a computer disk. English = erase, strike off, wipe off, delete.

get rid of.description: (As a Noun) The act of not accepting or not agreeing to a proposal or a request. English = rejection.; (As a Noun) Pieces of unwanted food which are thrown away or given to animals. English = scraps.; (As a Noun) A statement or condition that says someone does not have to obey, follow or perform a rule or duty. English = exemption.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

thin.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person or an animal, to have very little fat on its body. English = (be) thin, (be) skinny, (be) lean.; (As a Verb or Adjective) [With cheeks sucked in], to be very thin. English = (be) gaunt.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of anything, to have a small distance between its two opposite surfaces. English = (be) thin, (be) narrow.

sms.description: (As a Noun) Text messages you send or receive via a mobile phone device or via email. English = text, sms, email.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To send or receive text messages via a smart phone or via email. English = text, sms, email.

embarrassment.description: (As a Noun) The feeling of becoming shy or guilty about something. English = embarrassment.; (As a Noun) The uncomfortable feeling you have when you know that you have done something wrong or embarrassing, or when you know that someone close to you has. English = shame.; (As a Noun) The act of becoming redder in the face than usual because you are ashamed or embarrassed. English = blush.

exaggeration.description: (As a Noun) The act of making the thing that you are talking about seem bigger, better, or worse than it actually is, usually by adding extra details, or a story which is like that. English = exaggeration.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make the thing that you are talking about seem bigger, better, or worse than it actually is, usually by adding extra details. English = exaggerate.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make a story or account more interesting by adding details which are possibly untrue. English = embellish.

emergency.description: (As a Noun) Something that happens unexpectedly or without warning and is dangerous and must be dealt with immediately. English = emergency.; (As a Verb or Adjective) For something bad or serious to happen suddenly in a way which is dangerous and must be dealt with immediately; to be an emergency.

emergency%20procedure.description: (As a Noun) An EMERGENCY PROCEDURE is a plan of action that has to be followed when there is an emergency, for example: getting everyone out of a building when there is a fire.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term EMERGENCY PROCEDURE. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for EMERGENCY PROCEDURE (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for EMERGENCY PROCEDURE used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

emit.description: (General Definition) Any concentrated source of energy (light, heat, sound, etc.) which gives out rays or waves in all directions, like a pattern of lines drawn from the centre of a circle to various point on its edge, or any thing or any action that can be associated with this in a given context.; (As a Noun) A source of sound energy. English = speaker.; (As a Noun) A source of light energy. English = light.

emotion.description: (As a Noun) Anyone of a number of feelings that characterize a persons state of mind, such as joy, fear, anger, love, sorry, hate, horror, and so on. English = emotion.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to be showing one’s feelings openly, esp. when upset. English = emotional.

empathy.description: (As a Noun) The ability to share another person’s feelings as if they were your own. Formal English = empathy.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To share another person’s feelings as if they were your own. Formal English = empathize, empathise.

work.description: (As a Noun) An activity you do for which you are paid. English = work, job, employment, occupation.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Noun) Something that you need to do that requires some effort. English = work, task.; (As a Noun) The useful thing that something or someone does or is intended to do. English = function.

empower.description: (As a Noun) The giving of knowledge, skills or authority to someone to do something. English = empowerment.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To give someone the means to achieve something, for example to become stronger or more successful. English = empower.

empty.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To remove the contents from a container; of a container, to have nothing in it. English = empty; (be) empty.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of an amount of something, especially money, to become less and less until there is none left. English = exhaust, use up, dispose of.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To completely remove the information and data on a computer disk. English = erase, reformat, initialise a computer disk.

emu.description: (As a Noun) A large Australian bird with long legs that can run fast but cannot fly. English = emu.

enclosure.description: (As a Noun) An area of land that is surrounded by a wall or fence. English = enclosure.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To completely surround something with a wall-like structure. English = enclose, encircle.

surround.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be situated all around something. English = surround, encircle.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have people or things situated all around you. English = (be) surrounded, (be) encircled.

encounter.description: (As a Noun) The accidental meeting of someone.; (As a Verb or Adjective) For one person or thing to go to and meet another unexpectedly. Formal English = encounter. Idiomatic English = run into, bump into.

encourage.description: (As a Noun) The act of telling or the things you say when you tell someone that what they are doing is good and they should continue to do it. English = encouragement.; (As a Noun) The rounding up of sheep and cattle and bringing them together in one spot. English = (cattle) mustering, (sheep) shepherding.; (As a Noun) A person who looks after or rounds up sheep. English = shepherd.

encouragement.description: (As a Noun) The act of telling someone that you think that they should do something, or that they should continue doing something and by so doing making them think positively and making it more likely that they will continue. English = encouragement.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To tell someone that you think that they should do something, or that they should continue doing something and by so doing making them think positively and making it more likely that they will continue. English = encourage.

end%20directional.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a sign, to belong to a class of signs in which the location of the end point of the sign can be reversed or changed to show the relationship between two people or things and the action of the verb. English = (be) end directional.

endorphins.description: (As a Noun) When you exercise, ENDORPHINS are produced by the pituitary gland in the brain.  Endorphins can make you feel happy and well.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ENDORPHINS. If you know a sign for ENDORPHINS used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

endoscopy.description: (As a Noun) An ENDOSCOPY is a procedure using a long thin tube with a camera at the end, that can be inserted into a patient’s body.  This allows a doctor to look inside the body without doing surgery.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ENDOSCOPY. If you know a sign for ENDOSCOPY used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

endurance.description: (As a Noun) The ability to experience an unpleasant or painful situation for a period of time calmly and patiently. English = endurance.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To bear a painful or difficult situation calmly and patiently. English = endure.

fight.description: (As a Noun) A situation in which two or more people try to hurt each other physically. English = fight.; (As a Noun) A situation in which you try in a determined way to get or achieve something. English = fight.; (As a Noun) A situation in which you try in a determined way to prevent or stop something.

diamond ring.description: (As a Noun) A small circle of metal that you wear on your finger as an ornament or to show that you are engaged or married. It often has a diamond in it. English = diamond ring, engagement ring, wedding ring.; (As a Noun) An agreement that two people have made with each other to get married. English = engagement.; (As a Noun) The man to whom a woman is engaged to be married; the woman to whom a man is engaged to be married. English = fiancee; fiance.

engaged%20(busy).description: (General Definition) Something going up close to or hitting a large flat object, such as a wall or obstacle, or any action or any object that can be directly or indirectly associated with this in context.; (As a Noun) A physical object that a person or vehicle is unable to go over, go around or pass through; or a non-physical thing (such as a law, rule or policy) that stops someone doing something. English = barrier, obstacle.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Noun) Something that prevents two people or groups of people from agreeing, communicating, or working with each other. English = barrier, obstacle.

engagement%20ring.description: (As a Noun) A hard, bright, precious stone that consists of pure carbon. It is used especially in jewellery and rings. English = diamond.; (As a Noun) A small circle of metal that you wear on your finger as an ornament or to show that you are engaged or married. It often has a diamond in it. English = ring, diamond ring, engagement ring, wedding ring.

engine.description: (As a Noun) The part of a car or other vehicle that produces the power which makes the vehicle move. English = engine.

gears.description: (As a Noun) A device or system which controls the rate at which energy is converted into motion. It usually consists of moving wheels and levers which fit together. English = gears.; (As a Noun) A piece of equipment which uses electricity or power from an engine, especially one that has gears. English = machine.; (As a Noun) Part of a machine that uses electricity or fuel to produce movement, so that the machine can work. English = motor, engine.

engine%20mounting.description: (As a Noun) The small rubber and metal parts of a vehicle that attach the engine to the steel frame of the vehicle and reduce excessive engine vibration. English = engine mounting.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ENGINE MOUNTING for most signers (but some signers represent this visually using these depicting signs, once they have established the topic). This sign is a combination of the Auslan sign ENGINE followed by both hands depicting a hold action with a slight upwards motion. Source of this recommended sign: Victorian College for the Deaf.

england.description: (As a Noun) An island country in north western Europe between Ireland and the Continent. On the same island Scotland is to the north and Wales is to the west. English = England.; (As a Noun) The language used originally in England and now used in many countries around the world, including Australia and the United States. English = English.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be from or relate to England. English = (be) English.

enjoyment.description: (As a Noun) The feeling of pleasure that you have when you do or experience something you like. English = enjoyment.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have the feeling of pleasure that you have when you do or experience something you like. English = enjoy; (be) enjoyable.; (Interactive) Used alone as a polite way of replying to someone who has just thanked you for doing something. English = 'It's a pleasure', 'My pleasure!', 'Your welcome!'

enlargement.description: (As a Noun) Something, especially an image, which is a much larger copy or view of an original which is much smaller. English = enlargement.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make something, which was originally very small, much larger. English = enlarge.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Using a microscope, to make the image of something, which was originally very small, much larger so that it can be seen. English = magnify.

enlightenment.description: (As a Noun) The act of enlightening or the state of being enlightened. English = enlightenment.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To acquire more knowledge about something; to become better informed. Formal English = (be) enlightened.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make someone more aware and informed. English = enlighten.

join (enlist).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To become a member of an organisation, especially the army. English = join, enlist.

full (sated).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To have consumed enough food or drink. English = (be) full, (be) full up, (be) sated.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be as much as you need or want of something. English = (be) enough, (be) sufficient; suffice.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be bored or annoyed. English = (be) fed up.

enough%20(not%20enough).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be not as much as you need or want of something. English = (be) not enough, (be) insufficient.

enquiry.description: (As a Noun) The process of asking about something in order to find out information about it. English = enquiry, inquiry.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To ask about something in order to find out information about it. English = enquire, inquire.; (Augmented Meaning) To ask lots of questions over a period of time.

rage.description: (As a Noun) A strong, often sudden, anger that is difficult to control. English = rage, fury.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make you very very angry. English = enrage.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very very angry. English = (be) enraged, (be) furious.

fury.description: (As a Noun) The very strong emotion that you feel when you think that someone has behaved in an unfair, cruel, or insulting way; extreme anger. English = fury, rage.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To suddenly become extremely angry. Idiomatic English = blow one's top, blow up, hit the roof, fly off the handle.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be extremely angry. English = furious. Formal English = incensed, enraged.

slave.description: (As a Noun) A person who is the property of another person and has to work for that person. English = slave.; (As a Noun) A system by which people are owned by other people for whom they have to work. English = slavery.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make someone a slave. English = enslave.

enthusiastic.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very enthusiastic about and interested in something. Idiomatic English = crazy about.

enthusiastic%20about.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very enthusiastic about and interested in something. Idiomatic English = crazy about.

entice.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To tempt someone away from a place or an activity to come over to where you are and/or to do what you are doing or do something else. English = entice.

title.description: (As a Noun) The name of a book, play, film or piece of music. English = title.; (As a Noun) The thing, person, or idea that is being discussed or written about. English = topic, subject, theme.; (As a Noun) A word or phrase that is usually used in a particular situation or by particular people, and that you are quoting, explaining, or commenting on. English = expression.

prayer.description: (As a Noun) The activity of communicating to God, or a set of words which is used during a religious service; thanks to God made before a meal. English = prayer; grace.; (As a Noun) A religious ceremony in a church; a ceremony in some Christian churches during which people eat bread and drink wine in order to remember the last meal of Jesus Christ. English = service, church service; mass.; (As a Noun) An intense and emotional request for something, often made repeatedly. English = plea, entreaty.

envelope.description: (As a Noun) A rectangular paper cover in which you send a letter or card to someone through the post. English = envelope.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To seal, close or fold down an envelope.

jealousy.description: (As a Noun) The feeling of resentment and bitterness you have when you think someone is trying to take away something that belongs to you. English = jealousy.; (As a Noun) The feeling you have when you wish that you could have the qualities or possessions that someone else has. English = jealousy, envy.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To feel that you must try to keep something that you have, because you think someone else might take it away from you. English = (be) jealous.

environment.description: (As a Noun) Everything which affects a person in their daily life, for example the place where they live, the people around them, and the things that they experience. English = environment.; (As a Noun) The natural world of land, sea, air, plants, and animals that exists outside of towns and cities. English = environment.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be concerned with or to relate to either the surroundings in which a person or animal lives, or the natural world as a whole. English = environmental.

envy.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To wish you had things or qualities that other people have. English = envy someone, (be) envious of someone.; (Interactive) Used alone in response to being told by someone that they have done something or got possession of something that you wish you did or had. English = 'Lucky you!', 'What luck!', 'Can you believe it?', 'How did that happen?', 'How lucky is that?'; (Interactive) Used alone to show strong agreement with what your addressee has just said or done. English = 'That's it!', 'You are so right!', 'Spot on!' and so on.

enzyme.description: (As a Noun) An ENZYME is a chemical substance in the body which produces changes in other substances without being changed itself.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ENZYME. The signer in the video is explaining the meaning of this word using simple signs and fingerspelling. If you know a sign for ENZYME used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "missing sign feedback" and supply details. Thank you.

epidural.description: (As a Noun) An EPIDURAL is a type of anaesthetic which is injected into a person's spine so that they cannot feel anything from the waist downwards. EPIDURALS are sometimes given to women when they are giving birth.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for EPIDURAL. If you know a sign for EPIDURAL used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

epipen.description: (As a Noun) An EPIPEN is a small device used for injecting medication into someone's body when they are having a serious allergic reaction.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term EPIPEN. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for EPIPEN (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for EPIPEN used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.; (Note) Suggested sign #1×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

episodic.description: (As Modifier) Something that is EPISODIC occurs at irregular and infrequent intervals.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for EPISODIC. If you know a sign for EPISODIC used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

fairness.description: (As a Noun) The quality of being reasonable and just. English = fairness.; (As a Noun) The same status, rights, and opportunities for all the members of a society or group. English = equality.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Noun) The quality of being fair and equal in the treatment of people, as individuals or as groups. English = equity.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

equalize.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of two amounts of something, to make them both the same or equal. English = equalize, equalise.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To give everyone the same rights or opportunities in a particular area, for example society, education, health, etc. English = equalize, equalise.

equal%20(mathematics).description: (As a Noun) In mathematics, the symbol (=) used to indicate that two numbers, sets of numbers or mathematical expressions have the same value.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In mathematics, for two numbers, sets of numbers, or mathematical expressions to be the same in value, e.g., 1 + 1 = 2 ("one plus one equals two"). English = (be) equal, equal.

equal%20(symbol).description: (As a Noun) In mathematics, the symbol (=) used to indicate that two numbers, sets of numbers or mathematical expressions have the same value.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In mathematics, for two numbers, sets of numbers, or mathematical expressions to be the same in value, e.g., 1 + 1 = 2 ("one plus one equals two"). English = (be) equal, equal.

equation.description: (As a Noun) In mathematics, a statement saying that two amounts or values are the same, for example "6 x 4 = 12 x 2". English = equation.

equipment.description: (As a Noun) All the things that are needed for a particular activity. English = equipment.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To provide all the things that are needed for a particular activity. English = equip.

rubber (eraser).description: (As a Noun) A piece of rubber which is used for rubbing out writing. English = rubber. American English = eraser.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use a piece of rubber to get rid of writing or drawing. English = erase, rub out.

erect%20(build).description: (As a Noun) A structure which has a roof and walls, for example a house or a factory. English = building.; (As a Noun) A person whose job is to build houses and other buildings. English = builder.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make a structure which has a roof and walls, such as a house or a factory. English = build, construct, erect.

ergonomics.description: (As a Noun) EGONOMICS is the study and design of things so that they are comfortable, safe and easy to use. For example, an office desk, with seating, computer and keyboard set up in the right way.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term ERGONOMICS. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ERGONOMICS (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for ERGONOMICS used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

err.description: (Interactive) Used alone when you are hesitating because you can't think of the sign you want to use. It can also be used to stop the person you are talking to from interrupting you or finishing your sentence for you.

mistake.description: (As a Noun) An action or an opinion that is wrong. English = mistake, error.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be not correct or not suitable. English = (be) wrong.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be bad or immoral. English = (be) wrong.

escalator.description: (General Definition) To stand on the rungs of tiered object as it moves diagonally upwards, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially an escalator.; (As a Noun) A moving stair case on which people can go up or down. English = escalator.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move up an escalator.

telepathy.description: (As a Noun) An uncanny, almost unnatural or magical, ability to communicate with another person and understand them well, even without the help of words or signs.; (As a Noun) Direct communication between people's minds. English = telepathy, extrasensory perception (ESP).; (As a Verb or Adjective) To share the same interests and attitudes as someone else and to understand each other very well. Idiomatic English = (be) on the same wavelength.

perfection.description: (As a Noun) The quality of being the best of its kind, of being perfect. English = perfection.; (As a Noun) A physician highly trained in one particular area of medicine. English = specialist.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be as good as possible. English = (be) perfect.

et cetera.description: (As Modifier) Used at the end of a sentence to indicate that there are other items which you could mention if you had enough time, space or inclination. English = etc. (et cetera), and so on, and other different kinds of things.

et%20cetera.description: (As Modifier) Used at the end of a sentence to indicate that there are other items which you could mention if you had enough time, space or inclination. English = etc. (et cetera), and so on, and other different kinds of things.

eternity.description: (As a Noun) Time without an end, or a state of existence that is outside time, especially the state which some people believe they will pass into after they have died. English = eternity.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be something that continues for a very long time or without ever ending. English = (be) eternal, (be) everlasting.; (As Modifier) Used immediately after a verb to mean that the action continues for a very long time or without ever ending. English = for ever, for ever and ever, eternally.

ethnic.description: (As a Noun) A person whose country of origin, background, or culture is not Anglo-Australian, especially someone from southern Europe bordering the Mediterranean Sea.; (As a Noun) A person who moves from one country to another to live and work, particularly a person who moves to Australia. English = migrant, immigrant.; (As a Noun) A country in southern Europe, called Italy.

europe.description: (As a Noun) The continent which is the western part of the Eurasian landmass, called Europe.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To come from or relate to Europe. English = (be) European.

evacuate.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To EVACUATE means to move quickly out of a place because it is dangerous.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term EVACUATE. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for EVACUATE (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for EVACUATE used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

evaluate.description: (As a Noun) A decision about how significant, valuable, or effective something is, based on a  careful study of its good and bad features. English = evaluation.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To carefully study the good and bad features of something in order to decide how significant, valuable, or effective it is. English = evaluate; (Note) The variant sign was borrowed into the Australasian Signed English system from ASL in the 1980s. It uses the letter E in the one-handed fingerspelling alphabet. It has been accepted and used as an Auslan sign by some deaf people, especially in education by teachers of the deaf, their students, and interpreters.

evening.description: (As a Noun) The time of the day when it gets dark, between the end of the afternoon and the time when you go to bed. English = evening.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To become dark, to become night.; (Note) You can use two signs to say ‘Good evening': fist sign ‘good’, then sign ‘evening'.

ever%20(for%20ever).description: (As a Noun) Time without an end, or a state of existence that is outside time, especially the state which some people believe they will pass into after they have died. English = eternity.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be something that continues for a very long time or without ever ending. English = (be) eternal, (be) everlasting.; (As Modifier) Used immediately after a verb to mean that the action continues for a very long time or without ever ending. English = for ever, for ever and ever, eternally.

ever%20(not%20ever).description: (As Modifier) Used before (and after) a verb (action) sign to mean that the action has not happened at any time in the past or will not happen at any time in the future. English = never, not ever.; (As Modifier) Used before (and after) a verb (action) sign to mean that the action did not happen. English = never, did not.

everything.description: (As a Noun) All the objects, actions, activities, or facts in a particular situation. English = everything.; (As a Noun) All the people in a particular situation. English = everyone, everybody.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be or involve all of the objects, actions, activities, or facts in a particular situation. English = (be) all, (be) whole, (be) everything.

everyone.description: (As a Noun) Of a group or number of people, each and every single one of them. English = everyone.

evidence.description: (As a Noun) Any thing that you see, experience, read, or are told which causes you to believe that something is true or has really happened. English = evidence.; (As a Noun) A fact or a piece of evidence that shows that something is true or exists. English = proof.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To show that something is definitely true. English = prove.

devil.description: (As a Noun) In Christianity, the most powerful evil spirit. English = devil, Satan; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very bad and enjoy doing things that harm other people. English = (be) evil.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of children, to be eager to have fun or be naughty, especially be embarrassing people or by playing tricks. English = (be) mischievous.

exactitude.description: (As a Noun) The quality of being very accurate, correct in every detail, or careful. English = exactitude, precision, exactness.; (As a Noun) Behaviour which is morally good, religious, and praiseworthy. English = righteousness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be correct or accurate, rather than approximate; to be correct and complete in every detail. English = (be) exact, (be) precise.

exaltation.description: (As a Noun) The act of praising something or someone very highly. Formal religious English = exaltation.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To praise someone very highly. Formal religious English = exalt.

examine.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a good look at something in order to get more information about it. English = examine.; (Interactive) Used alone in response to your addressee's insistence that something is true or will happen to mean you do not agree but don't want to argue the point any further. English = 'We'll see.', 'That remains to be seen.', 'Let's wait and see' etc.; (As Modifier) Used to introduce a suggestion or idea. English = 'Let's see. How about...'.

example.description: (As a Noun) One thing of a particular kind, which is mentioned or pointed out in order to show the characteristics of that kind of thing. Its abbreviation in English is 'eg'. English = example.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning of a sentence to mean that what follows is mentioned or pointed out in order to show the characteristics of the kind of thing you have been talking about. Its abbreviation in English is 'eg'. English = for example.

excellence.description: (As a Noun) The quality of being very good indeed. English = excellence.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very good indeed-more so than all the rest you can compare it to. English = (be) excellent, (be) best of all.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To do very well at something, especially things requiring skill and intelligence. English = excel.

exception.description: (As a Noun) The thing, person, or situation that is not included in a general statement. English = exception.; (As Modifier) Used within a sentence or at the end of a sentence next to the thing or person that the main part of the sentence does not apply to. English = except.

outstanding.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very good, especially when compared to any one or anything else of its type. English = (be) outstanding, (be) exceptional.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be of very good quality and of a high social status. English = (be) high-class, (be) first class.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to be particularly attractive and desirable. English = (be) sexy.

excitement.description: (As a Noun) The state of being so happy that you are full of energy and cannot relax, usually because you are looking forward to something and cannot stop thinking about it or are already enjoying it so much. English = excitement.; (As a Noun) The desire to experience, learn or know more about something. English = interest.; (As a Noun) The desire to want to do something very much. English = keenness.

only.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be no others of its kind involved or relevant. English = (be) only.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Used immediately next to a verb to mean that the action is small and unimportant. English = just, merely.; (As Modifier) To be no others of its kind involved or relevant. English = (be) only.

excuse.description: (As a Noun) A reason which you give in order to explain why something has been done, has not been done, or will not be done. English = excuse.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To let someone free of a duty or responsibility. English = excuse.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To explain why you have done something wrong in an attempt to make yourself seem less bad. English = excuse yourself, make excuses.

excuse%20me.description: (As a Noun) A reason which you give in order to explain why something has been done, has not been done, or will not be done. English = excuse.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To let someone free of a duty or responsibility. English = excuse.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To explain why you have done something wrong in an attempt to make yourself seem less bad. English = excuse yourself, make excuses.

exercise%20(education).description: (As a Noun) In education or training, a task set in the course to practise or test a skill. English = exercise.

exercise%20(physical).description: (As a Noun) Energetic movements which you do in order to become fit or remain healthy. English = exercise.; (As a Noun) Simple exercises that you do to keep fit and healthy. English = callisthenics.; (As a Noun) A form of exercise which increases the amount of oxygen in your blood, and which strengthens your heart and lungs. English = aerobics.

exhaust pipe.description: (As a Noun) A pipe which carries the gas out of an engine and out of a car. English = exhaust, exhaust pipe.

exhaust%20clearance.description: (As a Noun) In a vehicle, the space around the exhaust pipe of the motor. English = exhaust clearance.; (Note) A depiction of a cylindrical object such as a pipe or exhaust of a car which moves in an S-shape towards the signer, and the Auslan sign HAVE-NONE circling the fixed object. Source of this recommended sign: Victorian College for the Deaf

exhaustion.description: (As a Noun) The damage that is caused to something during normal or prolonged use. English = wear and tear; (As a Noun) The state of being so tired that you have no energy left. English = exhaustion.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To become thinner or weaker because something is constantly being used over a long period of time. English = wear out.

exhaust%20leakage.description: (As a Noun) The release of gases from a vehicle due to a hole or crack in the exhaust system. English = exhaust leakage.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English keywords EXHAUST LEAKAGE.  There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for EXHAUST LEAKAGE for most signers (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for EXHAUST LEAKAGE used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

exhaust%20mounting.description: (As a Noun) The rubber and metal parts of a vehicle that attach the exhaust system to the frame of the vehicle. If you know a sign for EXHAUST MOUNTING used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.; (Note) Source of this recommended sign: Victorian College for the Deaf

exhaust%20pipe.description: (As a Noun) A pipe which carries the gas out of an engine and out of a car. English = exhaust, exhaust pipe.

exhaust%20(use%20up).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To remove the contents from a container; of a container, to have nothing in it. English = exhaust, use up, dispose of.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To completely remove the information and data on a computer disk. English = erase, reformat, initialise a computer disk.

English = expectation.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To want something to be true or to happen and to believe that it is possible. English = hope.

expert.description: (As a Noun) A person who is very skilled at doing something; a person who has studied a particular subject and knows a lot about it.
