go%20across.description: (As a Noun) The path between one place and another over or across something like a road, river, or some kind of obstacle.; (As a Noun) A place where pedestrians can cross a street and where motorists must stop to let them cross. English = pedestrian crossing, crossing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move from one side of an area or place (such as a road, room, or an area of land) to the other side. English = go across, cross.

go%20ahead.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To start to do something after either hesitating or waiting for permission to do so, or even contrary to the wishes of others. English = go ahead, proceed.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To suggest someone do something or to challenge someone to do something to show how brave or reckless they are. English = dare.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be prepared to do something that may be difficult, dangerous, or the product of a challenge or dare. English = (be) willing. Idiomatic English (be) up for it.

goal.description: (As a Noun) In soccer and similar ball games, the space into which the players try to get the ball in order to score a point for their team. It is inside a frame or between two posts. English = goal, goal posts.; (As a Noun) In soccer, an instance in which a player succeeds in getting the ball into the goal, and the point they score by doing this. English = goal.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To score a point by succeeding in getting the ball into the goal in a game of soccer or any similar game.

goal%20(afl).description: (As a Noun) The space into which the players try to get the ball in order to score a point for their team in Australian rules football. English = goal.; (As a Noun) A point scored by getting the ball to go between the two centre posts in the scoring space in Australian rules football. English = goal.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To score a goal in Australian rules football.

goal%20(basketball).description: (As a Noun) In basketball or netball, a point which a team scores by throwing the ball so that it passes through a narrow hoop. English = goal.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In basketball or netball, to score a goal.

goal%20(objective).description: (As a Noun) Something you plan or hope to achieve. English = aim, goal, objective, ambition.; (As a Noun) Something which you decide and plan to do. English = intention.; (As a Noun) The very strong desire to achieve or do something in your life. English = ambition.

goal%20posts.description: (As a Noun) In soccer and similar ball games, the space into which the players try to get the ball in order to score a point for their team. It is inside a frame or between two posts. English = goal, goal posts.; (As a Noun) In soccer, an instance in which a player succeeds in getting the ball into the goal, and the point they score by doing this. English = goal.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To score a point by succeeding in getting the ball into the goal in a game of soccer or any similar game.

goal%20umpire.description: (As a Noun) In Australian rules football, the person who signals if a goal or a behind has been scored. English = goal umpire.; (As a Noun) In soccer, the person who signals if the ball has gone out of the field and out of play. English = linesman.

goat.description: (As a Noun) An animal with horns and a short tail. They are found in mountain areas or are kept on farms. The male has a kind of beard. English = goat.

go%20back%20(return).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To go back to somewhere after having been away or gone somewhere else. English = go back, return.

go%20backward.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) In a competition or race, to be behind your rival(s) and for your position to get worse. English = fall behind, fall back, drop back, be losing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have progressed less quickly at something than had been planned. English = (be) behind.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move in a direction opposite to that intended. English = go backward.

go%20backwards.description: (As a Noun) The side or part of something that is towards the rear or farthest from the front. It is normally not used or seen as much as the front. English = back.; (As a Noun) Thinking of the future as a time which is in front of you, used to point to that period of time which is before the present and thus ‘behind’ you. English = past.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move in a direction which is the opposite direction to the one in which you normally face or in which you normally go when walking or driving. English = go backwards, back up, reverse.

go%20blank%20(forget).description: (As a Noun) [Especially when made with two hands] a chronic or persistent brain disease that causes memory loss, personality changes, and difficulty in reasoning (thinking). English = dementia.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To completely forget to do something that you should have remembered.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be unable to remember things you have learnt (such as your part in a play, or information for an exam) or to be unable to think of anything to say. English = go blank.

god.description: (As a Noun) The name given to the spirit or being who is worshipped as the creator and ruler of the world, especially by Christians, Jews, and Muslims. English = God.

go%20down.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To go down, to go downwards.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In a building, to go down to or be located at a lower floor. English = go downstairs, (be) downstairs.; (As Modifier) Used immediately after a verb of motion to mean that the direction of the movement was towards the ground or from high to low. English = downwards.

go%20flat%20(battery).description: (General Definition) A quantity of something, or the top of something which is, and/or becomes, lower, shorter or smaller relative to the reference point of the other hand, or any thing or any object that can be associated with this in context.; (As a Noun) A lowering in the number, level, or amount of something. English = reduction, decrease, depletion.; (As a Noun) A decrease in the value of something over time. English = depreciation.

go%20forth.description: (General Definition) The movement of some thing, usually upright and longer than it is wide, such as a person, away from the signer or starting point, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a one way trip.; (As a Noun) A movement (especially of a person or an upright entity) forward from its starting point.; (As a Noun) A journey or a trip out of or away from where you are now.

go%20forward.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To move in the direction that is in front of you. English = go forward, advance.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To change for the better over a period of time. English = advance, develop.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a signed sentence or next to a verb (action) sign to mean from a given time forward into the future. English = from this time on, henceforth.

go%20great.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of situations and events, for things to go or turn out very well.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of two people, to meet and get on very well.; (Interactive) Used alone (with a questioning facial expression) to ask someone how they are or how things have been going. English = 'How are things going?', 'How have you been?', and so on.

go%20home.description: (As a Noun) The place where you live and feel that you belong. English = home, place.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go home to one's own place.

go%20in.description: (As a Noun) The side of a place, building, object or container where you are surrounded by it. You often get there by passing through an opening designed for this purpose. English = inside.; (As a Noun) An opening in an object or building which allows you to go from outside to inside and vice versa. English = entrance, entry.; (As a Noun) The things which are located inside an object. English = insides, contents.

go%20(in%20vehicle).description: (General Definition) A flat handshape held in this orientation while it is moved forward or backward often describes the path a vehicle (such as a car or a truck) takes as it travels. This means the actual movement in the sign can be almost anything depending on the context and what you want to say, e.g., sideways for ‘skidding’, or diagonally away and upwards for ‘going up a hill’, and so on. Signs like these are called ‘depicting’ signs in the grammar of Auslan.; (As a Noun) The path taken by a vehicle.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To travel somewhere or go somewhere in a vehicle.

gold.description: (As a Noun) A valuable yellow-coloured metal that is used for making jewellery, and as an international currency. English = gold.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be made of gold. English = (be) gold.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To look bright yellow in colour and look rather like gold. English = (be) golden.

golf.description: (As a Noun) A game in which you use long sticks called clubs to hit a small, hard ball into holes that are spread out over a large area of grassy land. English = golf.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To play golf.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To strike a golf ball with a club.

gonorrhoea.description: (As a Noun) Gonorrhoea is a sexually transmitted disease.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for GONORRHOEA. If you know a sign for GONORRHOEA used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

go well.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of situations and events, for things to go or turn out very well.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of two people, to meet and get on very well.; (Interactive) Used alone (with a questioning facial expression) to ask someone how they are or how things have been going. English = 'How are things going?', 'How have you been?', and so on.

good%20afternoon.description: (As a Noun) The part of each day that begins at lunchtime and ends at about six o'clock. English = afternoon.; (Note) You can use two signs to say ‘Good afternoon’: fist sign ‘good’, then sign ‘afternoon’.

good%20evening.description: (As a Noun) The time of the day when it gets dark, between the end of the afternoon and the time when you go to bed. English = evening.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To become dark, to become night.; (Note) You can use two signs to say ‘Good evening': fist sign ‘good’, then sign ‘evening'.

good%20(good%20on%20you!).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To wish you had things or qualities that other people have. English = envy someone, (be) envious of someone.; (Interactive) Used alone in response to being told by someone that they have done something or got possession of something that you wish you did or had. English = 'Lucky you!', 'What luck!', 'Can you believe it?', 'How did that happen?', 'How lucky is that?'; (Interactive) Used alone to show strong agreement with what your addressee has just said or done. English = 'That's it!', 'You are so right!', 'Spot on!' and so on.

handsome.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To have handsome features, especially when talking about a male. English = (be) handsome, (be) good-looking.

good%20luck.description: (As a Noun) Success that does not come from your own abilities or efforts. English = luck.; (As a Noun) An opportunity to do something which will be good for you. English = chance.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have something that is very desirable; to be in a very desirable situation; to have something good happen to you that is not the result of your own efforts or happens by chance. English = (be) lucky, (be) fortunate.

good%20morning.description: (As a Noun) The part of each day between the time that people usually wake up and noon or lunchtime. English = morning.; (Interactive) Used alone to greet someone just after they have woken up or when you see them for the first time in the day if it is before noon or lunchtime. English = 'Good morning!', 'Morning!'; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning (or end) of a sentence to locate the action of that sentence in time; namely, in that part of each day between the time that people usually wake up and noon or lunchtime. English = in the morning.

goodness.description: (As a Noun) The quality of being desirable, acceptable or right, or behaviour which is gentle and kind. English = goodness, virtue.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be desirable, acceptable, or right or behave in such a way. English = (be) good, (be) virtuous.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say something is desirable, acceptable or right. English = to approve of.

good%20night.description: (Interactive) Used alone to say goodbye to people in the evening or at night. English = 'Good night.'

good%20(no%20good).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be no good, or to be unsatisfactory.; (Interactive) Used alone to mean that you think something is not good at all and is unacceptable as it is. English = 'That's no good!', 'That's not good enough!'

good%20(not%20good).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be no good, or to be unsatisfactory.; (Interactive) Used alone to mean that you think something is not good at all and is unacceptable as it is. English = 'That's no good!', 'That's not good enough!'

good%20riddance.description: (Interactive) Used alone to express your frustration, irritation or anger with someone or something. You want them out of your life and to no longer bother or worry you. English = 'I'm glad its all over', 'Good riddance to that!'; (Interactive) Used alone to mean you want someone or something to stay away from you because you do not like them. Usually used talking about it (3rd person) rather than to it (2nd person) English = 'Get lost!', 'Rack off!', 'Piss off!' and so on.

go%20off.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be of very bad quality and not to be liked at all; to be worth nothing at all. English = (be) lousy, (be) rotten; (be) worthless.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To severely harm, damage or spoil something; to damage something so that it no longer works. English = ruin.; (As a Verb or Adjective) (When talking of food, wood or the bodies of animals) to become no good because they are getting old, dying, or are dead and are being attacked by micro-organisms or insects. English = rot, decay, go off.

google.description: (As a Noun) An internet search engine and internet company, called Google.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To search for something on the internet. English = google.

go%20on%20(continue).description: (As a Noun) The quality of remaining the same for a long time or forever. English = permanence, permanency.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To do something over a period of time and to not stop doing it. English = continue. Idiomatic English = go on.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To happen over a period of time without any break. English = (be) continuous.

go%20on%20(exclamation).description: (Interactive) Used alone to express amused surprise or disbelief at what someone has said or done. English = 'Go on!', 'Really?!', 'Come off it!', 'Get a load of that!', How could you do that!?'; (Interactive) Used alone to express jocular dismissal and mock irritation at what someone has said or done, especially when they think it is funny but you consider it to be typical of them. English = 'Typical!', 'There you go again!', 'Hah, hah! Very funny!'

goose%20bumps.description: (As a Noun) The condition of your skin when you are cold or scared. The hairs on your skin stand up so that it is covered with tiny bumps. English = goose pimples, goose bumps. British English = goose flesh.; (As a Noun) A sudden feeling of great excitement and pleasure. English = thrill. Literary English = frisson.; (As a Noun) A sudden feeling of fear. English = horrors, scare, terror. Idiomatic English = shivers down one's spine, cold shivers, cold sweat. Informal English = the creeps, the heebie-jeebies.

goose%20flesh.description: (As a Noun) The condition of your skin when you are cold or scared. The hairs on your skin stand up so that it is covered with tiny bumps. English = goose pimples, goose bumps. British English = goose flesh.; (As a Noun) A sudden feeling of great excitement and pleasure. English = thrill. Literary English = frisson.; (As a Noun) A sudden feeling of fear. English = horrors, scare, terror. Idiomatic English = shivers down one's spine, cold shivers, cold sweat. Informal English = the creeps, the heebie-jeebies.

goose%20pimples.description: (As a Noun) The condition of your skin when you are cold or scared. The hairs on your skin stand up so that it is covered with tiny bumps. English = goose pimples, goose bumps. British English = goose flesh.; (As a Noun) A sudden feeling of great excitement and pleasure. English = thrill. Literary English = frisson.; (As a Noun) A sudden feeling of fear. English = horrors, scare, terror. Idiomatic English = shivers down one's spine, cold shivers, cold sweat. Informal English = the creeps, the heebie-jeebies.

go%20out.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To go out of a place, to leave a place.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go out of a place; to leave a place in order to go home.

gorilla.description: (As a Noun) An animal that looks like a very large monkey with a black face and black fur. It lives in African forests. English = gorilla.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To beat your chest like a gorilla.

gospel.description: (As a Noun) One of the four books of the Bible which describe the life and teachings of Jesus Christ. English = gospel.

go%20steady.description: (As a Noun) A person with whom you are having a romantic or sexual relationship. English = boyfriend, girlfriend.; (As a Noun) Two people who are in a romantic or sexual relationship. English = couple.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a romantic or sexual relationship with someone. Informal English = go steady.

go%20to.description: (As a Noun) [This sign can go in any comfortable more or less horizontal direction in a straight line or an arc, but always with the finger moving laterally in the direction of the movement.] The movement of a person from one place to another. English = going (away from point of reference), coming (towards point of reference).; (As a Noun) The fact that someone has travelled and is present at a meeting or some other event. English = attendance.; (As a Verb or Adjective) [This sign can go in any comfortable more or less horizontal direction in a straight line or an arc, but always with the finger moving laterally in the direction of the movement. When going vertically up or down it is considered to be a separate sign: see signs for 'go up' and 'go down'.] Of a person, to move from one place to another. English = go, go to (away from point of reference), come, come to (towards point of reference).

go%20to%20and%20fro.description: (As a Noun) A journey to and from a place; a person who does such a journey in a day; a person who does such a journey every day to work and back. English = round trip, return journey; day tripper; commuter.; (As a Noun) The movement to and fro between two locations (such as laps in a swimming pool).; (As a Noun) A ticket to travel somewhere and then to come back. English = return ticket.

go%20to%20bed.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To get into bed, to get under the covers.; (Interactive) Used alone to suggest to your addressee that you both go to bed. English = 'Let's go to bed', 'Time to hit the sack', etc.

go%20up.description: (As a Noun) The distance of an object above some other object when that is great; the length of the distance from the bottom to the top of some long, relatively thin, upright object. English = height, tallness.; (As a Noun) The place where some people believe God lives and where good people go when they die. English = heaven.; (As a Noun) The spirit or being who is worshipped as the creator and ruler of the world, especially by Christians, Jews, and Muslims. English = God.

go%20upwards.description: (As a Noun) The distance of an object above some other object when that is great; the length of the distance from the bottom to the top of some long, relatively thin, upright object. English = height, tallness.; (As a Noun) The place where some people believe God lives and where good people go when they die. English = heaven.; (As a Noun) The spirit or being who is worshipped as the creator and ruler of the world, especially by Christians, Jews, and Muslims. English = God.

government.description: (As a Noun) The group of people who are responsible for governing a country or state. English = government.; (As a Noun) The departments, ministries, and committees that carry out the decisions of the political leaders of a country. English = government.

go%20well.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of situations and events, for things to go or turn out very well.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of two people, to meet and get on very well.; (Interactive) Used alone (with a questioning facial expression) to ask someone how they are or how things have been going. English = 'How are things going?', 'How have you been?', and so on.

go%20with.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To go somewhere in the company of one or more other persons or things. English = go with, go together.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move together as a group, go as a party.

gp%20(general%20practitioner).description: (As a Noun) A doctor, or the type of work of such a doctor, who treats people at a surgery or in their homes, not in a hospital, and who does not specialize in particular illnesses or methods of treatment. English = general practice, GP.

grab%20and%20take.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To put your hand around something, hold it and bring it towards you. English = take.

plough.description: (As a Noun) A device used for turning or pushing soil aside in farming or construction.; (As a Noun) A large farming tool with sharp blades which is attached to a tractor or an animal such as a horse. It is pulled across the soil to turn it over, usually before seed are planted. English = plough.; (As a Noun) A tractor-like vehicle with a large flat metal device at the front which pushes and levels the ground, especially used in making roads. English = road grader.

gram.description: (General Definition) In context, this sign can be used to refer to any thing or any action which is named by an English word beginning with the letter 'G' particularly if that word has already been fully fingerspelt in the present conversation. Signers often also mouth the associated word when they make the sign. It is particularly associated with the words ‘gram’ and ‘grand’; (As a Noun) A very small unit of weight. One thousand of these units are equal to one kilogram. English = gram.; (As Modifier) As a prefix to family relationship signs, used to mean one generation removed (either older or younger). English = grand (as in ‘grandchild’, ‘grandmother’, and so on).

grammar.description: (As a Noun) The structure of language. English = grammar.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Relating to the structure of language. English = grammatical.

grandmother.description: (As a Noun) The mother of your father or mother. English = grandmother. Informal English = gran, nana, nan.

grandfather.description: (As a Noun) The father of your mother or father. English = grandfather. Informal English = grandad, pop.

grapefruit.description: (As a Noun) A large, round, yellow fruit, similar to an orange, that has a sharp, sour taste. It is often cut in half and eaten using a teaspoon. English = grapefruit.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To eat a grapefruit using a spoon.

grapes.description: (General Definition) The action of eating something small and delicate.; (As a Noun) Small, round fruits, green or purple in colour, which are eaten raw, used for making wine, or dried to make raisins, sultanas, currants. English = grapes.; (As a Noun) Dried grapes. English = sultanas.

graph%20paper.description: (As a Noun) Paper printed with a network of small squares to assist the drawing of graphs or other diagrams. English = graph paper.

grasp%20(understand).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To know what someone has signed and to understand what they mean by it. English = catch (someone's meaning), follow (someone's meaning).; (Interactive) Used alone with a positive facial expression to mean you did follow and understand what someone has just signed. English = 'Yes, I got that!', 'Yes, I'm following you.', and so on.; (Interactive) Used alone with a negative facial expression to mean you did not follow what someone has just signed. English = 'Sorry, I don't follow you.', 'I don't get it!', 'I didn't catch that!', and so on.

green.description: (As a Noun) The colour of grass or of leaves. English = green.; (As a Noun) A very common plant with narrow leaves that forms a layer covering an area of ground. English = grass.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be the colour of grass or of leaves. English = (be) green.

grasshopper.description: (General Definition) Any thing or animal which jumps or leaps across the ground, such as an insect, or any thing or action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a grasshopper or a frog.; (As a Noun) An insect which has long back legs and can jump high into the air. They make a high, vibrating sound. English = grasshopper.; (As a Noun) A small creature with smooth skin, big eyes, and long back legs which it uses for jumping. It lives near water. English = frog.

grass%20(marijuana).description: (As a Noun) A type of drug which is smoked in cigarettes and which is illegal in most countries. English = marijuana. Informal English = pot, grass, weed, dope.; (As a Noun) A cigarette made of marijuana. Informal English = joint.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put a marijuana cigarette in your mouth, suck the smoke into your lungs and blow it out again. English = smoke marijuana, smoke a marijuana cigarette. Informal English = smoke dope, smoke pot, smoke a joint.

unsolicited.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a thing or service, to be provided free of charge and without request. English = (be) gratis, (be) unsolicited, (be) free.; (Interactive) Used to express pleasure on receiving something for free.

grave%20(serious).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very bad and cause people to worry. English = (be) serious, (be) severe, (be) grave.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be important and deserve careful and thoughtful consideration. English = (be) serious.

gravity.description: (General Definition) The action of something being drawn down onto or concentrated into a specific place, usually on a flat surface or the ground, or any action or any thing directly or indirectly associated with this, especially gravity.; (As a Noun) The force which causes things to fall to the ground when you drop them, and to remain on the ground instead of floating in the air. English = gravity.; (As a Noun) The force which causes objects to be attracted towards each other because they have mass. A technical word in physics. English = gravitation.

gravy.description: (General Definition) The act of pouring something from a container onto something else, usually flat, such as sauce onto a dish, dressing onto a salad and, especially, gravy on to a meal.; (As a Noun) A thin savoury sauce that is served with meat. English = gravy.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To pour gravy on to a piece of meat.

grey.description: (As a Noun) The colour of ashes or of clouds on a rainy day; the colour half-way between black and white. English = grey, gray.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be or have the colour of ashes or of clouds on a rainy day; to be or have the colour half-way between black and white. English = (be) grey, (be) gray.

graze.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of an animal, to eat and chew grass. English = graze.

grease.description: (General Definition) The action of scooping something thick or paste-like out of a container with your fingers or with an implement, such as ice-cream or glue from a tub, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially grease.; (As a Noun) A quantity of something scooped out of a container. English = scoop.; (As a Noun) A thick, oily substance which is put on the moving parts of machines in order to make them work smoothly. English = grease.

grease%20gun.description: (As a Noun) A device for forcing grease into special holes in machines so that their moving parts will work smoothly. English = grease gun.; (As a Noun) Of a car, the action of examining, adjusting and cleaning it so that it will keep working efficiently and safely. English = service.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To apply grease using a grease gun.

maximum.description: (As a Noun) The largest amount or number of something that is possible or allowed. English = maximum, limit, upper limit.; (As a Noun) The distance something goes up into the air. English = height.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be the largest amount, size or number of something that is possible or allowed. English = (be) maximum, (be) greatest, (be) largest.

greece.description: (As a Noun) A country in south eastern Europe, called Greece.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To come from or relate to Greece. English = (be) Greek.

greed.description: (As a Noun) An eager desire for more of something such as food, money, or power than it is necessary or fair for you to have. English = greed.; (As a Noun) A person who is unpleasant in some way, especially because they are greedy or unkind. English = pig.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To want more of something such as food, money, or power than is necessary or fair for you to have. English = (be) greedy.

green%20(inexperienced).description: (As a Noun) Someone who is learning how to do something, especially drive a vehicle. English = learner.; (As a Noun) Someone who is not experienced at a job or activity they are doing. English = novice. Informal English = newbie, rookie.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to have very little experience at something, especially because you are young. Idiomatic English = (be) green.

grey-haired.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of someone, to have grey hair; (be) grey-haired.

grey%20(wa).description: (As a Noun) Difficulty in seeing something because of poor light, haziness or dirt. English = obscurity.; (As a Noun) A dirtiness in the air which reduces visibility. English = haziness.; (As a Noun) An idea which is difficult to think about or explain because it is not precise or exact enough. English = vague.

grief.description: (As a Noun) Extreme sadness, especially because someone has died. English = grief.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To feel very sad about something that has happened, especially if it involves the death of someone. Often you cannot talk to other people and struggle to control your emotions. English = grieve.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To not complain about something, even though it may be painful; to suffer something in silence. Formal English = (be) stoic. Idiomatic English = put up with something.

grill%20(cook).description: (General Definition) An object or device with an overlapping grid of wires or slats, such as a sieve, wire mesh, strainer, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a grill.; (As a Noun) A flat frame of metal bars on which you cook food over a fire. English = grill.; (As a Noun) A framework of metal bars or wire which is placed in front of or over something to protect it or to protect people. English = grille.

grille%20(guard).description: (General Definition) Any object with horizontal stripes or thin things, such as wires or bars, at the front of it, or any object or action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially the grille of a car.; (As a Noun) The framework of metal bars or wire placed in front of engine or body of a car. English = grille.

grin.description: (As a Noun) A big, broad smile, especially one in which you show your teeth. English = grin.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To smile broadly, especially if you show your teeth. English = grin.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very happy about something and to show it by grinning.

grind%20(car%20mechanics).description: (As a Noun) The action of removing something from a surface by pulling a knife or some other sharp object over it. English = scraping.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To remove something from a surface by pulling a knife or other sharp object over it. English = scrape.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In motor mechanics, to grind the head of the engine.

grind%20(mortar%20and%20pestle).description: (As a Noun) A device made up of two parts: a bowl (mortar), and a heavy, blunt object (pestle). Used for grinding ingredients into a very fine paste or powder. English = mortar and pestle.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To grind or crush something using a mortar and pestle.; (Note) This sign is a depiction of grinding something while holding a mortar (bowl) and a pestle (tool). Source of this recommended sign: DeafConnectED, Melbourne Polytechnic.

grind%20(valve).description: (General Definition) The act of rubbing your palms together or rubbing, scraping, or grinding anything between two other objects, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially griding the valves of a car.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To grind the valves of a car engine.

groomsman.description: (As a Noun) In a wedding ceremony, the man who is getting married. English = groomsman.

gross%20(crude).description: (As a Noun) Behaviour which is foolish or childish. English = silliness.; (As a Noun) Language or behaviour which is rude and offensive. English = crudeness, grossness, coarseness.; (As a Noun) A serious and stupid mess, muddle or mistake. Vulgar English = fuckup.

group.description: (As a Noun) A number of people or things which are together at one place at one time. English = group.; (As a Noun) A set of people or things which have something in common or who work together at a specifc job. English = group, class, team, unit.; (As a Noun) A group of pupils or students who are taught together. English = class.

grow%20up.description: (As a Noun) The period of time in which you gradually change from being a child into being an adult. English = childhood.; (As a Noun) Someone who has learned a language as their first language from childhood. English = native, native user, native speaker, native signer.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To gradually change from being a child into being an adult. English = grow up.

supervision.description: (As a Noun) The careful watching of something or someone to make sure everything happens correctly. English = supervision.; (As a Noun) The careful watching of something, especially by an organisation such as the police or the army. English = surveillance.; (As a Noun) A person who supervises activities or people, especially workers or students. English = supervisor.

guess.description: (As a Noun) An attempt to give the right answer to something when you do not know it. English = guess.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To give an answer or an opinion about something when you do not know whether it is correct. English = guess.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To attempt to give an approximate answer to something. English = estimate.

guesswork.description: (As a Noun) The process or result of trying to guess something without knowing all the facts. English = guesswork, speculation.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To behave in a foolish, strange or childish way. English = (be) crazy, (be) silly.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To lack good judgement or intelligence and to be not at all sensible. English = (be) stupid.

invite into.description: (As a Noun) A person who works in a cinema or theatre who shows people where to sit. English = usher (male or female), usherette (female only).; (As a Noun) Someone who is staying in your home or is at an occasion because you have invited them. English = guest.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To politely show someone where they should go often with a wave of the hand and letting them walk slightly in front of you. English = usher.

guffaw.description: (As a Noun) A very loud laugh. English = guffaw.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To laugh very loudly, especially at someone in an unkind way. English = guffaw, laugh at.

leader.description: (As a Noun) A person who takes a person or group of people somewhere. English = leader, guide.; (As a Noun) A person who controls and guides an activity or organisation. English = leader.; (As a Noun) The qualities of a good leader. English =  leadership.

guillotine.description: (As a Noun) A device consisting of a blade in a large frame which was used to execute people, especially in France in the past. English = guillotine.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To execute people by beheading them in with a device consisting of a blade in a large frame. English = guillotine.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To strike or chop the neck with a blade or an axe.

guitar.description: (As a Noun) A musical instrument with six strings. You play it by plucking or strumming the strings. English = guitar.; (As a Noun) A group of musicians who play jazz, rock, or pop music.  English = band.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To play a stringed instrument, especially a guitar. English = strum.

temptation.description: (As a Noun) The state you are in when you want to do or have something, although you know it may be wrong or harmful.  English = temptation.; (As a Noun) Something that makes you want to do or have something, even though you know it may wrong or harmful. English = temptation.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To offer something to someone that they want in order to encourage them to do something that you want them to do. English = tempt.

swallow.description: (As a Noun) The action of making something go from your mouth inside your throat and down into your stomach. English = swallow, gulp.; (As a Noun) A large quantity of food or drink which is taken into your mouth at one time (ie a full mouthful) and then made to go inside your throat and down into your stomach.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make something go from your mouth inside your throat and down into your stomach. English = swallow.

gun.description: (As a Noun) A weapon consisting mainly of a metal tube from which bullets are fired. English = gun.; (As a Noun) A kind of a gun that you hold in your hand. English = revolver, pistol.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To operate a gun or a revolver. English = shoot, fire.

gunfire.description: (As a Noun) The noise and smoke that comes out of a gun when it is fired. English = gunfire.

gutter.description: (General Definition) Any flat rectangular object above ones head with a border running around the edge, or any thing or any action that can be directly or indirectly associated with this sign in a given context, such as a cornice, eaves, and especially a gutter.; (As a Noun) A plastic or metal channel fixed to the edge of the roof of a building, which rain water drains into. English = gutter.

gymnasium.description: (As a Noun) A building or a large room which is used for physical exercise and usually has equipment such as bars and ropes in it. English = gymnasium, gym.; (As a Noun) Exercises which involve the lifting and moving of heavy weights. English = weight training, weight lifting.; (As a Noun) A sport's competition that involves the lifting of heavy weights. English = weight lifting.

h.description: (As a Noun) The letter H in the one-handed American manual alphabet.; (Note) We apologise for the poor quality of the video. We intend to re-film all the videos in Auslan Signbank when funds become available. Auslan Signbank is provided free of charge and we wish to keep it this way. If you are able to offer any suggestion for where we may find financial support to implement this and other improvements to Auslan Signbank please contact us by using the "Provide general site feedback" link under the sign video.

habit%20(nun).description: (As a Noun) A member of a female religious community. English = nun.; (As a Noun) A covering over the head and body which a nun wears. English = habit.

haemorrhoids.description: (As a Noun) HAEMORRHOIDS are painful swellings that can appear in the veins inside the anus.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for HAEMORRHOIDS. If you know a sign for HAEMORRHOIDS used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

hail.description: (As a Noun) Tiny balls of ice that fall like rain from the sky. English = hail, hailstone.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of tiny balls of ice, to fall from the sky like rain. English = hail.

hair.description: (As a Noun) The long, fine, thread-like things that grow in large numbers on your head. English = hair.

hairbrush.description: (As a Noun) A brush that you use to brush your hair. English = hairbrush, brush.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To untangle your hair by using a hairbrush. English = brush (one's hair).

hair%20bun.description: (As a Noun) A style of wearing long hair in which your hair is fastened into a round shape at the back of your head. English = bun, hair bun.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wear your hear in a bun.

hair%20cut.description: (As a Noun) The activity or occupation of cutting, washing, and styling people's hair. English = hairdressing.; (As a Noun) A person who cuts, washes and styles people's hair. English = hairdresser.; (As a Noun) The style in which you hair has been cut. English = hair cut.

hairdressing.description: (As a Noun) The activity or occupation of cutting, washing, and styling people's hair. English = hairdressing.; (As a Noun) A person who cuts, washes and styles people's hair. English = hairdresser.; (As a Noun) The style in which you hair has been cut. English = hair cut.

hair%20(long).description: (As a Noun) Hair which is worn long.; (As a Noun) Hair which is straight.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have long hair.

hair%20(short).description: (As a Noun) Hair which is worn short.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have short hair.

hair%20spray.description: (As a Noun) A dressing sprayed on the hair, often from a pressure pack, to keep the hairdo in place. English = hair spray.; (As a Noun) A pressure pack that contains hair spray.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To spray hair spray on to one's hair.

half.description: (As a Noun) One of two equal parts of an amount of something or an object. English = half.; (As a Noun) A piece or an area of a larger thing. English = part.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be one of two equal parts of an amount of something or an object. English = (be) half.

half%20hour.description: (As a Noun) A period of thirty minutes. English = half hour, half an hour.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of some situation or event, to last for half an hour.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of time, for half an hour to pass.

half%20past.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Used before number signs to describe the time as 'half past' the hour of the number.

half-slip.description: (As a Noun) A petticoat that hangs under a skirt. English = half-slip.

half-time.description: (As a Noun) The short period of time between the two parts of a sports match, when the players have a short rest. English = half-time.

hallelujah.description: (Interactive) Used alone by some Christians in church as an exclamation of praise and thanks to God. English = 'Hallelujah!'

hallucination.description: (As a Noun) A HALLUCINATION is the experience of seeing something that is not really there because you are ill or have taken a drug.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for HALLUCINATION. If you know a sign for HALLUCINATION used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

ham.description: (As a Noun) The salted meat from a pig's leg. English = ham.

hand.description: (As a Noun) The part of the body at the end of one of your arms. Each one has four fingers and one thumb. English = hand.

handball.description: (As a Noun) In Australian rules football, a pass in which a player attempts to deliver the ball to a team mate by holding the ball in one hand and hitting it away with the other fist. English = handball, handpass.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In Australian rules football, to pass the ball to a team mate by holding the ball in one hand and hitting it away with the other fist. English = handball, handpass.

hand%20brake.description: (General Definition) The action of holding something firmly in your hand, pressing a button with your thumb, and then using force to move the object upwards towards you, such as operating various kinds of levers which act as locking devices. Without context and performed with the left hand, Auslan signers will assume you mean a hand-brake in a car.; (As a Noun) A brake operated by hand, used to hold an already stationary vehicle. English = hand brake.

handkerchief.description: (As a Noun) A small square piece of fabric which you use for blowing your nose. English = handkerchief.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To force air out of your nose through your nostrils in order to clean it. English = blow your nose.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To blow your nose using a handkerchief or tissue.

hand-me-down.description: (As a Noun) Things, especially clothing, which have been used by other people before you and which have been given to you for your use. Idiomatic English = hand-me-down.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of the signer, to be given back something; of the addressee, to give something back to the signer. English = give back, return.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of the signer, to be given or handed something by someone, to be provided with it or allowed to have it; to be given something.

hand%20over.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To give something to someone; to hand over something to someone.

hand%20pump.description: (General Definition) The action of holding onto something in front of you and moving it up and down repeatedly, such as dunking clothes in water and rubbing them against a washboard or operating a hand held pump, or any thing or any action which can be easily associated with this when given enough context.; (As a Noun) A board or frame with corrugated metallic or other surface, on which clothes are scrubbed in the process of washing. English = washboard.; (As a Noun) A room in a house or hotel where clothes, sheets, and towels are washed; or a business that does this for people. English = laundry.

hand%20puppet.description: (As a Noun) A doll which you can move by putting your hand inside its body and moving your fingers. English = puppet, hand puppet, glove puppet.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To operate a hand puppet.

hands.description: (As a Noun) The parts of your body at the end of your arms. They have four fingers and one thumb each. English = hands.

telephone.description: (As a Noun) The piece of equipment you use when you talk to someone by telephone. English = telephone.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To dial someone's telephone number and speak to them by telephone. English = telephone, call.

handshape.description: (As a Noun) The particular arrangement of the fingers of the hand that is one of a limited set of typical and distinctive configurations used in a sign language. English = handshape.

hand%20towel.description: (As a Noun) A small cloth used for washing yourself. English = flannel, face flannel, face cloth, face washer.; (As a Noun) A small towel used for drying your hands and your face. English = hand towel.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wash your face, to freshen up.

handwriting.description: (As a Noun) A person's style of writing with a pen or pencil, rather than with a typewriter. English = handwriting.; (As a Noun) The art and skill of writing by hand. English = penmanship.

hook.description: (As a Noun) A piece of curved metal or plastic that is used for hanging things from. English = hook.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To attach one part of something to a hook, nail or rail etc. so that it is supported by it. The rest of the thing is free and unsupported. English = hang, suspend.

hanging.description: (As a Noun) The practice of executing people by tying a rope around their neck and taking away the support from under their feet so that they hang in the air. English = hanging.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To kill someone by tying a rope around their neck and taking away the support from under their feet so that they hang in the air. English = hang.

hang%20on.description: (Interactive) Used alone to tell someone to stop doing something (which usually involves trying to get your attention) and to wait until you are ready to attend to them. English = 'Hold on!', 'Hang on!', 'Wait a sec!' and so on.; (As Modifier) Used to introduce a statement which contrasts with what you have just said. English = but, yet, though, although.; (As Modifier) Used alone to show the person you are talking to that you are thinking and about to say something. English = umm, err.

hangover.description: (As a Noun) A headache and feeling of sickness that you have in the morning if you have drunk a lot of alcohol the night before. English = hangover.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a headache and a feeling of sickness in the morning because you have drunk a lot of alcohol the night before. English = have a hangover, (be) hungover.

happen%20(nothing%20happen).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To spend a long time, usually doing very little, before something happens. English = wait (a long time).; (As a Verb or Adjective) For nothing to happen for a long time.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a period of time, to have nothing interesting happen. English = (be) uneventful.

hard-boiled%20egg.description: (As a Noun) An egg which has been boiled in its shell until the yolk and the white are hard. English = hard-boiled egg.; (As a Noun) The rounded object produced by a female bird (and some other creatures) from which a baby bird later emerges. Especially used for the type produced by hens and eaten by people as a food. English = egg.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To crack open a hard-boiled egg using an implement such as a knife.

hard%20hat.description: (General Definition) To pull something down over the top of your head, or any thing or any action that can be associated with this in context.; (As a Noun) A mass of false hair which you wear on your head, for example because you are bald or because you want to cover up your own hair. English = wig.; (As a Noun) A rigid protective head cover worn by factory and building workers. English = hard hat, helmet.

hard%20of%20hearing.description: (As a Noun) A person who has difficulty hearing well, especially hearing the sounds of speech, but who nonetheless is not really very deaf; a person who is hard of hearing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be unable to hear very well, especially the sounds of speech. English = (be) hearing impaired, (be) hard of hearing.

hard%20on.description: (As a Noun) The state of a man's penis being stiff, swollen, and sticking up. For some Auslan users this is a vulgar sign. Formal English = erection. Vulgar English = stiff, boner. Idiomatic English = hard on.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a man's penis, to become stiff, swollen, and sticking up. For some Auslan users this is a vulgar sign. Formal English = become erect, get an erection. Vulgar English = become stiff, get a stiff, get a boner. Idiomatic English = get a hard on.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a man's penis, to be stiff, swollen, and sticking up. For some Auslan users this is a vulgar sign. Formal English = (be) erect. Vulgar English = (be) stiff. Idiomatic English = have a hard on.

pain.description: (As a Noun) An unpleasant feeling you have in your body because you are ill or have been hurt. English = pain.; (As a Noun) A series of strong beats or dull pains in your body. English = throb.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be in or experience an unpleasant feeling in your body because you are ill or have been hurt; (be) in pain.

harm%20(no%20harm).description: (Interactive) Used alone to indicate in response to a question or expression of concern that everything is alright and that the concern is unwarranted. English = 'No harm done!', 'It's no problem!', 'No sweat!', 'Not to worry.'

harp.description: (As a Noun) A large musical instrument consisting of a row of strings stretched from the top to the bottom of a frame, which you play by picking at the strings with your fingers. English = harp.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To play a harp, to stroke the strings of a harp.

harvest.description: (General Definition) The action of moving a flat object sideways close to the ground, such as the blade of a machete or scythe at the base of plants, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially harvesting.; (As a Noun) The cutting or picking of crops at the time of year when they are ripe. English = harvest.; (As a Noun) A year's crops that have ripened so that they can be cut or picked. English = harvest.

hash.description: (As a Noun) A drug made from the marijuana plant which people smoke or eat to make them feel relaxed. Informal English = hash, hashish.

hash%20(marijuana).description: (As a Noun) A small pipe used for smoking marijuana or hashish.; (As a Noun) A drug made from the hemp plant which people usually smoke like a cigarette or like tobacco in a pipe to make them feel relaxed. It is illegal in many countries. English = marijuana, hashish. Informal English = dope, hash.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To smoke marijuana or hashish using a pipe; to smoke dope.

trouble-free.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To cause or give no difficulties or no problems to someone. English = (be) trouble-free, (be) hassle-free.

hassle%20(no%20hassle).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To cause or give little or no difficulties or problems to someone because it is easy or a pleasure to do. English = (be) no bother, (be) not any bother, (be) no hassle, (be) not any hassle.; (Interactive) Used alone as a reply to the question whether something you have been asked to do or are obliged to do is difficult or causing you problems, to mean you have no problems, it is not difficult or that it is even a pleasure. English = 'It's no bother!'

hat.description: (As a Noun) A covering that you wear on your head, especially when you are outside. Used particularly, but not exclusively, for head wear worn by women. English = hat.; (As a Noun) A soft, flat hat which is usually worn by men or boys. English = cap.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put on a cap or a hat.

trapdoor.description: (As a Noun) A small horizontal door in a floor, ceiling, or stage. English = trapdoor.; (As a Noun) An opening in a deck of a ship, which is used for people to come on deck or go below, or during loading and unloading cargo. English = hatch.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To open a trapdoor.

have.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To own, possess or hold something. English = have, have got.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be part of you or very closely associated with you, e.g., family members and relationships. English = have, have got.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Used to introduce a topic of discussion or assert the existence or location of something, e.g., HAVE KANGAROOS AUSTRALIA (’There are kangaroos in Australia’, ‘Kangaroos exist in Australia’). English = be here, be there, exist, there’s.

have%20a%20look.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a good look at something in order to get more information about it. English = examine.; (Interactive) Used alone in response to your addressee's insistence that something is true or will happen to mean you do not agree but don't want to argue the point any further. English = 'We'll see.', 'That remains to be seen.', 'Let's wait and see' etc.; (As Modifier) Used to introduce a suggestion or idea. English = 'Let's see. How about...'.

have%20(exist).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To own, possess or hold something. English = have, have got.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be part of you or very closely associated with you, e.g., family members and relationships. English = have, have got.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Used to introduce a topic of discussion or assert the existence or location of something, e.g., HAVE KANGAROOS AUSTRALIA (’There are kangaroos in Australia’, ‘Kangaroos exist in Australia’). English = be here, be there, exist, there’s.

have%20got.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To own, possess or hold something. English = have, have got.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be part of you or very closely associated with you, e.g., family members and relationships. English = have, have got.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Used to introduce a topic of discussion or assert the existence or location of something, e.g., HAVE KANGAROOS AUSTRALIA (’There are kangaroos in Australia’, ‘Kangaroos exist in Australia’). English = be here, be there, exist, there’s.

have%20(have%20none).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of something or someone, to not be here or there, to not exist in a place.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To not own or possess something. English = not have any, have not got any, have none of.

have%20(not%20have).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of something or someone, to not be here or there, to not exist in a place.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To not own or possess something. English = not have any, have not got any, have none of.

have%20to.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of an action, to have no choice or freedom regarding doing it. English = (be) compulsory.; (Interactive) Used alone as a response to a question from your addressee or even yourself as to the likelihood of something happening or being true to mean that you are sure it is true or that it has happened. English = 'It must be!', 'It has to be!', 'It must have happened!'; (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb to mean that it is very important and necessary that the action happen; or that you want to do it and that you intend to do it very soon. English = must, have to.

hay%20fever.description: (As a Noun) An illness similar to a cold, in which people sneeze a lot because they are allergic to some types of pollen. English = hay fever.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To suffer from hay fever.

hazard%20lights.description: (As a Noun) The lights at the front and back of a car which are used to show that the car is turning or is about to turn left or right. English = indicators, blinkers.; (As a Noun) The lights at the front and back of a car which, when both are flashing simultaneously, are used to show that the car is stationary and a hazard to traffic. English = hazard lights.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To operate the blinkers on a car.

risk.description: (As a Noun) The possibility that something unpleasant will happen. English = risk.; (As a Noun) Something you do that is new and difficult so involves the risk of failure. English = venture.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of an activity or action, to be dangerous or likely to fail. English = (be) risky , (be) hazardous, (be) perilous.

obscurity.description: (As a Noun) Difficulty in seeing something because of poor light, haziness or dirt. English = obscurity.; (As a Noun) A dirtiness in the air which reduces visibility. English = haziness.; (As a Noun) An idea which is difficult to think about or explain because it is not precise or exact enough. English = vague.

it.description: (As a Pointing Sign) Used to refer to a location that is not near either the signer or the person addressed. English = there.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used to refer to something or someone separate and different from the signer and the person they are addressing. If the thing or other person is real and located in the situation, then you point to where it/he/she is located, otherwise you point to where you imagine it/he/she is located. When the pointing sign is made immediately before or after a verb sign, you usually mean that the thing or the other person does the action of the verb, or is affected by the action of the verb. English = it (thing); he, him (male); she, her (female); they, them (gender unimportant).; (As a Pointing Sign) When the pointing sign is made immediately before or after a noun sign, the signer usually expects the addressee to know which person or thing they mean because it is has already been talked about in the conversation or it is common knowledge. When used in this way, the signer is often not thinking of, and not really pointing to, any particular location (so it can be point at ‘odd’ angles). The sign can last for only a very brief time with very little movement. English = the.

head.description: (As a Noun) The part of your body which has your eyes, mouth, and brain in it. English = head.; (As a Noun) A covering that you wear on your head, especially when you are outside. Used particularly, but not exclusively, for head wear worn by women. English = hat.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To touch or pat one's head.

headache.description: (As a Noun) A pain that you feel in your head. English = headache.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a pain in your head. English = have a headache.

headlights.description: (As a Noun) The large bright lights at the front of a car. English = headlights.; (Note) Reverse the orientation of the hands for TAIL-LIGHTS.

head%20scarf.description: (As a Noun) A piece of cloth that you wear round your head, usually to keep yourself warm. English = scarf, head scarf, kerchief.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put on or wear a head scarf or kerchief.

head%20shake.description: (As a Noun) A statement in which you say something is not true, usually be shaking you head side to side.; (As a Noun) A statement in which you say something is not true, especially when it has been claimed to be true of you. English = denial.; (As a Noun) A rejection of an offer. English = refusal, rejection.

stubbornness.description: (As a Noun) The characteristic of being always determined to do what you want to do and to be very unwilling to change your mind. English = stubbornness, obstinacy. Informal English = pig-headedness.; (As a Noun) A stubborn person.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be determined to do what you want to do and to be very unwilling to change your mind. English = (be) stubborn, (be) obstinate, (be) headstrong, (be) steadfast. Informal English = (be) pig-headed.

health.description: (As a Noun) The state in which you are fit and well and not ill. English = health.; (As a Noun) The condition of your body. English = health.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be well and not suffering from any illness. English = (be) healthy, (be) fit.

heap.description: (As a Noun) A quantity of things which forms a mass that is high in the middle and has sloping sides. English = heap, pile.; (As a Noun) A quantity of earth which forms a mass that is high in the middle and has sloping sides. English = mound.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To become or be a mass of things that is high in the middle with sloping sides. English = heap up, pile up; (be) heaped up, (be) piled up.

hear.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be aware of sounds because they reach your ear. English = hear.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To give your attention to the sound of something, especially music. English = listen to.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To learn about news or information because someone tells you about it. English = hear of, hear about.

hear%20about.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To learn about, take in, or understand about things by listening or being told about them. English = hear of, hear about.

hearing.description: (As a Noun) A person who can hear.; (As a Noun) The sense of being able to hear sounds, especially speech; the sense of hearing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To learn about news or information because someone tells you about it, even if they tell you in sign language. English = hear about.

hearing%20aid.description: (As a Noun) The early type of analog instrument that helped hearing impaired and deaf people hear better. An obsolete sign. English = hearing-aid.

hearing-aid.description: (As a Noun) The early type of analog instrument that helped hearing impaired and deaf people hear better. An obsolete sign. English = hearing-aid.

hearing%20dog.description: (As a Noun) A dog which has been specially trained to help deaf or hearing impaired people by alerting them to sounds such as a ringing doorbell or an alarm. English = hearing dog.

hearing%20impaired.description: (As a Noun) A person who is unable to hear sounds fully or accurately, especially the sounds of speech. English = hearing impaired.; (As a Noun) A person who is unable to hear sounds fully or accurately, especially the sounds of speech, and who does not identify with the Deaf community.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be unable to hear sounds fully or accurately, especially the sounds of speech. English = (be) hearing impaired.

hearing%20loop.description: (As a Noun) A wire which is connected around the edge of a room or auditorium that facilitates the operation of FM-hearing aids. English = hearing loop.

hearing%20loss.description: (As a Noun) The gradual loss of hearing that a person can experience through aging or illness; hearing loss.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To gradually lose one's hearing through aging or illness.

hear%20of.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be aware of sounds because they reach your ear. English = hear.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To give your attention to the sound of something, especially music. English = listen to.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To learn about news or information because someone tells you about it. English = hear of, hear about.

heart%20(at%20heart).description: (As a Noun) The way a person behaves and thinks that makes them unique or of a particular type. English = character,  personality.; (As a Noun) Things which are thought to be related to or inside the heart. English = emotion.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very much your own and related to your feelings and emotions. English = (be) personal.

heart%20attack.description: (As a Noun) A sudden sickness in which your heart starts to beat irregularly or fails to pump blood properly, so that it causes you a lot of pain. People often die because of this. English = heart attack. Formal medical English = cardiac arrest.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have or suffer a heart attack; to have or suffer a cardiac arrest.

indigestion.description: (As a Noun) A burning pain you get in your stomach when you find it difficult to digest food. English = indigestion, heartburn.

heart%20failure.description: (As a Noun) HEART FAILURE is a serious medical condition in which someone's heart does not work as well as it should, sometimes stopping completely so that they die.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for HEART FAILURE. If you know a sign for HEART FAILURE used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

hot.description: (As a Noun) The quality of being very warm or hot. English = heat, hotness.; (As a Noun) The measure of the amount of heat in something, the measure of how hot or cold it is. English = temperature.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very warm, to have a high temperature. English = (be) hot.

heater.description: (As a Noun) A piece of equipment which is used to warm the air in a room. English = heater.

heaven.description: (As a Noun) The place where God is believed to live, and where good people are believed to go when they die. English = heaven.

sky.description: (As a Noun) The space around the Earth which you can see when you stand outside and look upwards, and where you can see the sun, the moon, and the stars. English = sky. In literary English = heavens.; (As a Noun) The high horizontal surface that forms the top part inside a room in which the walls go up a long way. English = (high) ceiling.; (As a Noun) The covering on the top of a building. English = roof.

height.description: (As a Noun) The distance of an object above some other object when that is great; the length of the distance from the bottom to the top of some long, relatively thin, upright object. English = height, tallness.; (As a Noun) The place where some people believe God lives and where good people go when they die. English = heaven.; (As a Noun) The spirit or being who is worshipped as the creator and ruler of the world, especially by Christians, Jews, and Muslims. English = God.

hell.description: (As a Noun) The place that some people believe wicked people go to when they die. English = hell.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go to hell.

wig.description: (General Definition) To pull something down over the top of your head, or any thing or any action that can be associated with this in context.; (As a Noun) A mass of false hair which you wear on your head, for example because you are bald or because you want to cover up your own hair. English = wig.; (As a Noun) A rigid protective head cover worn by factory and building workers. English = hard hat, helmet.

hepatitis.description: (As a Noun) HEPATITIS is a serious disease which affects the liver.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for HEPATITIS. If you know a sign for HEPATITIS used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

here.description: (As a Pointing Sign) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence or next to a verb to refer to the place where the signer is now. English = here.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used alone or next to a noun to refer to a person or thing which has been mentioned already in a conversation and is close in time, importance or relevance to the signer. English = this.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used immediately before or after a verb sign, to mean that something does the action of the verb, or it is affected by the action of the verb. English = it.

here%20(plural).description: (General Definition) Used to refer to people or things which are near to, or closely associated with, the signer. Small close things can be easily pointed to in this way; however, people and large things first need to be visualised in a map-like space in which they are imagined to be located.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used to refer to several locations that are near either the signer or the person addressed, i.e., ‘these places here’.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used immediately before or after a noun sign to mean particular or special things or persons which have already been talked about in the conversation or which contrast with something else which as already been mentioned. English = these.

hernia.description: (As a Noun) A HERNIA is a medical condition which is often caused by strain or injury. It results in one of your internal organs sticking through a weak point in the surrounding tissue.

syringe.description: (As a Noun) A small tube with a plunger and a fine hollow needle or pointed end. It is used for putting liquids into something and taking them out, for example drugs into a person's body or for taking blood samples from them. English = syringe, hypodermic needle.; (As a Noun) The act of using a syringe to put liquids into a person's body. English = injection. Informal English = jab.; (As a Noun) The act of injecting someone with a weak form of a disease as a way of protecting them from it. English = immunisation, inoculation, vaccination.

itself.description: (As a Pointing Sign) Used immediately before or after a verb to mean a thing or another  person (and not the signer or the person they are talking to) does the action of the verb alone (i.e., without anyone else present) or without the help of anyone else (i.e., they are the only person or thing responsible for the action). English = itself, herself (female), himself (male), themselves (gender unimportant).; (As a Pointing Sign) Used immediately before or after a verb to mean the action of the verb was done by that person or thing to the same person or thing and not by anyone or anything else, i.e., it makes the verb reflexive. English = itself, herself (female), himself (male), themselves (gender unimportant).

hey.description: (Interactive) Used alone to get the attention of someone. You try to move you hand so that it is in the line of vision of the person whose attention you are trying to get. In English you usually say or call out the person's name. Informal causal English = hey.

hi.description: (Interactive) Used alone to greet someone in an informal way. English = 'Hi!', 'Hello!'

hiccup.description: (As a Noun) Repeated little choking sounds in your throat due to muscle spasms often caused by eating or drinking too much or too quickly. English = hiccup, hiccough.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have the hiccups (or hiccoughs).

hide-and-seek.description: (As a Noun) A game in which one player covers his or her eyes until the other players have hidden themselves, and then he or she tries to find them. English = hide-and-seek.

hide%20away.description: (As a Noun) Something put into a secret place. Informal English = stash. Formal English = cache.; (As a Noun) The act of collecting money by not spending it, or the money itself. English = saving, savings.; (As a Noun) A collection of gold or silver objects, jewels or other valuable things, which has been hidden. English = treasure.

hide%20out.description: (As a Noun) A place where someone or something can be hidden, or where they are hiding. English = hiding place.; (As a Noun) A place where someone goes secretly because they do not want anyone to find them, for example if they are running away from the police. English = hide-out.; (As a Noun) The state of being hidden or the act of hiding something. English = concealment.

hierarchy.description: (As a Noun) A system in which people have different ranks or positions depending on how important they are. English = hierarchy.

high%20jump.description: (As a Noun) An athletics event which involves jumping over a raised bar. English = high jump.

high%20rise.description: (As a Noun) A tall structure or a high rise building such as an office building or a large hotel. English = high rise.; (As a Noun) A set of rooms for living in, usually on one floor of a large building. English = flat, apartment, home unit.

high%20school.description: (As a Noun) A school for people aged between eleven and eighteen. English = high school.

high%20vis.description: (As a Noun) HIGH VISIBILITY CLOTHING is clothing that is very bright and deliberately worn so that the person is easy to see.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English phrase HIGH VISIBILITY CLOTHING. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for HIGH VISIBILITY CLOTHING (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for HIGH VISIBILITY CLOTHING used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

high%20visibility%20clothing.description: (As a Noun) HIGH VISIBILITY CLOTHING is clothing that is very bright and deliberately worn so that the person is easy to see.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English phrase HIGH VISIBILITY CLOTHING. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for HIGH VISIBILITY CLOTHING (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for HIGH VISIBILITY CLOTHING used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

hill.description: (As a Noun) An area of land that is higher than the land that surrounds it, but is not as high as a mountain. English = hill.

mountains.description: (As a Noun) An area of land that is not flat and has many areas with steep sides which are difficult to climb English = mountains.; (As a Noun) A row of mountains that were formed at the same time in the earth's history.  English = mountains, mountain range.; (As a Noun) An area of land that is not flat. It is uneven and has many areas that are high, but not as high as a mountain. English = hills.

hip.description: (As a Noun) The area at the sides of your body between the tops of your legs and your waist. English = hip.

hippopotamus.description: (As a Noun) A large animal with short legs and thick, wrinkled skin and a large rounded jaw. They live near rivers in Africa. English = hippopotamus.

slap.description: (As a Noun) The action of hitting someone on the hand with the palm side of your hand.; (As a Noun) The action of hitting someone with the palm side of your hand. English = slap, smack.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To hit someone (especially a child) on the hand with the palm side of your hand, when they are reaching to do something or take something and you want them to stop; to slap or smack someone on the hand; to rap someone over the knuckles.

hitch-hiker.description: (As a Noun) A person who travels by getting lifts in other people's cars, which they ask for by standing at the side of the road with their thumb held out. English = hitch-hiker.; (As a Noun) The way of travelling by getting lifts in other people's cars, which you ask for by standing at the side of the road with your thumb held out. English = hitch-hiking.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To travel by getting lifts in other people's cars, which you ask for by standing at the side of the road with your thumb held out. English = hitch-hike.

hiv.description: (As a Noun) HIV is a virus which reduces people's resistance to illness and can cause AIDS. HIV is an abbreviation for `Human Immunodeficiency Virus'. If someone is "HIV positive", they are infected with the HIV virus, and may develop AIDS. If someone is HIV negative, they are not infected with the virus.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for HIV. If you know a sign for HIV used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

hi%20vis.description: (As a Noun) HIGH VISIBILITY CLOTHING is clothing that is very bright and deliberately worn so that the person is easy to see.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English phrase HIGH VISIBILITY CLOTHING. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for HIGH VISIBILITY CLOTHING (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for HIGH VISIBILITY CLOTHING used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

hobart.description: (As a Noun) The city of Hobart, capital city of the Australian state of Tasmania.

hockey.description: (As a Noun) An outdoor game, played between two teams of 11 players who use long curved sticks to hit a small ball and try to score goals. English = hockey.

hoist.description: (As a Noun) A HOIST is a machine with ropes and pulleys for lifting heavy things.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To HOIST something means to lift something by using a hoist.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term HOIST. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for HOIST (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic).
