If you know a sign for HOIST used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

hold.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To have your fingers and hands firmly around something. English = hold.

hold%20back.description: (As a Noun) Calm, controlled and unemotional behaviour. English = restraint.; (As a Noun) The ability to control your emotions and remain calm, particularly when those emotions could easily be very strong. English = restraint, self control.; (As a Noun) The inability to express your emotions or the inability to behave naturally and to show your real feelings. English = inhibition.

hold%20on%20(wait).description: (Interactive) Used alone to tell someone to stop doing something (which usually involves trying to get your attention) and to wait until you are ready to attend to them. English = 'Hold on!', 'Hang on!', 'Wait a sec!' and so on.; (As Modifier) Used to introduce a statement which contrasts with what you have just said. English = but, yet, though, although.; (As Modifier) Used alone to show the person you are talking to that you are thinking and about to say something. English = umm, err.

hold-up.description: (As a Noun) A situation in which someone is threatened with a weapon in order to make them hand over money. English = hold-up, stick-up, (armed) robbery.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To threaten someone with a weapon in order to make them hand over money. English = hold-up, stick up, rob (at gun point).; (As a Verb or Adjective) To draw pistols out of their holsters in order to threaten, challenge or shoot someone.

hole.description: (As a Noun) A large hollow space in something solid, especially  a flat surface such as the ground, with an opening on one side. English = hole.; (As a Noun) The edge that goes all the way around the top of a hollow space in something solid or a container like a cup or glass. English = rim.

holiday.description: (As a Noun) A period of time during which you are relaxing and enjoying yourself away from home; a period of time during which you are not working or attending school, college, or university. English = holiday, holidays, vacation.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go away for a period of time during which you relax and enjoy yourself away from home. English = holiday, go on holidays.

holland%20blind.description: (As a Noun) A roll of cloth or paper which you can pull down over a window in order to keep out the light. English = blind, shade, Holland blind.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To pull down a blind.

holy%20communion.description: (As a Noun) The most important religious service in the Christian church, in which people share bread and wine as a symbol of the Last Supper and crucifixion of Jesus Christ. English = Holy Communion.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To take Holy Communion.

holy%20spirit.description: (As a Noun) In the Christian religion, one of the three aspects of God, together with God the Father and God the Son. English = Holy Spirit.

home.description: (As a Noun) The place where you live and feel that you belong. English = home, place.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go home to one's own place.

home%20isolation.description: (As a Noun) With reference to infectious diseases, especially COVID-19, the period of time a regulation or law which obliges anyone who has the infection or is a near- or direct-contact to isolate at home to avoid infecting others. English = home isolation, self-isolation, quarantine.; (As a Verb or Adjective) With reference to infectious diseases, especially COVID-19, to stay at home for a  period of time to avoid infecting others because a regulation or law obliges you to do so. English = home isolate, self-isolate, quarantine.; (Note) Suggested sign #1×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

home%20unit.description: (As a Noun) A tall structure or a high rise building such as an office building or a large hotel. English = high rise.; (As a Noun) A set of rooms for living in, usually on one floor of a large building. English = flat, apartment, home unit.

honey.description: (As a Noun) A sweet sticky yellowish substance that is made by bees. English = honey.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To take honey out from a container using a spoon or other small utensil.

honeymoon.description: (As a Noun) A sweet sticky yellowish substance that is made by bees. English = honey.; (As a Noun) A holiday taken by a couple that have just got married. English = honeymoon.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go on a honeymoon. English = honeymoon.

hong%20kong.description: (As a Noun) A city in South-East China at the mouth of the Pearl River, called Hong Kong.

hood.description: (As a Noun) A part of a coat or cloak which you pull up to cover your head. English = hood.; (As a Noun) A jacket or coat which has a quilted lining and a hood with fur round the edge. English = parka.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To pull a hood over your head.

hood%20(car).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of the boot/trunk or hood/bonnet of a car, to open or be open.

hooker.description: (As a Noun) In Rugby football, the central forward in the front row of the scrum, whose job it is to pull back the ball with his foot. English = hooker.

hop.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to move along jumping on one foot. English = hop.

hope.description: (As a Noun) A feeling of confidence that what you want to happen might happen. English = hope.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To want something to be true or to happen and usually believe that it is possible. English = hope.

wish.description: (As a Noun) A longing or desire for something, often something that is difficult to obtain or achieve. English = wish.; (As a Noun) A feeling of confidence that that what you want to happen might happen. English = hope.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To want something to happen, even though you know that it may not be possible or is unlikely. English = wish.

hop%20(kangaroo).description: (As a Noun) A large Australian animal which moves by jumping on its back legs. Female ones carry their babies in a pouch on their stomachs. English = kangaroo.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To hop like a kangaroo.

horizontal.description: (General Definition) A line or a flat surface which is level and always at the same height or distance relative to another surface, such as the ground, or the bottom of a page, or another line; or any thing (e.g., stage or podium) or action (levelling sand, flattening fabric) that can be easily associated with this in context.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Used to describe, a line or a flat surface which is always at the same height relative to another surface, such as the ground, or the bottom of a page, or another line, and not at an angle to them. English = (be) horizontal, (be) level.; (Note) One of the variants uses the ‘H’ handshape in the one-handed alphabet. It was originally only used for Signed English in education. In mathematics and geometry, it is used by some teachers and their deaf students to mean ‘horizontal’ specifically, i.e., the main sign and the other variant are commonly used for ‘level’ and ‘horizontal’ and thus have a more general meaning.

horn%20(car).description: (As a Noun) The thing on a car that makes a loud noise as a signal or as a warning. English = horn.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To operate the horn on a car (usually done by pressing on a large button in the centre of the steering wheel); to blow the horn of a car; to sound the horn.

randiness.description: (As a Noun) An eagerness to have sex or sexual intercourse or the fact of being easily sexually aroused. English = sexual excitement. Informal English = randiness, horniness.; (As a Noun) The moment of greatest pleasure and excitement during sexual activity. English = orgasm.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be eager to have sex or sexual intercourse or to be easily sexually aroused. English = (be) sexually excited. Informal English = (be) randy, (be) horny.

horror.description: (As a Noun) A film or story which is very frightening and usually about ghosts, witches, or imaginary monsters. English = horror film, horror story.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a film or story, to be very frightening and usually about ghosts, witches, or imaginary monsters.

hors%20d'ouvres.description: (General Definition) Small items are placed on a circular object, such as food portions on a plate.; (As a Noun) Small servings of food that may be served prior to the course of a meal, typically eaten in one bite/mouthful. English = canapes; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for CANAPES (but some signers represent this visually using these depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for CANAPES used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

horse.description: (As a Noun) A large animal which you can ride. They are often used for transport or for pulling ploughs and carts. English = horse.; (As a Noun) The activity of riding horses, or any large animal. English = horse riding.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be sitting on a horse, or any large animal. English = straddle.

horse%20race.description: (As a Noun) Races run between horses in which people place bets on the horse they think will win. English = horse racing.; (As a Noun) A race run between horses. English = horse race.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To race horses.

horse%20racing.description: (As a Noun) Races run between horses in which people place bets on the horse they think will win. English = horse racing.; (As a Noun) A race run between horses. English = horse race.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To race horses.

horse%20riding.description: (As a Noun) A large animal which you can ride. They are often used for transport or for pulling ploughs and carts. English = horse.; (As a Noun) The activity of riding horses, or any large animal. English = horse riding.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be sitting on a horse, or any large animal. English = straddle.

hose.description: (General Definition) The action of holding something of small size and moving it side-to-side or up-and-down, or any action or any thing directly or indirectly associated with this, such as using a hose, or a cane.; (As a Noun) (When used for the first time in a conversation and you want or need to be more precise, this sign is usually preceded or followed by the sign for WATER.) A long, flexible pipe made of rubber or plastic, along which water is carried. English = hose.; (As a Noun) (When used for the first time in a conversation and you want or need to be more precise, this sign is usually preceded or followed by the sign for WATER or GARDEN.) The action of using a hose to spread water all over a garden or lawn. English = watering, hosing.

hospitality.description: (As a Noun) Friendly, welcoming behaviour towards guests or strangers. English = hospitality.; (As a Noun) The sector of the economy which deals with tourism, accommodation and entertainment. English = hospitality industry.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be friendly and welcoming to guests or strangers. English = (be) hospitable.

hospital.description: (As a Noun) A place where sick people are looked after by doctors and nurses. English = hospital.

hospitalise.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To put someone in hospital because they are sick, especially in an emergency. English = hospitalise.

hour.description: (As a Noun) One of the twenty-four equal parts that a day is divided into. It is made up of sixty minutes. English = hour.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of an event or activity, to last for an hour or to take an hour to complete.

hour%20after%20hour.description: (As a Noun) Time that you spend at your job in addition to your normal working hours. English = overtime.; (As Modifier) Used after a verb (action) sign to mean the action takes place over several hours making it take longer than is usual. Idiomatic English = hour by hour, round the clock, around the clock.; (As Modifier) Used after the sign work to mean the work is in addition to your normal working hours. English = overtime.

way.description: (As a Noun) The route or stages by which something is done; how something is done. English = way, manner, method.; (As Question) Used at the beginning, end or at both the beginning and the end of a sentence to ask for information about the route, stages or technique by which something is done. English = how.

how%20are%20you.description: (As a Noun) The state in which you are fit and well and not ill. English = health.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be not suffering from any illness. English = (be) well, (be) healthy.; (Interactive) Used alone with a questioning look to greet someone. English = 'How are you?'

how%20many.description: (As a Noun) An amount of something that you can measure or count. English = quantity, number.; (As a Noun) Any of the signs such as 'two', 'nine' or 'eleven', or the symbols such as 1, 2, or 47. You use them to say how many things you are referring to or where something comes in a series. English = number.; (As a Noun) A number a teacher or examiner gives your work to indicate how good or bad your work is. English = mark.

how%20much.description: (As a Noun) The amount of money you must pay in order to buy something. English = price, cost.; (As a Noun) The amount of money you must pay in order to buy something, especially a service rather than a thing. English = charge.; (As Question) Used to ask the amount of money that must be paid in order to buy something. English = How much?

how%20old.description: (As a Noun) The number of years that you have lived. English = age.; (As Modifier) Used next to a number sign to mean someone has that particular number of years in age. English = (be) aged.; (As Question) Used to ask the number of years a person has lived. English = how old, what age.

human.description: (As a Noun) A person. English = human.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Relating to or concerning people. English = (be) human.

humid.description: (As a Noun) The salty, colourless liquid which comes through your skin when you are hot, ill, or afraid. English = sweat, perspiration.; (As a Noun) Of the weather or air in a room, the quality of being hot. English = heat.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have sweat come through your skin because your are hot, ill, or afraid. English = sweat, perspire.

humiliation.description: (As a Noun) The extreme embarrassment that you feel when you are made to appear helpless or stupid. English = humiliation.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be made to feel extreme embarrassment and to feel ashamed, helpless, or stupid. English = (be) humiliated, (be) mortified. Idiomatic English = die of embarrassment.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In an argument or conflict, to retreat and admit that you have made a mistake with some loss of face; to be proven wrong; to concede a point.

hundred%20(one%20hundred).description: (As a Noun) The number 100, between 99 and 101. English = one hundred..; (Note) Apologies for the temporary video. It will be replaced as soon as possible.

hundreds.description: (As a Noun) A number of things which is made up of many smaller groups of one hundred. English = hundreds.; (As a Noun) A very large number of something.

hunger.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To want to eat food. English = (be) hungry.

starvation.description: (As a Noun) Extreme suffering or death caused by lack of food. English = starvation.; (As a Noun) The desire to eat food. English = hunger.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To suffer greatly from a lack of food and sometimes die. English = starve, go hungry.

rifle.description: (As a Noun) A gun with a long barrel. English = rifle.; (As a Noun) The chasing and killing of wild animals with guns and rifles for food or as a sport. English = hunting.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To fire a rifle.

hurdles.description: (As a Noun) Fences that runners jump over in some races. English = hurdles.; (As a Noun) The sport in which runners jump over fences. English = hurdles.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to jump over a fence. English = hurdle.

hurry.description: (As a Noun) A condition in which there is not much time to do something or during which you do things very quickly. English = hurry, rush.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To do something quickly. English = hurry, rush.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make someone do something quickly. English = hurry someone, rush someone.

husband.description: (As a Noun) The man a woman is married to. English = husband.

speedboat.description: (As a Noun) A small boat that is propelled by an engine and can travel at high speed. English = speedboat.; (As a Noun) A boat which can travel above the surface of the water by resting on a pair of special fins. English = hydrofoil.

hypertension.description: (As a Noun) HYPERTENSION is a medical condition in which a person has very high blood pressure.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for HYPERTENSION. If you know a sign for HYPERTENSION used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

hypocrite.description: (As a Noun) A person who pretends to have beliefs, principles, or feelings that they do not really have. Used to show disapproval. English = hypocrite.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say or pretend you have beliefs, principles, or feelings that you do not really have. English = (be) a hypocrite, (be) hypocritical. Idiomatic English = (be) two faced.

hypodermic%20needle.description: (As a Noun) A small tube with a plunger and a fine hollow needle or pointed end. It is used for putting liquids into something and taking them out, for example drugs into a person's body or for taking blood samples from them. English = syringe, hypodermic needle.; (As a Noun) The act of using a syringe to put liquids into a person's body. English = injection. Informal English = jab.; (As a Noun) The act of injecting someone with a weak form of a disease as a way of protecting them from it. English = immunisation, inoculation, vaccination.

hyponatremia.description: (As a Noun) Hyponatremia occurs when a person has an  abnormally low concentration of sodium in the blood. Too little sodium can cause cells to malfunction and extremely low sodium can be fatal.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for HYPONATREMIA. If you know a sign for HYPONATREMIA used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

hypotenuse.description: (As a Noun) In geometry, the longest side of a right-angled triangle, opposite the right angle. English = hypotenuse.

hypothesis.description: (As a Noun) An idea which is suggested as a possible explanation for something, but which has not yet been proved to be correct, a formal word. English = hypothesis.

hysteria.description: (As a Noun) A person who is suffering from HYSTERIA is mentally disturbed, often as a result of shock.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for HYSTERIA. If you know a sign for HYSTERIA used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

me.description: (As a Pointing Sign) Used to refer to the signer by the signer. The sign is usually used immediately next to a verb and can mean the signer is involved in the action. English = I, me.; (Note) Often when signers recount an event or tell a story they sometimes briefly assume one of the roles of the characters in the story. When this happens the sign can mean 'me, as the character' (I.e., 'he' or 'she' in the story), rather than ‘me, the signer’ (thus ‘I/me’).

ice%20(apply%20icing).description: (As a Noun) A sweet substance made from powdered sugar that is used to cover cakes as a decoration. English = icing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cover a cake with icing. English = ice.

ice-cream.description: (As a Noun) A very cold, sweet-tasting food made from milk and cream. English = ice-cream.; (As a Noun) A serve of ice-cream on the end of a soft thin biscuit shaped like a cone. Australian English = ice-cream cone.; (As a Noun) A very cold, sweet-tasting food made from water and sugar. English = ice-block, icy-pole.

ice-cream%20cone.description: (As a Noun) A very cold, sweet-tasting food made from milk and cream. English = ice-cream.; (As a Noun) A serve of ice-cream on the end of a soft thin biscuit shaped like a cone. Australian English = ice-cream cone.; (As a Noun) A very cold, sweet-tasting food made from water and sugar. English = ice-block, icy-pole.

ice%20hockey.description: (As a Noun) A game played on ice by two teams. Each team tries to score goals by using long sticks to hit a small, flat object called the puck into a goal. English = ice hockey.

iceland.description: (As a Noun) A island nation in the middle of the North Atlantic ocean, called Iceland.

ice skates.description: (As a Noun) Shoes with a metal blade attached to them that you wear when you move about or slide on a surface covered with ice. English = ice skates.; (As a Noun) A sport in which you move or slide about on a flat surface covered in ice on special shoes with a metal blade attached to them. English = ice-skating.; (As a Noun) Shoes with small wheels on the bottom, in a line down the centre. English = roller blades.

ice%20skates.description: (As a Noun) Shoes with a metal blade attached to them that you wear when you move about or slide on a surface covered with ice. English = ice skates.; (As a Noun) A sport in which you move or slide about on a flat surface covered in ice on special shoes with a metal blade attached to them. English = ice-skating.; (As a Noun) Shoes with small wheels on the bottom, in a line down the centre. English = roller blades.

ice-skates.description: (As a Noun) Shoes with a metal bar attached to them that you wear when you skate on ice. English = ice-skates.

icing.description: (As a Noun) A sweet substance made from powdered sugar that is used to cover cakes as a decoration. English = icing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cover a cake with icing. English = ice.

iconic.description: (As a Noun) In linguistics, the name of a relationship between a word or a sign which is iconic. English = iconicity.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In linguistics, a relationship between a word or a sign and its meaning in which there is a similarity between the sound of the word or the shape of the sign and what it means, i.e., the word sounds like what it means or the sign looks like what it means. English = iconic.

iconicity.description: (As a Noun) The quality that symbols (especially signs in a sign language) can have whereby the symbol looks like or resembles the thing it stands for or means. English = iconicity.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a symbol (especially a sign in a sign language) to look like or resemble the thing it stands for or means. English = (be) iconic.

idea.description: (As a Noun) A plan, suggestion, or possible course of action which you form in your mind. English = idea.; (As a Noun) An idea or plan which is put forward, made known or told to someone for them to think about. English = suggestion.; (As a Noun) The above average ability to think, understand and learn ideas. English = intelligence.

idea%20(get%20idea).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To suddenly get a good or surprising idea about what to do or how to solve a problem.; (As Modifier) Used to introduce a sentence which contains a new or interesting idea or suggestion you have, especially one that has just suddenly come to you and which you think is quite good or appropriate. English = 'What about this...', 'I've got a great idea...

identify.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be able to prove or recognise something as being a certain person or thing. English = identify; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan definition for the English term IDENTIFY as it is used in an educational context, especially in instructions for assignments or exam questions.; (Note) There appear to be no commonly used Auslan sign associated with this term. If you know a sign for IDENTIFY that is used in this context by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

idiom.description: (As a Noun) A group of words which have a different meaning when used together from the one they would have if you took the meaning of each word individually. For example, in English “I’m pulling your leg” means “I am not serious, I am joking”. English = idiom; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan definition of the English term IDIOM.; (Note) There appear to be no Auslan signs associated with this term. If you know a sign for IDIOM that is used in this context by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

idiot.description: (As a Noun) A very stupid person. English = idiot.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very stupid. English = (be) idiotic.

idiotic.description: (As a Noun) Behaviour which is foolish, silly or strange. English = foolishness, idiocy, craziness, stupidity.; (As a Noun) A person whose behaviour is foolish, silly or strange. English = fool, idiot, madman. Informal English = loony.; (As a Noun) Something written or said that you think is untrue, foolish or stupid. English = nonsense.

idle%20(engine).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a machine, motor or computer program, to be switched on and operating nicely. English = run, (be) running.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a car engine, to be running but not to be doing any work, for example because the car is not moving. English = idle.

idleness.description: (As a Noun) The fact of not doing anything, especially when you should be doing something, especially working. English = idleness, loafing.; (As a Noun) A person who spends their time not working or not doing the things that they ought to be doing. English = loafer.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be not doing something, especially when you should be working. English = (be) idle, loaf.

worship.description: (As a Noun) The showing of respect and admiration for a god, especially by kneeling down or bowing down and praying to it. English = worship.; (As a Noun) A statue that is worshiped by people who believe that it is a god. English = idol.; (As a Noun) The practice of worshiping idols. English = idolatry.

if.description: (As Modifier) Used to join two clauses where the events or situation in the second clause might happen, might be happening, or might have happened. The event in the first clause happens only as a result of the second being or coming true. English = if.; (As Modifier) Used to introduce and event or situation that might happen, might be happening, or might have happened. The clause is then followed by something that will or might happen as a result. English = if.

ignite.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To start a fire intentionally, to set something on fire. English = ignite.

lock.description: (As a Noun) [Often the movement is repeated] the part of a door, a drawer, or a suitcase which you use to keep it shut and to prevent other people from opening it. To open it, you must first put a key in it and turn it. English = lock.; (As a Noun) [Often the movement is repeated] a specially shaped piece of metal which you place in a lock and turn in order to open or lock a door, a drawer, or a suitcase; a specially shaped piece of metal that you turn, for example to wind up a clock.  English = key.; (As a Noun) [Often the movement is repeated] the keyhole in the dashboard of a car in which you insert a key in order to start the engine. English = ignition.

ignition%20(car).description: (General Definition) The action of holding something with one hand and turning something with the other hand, such as the steering wheel and ignition of a car, or any thing or any action which can be associated with this in a given context.; (As a Noun) The mechanism in an internal combustion engine of a vehicle that ignites (starts) the engine using a key or a switch. English = ignition.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To ignite (start) the internal combustion engine of a vehicle using a key or a switch.

ignoramus.description: (As a Noun) A person who is very stupid and dull-witted. English = moron, ignoramus.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very stupid and dull-witted. Idiomatic English = (be) thick, (be) thick in the head.

clever (not clever).description: (As a Noun) The inability to understand or learn things easily or be unable to plans things well. English =  ignorance.; (As a Noun) The inability to use your experience and knowledge in order to make sensible decisions and judgements. English = inexperience, immaturity.; (As a Noun) A person who is unable to understand or learn things easily, or to use their experience and knowledge in order to make sensible decisions and judgements. English = simpleton, ignoramus.

sickness.description: (As a Noun) The experience of having a disease or a health problem which makes you unable to work or to live normally for a period of time, particularly if it happens suddenly or lasts for only a short time. English = sickness, illness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To suffer from a disease or a health problem which makes you unable to work or to live normally. Used particularly for problems which happen suddenly or last for only a short time. English = (be) sick, (be) ill.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To become or get sick, to fall ill.

light.description: (As a Noun) The degree to which something is not very heavy; the lack of weight of something.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To not weigh very much. English = (be) light.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be not very much in amount, degree, or intensity. English = (be) light.

illustrate.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) In education, to show what something is like, or to show that something is true, by quoting specific examples or statistics or possibly the drawing of maps, graphs, sketches etc. English = illustrate; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term ILLUSTRATE as it is used in an educational or academic context, especially in instructions for assignments or for exam questions.

immune%20system.description: (As a Noun) Your IMMUNE SYSTEM consists of all the cells and processes in your body which protect you from illness and infection.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for IMMUNE SYSTEM. If you know a sign for IMMUNE SYSTEM used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

impact.description: (As a Noun) The great effect of a situation or a person on a person. English = impact.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Noun) The action of once object hitting another. English = impact.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a great effect on a situation or person. English = impact on.

matter (problem).description: (As a Noun) An event or situation which you have to deal with, especially one that involves problems. English = matter, problem.; (As a Noun) Damage or weakness of the body, especially the sense organs, which means that a part of your body does not work properly and seriously affects your life. English = impairment.; (As a Noun) An action or opinion that is wrong, or that is not what you intended to do. English = mistake, error.

build up.description: (As a Noun) The gradual increase, growth or improvement in something, especially after it had been damaged. English = build up.; (As a Noun) The rebuilding of something that has been destroyed or badly damaged. English = reconstruction.; (As a Noun) The carrying out of a plan, system or policy. English = implementation.

rudeness.description: (As a Noun) Behaviour that is not polite. English = rudeness, impoliteness.; (As a Noun) Language and behaviour that are likely to embarrass or offend people because they relate to sex or other bodily functions. English = rudeness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To behave in a way that is not polite. English = (be) rude, (be) impolite.

importance.description: (As a Noun) The quality of being important, necessary or significant in a particular situation. English = importance.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very significant, valuable, or necessary. English = (be) important, (be) vital.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of something, to be more important or better than other things of its kind. English = (be) special, (be) exceptional, (be) outstanding.

impossible.description: (As a Noun) The situation in which something cannot be done, cannot happen, or cannot be believed. English = impossibility.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be something that cannot be done, cannot happen, or cannot be believed. English = 'Impossible', 'No way!', 'Incredible!', and so on.

poverty.description: (As a Noun) The state of being extremely poor. English = poverty.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have very little money and few possessions. English = (be) poor, (be) impoverished.

get better.description: (As a Noun) The act of doing something, or causing it to happen, especially after a lot of effort. English = success.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of things or people, to get better over time. English = get better, improve.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To manage to do something you have been trying to do, especially after a lot of effort. English = succeed, (be) successful.

suspicion.description: (As a Noun) The feeling that you do not trust someone or that something is wrong in some way; a feeling that something is probably true (especially if it involves the guilt of someone) or is likely to happen. English = suspicion.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To lack trust in someone or to think that something is wrong in some way; to feel that something is probably true (especially someone's guilt) or is likely to happen. English = suspect, (be) suspicious of.

in%20addition.description: (As a Noun) The second of two things; the second of a pair.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning of a signed sentence or next to a verb (action) sign to mean you want to say one more thing (which you then say) or that the action is the second of a pair of actions. English = also, in addition.

unusual.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To happen not very often, or to look quite different from everyday or normal things. English = (be) unusual, (be) uncommon.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be surprising because you did not think it would happen. English = (be) unexpected.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be not suitable or right for a particular occasion or use. English = (be) inappropriate.

in%20case.description: (As Modifier) Used in a phrase to say that you have something or are doing something because a particular thing might happen or might have happened. English = in case.; (As Modifier) Used to join two phrases in which the second expresses something you think might happen and explains why you do the action in the first. English = in case.

incest.description: (As a Noun) INCEST is the crime of two members of the same family having sexual intercourse, for example a father and daughter, or a brother and sister.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for INCEST. If you know a sign for INCEST used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

inch.description: (As a Noun) A unit for measuring length, approximately equal to 2.54 centimetres. There are twelve of these in a foot. English = inch.

involve.description: (As a Noun) The act of taking part in something. English = inclusion, incorporation.; (As a Noun) The act of making a person or thing part of a group or collection. English = inclusion.

cross out.description: (As a Noun) A mark on a surface in the shape of a cross.; (As a Noun) A line or cross drawn through the words on a page, usually because they are wrong. incredible%20(exclamation).description: (Interactive) Used alone in response to your addressee's comments to mean you are amazed and disbelieving of what you have been told. English = 'Incredible!', 'Amazing!', 'Well, I'll be damned!', and so on.; (Interactive) Used alone in response to your addressee's comments to mean you are amazed at what has been said or done and that you think it stupid or foolish. English = 'Ridiculous!', 'Really?!', 'How could you (do that)?!', 'How dare you (do that)?!'

incubation.description: (As a Noun) INCUBATION refers to the process of a germ developing in the body before it starts to make you feel ill.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for INCUBATION. English = independence.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To exist, happen, or act separately from other people, groups, or things; (of countries), to be not ruled by other countries and to have their own government and laws. English = (be) independent.; (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb to mean the action is done by someone or something separately from other people, groups, or things. English = independently.

individual.description: (As a Noun) A person considered separately from everyone else; or a person's basic personality and nature. English = individual; self.; (As a Noun) A person who likes to do things in their own way; a person who likes to be alone. independent%20variable%20(mathematics)..description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of more than one thing or person, to be only one and not more of its kind; to be on its own and separate from other things. india.description: (As a Noun) A country in South Asia, between Pakistan and Bangladesh. English = India.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To come from or relate to India. English = (be) Indian.

indian%20(amerindian).description: (As a Noun) A member of one of the tribes of people who were living in North America when Europeans arrived there. Informal English = Indian, red Indian. English = Native American. Formal English = Amerindian.

indicators.description: (As a Noun) The lights at the front and back of a car which are used to show that the car is turning or is about to turn left or right. individually.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of more than one thing or person, to be only one and not more of its kind; to be on its own and separate from other things. English = (be) single.; (As Modifier) Used next to a verb sign to mean the action is done by each of several people on its own and separately from other actions. English = singly, only, alone.

indonesia.description: (As a Noun) A country in South-East Asia, north of Australia and south of Malaysia. English = Indonesia.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To come from or relate to Indonesia. English = (be) Indonesian.

inequality%20(mathematics).description: (As a Noun) In mathematics, the relation between two expressions that are not equal, represented by the symbols ≠ 'not equal to', > 'greater than', or < 'less than'. English = inequality.

innocent (inexperienced).description: (As a Noun) A person who has no experience or knowledge of the more complex or unpleasant aspects of life. in%20front%20of.description: (As a Noun) The part of something that faces you or faces forward, or that you normally see or use. innocent%20(inexperienced).description: (As a Noun) A person who has no experience or knowledge of the more complex or unpleasant aspects of life. insert%20(coin).description: (General Definition) The action of inserting something small into a space or slot, such as a coin into a pay phone or into  a machine in a laundromat, or any action or any thing directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a vending machine.; (As a Noun) A machine from which you can get things such as cigarettes, chocolate, or coffee by putting in money and pressing a button. integral%20(symbol).description: (As a Noun) In mathematics, a symbol (written ∫ ) which is used to represent integrals.; (As a Noun) In mathematics, a mathematical object that assigns numbers to functions in a way that describes displacement, area, volume and other related concepts. interrogation%20mark.description: (As a Noun) A special punctuation mark which is put at the end of a written sentence. English = question mark, interrogation mark.; (As a Noun) Something you check by asking about it because you are no sure that it is correct. English = query.; (Interactive) Used alone in response to your own or your addressee's previous comment to mean you wonder why such and such is the case. English = 'I wonder why?', 'Why's that?', and so on.

intersectionality.description: (As a Noun) The interconnected nature of social categorizations such as race, class, and gender as they apply to a given individual or group. English = intersectionality.

interview.description: (As a Noun) A meeting at which you ask someone else a lot of questions and they give you lots of answers. English = interview.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To ask someone a lot of questions and to get lots of answers back. English = interview.

interviewer.description: (General Definition) To hold something (eg, an ice-cream cone, a microphone) near your mouth and move it to and fro towards the person you are talking to, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this kind of action, especially interviewing or reporting.; (As a Noun) A news interview made by using a microphone, especially one made by a television news journalist.; (As a Noun) A person whose job is to interview people using a microphone for television news. English = interviewer, reporter.

in%20the%20front.description: (As a Noun) The part of something that faces you or faces forward, or that you normally see or use. English = front.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be located in that part of a thing (classroom, theatre, car, etc) which is as far as you can go and still face the direction in which most people normally sit or in which the thing normally moves. English = (be) in the front.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a difficult situation or something unpleasant, to not avoid it but to accept it and try to cope with it. English = face, front up to.

narrow-mindedness.description: (As a Noun) The condition of being unwilling to consider new ideas or other people's opinions. English = narrow-mindedness, small-mindedness.; (As a Noun) The disapproval of behaviour and opinions which are different from your own. English = intolerance.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be unwilling to consider new ideas or other people's opinions. English = (be) narrow-minded, (be) small-minded.

fascination.description: (As a Noun) A very strong and powerful interest in something that takes all your attention and makes you think and wonder. English = fascination.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a very strong and powerful interest in something that takes all your attention and makes you think and wonder. English = (be) fascinated by, (be) intrigued by.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make someone feel a very strong and powerful interest in something by taking all their attention and making them think and wonder. English = fascinate, intrigue.

introduction.description: (As a Noun) The act of telling two people each other's name and maybe a little bit about each other so that they can get to know each other. English = introduction.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To tell two people who have not met before each other's name and a maybe little bit about each other so that they may get to know each other. English = introduce.

intuition.description: (As a Noun) The feeling that something is true or exists although you have no evidence or proof of it. English = intuition.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To guess something by using your feelings, rather than your knowledge. English = sense. Formal English = intuit.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be an idea or feeling that something is true or exists which you have without any evidence or proof of it, but just from your feelings. English = (be) intuitive.

inverse%20(mathematics).description: (As a Noun) A change from one thing to another thing, especially its opposite. English = switch, changeover, conversion, inversion.; (As a Noun) A change back to something else that was the case before. English = reversion.; (As a Noun) In mathematics, a reciprocal quantity, mathematical expression, geometric figure, etc. which is the result of inversion. English = inverse.

inverted%20commas.description: (As a Noun) A sentence or phrase from a book, film, poem, song, or play. English = quote, quotation.; (As a Noun) Punctuation marks that are used to show where something someone has said or a quotation begins and ends. English = quotation marks, inverted commas.; (As a Noun) The thing, person, or idea that is being discussed or written about. English = topic.

undetectable.description: (As a Noun) The situation in which a thing or a person cannot be found and nobody knows where they have gone or where they have been taken to. English = disappearance.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a thing or person, to be unable to be seen because it (or he or she) has gone away or been taken away unexpectedly or has been lost. English = disappear, (be) missing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a thing or person, to be unable to be seen because it has gone away, is hidden, or is invisible. English = (be) undetectable, (be) invisible.

invitation.description: (As a Noun) A written, spoken or signed request to some to an event such as a party, a meal, or a meeting. English = invitation.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To ask someone to come to an occasion, such as a party or a meal. English = invite.

invite%20into.description: (As a Noun) A person who works in a cinema or theatre who shows people where to sit. English = usher (male or female), usherette (female only).; (As a Noun) Someone who is staying in your home or is at an occasion because you have invited them. English = guest.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To politely show someone where they should go often with a wave of the hand and letting them walk slightly in front of you. English = usher.

in%20vitro%20fertilisation.description: (As a Noun) IVF is a method of helping a woman to have a baby by fertilizing an egg outside her body. IVF is an abbreviation for `in vitro fertilization'.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for IVF. If you know a sign for IVF used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

invoice.description: (As a Noun) An INVOICE is a document that lists goods that have been supplied or services that have been done, and says how much money you owe for them.; (Note) Suggested sign #1×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (Note) Suggested sign #2×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

text-message.description: (As a Noun) An electronic message you send via a smart phone.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To send someone a text message via a smart phone. English = text, sms.

ireland.description: (As a Noun) An island country off the west coast of Great Britain. English = Ireland.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To come from or relate to Ireland. English = (be) Irish.

iron.description: (As a Noun) An electrical device which a handle and a heated flat metal base. You rub it over clothes to remove creases. English = iron.; (As a Noun) The activity of using a hot iron to remove creases from clothes. English = ironing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use an iron to remove creases from clothes. English = iron.

irritated.description: (As a Noun) The feeling you have if you are slightly angry because something gives you problems or difficulties. English = irritation, frustration.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be annoyed or frustrated. English = (be) irritated, (be) frustrated.

muslim.description: (As a Noun) A person who believes in Islam and lives according to its rules. English = Muslim, Moslem.; (As a Noun) The religion of the Muslims, which teaches that there is only one God and that Mohammed is His prophet. English = Islam.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To relate to Islam. English = (be) Muslim, (be) Moslem, (be) Islamic.

island.description: (As a Noun) A piece of land that is completely surrounded by water. English = island.; (As a Noun) A well-defined and relatively small place where something takes place. English = locale.

isolated.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to be alone because some aspect of their behaviour or character makes people keep their distance or remain aloof. English = (be) shunned, (be) isolated.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of people in general, to keep away from or avoid someone who is unpopular because of something unpleasant in their behaviour or character. English = shun.

isolate%20(home%20isolate).description: (As a Noun) With reference to infectious diseases, especially COVID-19, the period of time a regulation or law which obliges anyone who has the infection or is a near- or direct-contact to isolate at home to avoid infecting others. English = home isolation, self-isolation, quarantine.; (As a Verb or Adjective) With reference to infectious diseases, especially COVID-19, to stay at home for a  period of time to avoid infecting others because a regulation or law obliges you to do so. English = home isolate, self-isolate, quarantine.; (Note) Suggested sign #1×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

isolate%20(self-isolate).description: (As a Noun) With reference to infectious diseases, especially COVID-19, the period of time a regulation or law which obliges anyone who has the infection or is a near- or direct-contact to isolate at home to avoid infecting others. English = home isolation, self-isolation, quarantine.; (As a Verb or Adjective) With reference to infectious diseases, especially COVID-19, to stay at home for a  period of time to avoid infecting others because a regulation or law obliges you to do so. English = home isolate, self-isolate, quarantine.; (Note) Suggested sign #1×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

isolation%20(home%20isolation).description: (As a Noun) With reference to infectious diseases, especially COVID-19, the period of time a regulation or law which obliges anyone who has the infection or is a near- or direct-contact to isolate at home to avoid infecting others. English = home isolation, self-isolation, quarantine.; (As a Verb or Adjective) With reference to infectious diseases, especially COVID-19, to stay at home for a  period of time to avoid infecting others because a regulation or law obliges you to do so. English = home isolate, self-isolate, quarantine.; (Note) Suggested sign #1×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

isolation%20(self-isolation).description: (As a Noun) With reference to infectious diseases, especially COVID-19, the period of time a regulation or law which obliges anyone who has the infection or is a near- or direct-contact to isolate at home to avoid infecting others. English = home isolation, self-isolation, quarantine.; (As a Verb or Adjective) With reference to infectious diseases, especially COVID-19, to stay at home for a  period of time to avoid infecting others because a regulation or law obliges you to do so. English = home isolate, self-isolate, quarantine.; (Note) Suggested sign #1×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

jew.description: (As a Noun) A person who believes in and practises the religion of Judaism. English = Jew.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To relate to Judaism. English = (be) Jewish.; (Note) As with many signs, there are several explanations for the origins of this sign without there being definitive evidence on the matter. However, because this sign has possibly evolved from another sign for 'Jew' which has negative stereotypic associations—even though some signers would be unaware of this—avoid this sign and use the other one that matches the keyword ‘Jew’ in this dictionary which is described as preferred.

problem.description: (As a Noun) Something or a situation which is unsatisfactory and causes difficulties. English = problem.; (As a Noun) Something which causes difficulties or problems in an intrusive way or in a way which makes you slightly angry, or is a difficulty or problem in itself. English = trouble, hassle, bother, irritation, nuisance, annoyance.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cause or give difficulties because it is unsatisfactory in some way. English = problem.

italy.description: (As a Noun) A country in southern Europe. English = Italy.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be from or relate to Italy. English = (be) Italian.

itch.description: (As a Noun) An unpleasant feeling on your skin that makes you want to move your fingernails across it. English = itch.; (As a Noun) The act of moving your fingernails across an itchy spot on your skin. English = scratch.; (As a Noun) An itchy area of red spots that appear on your skin when you are ill or have an allergy. English = rash.

it%20(right%20here).description: (As a Pointing Sign) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence or next to a verb to refer to the place where the signer is now. English = here.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used alone or next to a noun to refer to a person or thing which has been mentioned already in a conversation and is close in time, importance or relevance to the signer. English = this.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used immediately before or after a verb sign, to mean that something does the action of the verb, or it is affected by the action of the verb. English = it.

ivf%20(in%20vitro%20fertilisation).description: (As a Noun) IVF is a method of helping a woman to have a baby by fertilizing an egg outside her body. IVF is an abbreviation for `in vitro fertilization'.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for IVF. If you know a sign for IVF used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

j.description: (As a Noun) The letter J in the one-handed manual alphabets.

poke.description: (As a Noun) A short sharp movement with your finger into the shoulder or upper part of the torso of someone. English = prod, jab, poke.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make quick pushing movements with your finger into the shoulder or upper part of the torso of someone, to get their attention or to aggressively make a point. You use this sign to mean the person who does it is rude and impolite.; (As a Verb or Adjective) English = poke, prod, jab (in the shoulder).

jack.description: (General Definition) The action of holding onto a bar or pole-like object, which is more or less horizontal, such as the arm of a water pump, and pushing it repeatedly up and down, or any action or any thing directly or indirectly related to this, especially a car jack.; (As a Noun) A mechanical device that is used to lift a heavy object, especially a car, off the ground. English = jack.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To lift a heavy object, especially a car, off the ground by using a special mechanical device. English = jack up.

coat (clothing).description: (As a Noun) A piece of clothing with long sleeves which you wear over your other clothes when you go outside. English = coat.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put on or wear a coat or jacket.

jack%20up.description: (General Definition) The action of holding onto a bar or pole-like object, which is more or less horizontal, such as the arm of a water pump, and pushing it repeatedly up and down, or any action or any thing directly or indirectly related to this, especially a car jack.; (As a Noun) A mechanical device that is used to lift a heavy object, especially a car, off the ground. English = jack.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To lift a heavy object, especially a car, off the ground by using a special mechanical device. English = jack up.

jam.description: (As a Noun) A food that is made by cooking fruit with sugar. Usually you spread it on bread or toast. English = jam.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To take jam out from a container using a spoon or other small utensil.

japan.description: (As a Noun) An island nation in North East Asia. English = Japan.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be from or relate to Japan. English = (be) Japanese.

top (lid).description: (As a Noun) A flat round covering to a container. English = top, cap, lid.; (As a Noun) A glass container with a cap that is used for storing food such as jam. English = jar.

jaundice.description: (As a Noun) JAUNDICE is an illness that makes your skin and eyes become yellow.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for JAUNDICE. If you know a sign for JAUNDICE used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

spear.description: (As a Noun) A weapon consisting of a long pole with a sharp point. English = spear.; (As a Noun) A long spear which is used in sports competitions. English = javelin.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To throw a spear, to spear.

jaws.description: (As a Noun) The large mouth of a large and often dangerous animal with large and sharp teeth. English = jaws.; (As a Noun) A large reptile with a long body and large jaws. It lives in rivers and eats meat. English = crocodile, alligator.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of an animal, to open and close its jaws or to bite with its jaws.

jeans.description: (As a Noun) Casual trousers that are usually made out of strong blue denim. English = jeans.

jelly.description: (As a Noun) A clear food made from gelatine, which is usually sweetened, flavoured with fruit juices, and eaten as a dessert. English = jelly.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To shake or tremble, especially of a substance like jelly. English = quiver.

jellyfish.description: (As a Noun) A creature that lives in the sea and has a body that looks like clear jelly. Some of them can sting you and most of them move by pulsating their mushroom shaped body. English = jellyfish.; (As a Noun) A sea creature with a long soft body and many tentacles. English = squid.

jesus.description: (As a Noun) The man who Christians believe was the son of God and whose teachings are the basis of Christianity, called Jesus.

jigsaw.description: (As a Noun) A game using a picture on cardboard or wood that has been cut up into odd shapes. You have to make the picture again by putting the pieces together correctly. English = jigsaw, jigsaw puzzle.

jigsaw%20puzzle.description: (As a Noun) A game using a picture on cardboard or wood that has been cut up into odd shapes. You have to make the picture again by putting the pieces together correctly. English = jigsaw, jigsaw puzzle.

jockey.description: (As a Noun) A person who rides horses in a race. English = jockey.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To hit an animal, especially a horse, with a piece of leather or rope fastened to a handle to make it work harder or run faster. English = whip.

join%20(enlist).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To become a member of an organisation, especially the army. English = join, enlist.

joint%20(marijuana).description: (As a Noun) A type of drug which is smoked in cigarettes and which is illegal in most countries. English = marijuana. Informal English = pot, grass, weed, dope.; (As a Noun) A cigarette made of marijuana. Informal English = joint.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put a marijuana cigarette in your mouth, suck the smoke into your lungs and blow it out again. English = smoke marijuana, smoke a marijuana cigarette. Informal English = smoke dope, smoke pot, smoke a joint.

magazine.description: (As a Noun) A publication with a paper cover which is issued regularly, usually weekly or monthly, and which contains articles, stories, photographs and advertisements. English = magazine.

journey.description: (General Definition) Of any two things, for one or both to go around or circle the other as both of them move in the same overall direction.; (As a Noun) A journey or travelling about which is relaxed, if not aimless. English = travels, wandering, roaming.; (As a Noun) The act of travelling from one place to another. English = journey.

joy.description: (As a Noun) A feeling of great happiness. English = joy.

judge.description: (As a Noun) The person in a court of law who decides how the law should be applied to people, for example how criminals should be punished. English = judge.; (As a Noun) A place where legal matters are decided by a judge and jury or by a magistrate. English = court.; (As a Noun) A mass of false hair which a judge wears on his or her head.

pourer.description: (General Definition) The action of holding onto something, especially something with a handle, and turning it to one side so that its contents flow out, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a kettle or teapot.; (As a Noun) A container with a handle that is used for holding liquids or other substances before you pour the contents into other containers or over other surfaces. English = pourer, jug, pitcher.; (As a Noun) A covered round container that you use for boiling water. It has a handle on top and a spout for pouring. English = kettle.

juggler.description: (As a Noun) Someone who juggles things in order to entertain people. English = juggler.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To throw things into the air, catching each one and throwing it up again so that there are several of them in the air at the same time. English = juggle.

juice.description: (As a Noun) A liquid that can be obtained from a fruit, such as an orange. English = juice.; (As a Noun) A special device with a raised centre and fluted sides on which you turn a piece of fruit to get the juice out of it. English = juicer, orange squeezer.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To squeeze the juice out of a piece of fruit by turning it on a juicer or squeezer.

julienne.description: (As a Noun) Food that has been cut into short, thin strips. English = julienne.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cut food into short, thin strips. English = (to) julienne.

jump.description: (As a Noun) The action of pushing your feet against the ground and going into the air. English = jump.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To push your feet against the ground and go into the air. English = jump, jump up.

jumper.description: (As a Noun) A piece of clothing made of knitted wool, that covers the upper part of your body and your arms and does not open at the front. Australian English = jumper. British English = pullover. American English = sweater.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put on or wear a jumper, pullover or sweater.

jumper%20leads.description: (As a Noun) Two thick wires with clamps at each end that can be used when a car will not start because its battery does not have enough power. They are used to connect the battery to the battery of another car. English = jumper leads.; (As a Noun) A device that produces electricity in a car. English = car battery.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Verb or Adjective) To attach jumper leads to a car battery.

jump%20off.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To push your feet against the ground and go into the air from and off an object. English = jump off.

jump%20up.description: (As a Noun) The action of pushing your feet against the ground and going into the air. English = jump.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To push your feet against the ground and go into the air. English = jump, jump up.

jungle.description: (As a Noun) A forest in a hot country where tall trees and other plants grow very closely together. English = jungle.

justify.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To show that an action or decision is reasonable or necessary. English = justify; (Note) The signer in the video is giving a definition in Auslan for the English term JUSTIFY. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for JUSTIFY (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for JUSTIFY used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

just%20in%20case.description: (As Modifier) Used in a phrase to say that you have something or are doing something because a particular thing might happen or might have happened. English = in case.; (As Modifier) Used to join two phrases in which the second expresses something you think might happen and explains why you do the action in the first. English = in case.

k.description: (As a Noun) The letter K in the two-handed manual alphabet.

kangaroo.description: (As a Noun) A large Australian animal which moves by jumping on its back legs. Female ones carry their babies in a pouch on their stomachs. English = kangaroo.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To hop like a kangaroo.

karate.description: (As a Noun) A sport in which people fight using their hands, elbows, feet, and legs. English = karate.

keen%20on.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of someone or something, to be very interesting or attractive so that you cannot stop looking at them.

keen%20on%20(not%20keen%20on).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To not desire something (or no longer find something desirable) because it has too much of some quality. English = (be) not keen on.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of something, to have too much of some quality so that it is not desirable or is no longer desirable. English = (be) disagreeable.; (As Modifier) Used before some noun signs to mean there is a lot or too much of that thing.

saving.description: (As a Noun) The act of collecting money by not spending it, or the money itself. English = saving, savings.; (As a Noun) The act of causing something to remain in the same state or place; the act of continuing to have something. English = retention, keeping.; (As a Noun) The helping of someone avoid harm or escape from a dangerous or unpleasant situation. English = rescue.

keep%20away%20from.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To keep away from something. English = avoid.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To keep something away from you; to keep something at bay.

keeping.description: (As a Noun) The act of causing someone or something to remain in a particular state or place; having something in a particular state or place so that you can use it whenever you want it; not giving something away. English = keeping, retaining, retention.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cause someone or something to remain in a particular state or place; to have something in a particular state or place so that you can use it whenever you want it; to not give something away. English = keep, retain.

keep%20out%20of.description: (General Definition) Some kind of vertical surface or line of things in front of and to the sides of you or the person, place or thing you represent, such as a barrier or fence, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To resolve that you will no longer consider or talk about someone else's concerns or affairs because you consider it to be none of your business.; (Interactive) Used alone to mean that something is none of one's business or concern and you have no intention of getting involved. English = 'I'm keeping right out of that. It's got nothing to do with me.'

keep%20quiet.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To promise to keep secret something that someone has just told you. Idiomatic English = seal one's lips.; (Interactive) You use this sign when you want some to keep secret something you have just told them, or when you mean that you will keep a secret that they have just told you. English = 'Not a word about this,' 'Keep quiet about this.'

safekeeping.description: (As a Noun) The act of keeping something safe so that it is not harmed or destroyed. English = safekeeping, protection.; (As a Noun) A small present that someone gives you so that you will not forget them. English = keepsake.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To not let someone have something that they want. English = withhold.

keep%20up%20with.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of two things or two quantities of something, to change position or size relative to each other even as both increase. English = neck and neck, keep up with.

scarf.description: (As a Noun) A piece of cloth that you wear round your head, usually to keep yourself warm. English = scarf, head scarf, kerchief.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put on or wear a head scarf or kerchief.

tomato sauce.description: (As a Noun) A thick, cold sauce made from tomatoes. English = tomato sauce. American English = ketchup.

spout.description: (As a Noun) A container for holding liquids that has a tube attached to it where the liquid comes out when you tip it sideways.; (As a Noun) The tube that liquid comes out of which is attached to a container. English = spout.; (As a Noun) A container with a lid, a handle, and a spout. You use it for making and serving tea. English = teapot.

kick%20football.description: (As a Noun) A team ball game played in Australia, called Australian rules football (AFL).; (As a Verb or Adjective) To prepare to kick or pass a ball in Australian rules football.

kick%20out.description: (As a Noun) A code of football which originated in Australia and which is most popular in the southern and western states of Australia. It has its origins in Gaelic football. English = Australian Rules. Informal English = Aussie Rules.; (As a Noun) Any game in which a ball is kicked around a field for most of the match. For example, Australian Rules, Rugby Union, Rugby League, Soccer, and Gridiron. English = football.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To play Australian Rules football.

kid.description: (As a Noun) A human being who is not yet an adult. English = child. Informal English = kid.

kidding.description: (Interactive) Used alone to tell your addressee that what has just happened is not to be taken seriously. English = 'Just kidding!'; (Interactive) Used alone to tell someone to be aware that what you are about to do to another person is just a joke and worth watching for its amusement value. English = 'Watch this...'.

kidneys.description: (As a Noun) Your KIDNEYS are the organs in your body that take waste matter from your blood and send it out of your body as urine.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for KIDNEY. If you know a sign for KIDNEY used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

kill.description: (As a Noun) The act of causing a living thing to die. English = killing.; (As a Noun) A person who has killed someone. English = killer.; (As a Noun) Anything that causes death to a person, animal or plant. English = killer.

kilogram.description: (As a Noun) A metric unit of weight that is equal to a thousand grams. Its abbreviation in English is 'kg'. English = kilogram.

kilometre.description: (As a Noun) A metric unit of distance that is a thousand metres. Its abbreviation in English is 'km'. English = kilometre, kilometer (US).

kilt.description: (As a Noun) A short pleated skirt that is sometimes worn by Scotsmen. They can also be worn by women and girls. English = kilt.

kindergarten.description: (As a Noun) A school for young children who are not old enough to go to a primary school. English = kindergarten.

kind%20(sort).description: (As a Noun) The sort of person that you usually like or are attracted to. English = type, kind, sort.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be the sort of person that you usually like or are attracted to. English = (be) your type.

monarch.description: (As a Noun) A member of a royal family who reigns over a country. English = monarch, sovereign.; (As a Noun) A male member of a royal family who reigns over a country. English = king.; (As a Noun) A female member of a royal family who reigns over a country. English = queen.

kiss.description: (As a Noun) The act of touching someone with your lips to show affection or to greet them. English = kiss.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To touch someone with your lips to show affection or to greet them. English = kiss.

maid.description: (As a Noun) A woman who works as in a hotel, boarding school or private house, cleaning, preparing and serving meals etc. English = maid, servant, kitchen-hand.; (As a Noun) A room that you use for cooking and for household jobs such as washing dishes. English = kitchen.; (As a Noun) The people who work for an organization or business. English = staff.

kitchen%20pass.description: (As a Noun) The area in a restaurant kitchen where finished dishes are passed from the chefs to the waiting staff. English = kitchen pass.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English keyword KITCHEN PASS. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for KITCHEN PASS (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic).  If you know a sign for KITCHEN PASS used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

kiwi.description: (As a Noun) A type of bird that lives in New Zealand. It cannot fly. English = kiwi.

underpants.description: (As a Noun) A piece of underwear which have two holes to put your legs through and elastic around the top. English = underpants, briefs; (women only) panties, knickers.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put on or pull on a pair of underpants.

knife.description: (As a Noun) An object you hold in your hand and use to cut things with. It consists of a sharp, flat piece of metal attached to a handle. English = knife (singular), knives (plural).; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cut food with a knife in order to eat it.

knitting.description: (As a Noun) The action or process of making something from wool or similar thread using special stick-like needles or a machine. English = knitting.; (As a Noun) The special stick-like needles used in knitting. English = knitting needles.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make something from wool or similar thread using special stick-like needles or a machine. English = knit.

knitting%20needles.description: (As a Noun) The action or process of making something from wool or similar thread using special stick-like needles or a machine. English = knitting.; (As a Noun) The special stick-like needles used in knitting. English = knitting needles.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make something from wool or similar thread using special stick-like needles or a machine. English = knit.

knock.description: (As a Noun) The sound of someone hitting a door, window or wall with the knuckles of their closed fist. English = knock, knocking, door knock.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To hit a door, window or a wall several times with the knuckles of your closed fist in order to attract someone's attention. English = knock, rap.

knockout.description: (As a Noun) In boxing, a blow or punch that makes one of the boxers fall to the floor and not be able to stand up before the referee has counted to ten. English = knockout.; (As a Noun) A competition in which the winner of each match goes on to the next round, until one competitor or team is the winner. English = knockout competition.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In boxing, to punch your opponent so that he falls to the floor and is not able to stand up before the referee has counted to ten. English = knockout.

knot.description: (As a Noun) A place in a piece of string, rope, or cloth where one end has been passed through a loop and pulled tight. You do this in order to join two things together or to keep something firmly in place. English = knot.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To tie a knot in a piece of string, rope, or cloth; to fasten something using a knot.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To fasten one thing to another, often using string or rope. English = tie, tie up.

knowledge.description: (As a Noun) Information and understanding about a subject, which someone has in their mind. English = knowledge.; (Interactive) Used alone in response to your addressee's comments or to interrupt your addressee to confirm understanding or to encourage them to continue. English = 'I know', 'Yeah!', 'Ugh huh', 'Hmmm' and so on.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning of a sentence to introduce a new topic of conversation.

know%20(already).description: (As a Noun) The condition of knowing something or someone already because you have met, seen or been told about them. English = familiarity.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To know something or someone already because you have met, seen or been told about them before. English = (be) familiar with.; (Interactive) Used alone in reply to someone who tells you something you know already, especially when you think they should know you know because it is old news.

know%20finish%20(been%20there,%20done%20.description: (Interactive) Used alone in response to a question as to whether you have done or experienced something, or met someone, to mean that you have and that it was not a pleasant or memorable experience. You are glad that it is in the past and behind you.; (Interactive) Used alone to mean that something unexpected or bad happened because of what you did and that you have learnt from this experience. Idiomatic English = "that'll teach me", "I've learnt my lesson!"

know%20(not%20know).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To have no information or incorrect information about something; to not have something correctly in your mind; to have heard nothing about something. English = not know.; (Interactive) Used alone to say you have no idea or knowledge about something. English = 'I know nothing!', 'It's got nothing to do with me!', 'Don't look at me!', etc.

know%20well.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To recognise someone or something or know about them well because you have seen, heard, or experienced them before. English = know well, (be) well-known, (be) familiar with.; (Interactive) Used alone in reply to someone who tells you something that is well-known to you already or mentions to you someone well-known to you as if you did not know them.

kookaburra.description: (As a Noun) A large Australian bird of the kingfisher family with a laughing, cackling call. English = kookaburra.

korea.description: (As a Noun) A country in North East Asia, between China and Japan. English = Korea.; (As a Noun) A person from the country in North East Asia, between China and Japan. English = Korean.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To come from or relate to Korea. English = (be) Korean.

l.description: (As a Noun) The letter L in the two-handed manual alphabet.

lac%20(local%20area%20coordination).description: (General Definition) Local Area Coordination (LAC) are local organisations working in partnership with the NDIA, to help participants, their families and carers access the NDIS. LACs will help participants write and manage their plans and also connect participants to mainstream services and local and community-based supports.
