English = 'It doesn't matter', 'No problems', 'Forget about it'; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of the first of two sign phrases to mean that what you say in the second phrase is surprising given the first phrase. English = despite, despite that.

matter%20(problem).description: (As a Noun) An event or situation which you have to deal with, especially one that involves problems. English = matter, problem.; (As a Noun) Damage or weakness of the body, especially the sense organs, which means that a part of your body does not work properly and seriously affects your life. English = impairment.; (As a Noun) An action or opinion that is wrong, or that is not what you intended to do. English = mistake, error.

mattress.description: (As a Noun) A large, flat cushion the same size as a bed, which is put on a bed to make it soft to lie on. English = mattress.

purple.description: (As a Noun) A colour that is between red and blue; a reddish-blue colour. English = purple.; (As a Noun) A colour that is between red and blue, but with more blue than red; a bluish purple. English = violet.; (As a Noun) A colour that is between red and blue, but which is more pale (ie lighter or whiter) than purple; a light purple. English = mauve.

may.description: (As a Noun) In mathematics, the extent to which an event is likely to occcur, measured by the ratio of the favourable cases to the whole number of cases possible. English = probability.; (As Modifier) Used to indicate that something is possible or may be true, but you are not certain; to indicate that you are making a rough guess at a number or quantity, rather than stating it exactly. English = perhaps, maybe.; (As Modifier) Used to link a number of alternatives, to give another alternative, or to introduce a comment which corrects or modifies something you have just said. English = or.

may%20not.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To not have the possibility, skill or permission to do something. English = (be) unable to.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be unlikely to be true or happen. English = (be) improbable.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be not easy to believe or to have little chance of being true, and therefore unlikely to be true or genuine. English = (be) implausible.

mean%20(average).description: (As a Noun) The condition in which something is the same over time. English = uniformity.; (As a Noun) A state in which everyone or everything behaves or looks the same as everyone or everything else. English = uniformity.; (As a Noun) Something which is the same for everyone or is considered to be the correct and acceptable form for everyone (especially regarding the words and signs of a language). English = standard.

sign language.description: (As a Noun) A language which is made and communicated by using visual-gestural signs. English = sign language, sign.; (As a Noun) The thing that a single unit of a language (word or sign) or a whole expression refers to or expresses. Often this 'thing' is just other words and signs, rather than something you can point at. English = meaning, significance.; (As a Noun) A single visual-gestural unit of a sign language. English = sign.

meaning%20(semantics).description: (As a Noun) The thing that a single unit of a language (word or sign) or a whole expression refers to or expresses. Often this 'thing' is just other words and signs, rather than something you can point at. English = meaning, significance.; (As a Noun) The study of the meaning of words, signs, and sentences. English = semantics.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a unit of language (word or sign) or a whole expression, to refer to a thing or idea or express something. English = mean. Formal English = signify.

meanness.description: (As a Noun) The unwillingness to spend much money or to use very much of a particular thing. English = meanness.; (As a Noun) A person who is very mean and enjoys saving money and hate spending it. English = miser.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be unwilling to spend much money or to use very much of a particular thing. English = (be) mean, (be) stingy

mean%20(signify).description: (As a Noun) A language which is made and communicated by using visual-gestural signs. English = sign language, sign.; (As a Noun) The thing that a single unit of a language (word or sign) or a whole expression refers to or expresses. Often this 'thing' is just other words and signs, rather than something you can point at. English = meaning, significance.; (As a Noun) A single visual-gestural unit of a sign language. English = sign.

mean%20(stingy).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to be very unwilling to spend money. English = (be) mean, (be) stingy. Formal English = (be) parsimonious

mean%20(unkind).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To deliberately cause people or animals pain or distress. English = (be) cruel, (be) mean.

measles.description: (As a Noun) An infectious disease that gives you red spots on your skin. English = measles.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have measles.

tape measure.description: (As a Noun) A strip of plastic or cloth with centimetres or inches marked on it. You use it for measuring things. English = tape measure.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To find out how big, long, wide or high something is using a tape-measure or other measuring device. English = measure.; (Note) The variant sign was created for the Australasian Signed English in the 1980s. It uses the letter M in the one-handed fingerspelling alphabet. It has been accepted and used as an Auslan sign by some deaf people, especially in education by teachers of the deaf, their students, and interpreters. The main sign and another sign listed in this dictionary are more commonly used for ‘measure’ in Auslan.

medal.description: (As a Noun) A small piece of metal with a design on it. It is given as an award for bravery or as a prize in sporting events.  English = medal.; (As a Noun) A round piece of metal which is worn as an ornament on a chain round a person's neck. English = medallion, pendant.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wear a medal, medallion or pendant.

mediation.description: (As a Noun) MEDIATION is a process where a neutral third person helps to resolve problem or disagreement.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term MEDIATION. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for MEDIATION (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for MEDIATION used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

meds.description: (As a Noun) A firm, specially shaped piece of cotton wool that a woman puts inside her vagina to absorb the blood when she has a period. English = tampon. (Former) English brand names = Meds, Modess.; (As a Noun) An absorbent pad worn by women to absorb the blood when she has a period. English = sanitary pad, sanitary napkin, sanitary towel.

melburnian.description: (As a Noun) The capital city of the Australian state of Victoria, called Melbourne.; (As a Noun) A person who comes from Melbourne. English = Melburnian, Melbournian.

melon.description: (As a Noun) A large juicy fruit which has a thick green or yellow skin. English = melon.; (As a Noun) A large round fruit which has a green skin and is pink and juicy inside with a lot of black seeds. English = watermelon.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To eat a piece of melon or watermelon.

remember.description: (As a Noun) The bringing back into your mind the thought or impression of something that happened in the past. English = remembrance, recollection.; (As a Noun) Your ability to remember things. English = memory, recall.; (As a Noun) Something that you remember about the past. English = memory.

memory.description: (As a Noun) The ability to remember things. (This sense is becoming obsolete and is used in this way mostly by older members of the deaf community.) English = memory.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To commit something to memory. English = memorise.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To bring something that has happened in the past back into your mind and think about it. (This sense is becoming obsolete and is used in this way mostly by older members of the deaf community.) English = remember.

meningitis.description: (As a Noun) MENINGITIS is a serious infectious illness which affects your brain and spinal cord.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for MENINGITIS. If you know a sign for MENINGITIS used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

menopause.description: (As a Noun) The MENOPAUSE is the time during which a woman gradually stops menstruating, usually when she is about fifty years old.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for MENOPAUSE. If you know a sign for MENOPAUSE used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

menstruation.description: (As a Noun) The period of time each month during which a fertile woman loses blood from her womb. English = menstruation, period.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To lose blood from your womb for a period of time each month as part of a natural cycle associated with sexual fertility. English = menstruate, have your periods.

mind.description: (As a Noun) Your ability to think, including all the thoughts that you have. English = mind.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be related to the processes of thinking or to intelligence, rather than to simple physical processes. English = (be) mental.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To talk or behave in a strange or foolish way because of stupidity, mental retardation or mental illness. English = (be) crazy, (be) silly, (be) mental.

mental%20disability.description: (As a Noun) A disability affecting the brain so that a person has a reduced capacity for such things as learning, receptive and expressive language, and independent living. English = mental disability, intellectual disability.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to have a disability affecting the brain so that he/she has a reduced intellectual capacity for such things as learning, receptive and expressive language, and independent living. English = mentally disabled, intellectually disabled.

mental%20health.description: (As a Noun) A person's condition with regard to their psychological and emotional well-being. English = mental health.

mental%20illness.description: (As a Noun) A condition or illness which causes serious disorder in a person's behaviour or thinking. English = mental illness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a condition or illness which causes serious disorder in a person's behaviour or thinking. English = (be) mentally ill.

mentally%20disabled.description: (As a Noun) A disability affecting the brain so that a person has a reduced capacity for such things as learning, receptive and expressive language, and independent living. English = mental disability, intellectual disability.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to have a disability affecting the brain so that he/she has a reduced intellectual capacity for such things as learning, receptive and expressive language, and independent living. English = mentally disabled, intellectually disabled.

mentally%20ill.description: (As a Noun) A condition or illness which causes serious disorder in a person's behaviour or thinking. English = mental illness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a condition or illness which causes serious disorder in a person's behaviour or thinking. English = (be) mentally ill.

unique.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be alone or the only one of of its kind. English = (be) unique.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be no others of its kind involved or relevant. English = (be) only.; (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb or adjective to mean in a way that belongs or is connected to only one particular person or thing, is the case in a very special or unusual way. English = uniquely.

meringue.description:
(As a Noun) A mixture consisting of egg whites and sugar beaten until it is
 stiff and creamy. The mixture is then baked in the oven. English = meringue.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English keyword MERINGUE. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for MERINGUE (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic).  If you know a sign for MERINGUE used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

ride (horse).description: (As a Noun) The activity of riding horses, especially in the manner of a prince or knight. Used particularly to recount children's stories. English = horse riding.; (As a Noun) A large circular platform with wooden or plastic animals and vehicles on it which children ride on as it turns round. English = merry-go-round.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To ride a horse in the manner of a prince or knight. Used particularly to recount children's stories.

merry%20(tipsy).description: (As a Noun) Someone who often gets drunk. English = drunkard.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have drunk enough to make you behave a little different from normally, usually friendlier or sillier than usual. English = (be) tipsy, (be) merry.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have drunk so much alcohol that you cannot speak or sign clearly or behave sensibly. English = (be) drunk. Formal English = (be) inebriated. Informal English = (be) sloshed, (be) pissed.

net.description: (As a Noun) A kind of cloth made of very fine threads that are woven together so that there are small equal spaces between them and you can see through the cloth. English = net.; (As a Noun) Material like a net made from wire, thread, or plastic. English = mesh.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be made with threads of wire, fabric or plastic which are woven loosely together. English = (be) meshed.

mess.description: (As a Noun) Something that is in a very untidy state. English = mess.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be untidy or disorganised. English = (be) messy, (be) in a mess.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be in a confused or disorganised state. Informal English = (be) topsy-turvy.

mess%20about.description: (As a Noun) The act of doing something that is very pleasant to do but not very important, especially something around the house. English = pottering.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To do something that is pleasant to do but not very important, especially something around the house. English = potter, potter about, mess about.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To do something in a very disorganised or casual way without really achieving very much but, nonetheless, enjoying yourself. British English = faff, faff about.

wire (telegram).description: (As a Noun) The act of sending a message out along a wire to another place.; (As a Noun) A message that has been sent out along a wire to another place. English = wire, telegram.; (As a Noun) Information which has been sent from one place to another by any means whatsoever. English = message.

messiah.description: (As a Noun) For Jews, the King of the Jews, who will be sent to them by God. English = Messiah.; (As a Noun) For Christians, Jesus Christ. English = Messiah.

rock.description: (As a Noun) The hard substance which the earth is made of. It often sticks out of the ground or the sea. It is often used for building houses. English = stone, rock.; (As a Noun) A hard substance such as iron, steel, copper, or lead. English = metal.; (As a Noun) A hard dark metal found in rocks. English = iron.

metalanguage.description: (As a Noun) In language study, special words you use to discuss language (like noun, verb, conjunction, sentence, metaphor, etc.). Technical English = metalanguage; (Note) The signer in the video is giving a definition in Auslan for the English term METALANGUAGE.

metaphor.description: (As a Noun) An imaginative way of describing something by saying that it is something else which has the qualities that you are trying to describe. For example, if you want to say that someone is very shy and timid, you might say that they are a mouse. English = metaphor; (Note) The signer in the video is giving a definition in Auslan for the English term METAPHOR. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for METAPHOR, but some signers have borrowed the BSL sign for METAPHOR (see the other sign listed in Signbank that matches this keyword). If you know of another sign for METAPHOR used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

metre.description: (As a Noun) A unit of length equal to one hundred centimetres. English = metre, meter (US).; (Note) This sign was created for the Australasian Signed English in the 1980s. It uses the letter M. It has been accepted and used as an Auslan sign by some deaf people, especially in education by teachers of the deaf, their students, and interpreters. Look at other matches for ‘metre’ to see a more common way of expressing this in Auslan.

meter%20(gauge).description: (As a Noun) An instrument such as a clock or meter that shows you the amount or measurement of something. English = dial, meter, gauge.; (As a Noun) On an instrument such as a clock, meter, or compass, the indicator which shows you the time, measurement or direction. English = dial, needle.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a dial or gauge, to move to and fro, to oscillate.

methodist.description: (As a Noun) A Christian who follow the teachings of John Wesley. English = Methodist.; (As a Noun) The beliefs and practices of Methodists. English = Methodism.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of or relating to the Methodists, their church, and their beliefs. English = (be) Methodist.

mexico.description: (As a Noun) A country in North America, south of the United States, called Mexico.; (As a Noun) A man's hat with a very wide brim which is worn especially in Mexico. English = sombrero.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To come from or relate to Mexico. English = Mexican.

mouse.description: (As a Noun) A very small furry animal with a long tail. English = mouse (singular), mice (plural).

mickey%20mouse.description: (As a Noun) A cartoon character created by Walt Disney who is an animated mouse with big ears, called Mickey Mouse.

microscope.description: (As a Noun) An instrument which magnifies very small objects so that you can see and study them. English = microscope.; (As a Noun) The study of very small organisms using a microscope. English = microbiology.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To look through or examine through a microscope.

microwave.description: (As a Noun) An oven or cooker which cooks food very quickly by short-wave radiation rather than by heat. English = microwave, microwave oven.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cook in a microwave oven. English = microwave.

microwave%20oven.description: (As a Noun) An oven or cooker which cooks food very quickly by short-wave radiation rather than by heat. English = microwave, microwave oven.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cook in a microwave oven. English = microwave.

middle.description: (As a Noun) That part of a thing that is furthest from its edges, ends, or outside surface. English = middle.; (As a Noun) Of an event or period of time, that part that comes after the first part and before the last part. English = middle.; (As a Noun) The result you get when you add two or more numbers together and divide the total by the number of numbers you added together; the amount or quantity of something that is normal or typical. English = average.

soldier.description: (As a Noun) A person who fights in an army. English = soldier.; (As a Noun) A large organised group of people who are armed and trained to fight on land in a war. English = army.; (As a Noun) The armed forces of a country. English = military.

milk.description: (As a Noun) A white liquid produced by cows, goats and other animals. English = milk.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To get milk from a cow or goat by pulling on the udders. English = milk.

milkshake.description: (As a Noun) A cold drink made by mixing milk with a flavouring or fruit, and sometimes ice cream. English = milkshake.

millilitre.description: (As a Noun) A metric unit of volume for liquids and gasses that is equal to one thousandth of a litre. English = millilitre.

millimetre.description: (As a Noun) A metric unit of length that is equal to one tenth of a centimetre, or one thousandth of a metre. English = millimetre.

million.description: (As a Noun) The number 1,000,000. English = million.; (As a Noun) Often used to mean an extremely large number. English = millions (of).

milli%20(prefix).description: (As Modifier) A prefix (something added to the beginning of a word) in English. It is added to units of measurement, such as metre or second, to mean a thousand, e.g., millimetre or milli-second. It usually means one thousandth of that unit. English = milli-

mime.description: (As a Noun) The use of movements and gestures to express something or tell a story without using speech or signs. English = mime.; (As a Noun) An actor who uses mime in his or her performances. English = mime.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use movements and gestures to express something or tell a story without using speech or signs. English = mime.

mince.description: (As a Noun) Something which has been chopped into very fine pieces by hand.; (As a Noun) Meat which has been chopped into very small pieces. English = mince, mincemeat.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cut or chop something into very small pieces, to chop finely.

mince%20(garlic).description: (As a Noun) A small device in which you place a clove of garlic and then press or squeeze it closed in order to crush it and force it out minced. English = garlic press.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To mince garlic into very small pieces using a garlic press. English = mince.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for MINCE GARLIC (but  signers can represent this visually using depicting signs in context). This suggested sign depicts holding two parts of a garlic press and pressing it together, then a depiction of something emerging from it in pieces. Source: DeafConnectED, Melbourne Polytechnic.

mincer.description: (General Definition) The action of turning a handle on a mechanical device of some kind, such as and old-fashioned barrel organ, a printing press, or a clothes wringer, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this in context.; (As a Noun) A machine which cuts meat into very small pieces, especially a hand operated one. English = mincer.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cut meat into very small pieces using a mincer, especially a hand operated one. English = mince.

mind%20(not%20mind).description: (Interactive) Used alone in response to a question to mean you are not annoyed or bothered by something, or happy with anything that has been offered. English = 'I don't mind.'

my.description: (As a Pointing Sign) Used to mean something is owned or possessed by the signer. It is usually signed immediately next to the noun sign for the thing that is owned. English = my.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used alone to mean something which is possessed by the signer. Used alone without saying what is possessed if it is clear from context or because someone has mentioned it before. English = mine.

mine%20(excavate).description: (As a Noun) The act of making holes in the ground using your hand, a spade, or some special machine. English = digging.; (As a Noun) The digging of deep holes and tunnels in the ground in order to find coal, diamonds, gold, and other precious things. English = mining.; (As a Noun) The removing of earth carefully from a piece of land and to look for the remains of pots, bones, or buildings, in order to discover information about the past. English = excavation.

mine%20(not%20mine).description: (Interactive) Used alone to mean that you deny all responsibility or involvement in something someone has done or said. English = 'It's got nothing to do with me!'.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used to mean something is NOT owned or possessed by the signer. It is usually signed immediately next to the noun sign for the thing that is owned. English = not my.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used to mean something is NOT owned or possessed by the signer. Used alone without saying again what is NOT possessed is if it is clear from context or because someone has mentioned it before. English = not mine.

mingle.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To move around a group of people and chat to people, especially people you do not already know. English = mingle.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To meet with other people and talk to them at a social event such as a party. English = mix.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To leave your house and meet other people, particularly at parties, pubs, restaurants and so on. English = socialise.

minor.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be something that is not as important, serious, or significant as other things. English = (be) minor, (be) unimportant, (be) insignificant.

minus.description: (As a Noun) The symbol (-) which is put between two numbers in order to show that the second number is being subtracted from the first number.; (As Modifier) The symbol (-) which is put before a number when talking about the weather and temperatures to mean a temperature below zero degrees.

minutes.description: (As a Noun) Some of the sixty equal parts of an hour. English = minutes.; (As a Noun) The written records of what is said or decided at a meeting. English = minutes.

minute%20(time).description: (As a Noun) One of the sixty equal parts that an hour is divided into. English = minute.; (As a Noun) The written records of what is said or decided at a meeting. English = minutes.

minute%20(very%20small).description: (As a Noun) A very small amount or piece of something. English = bit.; (As a Noun) A very small thing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very small or very little. English = (be) tiny.

mirror.description: (As a Noun) A flat piece of glass which reflects light, so that when you look at it you can see yourself reflected in it. English = mirror.

bad luck.description: (As a Noun) A lack of success or bad things that happen to you, that have not been caused by yourself or other people. English = bad luck. Formal English = misfortune.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have bad luck. English = unlucky. Formal English = unfortunate.; (Interactive) Used to express sympathy for someone who has failed to do something or failed to get something. English = 'Bad luck!', 'Hard luck!', 'Shame!', 'What a pity!' and so on.

misinterpret.description: (As a Noun) An understanding of something which is wrong. English = misinterpretation.; (As a Noun) A failure to understand something such as a situation or a person's remarks. English = misunderstanding.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To understand something wrongly. English = misinterpret.

miss.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To not notice something. English = miss, overlook.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To fail to hit something when you have aimed something at it; to fail to catch something such as a bus, plane, or train; to fail to be involved in something. English = miss; miss; miss out.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To feel sad because someone is no longer with you; or to feel sad because you no longer have or experience something. English = miss.

missionary.description: (As a Noun) A Christian who has been sent to a foreign country to teach people about Christianity. English = missionary.

miss%20out.description: (Interactive) Used in response to someone's request for you to clarify or to repeat something because they  have joined or rejoined a conversation you are having with someone else. It is too late for them to follow because they have missed something vital. Idiomatic English = "Miss the boat"; (Interactive) You are not really prepared to repeat yourself. It is used particularly when you have just given the punch-line to a joke and someone does not understand because they were not paying full attention.

miss%20the%20boat.description: (Interactive) Used in response to someone's request for you to clarify or to repeat something because they  have joined or rejoined a conversation you are having with someone else. It is too late for them to follow because they have missed something vital. Idiomatic English = "Miss the boat"; (Interactive) You are not really prepared to repeat yourself. It is used particularly when you have just given the punch-line to a joke and someone does not understand because they were not paying full attention.

pope.description: (As a Noun) The head of the Roman Catholic Church. English = Pope.; (As a Noun) A tall pointed hat that is worn by bishops and archbishops on ceremonial occasions. English = mitre.

stirring.description: (As a Noun) The act of mixing a liquid inside a container by using something such as a spoon. English = stirring, mixing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To mix a liquid inside a container by using something such as a spoon. English = stir, mix.

mixed%20up.description: (As a Noun) The act of making a mistake about a person or thing and thinking that they are another person or thing. English = confusion. Idiomatic English = mix up.; (As a Noun) A situation where it is not clear what is happening. English = confusion.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To mix up one or more separate things so that you think one of them is actually another one. English = confuse. Idiomatic English = mix up.

mixer.description: (As a Noun) A device used in the kitchen for beating and mixing ingredients together. English = mixer.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To operate a mixer.

mixture.description: (As a Noun) A substance that consists of other substances which have been stirred or shaken together. English = mixture.; (As a Noun) Several different things brought together. English = mixture.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To stir or shake two or more substances together. English = mix, mix up.

mix%20up.description: (As a Noun) The act of making a mistake about a person or thing and thinking that they are another person or thing. English = confusion. Idiomatic English = mix up.; (As a Noun) A situation where it is not clear what is happening. English = confusion.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To mix up one or more separate things so that you think one of them is actually another one. English = confuse. Idiomatic English = mix up.

mobile%20phone.description: (As a Noun) A small cordless portable telephone that you can take with you anywhere and make and receive calls. English = mobile-phone.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use a mobile-phone.

mobility.description: (As a Noun) The ability to move physically. English = mobility.

model.description: (As a Noun) A person who displays clothes by wearing them, especially in a fashion show. English = model.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To display clothes by wearing them, especially in a fashion show. English = model (clothes).

modem.description: (As a Noun) A device which allows one computer to sent information to another computer over a telephone line. English = modem.

monday.description: (As a Noun) The first day of the working week, after Sunday and before Tuesday. English = Monday.

monitor%20(computer).description: (As a Noun) The vertical surface of a computer on which information and pictures are displayed. English = visual display screen, display screen, visual display unit (VDU), computer screen, monitor.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To display information or pictures on a computer screen.

monkey.description: (As a Noun) An animal which has a long tail, lives in hot countries and climbs trees. English = monkey.

peeping tom.description: (General Definition) Something small and round in the eye, on the eye, or close to the eye, such as a pupil or a monocle, or anything directly or indirectly associated with this, especially peeping through a hole.; (As a Noun) A person who secretly looks at other people when they believe they are not being watched, especially when they are undressing. English = Peeping Tom.; (As a Noun) The small, round, black hole in the centre of your eye. English = pupil.

monomial.description: (As a Noun) In mathematics, an algebraic expression consisting of one term. English = monomial.

monotony.description: (As a Noun) The repetition of some activity time and time again without any variety or change. English = monotony, tedium.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be unchanging and always the same, especially when it is uninteresting and boring. English = (be) monotonous, (be) repetitive.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To do the same thing time and time again without changing in a boring way. English = (be) tedious.

minute (time).description: (General Definition) In context, used to refer to any thing or any action named with an English word beginning with 'm' particularly if it has already been fully fingerspelt earlier in the conversation. It is commonly used for minute, month, metre, and maiden.; (As a Noun) An abbreviation used to stand for one of the sixty equal parts of an hour. English = minute.; (As a Noun) An abbreviation used to stand for one of the twelve periods of time that a year is divided into, for example January or February. English = month.

fourth (every fourth).description: (As a Noun) Each and every week which is the fourth week in a cycle (usually of four weeks), or each and every unit of time which is the fourth unit in a cycle.; (As Modifier) Used in a sentence (immediately next to a verb, or at the beginning or end of the sentence) to mean that the action happens every fourth unit of time which has already been established (day, week, month, semester, year, etc.). Most commonly refers to weeks, i.e., every four weeks or monthly.

month%20(this%20month).description: (As a Noun) A recurring period of time (such as a week, month or year) the unit of which has already been mentioned and which the signer is in at the time of speaking. English = this week, this month, this year, etc.; (As a Noun) The remaining time within the unit of time (week, month, year, etc.) being talked about; the rest of this week, this month, this year, etc.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence, or immediately next to a verb, to mean the action takes place sometime during the following unit of time being talked about (week, month, year, etc.), or after some other time reference point. English = during this week (month, year), during that week (month, year), this time.

month%20(this%20past%20month).description: (As a Noun) A recurring period of time (such as a week, month or year) before the time of speaking. The unit of time has already been mentioned. English = this week, this month, this year, etc.; (As a Noun) The used up or elapsed time within the unit of time (week, month, year, etc.) being talked about; this past week, this past month, this past year, etc.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence, or immediately next to a verb, to mean the action takes place sometime during the previous unit of time being talked about, or before some other reference time.

montreal.description: (As a Noun) A city in the Canadian province of Québec, called Montréal.

moodle.description: (Note) Suggested sign #1×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

moon.description: (As a Noun) The round object in the sky that you can often see at night. English = moon.

mop.description: (As a Noun) A tool for washing floors. It consists of a sponge or a cluster of pieces of string attached to a long handle. English = mop.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To clean a floor with a mop. English = mop.

moreton%20bay%20bug.description: (As a Noun) An animal with a hard outer shell and several pairs of legs, which usually lives in water, such as crayfish and lobsters. English = crustacean.; (As a Noun) A sea creature that has a hard shell, two large claws, and eight legs. English = lobster.; (As a Noun) A small shellfish with five pairs of legs which lives in rivers and ponds. It has strong pincers on its front legs which it uses for catching food. English = crayfish.

mormon.description: (As a Noun) A person who belongs to the religious group called the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints. English = Mormon.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of or relating to the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints. English = (be) Mormon.

morning.description: (As a Noun) The part of each day between the time that people usually wake up and noon or lunchtime. English = morning.; (Interactive) Used alone to greet someone just after they have woken up or when you see them for the first time in the day if it is before noon or lunchtime. English = 'Good morning!', 'Morning!'; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning (or end) of a sentence to locate the action of that sentence in time; namely, in that part of each day between the time that people usually wake up and noon or lunchtime. English = in the morning.

morphology.description: (As a Noun) The study of the smallest units of meaning in a spoken language (like words or parts of words), or a signed language (like signs or parts of signs). English = morphology.; (As a Noun) The smallest units of meaning in a spoken language (like words or parts of words), or a signed language (like signs or parts of signs). In English, for example, ‘boy’ is one word and one morpheme, but ‘boys’ is one word and two morphemes (boy + s). The ‘s’ adds the meanings ‘more than one, or plural’. Another example, ‘walk’ is one word and one morpheme, but ‘walked’ is one word and two morphemes. The ‘-ed’ adds the meaning ‘in the past’. In Auslan, for example, BELIEVE is one sign and one morpheme, but the sign BELIEVE-NOT is one sign and two morphemes. English = morpheme.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

mortar%20and%20pestle.description: (As a Noun) A device made up of two parts: a bowl (mortar), and a heavy, blunt object (pestle). Used for grinding ingredients into a very fine paste or powder. English = mortar and pestle.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To grind or crush something using a mortar and pestle.; (Note) This sign is a depiction of grinding something while holding a mortar (bowl) and a pestle (tool). Source of this recommended sign: DeafConnectED, Melbourne Polytechnic.

mother.description: (As a Noun) The woman who gave birth to you. English = mother.

motor.description: (As a Noun) The part of a machine or vehicle that uses electricity or fuel to produce movement, so that the machine or vehicle can work. English = motor, engine.

motorcycle.description: (As a Noun) A two-wheeled vehicle that has an engine. English = motorcycle, motorbike.; (As a Noun) A motorbike enthusiast. Informal English = bikie.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To operate and ride a motorbike or motorcycle.

mountain.description: (As a Noun) A very high piece of land with steep sides which are difficult to climb English = mountain.

mouse%20(computer).description: (As a Noun) In computing, a small device that you hold in your hand and use to control the movement of the cursor on the computer screen, or to select computer functions, without using the keyboard. English = mouse.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move or operate a computer mouse.

mousse.description: (As a Noun) A sweet or savoury dish usually made with egg-whites or cream, giving it a light, airy texture. English = mousse.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English keyword MOUSSE. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for MOUSSE (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic).  If you know a sign for MOUSSE used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

moustache.description: (As a Noun) The hair grows on a man's upper lip. English = moustache.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a moustache, or wear a moustache.

mouth.description: (As a Noun) Your lips, or the space behind your lips where your teeth and tongue are. You use it for eating, speaking and making facial gestures. English = mouth.; (As a Noun) The action of making facial gestures with your mouth, or of forming words with your lips without making any sound. English = mouthing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To form words with your lips without making any sound. English = mouth.

mouth%20gesture.description: (As a Noun) In linguistics, a particular mouth pattern that is produced at the same time a manual sign is being produced in a signed language. English = mouth gesture.

move.description: (As a Noun) A transfer from living in one house into another. English = move.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go and live in a different house, taking your possessions with you. English = move, move house, move out, shift.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To change your position or to go to a different place, especially by moving sideways. English = move, move aside, move sideways, step sideways, step aside.

move%20ahead.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be progressing more quickly than others. English = move ahead.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be ahead of others. English = (be) leading.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move in the intended direction. English = go forward.

movements.description: (As a Noun) The changes in a persons position and the placement of their limbs as they do things or as they go from one place to another, especially by walking. English = movements.; (As a Noun) The swaying of the hips of a person, especially a woman, as they walk.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move your body about in space as a natural consequence of doing something. English = move.

move%20(motion%20in%20meeting).description: (As a Noun) A formal proposal which the people present at a meeting discuss and then vote on. English = motion.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To formally propose something at a meeting so that everyone present can vote for or against it. English = move.

move%20stack.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To attend to a problem by assigning it to someone else. English = offload.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To get rid of a problem by giving it to someone else to solve. English = offload. Idiomatic English = to pass the buck.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be undecided about how to solve a problem or whom to ask help in solving it.

move%20(vehicle).description: (General Definition) A flat handshape held in this orientation while it is moved forward or backward often describes the path a vehicle (such as a car or a truck) takes as it travels. This means the actual movement in the sign can be almost anything depending on the context and what you want to say, e.g., sideways for ‘skidding’, or diagonally away and upwards for ‘going up a hill’, and so on. Signs like these are called ‘depicting’ signs in the grammar of Auslan.; (As a Noun) The path taken by a vehicle.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To travel somewhere or go somewhere in a vehicle.

movie%20theatre.description: (As a Noun) Moving pictures that have been recorded so that they can be shown in a cinema or on television. English = pictures, film, films, movie, movies.; (As a Noun) A theatre where moving pictures are shown. English = cinema, movie theatre. Informal English = pictures.

moving%20on.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To push something to one side.; (Interactive) Used alone in a discussion with someone to mean that you want to put one issue or topic to the side so that you can continue to discuss another related issue or topic. English = "let's forget about that for the moment", "putting that issue to the side" and so on.; (As Modifier) Used between two separate topics of discussion (at the end of the first or at the beginning of the second) to mean that you are ending the first topic and changing topics to a second one. English = moving on, on the other hand, putting that aside...

msds%20(material%20safety%20data%20sheet.description: (As a Noun) A MSDS (or Material Safety Data Sheet) is a document that contains information about potential health problems from chemicals, or other substances, and the correct way for working with these substances.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEET or MSDS.

mug.description: (As a Noun) A large, deep cup with straight sides. English = mug.; (As a Noun) A large mug for drinking beer. English = stein.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To drink from a mug.

mull%20over.description: (As a Noun) Activity in the mind. English = thinking.; (As a Noun) The study or creation of theories about basic things such as the nature of existence or how people should live; or a particular set of such ideas. English = philosophy.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To think about something for a long time, often before deciding what to do. English = mull over.

multiplication.description: (As a Noun) In mathematics, the symbol (x) which is put between two numbers to show that they are being multiplied. English = multiplication sign.; (As a Noun) In mathematics, the process of calculating the total of one number multiplied by another number. English = multiplication.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In mathematics, to calculate the total which you get when you add a number to itself a particular number of times. English = multiply.

mum.description: (As a Noun) The woman who gave birth to you. This is an informal sign used particularly by children. English = mum, mummy.; (As a Noun) The woman who gave birth to you. English = mother.

mum%20and%20dad.description: (As a Noun) Your mum and your dad. English = parents.

mumps.description: (As a Noun) A disease that causes a painful swelling of the glands in the neck. English =  mumps.; (As a Noun) A swelling of the glands in the neck.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have the mumps.

munich.description: (As a Noun) The capital city of the German state of Bavaria, called Munich.

murder.description: (As a Noun) The deliberate and unlawful killing of a person. English = murder.; (As a Noun) A person who deliberately and unlawfully kills a person. English = murderer.; (As a Noun) A cut or a slit on a throat.

muscular.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To have powerful, firm muscles which you can see and which make your body look big. English = (be) muscular, (be) muscle-bound.

musculoskeletal.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) MUSCULOSKELETAL means relating to the muscles and skeleton and including bones, joints, tendons and muscles.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term MUSCULOSKELETAL. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for MUSCULOSKELETAL (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for MUSCULOSKELETAL used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

museum.description: (As a Noun) A building where large numbers of interesting and valuable objects are kept and displayed to the public. English = museum.

mushroom.description: (As a Noun) A fungus with a short stem and a round top which is eaten as a food. English = mushroom.

must%20(must%20not).description: (Interactive) Used alone to mean you think that the action under discussion is not right, it is not good that it happens, or that you feel that it will not happen.; (As Modifier) Used before or after a verb (action) sign to mean that you think that it is not right or not good that the action happens, or that you feel that it will not happen. English = shouldn't, ought not to.; (As Modifier) You use this sign when you are suggesting that someone not do something.

mute.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a secret or a piece of information, to not tell anyone about it. English = keep mum, (be) mum.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To communicate without using any or very few lip patterns or facial expressions, usually when you are signing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To keep quiet, especially when suffering pain or discomfort; to not complain.

my%20(not%20my).description: (Interactive) Used alone to mean that you deny all responsibility or involvement in something someone has done or said. English = 'It's got nothing to do with me!'.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used to mean something is NOT owned or possessed by the signer. It is usually signed immediately next to the noun sign for the thing that is owned. English = not my.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used to mean something is NOT owned or possessed by the signer. Used alone without saying again what is NOT possessed is if it is clear from context or because someone has mentioned it before. English = not mine.

myself.description: (As a Pointing Sign) Used immediately before or after a verb to mean the signer does the action of the verb alone (i.e., without anyone else present) or without the help of anyone else (i.e. the signer is the only person responsible for the action). English = myself, independently.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used immediately before or after a verb, but usually after, to mean the action of the verb was done by the signer to the signer, not by anyone or anything else to the signer, i.e., it makes the verb reflexive. English = myself.

stress (anxiety).description: (As a Noun) The worry and tenseness you feel because of difficulties in your life. English = stress, tension.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To feel worried and tense because of difficulties in your life. English = (be) stressed, suffer from stress, (be) tense.

n.description: (As a Noun) The letter N in the one-handed manual alphabets.

nag.description: (As a Noun) A person who always complains in an irritating way. English = nag.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To keep complaining in an irritating way, to keep on talking about something to someone in an irritating way. English = nag.

nail%20brush.description: (As a Noun) A small brush that you use for cleaning your nails. English = nail brush.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use a nail brush.

nail%20polish.description: (As a Noun) A thick coloured liquid that women paint on their nails. English = nail polish.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To apply nail polish.

forget (go blank).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To completely forget to do something that you should have remembered, or to completely forget what you were going to say next, especially when it is important and potentially embarrassing, e.g., giving a formal talk or acting a role in a play. Idiomatic English = go blank.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To not know much about something or things in general and thus to have an empty mind. English = (be) ignorant.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To believe that things are much less complicated and difficult than they really are because you do not have much experience of the world. English = (be) naive.

naked.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to not be wearing any clothes. English = (be) naked, (be) nude.

name.description: (As a Noun) Of a person, thing, or place, the word or group of words that you use to identify them. English = name.; (As a Noun) The opinion that people have about what someone or something is like, especially about how good they are. English = name, reputation.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To give someone or something a name. English = name, call.

sign-name.description: (As a Noun) The number name-sign for children in some of the old residential schools for the deaf. It was based on the bed, locker, coat hook, towel hook, or toothbrush hanger number that was painted on it and which each pupil used exclusively. The sign consists of a compound of the sign BOY or GIRL followed by their number made as the hand moves away from the face (chin for boys and cheek for girls). Many teachers and staff only referred to the children by their ‘number name-sign’, not knowing or not caring what the child’s actual name-sign was. Interestingly, some pupils also referred to each other this way as a kind of nickname, even into adulthood. However, in adulthood it was mostly used to refer to other old school friends when reminiscing about school days.

name%20tag.description: (As a Noun) An older pupil at a school who does special duties and helps the teachers to control the younger pupils. English = prefect.; (As a Noun) A small piece of cloth, metal or paper that is worn on your chest and which has your name on it. English = name tag.

nap.description: (As a Noun) A short rest in which you lie down on a bed. English = lie-down, nap, snooze.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move into a horizontal position, usually in order to rest or sleep. English = lie down, recline.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be lying somewhere with your legs and arms out in a careless way. English = (be) sprawled out.

nappy.description: (As a Noun) A piece of soft thick cloth or paper which is fastened round a baby's bottom in order to soak up its urine and faeces. English = nappy.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To fasten a nappy on to a baby; to be wearing a nappy.

narrow.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To have a very small distance between the two sides of a thing. English = (be) narrow.

nose.description: (As a Noun) The part of your face which sticks out above your mouth. You use it for smelling and breathing. English = nose.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of or relating to the nose. English = (be) nasal.; (Note) Please do a keyword search for ‘body parts’ for more information about signs for body parts in Auslan.

nasty.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to be unkind and unpleasant. English = (be) nasty.

native%20(language).description: (As a Noun) The period of time in which you gradually change from being a child into being an adult. English = childhood.; (As a Noun) Someone who has learned a language as their first language from childhood. English = native, native user, native speaker, native signer.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To gradually change from being a child into being an adult. English = grow up.

natural.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be what happens or is the case because it is part of the usual processes of life and has little or nothing to do with changes made by humans. English = (be) natural.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be a part of someone's personality without them acting or changing themselves in any way. English = (be) natural.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be usual and ordinary, and what people expect. English = (be) normal.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

nausea.description: (As a Noun) The feeling of being sick as if you were going to vomit. English = nausea, queasiness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To feel sick as if you are likely to vomit. English = (be) nauseous, (be) queasy.

sailor.description: (As a Noun) A person who works on a ship as a member of its crew. English = sailor.; (As a Noun) That part of the armed forces of a country that fights at sea on ships. English = navy.

nazareth.description: (As a Noun) In the Bible, the town in Israel where Jesus Christ grew up. English = Nazareth.

near.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be located only a short distance from something. English = (be) near.; (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb and a following noun to mean the action takes place only a short distance away from the thing. English = near.

necessity.description: (As a Noun) Something that needs to be done, or something that is needed in order for something else to be done. English = necessity.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be needed in order to get the result that is wanted. English = (be) necessary.

neck.description: (As a Noun) The part of your body which joins your head to the rest of your body. English = neck.; (As a Noun) The front part of your neck. English = throat.

neck%20and%20neck.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of two things or two quantities of something, to change position or size relative to each other even as both increase. English = neck and neck, keep up with.

petting.description: (As a Noun) Of two people, especially teenage couples, the activity of kissing and stroking each other. English = petting. Informal English = necking.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of two people, especially a teenage couple, to kiss and stroke each other. English = pet. Informal English = neck, go parking.

necklace.description: (As a Noun) A piece of jewellery, such as a chain or string of beads, which a woman wears round her neck. English = necklace; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wear a necklace.

neck%20(pet).description: (As a Noun) Of two people, especially teenage couples, the activity of kissing and stroking each other. English = petting. Informal English = necking.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of two people, especially a teenage couple, to kiss and stroke each other. English = pet. Informal English = neck, go parking.

tie (necktie).description: (As a Noun) A long, narrow piece of cloth that is worn around someone's neck under their shirt collar and tied in a knot at the front. It is worn mainly by men. English = tie, necktie.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put on or wear a tie.

need.description: (As a Noun) The strong feeling that you must have something or must do something. English = need.; (As a Noun) The need to do something. English = necessity.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be necessary to have or do something; to have a strong feeling that you must have something or must do something. English = need.

preference.description: (As a Noun) Something that you would rather have given a choice; the choice of something instead of something else; the liking of one thing above another thing or other things. English = preference.; (As a Noun) Something that you must have in order to do something that you want to do. English = requirement.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To like one thing more than another thing or other things, and to be more likely to choose the first above the other or all the rest if there is a choice. English = prefer.

needle.description: (As a Noun) A small, very thin piece of polished metal which is used for sewing. It has a sharp point at one end and a hole in the other end for a thread to go through. English = needle.

sewing.description: (As a Noun) The activity of making,  mending or decorating clothes or other material using a needle and thread. English = sewing, needlework, stitching.; (As a Noun) The activity of tying the skin together using a special needle and thread. English = stitching.; (As a Noun) A woman who sews and makes clothes as her job. English = seamstress.

negative.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be something that gives or suggests the answer 'no'. English = (be) negative.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To consider only the disadvantages and bad aspects of a situation, rather than the advantages and good aspects. English = (be) negative.; (As Modifier) In mathematics, used to describe numbers that are less than zero. English = negative.

negotiation.description: (As a Noun) Discussions that take place between people with different interests, in which they try to reach an agreement. English = negotiation.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To reach an agreement or make a deal, or to obtain or organise something, by having discussions with other people. English = negotiate.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To try to cause someone to do something by giving them good reasons for doing it, usually by talking to them. English = persuade.

black (person).description: (As a Noun) A person who is black. English = black, Negro.; (As a Noun) A person who belongs to the indigenous, black population of Australia. English = Aborigine.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To relate to the indigenous, black population of Australia. English = (be) aboriginal.

neighbour.description: (As a Noun) The person, group of people, or family, that lives immediately next to, or very close to, your house or home. English = neighbour, neighbours.; (As a Noun) The house that belongs to the people who live immediately beside your house. English = next door, the place next door.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To live next door or very close to someone. English = (be) the next door neighbour, (be) a neighbour.

neither.description: (As Modifier) You use this sign to refer to both of two things or people, when you are making a negative statement about both of them. English = neither, neither of the two, not either.

nephew.description: (As a Noun) The son of someone's sister or brother. English = nephew.

nerve.description: (General Definition) Something long and thin lying on a flat surface or travelling along a flat surface, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially nerves and nerve signals travelling through the body.; (As a Noun) A long, thin fibre in your body that transmits messages and feelings between your brain and other parts of your body. English = nerve.

nervousness.description: (As a Noun) Worry and fear about something and the way this is shown in your behaviour. English = nervousness, nerves.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be worried and frightened of something, and to show this in your behaviour. English = (be) nervous.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very tense, anxious, and easily upset. English = (be) nervy.

bowl (dish).description: (General Definition) An object, particularly a container, with shallow, curved sides and a wide, uncovered top, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, such as a bowl, dish, pot or nest.; (As a Noun) A circular container with a wide, uncovered top. It is used, for example, for serving food or for mixing ingredients when cooking. English = bowl, dish.; (As a Noun) A deep round container used for cooking, especially one used for cooking stews and soups. English = pot.

netball.description: (As a Noun) A game played by two teams of seven players, usually women. Each team tries to score goals by throwing a ball through a net which is at the top of a pole at each end of the court. English = netball.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To play netball.

neurodiversity.description: (As a Noun) The normal variation in individual brain function and individual behaviour found in a human population, especially in the context of autistic spectrum disorders. English = neurodiversity.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have neurologically atypical patterns of thought or behaviour, especially with reference to autism. English = (be) neurodiverse.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (Note) Suggested sign for 'neurodiverse'.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

never.description: (As Modifier) Used before (and after) a verb (action) sign to mean that the action has not happened at any time in the past or will not happen at any time in the future. English = never, not ever.; (As Modifier) Used before (and after) a verb (action) sign to mean that the action did not happen. English = never, did not.

never%20mind.description: (Interactive) Used to try to reassure your addressee when they are worried or concerned about something. English = 'Never mind', 'Don't worry', 'It's not important', and so on.; (Interactive) Used in response to your addressee's questions expressing concern for you when you want them to stop worrying or tell them everything is okay. English = 'It doesn't matter', 'No problems', 'Forget about it'; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of the first of two sign phrases to mean that what you say in the second phrase is surprising given the first phrase. English = despite, despite that.

new.description: (As a Noun) The quality of being recently made or created; of not being owned or used before; of being different from what you had before; or of being only recently discovered. English = newness.; (As a Noun) The quality of being different, new, and unusual. English = novelty.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be made or created recently; to be not owned or used by anyone else before; to be different from what you had, used, or experienced before; or to be only recently discovered. English = (be) new.

news.description: (As a Noun) Information about a recent event or a recently changed situation. English = news.; (As a Noun) Information that is given in newspapers and on radio and television about recent events in the country or the world. English = news.

newsagent.description: (As a Noun) A shop which sells newspapers and magazines, and often cigarettes, sweets, and stationery. English = newsagent, newsagent's.

newspaper.description: (As a Noun) A number of large sheets of folded paper on which news, advertisements, and other information is printed. Some are available everyday and other once a week. English = newspaper.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To open up a newspaper in order to read it.

newtown.description: (As a Noun) A suburb in the Australian city of Sydney, near the old Institute for the Deaf and Blind, called Newtown.; (Note) Apologies for the poor quality of this video. It will be replaced as soon as possible.

new%20york.description: (As a Noun) The largest city in the United States in the state of New York, called New York.

new%20zealand.description: (As a Noun) A country in the south Pacific Ocean, east of Australia. English = New Zealand.

next%20door.description: (As a Noun) The person, group of people, or family, that lives immediately next to, or very close to, your house or home. English = neighbour, neighbours.; (As a Noun) The house that belongs to the people who live immediately beside your house. English = next door, the place next door.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To live next door or very close to someone. English = (be) the next door neighbour, (be) a neighbour.

next%20to.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be located at the side of something or next to it. English = (be) beside.; (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb and a following noun to mean the action takes place at the side of or next to the thing. English = beside, next to.

next%20week.description: (As a Noun) The next calendar week after the week of speaking. English = next week.; (As a Noun) A period of seven days after another specified day in the past or future.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence or immediately next to a verb to mean the action takes place during the next calendar week after the week of speaking. English = next week.

next%20year.description: (As a Noun) A period of a year after the time of talking. English = the next year.; (As a Noun) A period of one year after some reference time in the past. English = the following year, the year after that.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence to mean the action takes place sometime during the following twelve months or year; or after at least a year. English = in the next year, during the next year; in a year's time.

snack food.description: (As a Noun) Small foods which you can eat between main meals. English = snack food. Informal English = nibbles, nibblies.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put something small into your mouth, chew it, and swallow it.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To eat something slowly by taking small bites out of it. English = nibble.

nice.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Something enjoyable, pleasant or attractive. English = nice.; (Note) Some older signers may think of this sign as an invented sign (for Signed English in education) but for most younger signers it has now just become another Auslan sign.

nickname.description: (As a Noun) A name given to someone which is not their real name. English = nickname, sobriquet.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To give a name to someone or something; or to be given a particular name and to be known by that name. English = call, name; (be) called, (be) named.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To describe a thing or a person by using a particular word, sign or phrase. English = call.

nick%20off.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To leave a place, especially a room, suddenly and quickly because you do not want to be there any longer. English = get out.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To leave a place where you are normally obliged to stay because of responsibilities (eg work or home) without regard to the consequences or without permission. You would do this because you are angry, irritated or irresponsible.; (As a Verb or Adjective) English = walk out. Informal English = nick off, bugger off.

niece.description: (As a Noun) The daughter of someone's sister or brother. English = niece.

night.description: (As a Noun) The part of each period of twenty-four hours when it is dark outside, especially the time when most people are sleeping. English = night.; (As a Noun) The period of time between the end of the afternoon and midnight, or between the end of the afternoon and the time when you go to bed. English = night.; (As a Noun) The evening or night that will come at the end of today. English = tonight.

nightdress.description: (As a Noun) A sort of a dress that women or girls wear in bed. English = nightdress, nightie.; (As a Noun) Loose trousers and a loose jacket that people wear in bed. English = pyjamas.

nightly.description: (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb to mean the action happens regularly or all the time during the night. English = every night, nightly, nights.

nine.description: (As a Noun) The number 9, between 8 and 10. English = nine.

nineteen.description: (As a Noun) The number 19, between 18 and 20. English = nineteen.

ninth.description: (As Modifier) Of a sequence of numbers or things, the one which is between eight (eighth) and ten (tenth) in that sequence. English = ninth.

teat.description: (As a Noun) One of the pieces of flesh that stick out on the chest or stomach of a female animal and from which its babies suck milk. English = teat, nipple.; (As a Noun) A piece of rubber or plastic that is shaped like a teat and is fitted to a bottle so that a baby can suck liquids from it. English = teat.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a baby, to suck milk from its mother's breast or from a bottle fitted with a teat. English = suckle.

no.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To say no.; (Interactive) Used alone to say that something is not true, to refuse an offer, or to refuse permission. English = 'No.'

no one.description: (As a Noun) No person, not a single person. English = no one, nobody.

no%20idea.description: (As a Noun) A mind which has no ideas or thoughts in it at all; a mind which is empty. Formal English = tabula rasa.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have no ideas or thoughts at all; to have a blank mind.

sound.description: (As a Noun) Something that you hear. English = sound.; (As a Noun) A sound that someone or something makes, often loud and unpleasant. English = noise.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make a noise or a sound.

none%20(have%20none).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of something or someone, to not be here or there, to not exist in a place.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To not own or possess something. English = not have any, have not got any, have none of.

none%20of%20my%20business.description: (General Definition) Some kind of vertical surface or line of things in front of and to the sides of you or the person, place or thing you represent, such as a barrier or fence, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To resolve that you will no longer consider or talk about someone else's concerns or affairs because you consider it to be none of your business.; (Interactive) Used alone to mean that something is none of one's business or concern and you have no intention of getting involved. English = 'I'm keeping right out of that. It's got nothing to do with me.'

none%20of%20one's%20business.description: (Interactive) Used alone in response to someone's question when you believe they have no right to ask you that or know the answer. Abrupt and offensive if used with strangers. English = '(It's) none of your business!', 'Butt out!', 'Mind your own business!'

none%20of%20your%20business.description: (Interactive) Used alone to mean that you do not what to tell or show someone something. English = 'It's none of your business!', and so on.

bullshit (nonsense).description: (As a Noun) Something which is nonsense, completely untrue, or not worth taking seriously. English = bullshit, rubbish.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To dislike something quite strongly. English = hate, loathe.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To reject, refuse or dismiss something because you do not like it.

noon.description: (As a Noun) Twelve o'clock in the middle of the day. English = noon.

no%20one.description: (As a Noun) No person, not a single person. English = no one, nobody.

no%20problems.description: (Interactive) Used alone to mean that some action or task is very easy to do and you don't mind doing it. Informal English = 'easy-peasy', 'no worries', 'no problems'.

no%20(refuse).description: (As a Noun) A law, decree or public statement that says you cannot do something. English = ban, prohibition.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say publicly by decree or to make a law that says you cannot do something; to be officially not allowed. English = ban, prohibit; (be) banned, (be) prohibited, (be) illegal.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To order someone not to do something; to be not allowed. English = forbid; (be) forbidden.

no%20responsibility.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To not have the duty to deal with, make decision about, or accept the blame for something; (be) not responsible for; to have no responsibility.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say that you did not do something after others claim or assume that you did do it. English = deny responsibility.; (Interactive) Used alone to mean you have no interest or connection with what someone is talking about, especially because they mistakenly think you have done something or are someway involved in it. English = 'It's got nothing to do with me!', 'It's not my responsibility!', 'Damned if I know or care!', and so on.

normality.description: (As a Noun) The situation in which everything is normal and as people expect. English = normality, normalcy.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be what happens or is the case because it is part of the usual processes of life and has little or nothing to do with changes made by humans. English = (be) natural.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be a part of someone's personality without them acting or changing themselves in any way. English = (be) natural.

north.description: (As a Noun) The direction which is on your left when you are looking towards the direction where the sun rises. English = north.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be a direction or point which is to the north or towards the north. English = (be) northerly, (be) northern.

norway.description: (As a Noun) A country in Northern Europe, west of Sweden. English = Norway.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To come from or relate to Norway. English = (be) Norwegian.

nose%20(big%20nose).description: (As a Noun) A person who is very inquisitive and always wants to know everything that is happening, particularly other people's affairs. Informal English = busybody, sticky-beak.; (As a Noun) The part of your face which sticks out above your mouth. You use it for smelling and breathing. English = nose.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To ask lots of questions about other people's affairs or about things that do not concern you, often in a way that irritates them. English = (be) nosey, (be) inquisitive.

nose%20ring.description: (General Definition) Something round placed through the nose, such as a nose ring, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially a bull.; (As a Noun) A male animal of the cow family. English = bull.; (As a Noun) A piece of jewellery worn in the nose. English = nose ring.

notes.description: (As a Noun) Information which is written down about someone or something in an official or semi-official capacity. English = notes, records, report.; (As a Noun) Information which is written down about things which have been said, done or agreed to during a meeting. English = minutes.; (As a Noun) A person whose job is to write down the things which have been said, done or agreed to during a meeting. English = minutes secretary.

no%20thank%20you.description: (Interactive) Used alone to refuse an offer. English = 'No!', 'No thanks!'; (Interactive) Used alone to mean that you think there is no possibility or likelihood of what is being discussed actually happening or being really true. English = 'No!', 'No, that's not right!', 'No way!', 'Absolutely not!'; (As Modifier) Used (i) immediately next to a verb or adjective to negate it, i.e., to mean that the action does not happen, or that something does not have that quality, or (ii) used at the end of a question-like sentence as a kind of answer, i.e., it makes the whole sentence negative. For example ME FRIGHTENED SPIDERS? NO-WAY (“I’m not frightened of spiders”). English = not, don't, doesn't, didn't.

nothing.description: (As a Noun) Something which is not very important. English = trifle, triviality.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very unimportant and not worth attention. English = (be) nothing, (be) trivial, (be) trifling, (be) insignificant.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To do nothing at all, usually because you are lazy or uninterested.

nothing%20happen.description: (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb to mean that the action did not occur during the period of an hour.

notice.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To look at something because you have just become aware of it. English = notice.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To become aware of something by having seen it or looked at it. English = notice, observe.

nought.description: (As a Noun) The number 0. English = zero, nought.; (As a Noun) In tennis, a score of zero. English = love.

noun.description: (As a Noun) In grammar, a word which is used to refer to a person, a thing, or an abstract idea such as a feeling or quality. English = noun; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term NOUN as it is used in an educational or academic context, especially when talking or writing about language and grammar. If you know a sign for NOUN used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign and supply details. Thank you.

novel.description: (As a Noun) The quality of being recently made or created; of not being owned or used before; of being different from what you had before; or of being only recently discovered. English = newness.; (As a Noun) The quality of being different, new, and unusual.
