score (tally).description: (As a Noun) The points each of the opposing teams or competitors have made in a game. English = score, tally.; (As a Noun) A person who calculates the points of opposing teams or competitors have made in a game. English = scorer.; (As a Noun) The process of working out a number or an amount by doing some arithmetic. English = calculation.

score%20(romantically).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To meet and talk to someone, get to know them and then to finally succeed in establishing a romantic or sexual relationship with them. Idiomatic English = catch (get) your man (woman).; (As a Verb or Adjective) To succeed in getting the man (or woman) you have had a romantic or sexual interest in for some time.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To meet someone for the first time or casually, to talk to them in order to start a sexual relationship with them, and to succeed at it. Idiomatic English = pick up, score.

score%20(scratch).description: (As a Noun) A line cut into the surface of something hard (like glass, metal, or ceramics) with something sharp and hard, often in order to break it along that line.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To cut a line into the surface of something hard (like glass, metal, or ceramics) with something sharp and hard, often in order to break it along that line. Formal English = score.

score%20(tally).description: (As a Noun) The points each of the opposing teams or competitors have made in a game. English = score, tally.; (As a Noun) A person who calculates the points of opposing teams or competitors have made in a game. English = scorer.; (As a Noun) The process of working out a number or an amount by doing some arithmetic. English = calculation.

scotland.description: (As a Noun) The country to the north of England, called Scotland.; (As a Noun) A person from Scotland. English = Scot, Scots.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To belong to or relate to Scotland. English = (be) Scottish, (be) Scots.

whisky.description: (As a Noun) A strong alcoholic drink made from grain such as barley or rye, especially in Scotland. English = whisky, whiskey, scotch.; (As a Noun) A strong alcoholic drink, such as whisky and gin. English = spirits.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To open a bottle of whisky or spirits.

scout.description: (As a Noun) A boy who is a member of the Scout Association. They go camping, learn how to look after themselves, and do things to help other people. English = scout.; (As a Noun) The salute used by scouts.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make a scout salute.

scout's%20hat.description: (As a Noun) A covering that you wear on your head which is tall and peaked. English = (peaked) hat.; (As a Noun) A long peaked black hat that witches are often portrayed as wearing. English = witch's hat.; (As a Noun) The peaked hat often worn by scouts. English = scout's hat.

scrambled%20eggs.description: (As a Noun) A food which is made of eggs mixed together and then cooked in a pan. English = scrambled eggs.

scrape.description: (As a Noun) The action of removing something from a surface by pulling a knife or some other sharp object over it. English = scraping.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To remove something from a surface by pulling a knife or other sharp object over it. English = scrape.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In motor mechanics, to grind the head of the engine.

scrape%20by.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of two objects, for one to pass very close by the other one (often slightly touching it) but continuing to move forward. English = skim over/past, glance by/off, scrape along/by; (As a Verb or Adjective) To try to deliberately hit one object with another, but to pass by without hitting, e.g., in snooker, for one ball to pass and just miss another ball. English = just miss.

scraps%20(food).description: (As a Noun) The act of not accepting or not agreeing to a proposal or a request. English = rejection.; (As a Noun) Pieces of unwanted food which are thrown away or given to animals. English = scraps.; (As a Noun) A statement or condition that says someone does not have to obey, follow or perform a rule or duty. English = exemption.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

claw.description: (As a Noun) Marks left on a person's or an animal's body from being clawed at or scratched. English = scratches.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of an animal or bird, to rub or move its claws over something. English = claw, scratch.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to rub or drag your fingernails across another person with the aim of hurting them. English = scratch.

skinniness.description: (As a Noun) A person who has extremely little fat on their body.; (As a Noun) The condition of having extremely little fat on your body. English = skinniness, scrawniness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have extremely little fat on your body. English = (be) thin, (be) skinny, (be) scrawny.

scream.description: (As a Noun) A very loud, high-pitched noise made with your voice and mouth, usually because you are in pain or are very frightened. English = scream, cry.; (As a Noun) A sudden loud scream. English = shriek.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make a very loud, high-pitched noise with your voice and mouth, usually because you are in pain or are very frightened. English = scream, scream out, cry, cry out.

screen%20(computer).description: (As a Noun) The vertical surface of a computer on which information and pictures are displayed. English = visual display screen, display screen, visual display unit (VDU), computer screen, monitor.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To display information or pictures on a computer screen.

screwdriver.description: (As a Noun) A tool that is used for turning screws. It consists of a metal rod with a thin end that fits into the top of a screw. English = screwdriver.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use a screwdriver, i.e., to screw in a screw. English = screw.

screw%20(sexual%20act).description: (As a Noun) The act of sexual intercourse between two people. Informal Australian English = screw, root.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have sex with someone. informal English = bonk.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have sexual intercourse with someone. Informal Australian English = screw, root.

screw-top.description: (As a Noun) A flat round covering to a container, such as a jar, that is fastened by being tightly twisted. English = screw-top, top, cap, lid.; (As a Noun) A glass container with a screw-top that is used for storing food such as jam. English = jar.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To fasten or unfasten a screw-top on a jar.

screw%20(use%20screwdriver).description: (As a Noun) A tool that is used for turning screws. It consists of a metal rod with a thin end that fits into the top of a screw. English = screwdriver.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use a screwdriver, i.e., to screw in a screw. English = screw.

scribble.description: (As a Noun) The act or result of writing something quickly or roughly, or making meaningless marks or rough drawings using a pen or a pencil. English = scribble, scribbling.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To write something quickly or roughly, or to make meaningless marks or rough drawings using a pen or a pencil. English = scribble.

scrimp%20and%20save.description: (As a Noun) The spending of as little money as possible by living cheaply, mainly because of difficult economic circumstances. English = frugality, sparingness, scrimping, economising.; (As a Noun) A plan showing how much money a person or organisation has available and how it should be spent. English = budget.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To live cheaply and spend as little money as possible; to use severe economy; to manage under difficult economic circumstances. English = scrimp, scrimp and save, (be) frugal, (be) sparing, make ends meet.

script.description: (As a Noun) The written version of a play, film, or television program. English = script.

scrum.description: (As a Noun) In rugby, a formation in which players from each side form a tight group and push against each other with their heads down in an attempt to get the ball. English = scrum.

scuba%20dive.description: (As a Noun) The activity in which you go under water, usually in the sea, using special breathing equipment for pleasure or work.; (As a Noun) A person who goes deep sea diving for pleasure or work. English = diver, deep sea diver, scuba diver.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go under water, usually in the sea, using special breathing equipment for pleasure or work. English = dive, go deep sea diving, go scuba diving.

scuba%20diver.description: (As a Noun) The activity in which you go under water, usually in the sea, using special breathing equipment for pleasure or work.; (As a Noun) A person who goes deep sea diving for pleasure or work. English = diver, deep sea diver, scuba diver.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go under water, usually in the sea, using special breathing equipment for pleasure or work. English = dive, go deep sea diving, go scuba diving.

seal%20(animal).description: (As a Noun) A large, shiny animal without legs, which eats fish and lives partly on land and partly in the sea. English = seal.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a seal, to clap flippers together.

sealed%20(closed%20with%20seal).description: (As a Noun) A small block of wood, metal or plastic with a handle, which has a pattern or a group of letters on one side. You press it into an inky pad and then onto a piece of paper in order to produce a mark. English = stamp.; (As a Noun) The mark left on a piece of paper by a stamp; an official mark left on a document to show that it is legal or genuine. English = stamp; seal.; (As a Noun) A stamp, usually made in wax, that marks and closes a container or a letter that must be broken before it can be opened. English = seal.

seal%20(mark).description: (As a Noun) A small block of wood, metal or plastic with a handle, which has a pattern or a group of letters on one side. You press it into an inky pad and then onto a piece of paper in order to produce a mark. English = stamp.; (As a Noun) The mark left on a piece of paper by a stamp; an official mark left on a document to show that it is legal or genuine. English = stamp; seal.; (As a Noun) A stamp, usually made in wax, that marks and closes a container or a letter that must be broken before it can be opened. English = seal.

seal%20(stick%20together).description: (As a Noun) A surface which has been joined, repaired or had something attached to it with long sticky strips of plastic.; (As a Noun) A stiff paste used to fix glass panes into frames and to fill cracks or holes in woodwork. English = putty.; (As a Noun) A rectangular paper cover in which you send a letter or card to someone through the post which has been closed along its sticky edge or with the use of a long sticky strip of plastic. English = sealed envelope.

sear.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) SEAR means to brown meat quickly over high heat to seal in the juices.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English keyword SEAR. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for SEAR (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic).  If you know a specific sign for SEAR used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

search.description: (As a Noun) An attempt to find something by looking for it. English = search.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To try to find something that you want but do not have, or that you did have but have lost, by looking carefully for it. English = look for, search. Formal English = seek.

seat-belt%20anchor.description: (As a Noun) The points on the inside of a car where the seat belts are attached to the frame of the vehicle. English = seat belt anchor.; (Note) A combination of the Auslan sign SEAT-BELT and a visual depiction of the two locations on one side of the body to which it is attached and the third bottom location to which the buckle being fastened. Source of this recommended sign: Victorian College for the Deaf.

seat%20belt%20(car).description: (As a Noun) A strap attached to a seat in a car. You fasten it across your body in order to prevent yourself being thrown out of the seat if there is a sudden movement. English = seat-belt.

seat%20belt%20(plane).description: (As a Noun) A strap attached to a seat in a car or an aeroplane. You fasten it across your body in order to prevent yourself being thrown out of the seat if there is a sudden movement. English = seat belt.; (As a Noun) A piece of metal or plastic attached to one end of a belt or strap, which is used to fasten it. English = buckle.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put on a belt, to fasten a belt, to buckle up a belt.

seat.description: (As a Noun) A object or a piece of furniture for people to sit on. English = seat, chair, stool.; (As a Noun) A place in a theatre or cinema from where you watch the performance. English = seat.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To support the weight of your body by resting your buttocks on a chair or seat with the upper part of your body upright. English = sit, sit down; (be) seated.

seated%20(at).description: (General Definition) A bent two (or ‘kneeling’) handshape held in this orientation, moved somewhere in the signing space and then moved slightly down with an abrupt off-set (i.e., bounce) is used to mean something is to be understood as being seated at that place. It usually means a person but it can also mean an animal. The sign is one of the types of ‘depicting’ signs that are used in Auslan.

second (time).description: (As a Noun) One of the sixty parts that a minute is divided into. English = second.; (As a Noun) A very brief period of time. English = second. Informal English = sec.; (As a Noun) In mathematics, the ratio of the hypotenuse to the shorter side adjacent to an acute angle (in a right angled triangle); the reciprocal of a cosine. English = secant.

second.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be the thing, person, event or period of time that happens or comes before all the others of the same kind, except for one. English = (be) second.; (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb to mean the action is done before anyone else or anything else does it, except for one. English = second.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning of a sentence after you have started to mention several things (events, reasons, etc.) and have got to your number two point. English = second, secondly.

secondary.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of education, to be the level of education for students between the ages of 11 or 12 and 18. English = (be) secondary.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be less important that something else. English = (be) secondary.

second (list).description: (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a phrase to mean that what you are talking about is the second of two, or the second in a series. It is often used to relate siblings in a family. English = secondly, the second is, the second-born is, and so on.

second%20(every%20second).description: (As a Noun) Each and every week which is the second week in a cycle (usually of four weeks or a month), or each and every unit of time which is the second unit in a cycle.; (As a Noun) A period of two weeks. English = fortnight.; (As Modifier) Used in a sentence (immediately next to a verb, or at the beginning or end of the sentence) to mean that the action happens every second week or every second unit of time which has already been established (day, month, semester, year, etc.).

second-hand.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To have been owned by someone else before and not be new. English = (be) second-hand.

second%20(list).description: (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a phrase to mean that what you are talking about is the second of two, or the second in a series. It is often used to relate siblings in a family. English = secondly, the second is, the second-born is, and so on.

second%20(of%20month).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) When giving dates of the calendar, to be the second day in the month.

second%20rower.description: (As a Noun) In rugby, either of the two forwards who pack down in the second row of a rugby scrum. English = second rower, second row forward.

second%20row%20forward.description: (As a Noun) In rugby, either of the two forwards who pack down in the second row of a rugby scrum. English = second rower, second row forward.

second%20(support).description: (As a Noun) A person who offers to do something without being obliged or forced to do so, especially socially useful work for which they are not paid. English = volunteer.; (As a Noun) Someone who chooses to join the army, navy, or air force, especially in wartime, as opposed to being forced to join by law. English = volunteer.; (As a Noun) Someone who has been chosen to talk or act on behalf of another person or a group of people and to express their views. English = representative.

second%20thoughts.description: (As a Noun) The act of changing a decision you have made or an opinion that you had. English = reconsideration. Idiomatic English = change of mind, second thoughts.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To change a decision you have made or an opinion that you had. English = reconsider. Idiomatic English = change one's mind, have second thoughts, think twice.

second%20(time).description: (As a Noun) One of the sixty parts that a minute is divided into. English = second.

secret.description: (As a Noun) Something that is known about by only a small number of people, and is not told or shown to anyone else.  English = secret.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be known about only by a small number of people and be kept that way by not being told or shown to anyone else. English = (be) secret, (be) confidential, (be) private.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make something a secret, to make something confidential; to keep a secret, to keep someone's confidence.

seen.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To have seen or done something before the time of speaking.; (Augmented Meaning) Auslan verb signs usually do not change to show time (i.e. past, present and future tense). However, there are a few exceptions, almost all of them made by joining the verb sign with a sign derived from one of two signs meaning 'finish'. The two signs are made like a single sign and often the overall meaning of the sign can change, as in this example.

see%20(not%20see).description: (As a Noun) Something which has been previously unseen because it is new, different and unusual. English = novelty.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have not seen or noticed something.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To not notice something or not realise its importance. English = (be) unaware of, overlook.

seesaw.description: (As a Noun) A long board which is balanced on a fixed part in the middle. Children play on it by making the board tilt up and down when one child sits on each end. English = seesaw.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go up and down on a seesaw. English = seesaw.

see%20you%20again.description: (Interactive) Used alone on leave-taking to mean that you hope and expect to see that person again soon. English = 'See you again.', 'Until next time.'

seize%20upon.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To take a child into your own family and make it legally your son or daughter. English = adopt (a child).; (As a Verb or Adjective) To eagerly take over something and make it your own because you want it or like it. English = seize upon, adopt.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To grab onto something and keep it for yourself or close to yourself because you want it or like it.

self%20(affix).description: (As Modifier) The sign can combine with verb and adjective signs (usually before them) to describe a person, device or a process that does an action automatically or by itself. English = self-; (Note) Like the pointing signs listed in this dictionary with the keywords ‘I/me’, ‘you’, ‘he/him’, ‘she/her’, ‘it’, ‘we/us’ and ‘they/them’ this sign can point in any direction. Also, like the possessive pointing signs ‘my/mine’, ‘your/yours’, etc., the sign points or indicates with the palm. It points in the direction of the thing or person it is referring to so it can mean other things and people too, like ‘myself’, ‘itself’, ‘himself’, ‘herself’, ‘ourselves’ and ‘themselves’. Use the keyword search to look at the form and definition of these other directed forms listed in the dictionary.

self%20control.description: (As a Noun) Calm, controlled and unemotional behaviour. English = restraint.; (As a Noun) The ability to control your emotions and remain calm, particularly when those emotions could easily be very strong. English = restraint, self control.; (As a Noun) The inability to express your emotions or the inability to behave naturally and to show your real feelings. English = inhibition.

self%20controlled.description: (As a Noun) Calm, controlled and unemotional behaviour. English = restraint.; (As a Noun) The ability to control your emotions and remain calm, particularly when those emotions could easily be very strong. English = restraint, self control.; (As a Noun) The inability to express your emotions or the inability to behave naturally and to show your real feelings. English = inhibition.

self%20(individual).description: (As a Noun) A person considered separately from everyone else; or a person's basic personality and nature. English = individual; self.; (As a Noun) A person who likes to do things in their own way; a person who likes to be alone. English = individualist; loner.; (As a Noun) A person who is not married, a single person.

self-managed%20(ndis).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To manage something by yourself for yourself without needing to rely on anyone else to manage it. English = self-manage, (be) self-managed.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In the NDIS (National Disability Insurance Scheme) a managemment plan which you directly manage yourself. You are responsible for all transactions. You may choose to employ support staff directly and do all the financial transactions or pay an organisation of your choice to do this on your behalf. This option has the most paperwork, but provides the most flexibility. English = self-managed (plan).×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

self-reflection.description: (As a Noun) Serious thought about one's character and actions. English = self-reflection.; (Note) Other suggested sign #1×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (Note) Other suggested sign #2×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

sell%20off.description: (As a Noun) Things that you no longer want and have thrown away or plan to throw away.; (As a Noun) Something which is not accepted, especially a product because something is wrong with it. English = reject.; (As a Noun) The act of expelling a member of a school or an organisation because of bad behaviour. English = expulsion.

meaning (semantics).description: (As a Noun) The thing that a single unit of a language (word or sign) or a whole expression refers to or expresses. Often this 'thing' is just other words and signs, rather than something you can point at. English = meaning, significance.; (As a Noun) The study of the meaning of words, signs, and sentences. English = semantics.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a unit of language (word or sign) or a whole expression, to refer to a thing or idea or express something. English = mean. Formal English = signify.

semester.description: (As a Noun) One of the two periods into which the year is divided at many universities and colleges. English = semester.

send.description: (As a Noun) The act of sending someone or something out and away from somewhere.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To send someone or something out and away from somewhere.

send%20away.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To get rid of something that you do not want; to throw something out.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To send something large and bulky somewhere.

send%20from.description: (As a Noun) The act of sending someone or something out and away from somewhere.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To send someone or something out and away from somewhere.

send%20off.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To order someone to leave somewhere, especially to go out of a room; to eject someone from a room or building.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a player in a team, to be told to stop playing by the referee and to be told to leave the court or field. English = (be) sent off.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To send someone out to get something, to send someone on an errand, or to a job.

send%20off%20(sport).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) In sports, to tell a player to leave the playing field because they have broken the rules of the game in some way. English = send off, dismiss.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In sports and games, to have done something which means you can no longer participate. English = (be) out.; (As Modifier) A Signed English sign for the English word 'out' used in all its senses.

send%20out.description: (As a Noun) The act of sending someone or something out and away from somewhere.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To send someone or something out and away from somewhere.

senile.description: (As a Noun) The condition of having lost one's mental powers and become less and less capable, especially because of age. English = senility.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To lose one's mental powers and become less and less capable, especially because of age. English = become senile, be senile.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of mental capacity or intelligence or knowledge, to become diminished, less and less, weaker or enfeebled.

separate%20(partners).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To end a relationship with someone, especially a casual sexual relationship or a defacto relationship. English = separate. Idiomatic English = break up, split up, dump, ditch, give someone the flick, tell someone it's over, (be) finished with.

sequence%20(mathematics).description: (As a Noun) A number of things or events that come one after the other. English = series.; (As a Noun) A number of things or events that come one after the other in a particular order. English = sequence.; (As a Noun) The particular order and series in which things of a particular type come one after another. English = succession.

sergeant.description: (As a Noun) A non-commissioned officer of middle rank in the army or air force. English = sergeant.

serious.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be very bad and cause people to worry. English = (be) serious, (be) severe, (be) grave.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be important and deserve careful and thoughtful consideration. English = (be) serious.

serotonin.description: (As a Noun) SEROTONIN is a chemical produced naturally in your brain that affects the way you feel, for example making you feel happier, calmer, or less hungry.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for SEROTONIN. If you know a sign for SEROTONIN used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

serve%20(tennis).description: (As a Noun) A game played by two or four players on a rectangular court. They use rackets to hit a ball over a net which is between them. English = tennis.; (As a Noun) The beginning of play in tennis when someone throws up the ball and hits it. English = serve.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To play tennis.

serve%20you%20right.description: (Interactive) Used alone to mean that you feel that what has happened to your addressee was deserved (maybe you had even warned them before hand), and that you hope the experience will serve them as a lesson in the future. You have little sympathy for them. Literally means ‘Let that remind you!”. English = 'That'll teach you!', 'Let that be a lesson', 'Serves you right!'.

service%20provider%20(ndis).description: (General Definition) Someone who has products or services to help participants achieve the goals in their plan. Participants can choose their providers and change providers at any time, this is also known as choice and control.

set%20aside.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To remove something or someone from something.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To take away some part of a larger thing or to take a person away from a family, group or organisation so that it is separate from the larger entity. English = remove from, separate from.

set%20(sun).description: (As a Noun) The time in the evening when the sky grows dark and then the sun disappears below the horizon. English = sunset.; (As a Noun) The colours and light that you see in the western part of the sky when the sun disappears in the evening. English = sunset.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of the sun, to go below the horizon. English = set.

seven.description: (As a Noun) The number 7, between 6 and 8. English = seven.

seventeen.description: (As a Noun) The number 17, between 16 and 18. English = seventeen.

seventh.description: (As Modifier) Of a sequence of numbers or things, the one which is between six (sixth) and eight (eighth) in that sequence. English = seventh.

sewing%20machine.description: (As a Noun) A machine that you use for sewing. English = sewing machine.; (As a Noun) A person whose job is to operate a sewing machine and make clothes. English = dressmaker.; (As a Noun) A job where a person uses sewing machines to make clothes. English = dressmaking.

sexual%20harassment.description: (As a Noun) Repeated and unwanted comments, proposals or behaviour of a sexual nature. English = sexual harassment.

sexual%20intercourse.description: (As a Noun) The act of having sex. Formal English = sexual intercourse, copulation.; (As a Noun) The physical activity which people and animals do with each other to produce offspring and/or to experience pleasure. English = sex.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have sex. Formal English = have sexual intercourse, copulate. English = make love.

sexually%20harass.description: (As a Noun) Repeated and unwanted comments, proposals or behaviour of a sexual nature. English = sexual harassment.

shake.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To hold someone or something firmly and move them quickly backwards and forwards or up and down. English = shake.

shake%20hands.description: (As a Noun) The act of holding someone's right hand in your own and moving it up and down when you are meeting them, saying goodbye to them, or congratulating them. English = handshake.; (As a Noun) The act of praising someone for something they have done, especially by shaking their hand. English = congratulations.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To take someone's hand in your hand and hold it firmly or move it up and down. You do this as a sign of greeting, to show that you have agreed about something, or to congratulate them. English = shake hands.

shake%20head.description: (As a Noun) A statement in which you say something is not true, usually be shaking you head side to side.; (As a Noun) A statement in which you say something is not true, especially when it has been claimed to be true of you. English = denial.; (As a Noun) A rejection of an offer. English = refusal, rejection.

will.description: (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb or verb phrase to mean that the person responsible for the action intends to do it or wants to do it after the time of speaking, sometime in the future. It expresses intent, determination or willingness, not just future tense. English = will, shall (when time of speaking is now and action is in the future), would (when time of speaking was in the past and the action was, or still is, in the future).

shallow.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of water in a sea, lake, river, or pool, to measure only a short distance from the bottom to the top. English = (be) shallow.

shampoo.description: (As a Noun) The act of washing your hair.; (As a Noun) A soapy liquid you use for washing your hair. English = shampoo.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wash your hair.

figure (body shape).description: (As a Noun) The appearance of the outside edges of a person, usually a woman. English = figure.; (As a Noun) The appearance of the outside edges of an object. English = figure, shape.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Particularly of women, to have an attractive figure. English = (be) shapely.

shark.description: (As a Noun) A very large fish with sharp teeth. It sometimes attacks people. English = shark.

sharp.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a knife etc., to have a very thin edge that is good for cutting things. English = (be) sharp.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make a knife or other cutting implement sharp. English = sharpen.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of someone's mind or intelligence, to be very good, clever and quick. English = (be) sharp, (be) quick witted.

splash.description: (As a Noun) A small quantity of a liquid, especially water, that has been spilt on something or caused to fly up into the air. English = splash.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To hit or disturb a liquid, especially water, in a noisy way, causing it to spill or causing some of it to fly up into the air. English = splash.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a thing, to break into many small pieces when it falls and hits the ground. English = smash, shatter.

shave%20(face).description: (As a Noun) The act of cutting hair from your face using a razor. English = shave.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a man, to cut the hair from his face using a razor. English = shave, have a shave.

shave%20(head).description: (As a Noun) A head with no hair on it because it has all been shaved off.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To shave all the hair off your head.

shave%20(leg).description: (As a Noun) Legs which have been shaved.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To shave your legs.

shaver.description: (As a Noun) An electric tool used for shaving hair from the face and body. English = shaver, electric shaver.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To shave oneself using an electric shaver.

shave%20(underarm).description: (As a Noun) Armpits which have been shaved.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To shave under your arms.

sheep%20shearer.description: (As a Noun) Someone who makes a living shearing sheep for sheep farmers. English = sheep shearer.; (As a Noun) The act of shearing a sheep. English = sheep shearing.; (As a Noun) A farm animal with a thick woolly coat. It is kept for its wool or for its meat. English = sheep.

sheep%20shearing.description: (As a Noun) Someone who makes a living shearing sheep for sheep farmers. English = sheep shearer.; (As a Noun) The act of shearing a sheep. English = sheep shearing.; (As a Noun) A farm animal with a thick woolly coat. It is kept for its wool or for its meat. English = sheep.

sheet.description: (As a Noun) A large rectangular piece of cloth , usually made of cotton and used with blankets or a doona to make a bed. English = sheet.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To pull a sheet up over your body, usually in a bed.

sheet%20of%20paper.description: (As a Noun) A piece of paper with questions on it. You write the answers on the same piece of paper. English = form.; (As a Noun) A sheet of paper, usually one which is longer than it is wide, e.g., an A4 size of paper.

shelf.description: (As a Noun) A flat piece of wood, metal, or glass which is attached to a wall or the sides of a cupboard. They are used for keeping things on. English = shelf.; (As a Noun) A narrow shelf along the bottom edge of a window. English = ledge.; (As a Noun) A narrow, flat place in the side of a cliff or mountain. English = ledge.

shell.description: (As a Noun) The hard covering which surrounds an egg or nut, or the hard, protective covering on the back of a tortoise, snail, or crab. English = shell.

shepherd.description: (As a Noun) A person who looks after or rounds up sheep. English = shepherd.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To round up sheep and direct them to go in a certain direction. English = shepherd, herd (sheep).; (As a Verb or Adjective) To look after and guide someone towards where you want them to go. Often used in a religious sense. English = shepherd.

shield.description: (As a Noun) A sports trophy or badge in the shape of a shield. English = shield.

shift%20(move).description: (As a Noun) A transfer from living in one house into another. English = move.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To go and live in a different house, taking your possessions with you. English = move, move house, move out, shift.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To change your position or to go to a different place, especially by moving sideways. English = move, move aside, move sideways, step sideways, step aside.

shift%20(work).description: (As a Noun) A set period of time during which people work in a factory. English = shift.; (As a Noun) Work which is done for periods of time during different shifts throughout the day. English = shift work.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To work on a shift.

shine%20(reflect).description: (As a Noun) The bright or glassy appearance of an object because light bounces off it into your eyes. English = shine, shininess.; (As a Noun) The process by which light is sent back or bounces off a surface, particularly when it produces a clear image of the observer or another object. English = reflection.; (As a Noun) A hard, shiny silver-colored metal. English = chrome, chromium.

shock%20absorber.description: (General Definition) A cylinder that moves up and down inside another one or any thing or any action that can be associated with this in context.; (As a Noun) A device in a car which contracts and expands in order to absorb sudden movement. English = shock absorber.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for SHOCK ABSORBER for most signers (but signers can represent this visually using depicting signs in context). Source of this recommended sign: Victorian College for the Deaf.

shoe.description: (As a Noun) Objects which you wear on your feet which are made of leather or plastic which has a shiny surface. They cover most of your foot and you wear them over socks or stockings. English = patent leather shoes.; (As a Noun) Objects which you wear on your feet which are polished. They cover most of your foot and you wear them over socks or stockings. English = polished shoes.; (As a Noun) Objects which you wear on your feet. They cover most of your foot and you wear them over socks or stockings. English = shoes.

shoe%20polish.description: (As a Noun) Objects which you wear on your feet which are made of leather or plastic which has a shiny surface. They cover most of your foot and you wear them over socks or stockings. English = patent leather shoes.; (As a Noun) Objects which you wear on your feet which are polished. They cover most of your foot and you wear them over socks or stockings. English = polished shoes.; (As a Noun) Objects which you wear on your feet. They cover most of your foot and you wear them over socks or stockings. English = shoes.

shoot%20up.description: (As a Noun) A small tube with a plunger and a fine hollow needle or pointed end. It is used for putting liquids into something and taking them out, for example drugs into a person's body or for taking blood samples from them. English = syringe, hypodermic needle.; (As a Noun) The act of using a syringe to put liquids into a person's body. English = injection. Informal English = jab.; (As a Noun) The act of injecting someone with a weak form of a disease as a way of protecting them from it. English = immunisation, inoculation, vaccination.

shop.description: (As a Noun) A building or part of a building where things are sold. English = shop, store.; (As a Noun) The act of going to shops and buying things. English = shopping.; (As a Noun) Things that you have bought at a shop. English = shopping.

bank (shore).description: (As a Noun) A place where land or some other solid surface is found right next to a body of water.; (As a Noun) The land along the edge of a sea, lake, or wide river, where water and land come together. English = shore.; (As a Noun) The raised ground along the edge of a river or lake. English = bank.

short.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be not as tall as most people. English = (be) short.

shortcrust%20pastry.description: (As a Noun) A crumbly pastry made with flour, fat, and a little water, usually used for pies, flans, and tarts. English = shortcrust pastry.; (Note) The following signs or sign expressions are recommended for ‘shortcrust pastry’. Source: DeafConnectED, Melbourne Polytechnic.; (Note) Suggested sign #1×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

short%20hair.description: (As a Noun) Hair which is worn short.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To have short hair.

short%20of.description: (As a Noun) The process of making something smaller. English = reduction.; (As a Noun) A short account of something, which gives the main points but not the details. English = summary.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Noun) A shortened form of a word or phrase, e.g., Dr for Doctor, cm for centimeter, PM for Prime Minister. English = abbreviation.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

shorts.description: (As a Noun) Short pants that do not go beyond your knees. English = shorts, pair of shorts.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wear shorts.

short%20sleeved.description: (General Definition) To trace a line across a limb or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this.; (As a Noun) A piece of clothing worn over your arms which is attached at the shoulders to the rest of a garment and which ends before the elbow. English = short sleeve shirt.; (As a Noun) A piece of clothing that you wear on the top half of your body. It has short sleeves, no collar, and no buttons down the front. English = T-shirt.

short%20sleeve%20shirt.description: (General Definition) To trace a line across a limb or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this.; (As a Noun) A piece of clothing worn over your arms which is attached at the shoulders to the rest of a garment and which ends before the elbow. English = short sleeve shirt.; (As a Noun) A piece of clothing that you wear on the top half of your body. It has short sleeves, no collar, and no buttons down the front. English = T-shirt.

shot-put.description: (As a Noun) In athletics, a competition in which the contestants throw a heavy metal ball as far as possible. English = shot put.

should.description: (Interactive) Used alone to mean you think that the action under discussion is right, it is good that it happens, or that you feel that it will happen. English = 'It should...," "It ought to...,"; (As Modifier) Used before or after a verb to mean that you think that it is right or good that the action happens, or that you feel that it will happen. You use this sign when you are suggesting that someone do something. English = should, ought to.; (Augmented Meaning) If you make the sign with more stress (increasing the size and speed of the movement, and making it stop suddenly at the end) you 'harden the meaning' of this sign. It then means that you feel very strongly that it happens, or that you are ordering someone to do something. English = must, have to.

shoulder.description: (As a Noun) The part of your body between your neck and the top of your arm. English = shoulder.

should%20(should%20not).description: (Interactive) Used alone to mean you think that the action under discussion is not right, it is not good that it happens, or that you feel that it will not happen.; (As Modifier) Used before or after a verb (action) sign to mean that you think that it is not right or not good that the action happens, or that you feel that it will not happen. English = shouldn't, ought not to.; (As Modifier) You use this sign when you are suggesting that someone not do something.

shower.description: (As a Noun) A device used for washing yourself. It consists of a pipe or hose which ends in a flat piece with a lot of holes in it so that water comes out in a spray over your head and onto your body. English = shower.; (As a Noun) A wash you have by standing under a shower. English = shower.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wash yourself by standing under a shower. English = shower, have a shower.

show%20(fair).description: (As a Noun) At a fair, a device which people ride for fun which is made of a large wheel rotating vertically with seats attached around its rim.  English = Ferris wheel.; (As a Noun) A large annual fair or show in any one of the state capitals of Australia in which there is a competitive display of farm produce and livestock and amusement rides. Australian English = show.

show%20off.description: (As a Noun) A person who behaves in a way that shows their skills or abilities very obviously, in order to impress people. English = show-off, show off.

show-off.description: (As a Noun) A person who behaves in a way that makes their skills or good qualities very obvious, in order to impress people. English = show-off.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To behave in a way that makes your skills or good qualities very obvious, in order to impress people. English = show off.

show%20(performance).description: (As a Noun) An arrangement of things that is intended to attract people's attention. English = show, display.; (As a Noun) A public event that is intended to entertain people. English = show.; (As a Noun) The entertaining of an audience by doing something like singing, dancing, playing music, acting a play, or acting a role in a play. English = performance.

show%20up.description: (As a Noun) Something that happens unexpectedly or without warning.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To happen suddenly or as a surprise. English = (be) unexpected.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To appear in a place unexpectedly or to attend an event unexpectedly or without having been invited. Idiomatic English = show up, pop up.

shrinkage.description: (As a Noun) A decrease in the size or amount of something, especially clothes after they have been washed. English = shrinkage.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a cloth or clothes, to become smaller in size, usually as a result of being washed. English = shrink.

shuffle%20(cards).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To mix up a pack of cards before you begin a game. English = shuffle.

shut.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To close the entrance to a building, room, or vehicle by swinging a piece of wood, glass, or metal across the entrance; to close a door. English = close, shut.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To close the opening on any kind of object.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a door, to close or be closed.

shut%20(door).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To close the entrance to a building, room, or vehicle by swinging a piece of wood, glass, or metal across the entrance; to close a door. English = close, shut.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To close the opening on any kind of object.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a door, to close or be closed.

shut%20up.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To stop talking (signing or speech) abruptly. English = shut up.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To talk rudely or abruptly to someone, often ending by telling them to shut up; to snap at someone.; (Interactive) Used alone to tell your addressee to stop talking (speech or signing) immediately, especially if they are about to say something which should not be overseen by others.

sickie.description: (As a Noun) A day taken off work with pay for genuine or, especially, feigned illness. Informal English = sickie.; (As a Noun) The time that a person is officially allowed to spend away from work because of illness or injury. English = sick leave.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To take a day off work with pay for genuine or, especially, feigned illness. Informal English = take a sickie, chuck a sickie.

sick%20leave.description: (As a Noun) A day taken off work with pay for genuine or, especially, feigned illness. Informal English = sickie.; (As a Noun) The time that a person is officially allowed to spend away from work because of illness or injury. English = sick leave.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To take a day off work with pay for genuine or, especially, feigned illness. Informal English = take a sickie, chuck a sickie.

side.description: (As a Noun) The position to the left or right of something, rather than in front of it or behind it. English = side.; (As a Noun) The parts of your body under your arms from your armpits down to your hips. English = side, sides.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be located next to the side of a person. English = beside.

sideboards.description: (As a Noun) On a man, a strip of hair growing down the side of each cheek. English = sideboards, sideburns.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a man, to have sideburns.

side-effect.description: (As a Noun) The SIDE-EFFECTS of a drug are the effects, usually bad ones, that the drug has on you in addition to its function of curing illness or pain.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for SIDE-EFFECT. If you know a sign for SIDE-EFFECT used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

sideward.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To go from or to the side of something or someone. English = go sidewards.

sieve.description: (As a Noun) A tool used for separating liquids from solids or larger pieces of something from smaller pieces of it. It usually consists of a wire net which the liquids or smaller pieces pass through. English = sieve.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To operate a device with an overlapping grid of wires or slats, especially in order to let objects only of a certain size pass through; to operate a sieve. English = sift.

sifter.description: (As a Noun) A sieve for sifting flour operated by pulling on a lever attached to a handle on the side. It is a device used in the kitchen. English = sifter.

sigma.description: (As a Noun) The eighteenth letter of the Greek alphabet, written as Σ in upper case, called ‘sigma’. It is used as a symbol in mathematics and scientific notation to mean sum or summation (i.e., total). English = sigma.

sign%20badly.description: (As a Noun) Signing which is very bad and unclear, either because you have not learned to sign well or perhaps because you are nervous, distracted or intoxicated.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To sign in an unclear and sloppy way, either because you have not learned to sign well or perhaps because you are nervous, distracted or intoxicated. English = slur, slur one's words.

sign%20language.description: (As a Noun) A language which is made and communicated by using visual-gestural signs. English = sign language, sign.; (As a Noun) The thing that a single unit of a language (word or sign) or a whole expression refers to or expresses. Often this 'thing' is just other words and signs, rather than something you can point at. English = meaning, significance.; (As a Noun) A single visual-gestural unit of a sign language. English = sign.

sign%20(notice).description: (General Definition) The outline of a square or square-shaped object. It can be enlarged or reduced, raised or lowered, to depict any type of object which is square or rectangular, such as a picture, poster, notice, sign, chart, window, square, or rectangle.; (As a Noun) A rectangular surface on which lines and shapes are drawn, painted, or printed that show a person, a thing, or scene. English = picture.; (As a Noun) A rectangular surface on which words and pictures are drawn, painted, or printed to inform people about something. English = poster, notice, sign, chart.

signpost.description: (As a Noun) A sign beside a road which has information on it such as the name of a town and how far away it is. It usually points in the direction and is often actually shaped like an arrow. English = signpost.

sign%20(signature).description: (As a Noun) Your name when you write it in your own characteristic way. English = signature.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To write your name on a document, usually at the end or in a special place. English = sign.

sign%20(sign%20language).description: (As a Noun) A language which is made and communicated by using visual-gestural signs. English = sign language, sign.; (As a Noun) The thing that a single unit of a language (word or sign) or a whole expression refers to or expresses. Often this 'thing' is just other words and signs, rather than something you can point at. English = meaning, significance.; (As a Noun) A single visual-gestural unit of a sign language. English = sign.

sign%20(signpost).description: (As a Noun) A piece of wood, metal, or plastic with words or pictures on it, found hanging outside buildings or on the top of poles in the street. It tells you where or what a particular place is, or gives you a warning or an instruction. English = sign.; (As a Noun) A sign found at the top of a pole at a street corner that tells you the name of a street. English = street sign.

silly%20mid%20on%20(cricket).description: (As a Noun) In cricket, fielding positions close in to the batsman's wicket. English = silly mid-on, silly mid-off.

silver.description: (As a Noun) A valuable greyish-white metal that is used for making jewellery and ornaments. English = silver.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be greyish-white in colour. English = (be) silver.

similar.description: (As a Noun) The quality of two or more things, qualities, quantities or actions being exactly alike in some way. English = similarity, likeness.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of two or more things, they have features that are like each other but not exactly the same. English = (be) similar.

simmer.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To cook food by keeping it at or just below the boiling point. English = simmer.

since%20(not%20since).description: (Interactive) Used alone on meeting people to mean it has been a long time since you saw them last. English = 'I haven't seen you for ages!', 'It's been ages!', and so on.; (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb to mean that the action did not begin at the present time (or a time which is understood) and does not extend into the future (or after that time). English =  not since.; (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a time sign to mean the something will not happen from that time and into the future from that time. English = not since.

sine.description: (As a Noun) In mathematics, a trigonometric function that is equal to the ratio of the side opposite a given angle (in a right angled triangle) to the hypotenuse.

singapore.description: (As a Noun) An island nation at the tip of the Malay peninsula, called Singapore.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To come from or relate to Singapore. English = (be) Singaporean.

singles.description: (As a Noun) A sports competition in which only two people compete against each other. English = singles.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be only one and not more. English = (be) single.

single-minded.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To have only one aim or purpose and to be determined to achieve it. English = (be) single-minded.

singlet.description: (General Definition) Something long and narrow that goes over your shoulder, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, such as the strap of a bag or satchel, the strap of a bra, slip or dress, and especially a singlet.; (As a Noun) A sleeveless piece of underwear that is worn by a man on the top half of his body. English = singlet.

sink.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a boat, to stop floating and to move slowly downwards below the level of the water. English = sink.

sinking.description: (As a Noun) The action of something moving slowly downwards through air or water.; (As a Noun) The action of moving slowly downwards, especially below the surface of water. English = sinking.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move slowly downwards through air or water.

alarm (siren).description: (As a Noun) A warning device which consists of a rapidly rotating and flashing light (usually red) attached inside buildings onto ceilings or walls, or on the top of emergency vehicles (fire, police, etc). It lights and spins when there is an alarm. English = visual alarm.; (As a Noun) A warning device which consists of a rapidly rotating and flashing light (usually red) and a long, loud, wailing noise. It is usually located on the top of emergency vehicles (fire, police, etc). English = siren.; (As a Noun) A warning device that makes a long, loud, wailing noise when there is an alarm. English = siren.

sister.description: (As a Noun) A girl or a woman who has the same parents as you. English = sister.; (As a Noun) A woman who is a member of a religious order. English = sister.; (As a Noun) A senior nurse who supervises a hospital ward. English = sister.

sit%20(at).description: (General Definition) A bent two (or ‘kneeling’) handshape held in this orientation, moved somewhere in the signing space and then moved slightly down with an abrupt off-set (i.e., bounce) is used to mean something is to be understood as being seated at that place. It usually means a person but it can also mean an animal. The sign is one of the types of ‘depicting’ signs that are used in Auslan.

sit%20on.description: (As a Noun) A person who is sitting down, a seated person.; (As a Noun) A piece of furniture for one person to sit on, with a back and four legs. English = chair.; (As a Noun) An object you can sit on, for example a chair. English = seat.

sit%20(opposite%20each%20other).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To sit opposite someone across a table or a room.

situation.description: (As a Noun) The general happenings in a particular place at a particular time; the things that are happening to you or that are likely to happen to you at a particular time. English = situation.

six.description: (As a Noun) The number 6 between 5 and 7. English = six.

six-cylinder.description: (As a Noun) A car which has a six-cylinder engine.

sixteen.description: (As a Noun) The number 16 between 15 and 17. English = sixteen.

sixth.description: (As Modifier) Of a sequence of numbers or things, the one which is between five (fifth) and seven (seventh) in that sequence. English = sixth.

size%20(in%20width%20or%20clothes).description: (As a Noun) The measure of bigness or smallness, or narrowness or width of something, especially clothes. English = size.

size%20(of%20container).description: (As a Noun) The measure of bigness or smallness of a container of something, usually a pre-packaged product of food you buy in a store. The products usually come in a series of graded measurements shared across products. English = size.

skewer.description: (As a Noun) A thin, pointed metal or wooden rod onto which chunks of food are threaded, to secure food during cooking. English = skewer.; (Note) The following signs or sign expressions are recommended for ‘skewer’. Source: DeafConnectED, Melbourne Polytechnic.; (Note) Suggested sign #1×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video

skiing.description: (As a Noun) The sport in which you move on snow wearing long, flat, narrow pieces of wood, metal, or plastic that are fastened to boots. English = skiing.; (As a Noun) The sport in which you ski on water while being pulled by a boat. English = water-skiing.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move over snow using skis. English = ski.

skim.description: (General Definition) The action of scooping something off the top of something and discarding it, or any thing or any action that can be easily associated with this in a given context.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To remove the top layer off a liquid. English = skim.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for SKIM (but some signers represent this visually using these depicting signs, once they have established the topic).    If you know a sign for SKIM used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

skim%20over.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of two objects, for one to pass very close by the other one (often slightly touching it) but continuing to move forward. English = skim over/past, glance by/off, scrape along/by; (As a Verb or Adjective) To try to deliberately hit one object with another, but to pass by without hitting, e.g., in snooker, for one ball to pass and just miss another ball. English = just miss.

skim%20(read).description: (As a Noun) One side of one of the pieces of paper in a book, magazine, or newspaper. English = page.; (As a Noun) The pieces of paper that a book, magazine, or newspaper consist of. English = page.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To turn over a page or the pages of a book or magazine.

skipping.description: (As a Noun) A type of movement, almost like dancing, in which you make a series of little jumps from one foot to the other. English = skipping.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move by making a series of little jumps from one foot to the other. English = skip.

skipping%20rope.description: (As a Noun) A rope, usually with a handle at each end, that is used for skipping. English = skipping rope.; (As a Noun) The game or activity of jumping up and down over a rope. English = skipping.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To jump up and down over a rope which you or two other people are holding at each end and turning round and round. English = skip.

skipping%20(with%20rope).description: (As a Noun) A rope, usually with a handle at each end, that is used for skipping. English = skipping.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To jump up and down over a rope which you or two other people are holding at each end and turning round and round. English = skip.

skirt.description: (As a Noun) A piece of clothing worn by women and girls which fastens at the waist and hangs down to above or below the knees. English = skirt.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wear a skirt.

video call.description: (As a Noun) A way of communicating with people through the internet using on-line video as well as sound. The people talking or signing to each other can see each other on a computer screen. English = video call.; (As a Noun) A computer program that allows you to call someone and communicate via sound and video, or by video alone, through the internet.
