English = next week.; (As a Noun) A period of seven days after another specified day in the past or future.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence or immediately next to a verb to mean the action takes place during the next calendar week after the week of speaking. English = next week.

week%20(this%20past%20week).description: (As a Noun) A recurring period of time (such as a week, month or year) before the time of speaking. The unit of time has already been mentioned. English = this week, this month, this year, etc.; (As a Noun) The used up or elapsed time within the unit of time (week, month, year, etc.) being talked about; this past week, this past month, this past year, etc.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence, or immediately next to a verb, to mean the action takes place sometime during the previous unit of time being talked about, or before some other reference time.

week%20(this%20week).description: (As a Noun) A recurring period of time (such as a week, month or year) the unit of which has already been mentioned and which the signer is in at the time of speaking. English = this week, this month, this year, etc.; (As a Noun) The remaining time within the unit of time (week, month, year, etc.) being talked about; the rest of this week, this month, this year, etc.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence, or immediately next to a verb, to mean the action takes place sometime during the following unit of time being talked about (week, month, year, etc.), or after some other time reference point. English = during this week (month, year), during that week (month, year), this time.

week%20(week%20after).description: (As a Noun) A period of seven days after the day of speaking or after another specified day in the past or future.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence or immediately next to a verb to mean the action takes place during the next seven days after the week of speaking. English = during the next seven days.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence or immediately next to a verb to mean the action takes place during the seven days immediately following some other day. English = during the following seven days.

week%20(week%20ago).description: (As a Noun) The period of seven days before the time of speaking.; (As a Noun) A period of seven days before another day already specified in the past or future.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence or immediately next to a verb to mean that the action took place sometime during the previous seven days from the day of speaking. English = during the past week, during the past seven days.

weight%20lifter.description: (As a Noun) A building or a large room which is used for physical exercise and usually has equipment such as bars and ropes in it. English = gymnasium, gym.; (As a Noun) Exercises which involve the lifting and moving of heavy weights. English = weight training, weight lifting.; (As a Noun) A sport's competition that involves the lifting of heavy weights. English = weight lifting.

weight%20lifting.description: (As a Noun) A building or a large room which is used for physical exercise and usually has equipment such as bars and ropes in it. English = gymnasium, gym.; (As a Noun) Exercises which involve the lifting and moving of heavy weights. English = weight training, weight lifting.; (As a Noun) A sport's competition that involves the lifting of heavy weights. English = weight lifting.

weight%20training.description: (As a Noun) A building or a large room which is used for physical exercise and usually has equipment such as bars and ropes in it. English = gymnasium, gym.; (As a Noun) Exercises which involve the lifting and moving of heavy weights. English = weight training, weight lifting.; (As a Noun) A sport's competition that involves the lifting of heavy weights. English = weight lifting.

weigh%20up.description: (As a Noun) A choice that you make about what should be done or about which is the best of various alternatives. English = decision.; (As a Noun) The act of deciding something. English = decision, decision making.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To choose to do something, usually after you have thought carefully about the other possibilities. English = decide.

weird.description: (As a Noun) A strange thought, idea or suggestion.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of something or someone, to seem strange and peculiar. English = (be) weird.

welcome.description: (As a Noun) The act of greeting someone in a friendly way when they arrive somewhere. English = welcome.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To greet someone in a friendly way when they arrive somewhere. English = to welcome.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be friendly and welcoming to guests and strangers. English = (be) welcoming, (be) hospitable.

welder.description: (As a Noun) A person whose job is welding metal. English = welder.; (As a Noun) A join where two pieces of metal have been welded together. English = weld.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To join two pieces of metal together by heating their edges and fixing them together so that they cool and harden into one piece. English = weld.

welfare%20work.description: (As a Noun) Work which involves giving help and advice to people with serious financial problems or family problems. English = social work, welfare work.; (As a Noun) A person whose job is to do social or welfare work. English = social worker, welfare worker.; (As a Noun) Someone whose job is to be in charge of something, especially an institution (such as a hospital, hostel, dormitory, welfare association etc.). He or she is also often a social or welfare worker. English = superintendent.

welfare%20worker.description: (As a Noun) Work which involves giving help and advice to people with serious financial problems or family problems. English = social work, welfare work.; (As a Noun) A person whose job is to do social or welfare work. English = social worker, welfare worker.; (As a Noun) Someone whose job is to be in charge of something, especially an institution (such as a hospital, hostel, dormitory, welfare association etc.). He or she is also often a social or welfare worker. English = superintendent.

well-being.description: (As a Noun) Your condition in life (mental and physical), that is whether you are healthy and happy. English = well-being.

well%20(get%20well).description: (As a Noun) The change from being sick to being healthy again. English = cure, recovery, recuperation.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To change from being sick to being healthy again. English = (be) healed, become well, get better, (be) cured; recuperate, recover.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make someone change from being sick to being healthy again. English = heal, cure.

well%20(healthy).description: (As a Noun) The state in which you are fit and well and not ill. English = health.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be not suffering from any illness. English = (be) well, (be) healthy.; (Interactive) Used alone with a questioning look to greet someone. English = 'How are you?'

well-known%20(familiar).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To recognise someone or something or know about them well because you have seen, heard, or experienced them before. English = know well, (be) well-known, (be) familiar with.; (Interactive) Used alone in reply to someone who tells you something that is well-known to you already or mentions to you someone well-known to you as if you did not know them.

well-known%20(famous).description: (As a Noun) Someone who is well known, especially in acting or show business. English = celebrity.; (As a Noun) The state of being well known by everyone, especially for your achievements. English = fame.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be well known, especially in acting or show business. English = (be) famous.

well%20(not%20badly).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of situations and events, for things to go or turn out very well.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of two people, to meet and get on very well.; (Interactive) Used alone (with a questioning facial expression) to ask someone how they are or how things have been going. English = 'How are things going?', 'How have you been?', and so on.

well%20(palm%20up%20gesture).description: (Interactive) Used alone when you mean what you are about to say is easily understood or easy for anyone to agree with given the context, or that it is easy to understand or agree with what the person you have been talking to has said given the context. English = 'Well...', 'Well, there you are...', 'Well, there you go...', 'That's all there is to it...', 'That's it...', 'Yeah...', 'Yep...', 'Yep, of course...', and so on.; (Interactive) Used alone when you are hesitating, usually because you have not decided what to say next. It also means you don't mind if the person you are talking to interrupts or takes over. English = 'Well...', 'Umm...', 'Err...', and so on.; (As Question) Used alone as general question sign to suggest that one or more questions (who, what, where, why, how, or when) could be asked about what has just been said by either the signer or the addressee, depending on the context. For example, “Who would do such a thing...?”, “Why would anyone do that...?”, “Where’s that...?”, “How exactly did that happen...?’, and so on.

west.description: (As a Noun) The direction which you look towards in order to see the sun set. English = west.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be located in or associated with the west. English = (be) west, (be) western, (be) westerly.; (As Modifier) Used next to a verb to mean the direction of movement is towards the west. English = west, westwards.

western%20(movie).description: (As a Noun) A book or film about life in the west of America in the nineteenth century. The story usually involves a lot of fighting and shooting. English = western.; (As a Noun) A male character in a western book or film. English = cowboy.; (As a Noun) A man employed to look after cattle in the nineteenth century American West. English = cowboy.

wet%20the%20bed.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of people, especially children, to urinate in your bed because you cannot control your bladder. Idiomatic English = wet the bed.

wfd.description: (As a Noun) An international association which represents deaf people. English = World Federation of the Deaf (WFD).

whale.description: (As a Noun) A very large animal that lives in the sea and looks like a huge fish. English = whale.

what%20age.description: (As a Noun) The number of years that you have lived. English = age.; (As Modifier) Used next to a number sign to mean someone has that particular number of years in age. English = (be) aged.; (As Question) Used to ask the number of years a person has lived. English = how old, what age.

wheel%20alignment.description: (As a Noun) The adjustment of the wheels of the car so that they are perfectly parallel to each other. English = wheel alignment.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In car mechanics, to adjust the wheels of a car so that they are perfectly parallel to each other; to align the wheels of a car.

wheelchair.description: (As a Noun) A chair with wheels that ill or injured people use in order to move about, when they cannot walk. English = wheelchair.

whip%20(hit).description: (As a Noun) A piece of leather or rope fastened to a handle, which is used for hitting people or animals. English = whip.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To hit a person or animal with a whip. English = whip.

whip%20(mix).description: (As a Noun) A kitchen tool with rotating blades used for beating eggs or whipping cream. English = egg-beater.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To stir cream or eggs very fast until they are thick and frothy or stiff, especially using an egg-beater. English = whip.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use an egg-beater. English = whip, beat.

whipped%20cream.description: (As a Noun) A kitchen tool with rotating blades used for beating eggs or whipping cream. English = egg-beater.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To stir cream or eggs very fast until they are thick and frothy or stiff, especially using an egg-beater. English = whip.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To use an egg-beater. English = whip, beat.

whisper.description: (As a Noun) A very quiet voice in which you use your breath and not your throat. English = whisper.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To say something to someone very quietly, using only your breath and not your throat, so that other people cannot hear what you are saying; to sign secretly by hiding one's hands from the view of other people. English = whisper.

whistle.description: (As a Noun) A small metal tube which you blow in order to produce a loud sound and attract someone's attention. English = whistle.; (As a Noun) A sound that you make when you force your breath out between your lips or blow on a whistle. English = whistle.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To make a sound by forcing air out between your lips; to blow on a whistle. English = whistle.

white.description: (As a Noun) The lightest colour that there is, the colour of snow or milk. English = white.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be or have the colour of snow or milk. English = (be) white.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To become white or even more white. English = whiten.

whiting.description: (As a Noun) A kind of small fish. English = whiting.

whs%20(workplace%20health%20and%20safety.description: (As a Noun) WHS (Workplace Health and Safety) are the rules protecting the health, safety and welfare of people engaged in work or employment.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term WORKPLACE HEALTH AND SAFETY (WHS). There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for WORKPLACE HEALTH AND SAFETY (WHS) (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for WORKPLACE HEALTH AND SAFETY (WHS)used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

wicket.description: (As a Noun) A set of three upright sticks with two small sticks on top of them, which the ball is bowled at in cricket. There is one at each end of a cricket pitch. English = wicket.

wicket-keeper.description: (As a Noun) The player in a cricket team who stands behind the wicket in order to stop balls that the batsman misses or to catch balls that the batsman hits. English = wicket-keeper.

wide%20ball%20(cricket).description: (As a Noun) In cricket, a ball which is bowled too far or too much to one side. English = wide ball.

wild.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of animals and plants, to live or grow in natural surroundings and not to be looked after by people. English = (be) wild.

will%20(bequeath).description: (As a Noun) Money or property that someone gives to someone else after they die, or money  or property that someone receives after someone else has died.; (As a Noun) Money or property that someone gives to someone else after they die. Formal English = bequest.; (As a Noun) Money or property that someone is given by someone who dies. English = inheritance.

go ahead.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To start to do something after either hesitating or waiting for permission to do so, or even contrary to the wishes of others. English = go ahead, proceed.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To suggest someone do something or to challenge someone to do something to show how brave or reckless they are. English = dare.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be prepared to do something that may be difficult, dangerous, or the product of a challenge or dare. English = (be) willing. Idiomatic English (be) up for it.

will%20not.description: (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb or verb phrase to mean that the person responsible for the action does not intend to do it after the time of speaking, i.e., some time in the future. It expresses lack of intent, determination not to or unwillingness. English = won't, will not, wouldn't.

wind%20(air).description: (As a Noun) A current of air moving across the earth's surface which you can feel blowing past your body, especially your face. English = wind.; (As a Noun) A gentle wind. English = breeze.; (As a Noun) A gust of wind.

wind%20forward%20(tape).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To play the tape on a tape recorder or video so that it moves forward and you can see or hear what is on it. English = play tape.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move the tape on a tape recorder or video forward so that it goes to a place nearer the end where you want to be. English = wind forward.

wind%20instrument.description: (As a Noun) A musical instrument that you blow into in order to produce sounds, for example a trumpet, a clarinet, a flute, a recorder. English = wind instrument.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To play a wind instrument.

window.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To open a space in a wall or roof or in the side of a vehicle, often with glass in it so that light can pass through it and people can see through it; to open a window.

window%20frame.description: (As a Noun) A support for the glass in a window that goes around the edge of the window. English = window frame.; (As a Noun) In a vehicle, a strip of rubber that seals the edge of a door or window against the rain and wind . English = weather strip.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for WEATHER STRIP for most signers (but signers can represent this visually using depicting signs in context). This recommended expression is a compound of the signs WINDOW + FRAME. Source: Victorian College for the Deaf.

windowpane.description: (As a Noun) A flat sheet of glass in a window or a door. English = windowpane, pane, pane of glass; (As a Noun) A hard transparent substance that windows and bottles are made from. English = glass.

windscreen%20washers.description: (General Definition) The flicking of objects or the squirting liquids up towards you, or any thing or any action directly or indirectly associated with this, especially car windscreen washer jets.; (As a Noun) Two small outlets at the bottom of the outside of a car windscreen that squirt water onto the glass in order to clean it. English = windscreen washers.

windscreen%20wiper.description: (As a Noun) Long thin pieces of metal with a rubber edge which are electrically operated and which wipe rain from the windscreen of a vehicle. English = windscreen wiper.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To operate the windscreen wipers on a vehicle.

wind%20up.description: (As a Noun) The handle used to wind up the window in a car door.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wind up the window in a car door.

wind%20up%20(watch).description: (As a Noun) The turning mechanism that winds a watch.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To wind up a watch.

wine.description: (As a Noun) An alcoholic drink made from grapes. There are two main kinds, red and white. English = wine.

winger%20(sport).description: (General Definition) The action of beating or flapping wings, or any real or imagined creature that is able to fly or, especially, the body parts with which they fly.; (As a Noun) The two parts of the body of some animals, insects and birds that are used for flying. English = wings.; (As a Noun) In football or hockey, an attacking player who plays mainly on the far left or the far right of the pitch. English = winger.

wintertime.description: (As a Noun) The period of time during which winter lasts. English = wintertime.

wiping.description: (As a Noun) The act of rubbing the surface of something lightly in order to remove dirt or liquid from it. English = wiping.; (As a Noun) The drying of plates, knives, forks, and other things with a cloth when they have been washed after a meal. English = wiping up, drying up.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To rub the surface of something lightly in order to remove dirt or liquid from it. English = wipe.

wipe%20off.description: (As a Noun) The complete removal of something, especially when it is something that you do not want or need. English = elimination, eradication.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To remove something completely, especially when it is something that you do not want or need. English = eliminate, eradicate.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To remove an item from a surface, especially something written on a page, a name from a list, or information on a computer disk. English = erase, strike off, wipe off, delete.

wiper%20(windscreen%20wiper).description: (As a Noun) Long thin pieces of metal with a rubber edge which are electrically operated and which wipe rain from the windscreen of a vehicle. English = windscreen wiper.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To operate the windscreen wipers on a vehicle.

wipe%20up.description: (As a Noun) The act of rubbing the surface of something lightly in order to remove dirt or liquid from it. English = wiping.; (As a Noun) The drying of plates, knives, forks, and other things with a cloth when they have been washed after a meal. English = wiping up, drying up.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To rub the surface of something lightly in order to remove dirt or liquid from it. English = wipe.

wiping%20up.description: (As a Noun) The act of rubbing the surface of something lightly in order to remove dirt or liquid from it. English = wiping.; (As a Noun) The drying of plates, knives, forks, and other things with a cloth when they have been washed after a meal. English = wiping up, drying up.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To rub the surface of something lightly in order to remove dirt or liquid from it. English = wipe.

wire%20(telegram).description: (As a Noun) The act of sending a message out along a wire to another place.; (As a Noun) A message that has been sent out along a wire to another place. English = wire, telegram.; (As a Noun) Information which has been sent from one place to another by any means whatsoever. English = message.

wisdom.description: (As a Noun) The ability to use your experience and knowledge in order to make sensible decisions and judgments. English = wisdom; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be able to use your experience and knowledge in order to make sensible decisions and judgments mostly because you are both old and intelligent. English = (be) wise.

witch.description: (As a Noun) A woman who is believed to have magic powers, especially evil ones. English = witch.

witch's%20hat.description: (As a Noun) A covering that you wear on your head which is tall and peaked. English = (peaked) hat.; (As a Noun) A long peaked black hat that witches are often portrayed as wearing. English = witch's hat.; (As a Noun) The peaked hat often worn by scouts. English = scout's hat.

with%20(go%20with).description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To go somewhere in the company of one or more other persons or things. English = go with, go together.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To move together as a group, go as a party.

without.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To not have something. English = (be) without.; (As Modifier) Used to join two sentences together. The action in the second sentence does not happen. English = without.

woman.description: (As a Noun) Adult female human being. English = woman (singular), women (plural).; (As a Noun) A polite way of referring to an adult female human being (woman). English = lady.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To behave or look like a woman. English = (be) womanly, (be) feminine.

womb.description: (As a Noun) The part inside a woman's body where a baby grows before it is born. English = womb.; (Note) This sign was created in 1979 for use in Australasian Signed English in some schools for the deaf and it does not appear to be widely used. However, some deaf people and their interpreters do use this sign and it may eventually become more commonly accepted.

wombat.description: (As a Noun) A hairy Australian animal which has very short legs and eats plants. English = wombat.

won't.description: (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb or verb phrase to mean that the person responsible for the action does not intend to do it after the time of speaking, i.e., some time in the future. It expresses lack of intent, determination not to or unwillingness. English = won't, will not, wouldn't.

wool.description: (As a Noun) The hair that grows on sheep and other animals. English = wool.; (As a Noun) A material made from animals' wool. It is used for making things such as clothes, blankets, and carpets. English = wool.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be made of wool. English = (be) woollen, (be) woolly.

word%20order.description:
(As a Noun) In grammar, the arrangement of words or signs in a language according to rules or common use. 
English = syntax, word order, grammar

work%20out.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To think about a mystery or a problem and solve it or understand it. English = work out, figure out.; (As a Verb or Adjective) In an educational context (e.g., essay or exam), to make an examination and judgement of a situation or of a person's work or ideas. English = criticise. Formal English = critique.

workplace%20health%20and%20safety%20(whs.description: (As a Noun) WHS (Workplace Health and Safety) are the rules protecting the health, safety and welfare of people engaged in work or employment.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English term WORKPLACE HEALTH AND SAFETY (WHS). There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for WORKPLACE HEALTH AND SAFETY (WHS) (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic). If you know a sign for WORKPLACE HEALTH AND SAFETY (WHS)used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

worksafe%20australia.description: (As a Noun) An Australian government organisation that looks after national policy relating to Work Health and Safety and workers' compensation. English = Worksafe Australia

workshop.description: (As a Noun) A period of discussion or practical work in which a group of people learn about a particular subject by sharing their knowledge or experience. English = workshop.

world%20federation%20of%20the%20deaf.description: (As a Noun) An international association which represents deaf people. English = World Federation of the Deaf (WFD).

worn%20out.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be no good for anything, not right for its supposed purpose, not successful. English = (be) useless, (be) hopeless.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be no longer good for its purpose because something is too old and broken, or used too much and no longer efficient or working. English = worn out.

worse.description: (As a Noun) A thing which is very bad indeed and more so than all the other things of its type you can compare it with. English = the worst.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be one of two things which you dislike more than the other thing. The one you dislike is very bad and more so than the other thing you can compare it with. English = (be) worse.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be more ill than you were before; to be more sick. English = (be) worse, get worse, worsen.

wound%20(injury).description: (As a Noun) An unpleasant feeling of discomfort from a part of your body. English = pain.; (As a Noun) A painful place on your body where the skin is infected. English = sore.; (As a Noun) Damage done to a person's body. English = injury, harm.

wrestling.description: (As a Noun) A sport in which two people wrestle and try to throw each other to the ground. English = wrestling.; (As a Noun) A person who wrestles as a sport. English = wrestler.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To fight someone by forcing them into painful positions or throwing them to the ground, rather than by hitting them. English = wrestle.

wriggle.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) Of a person, to be on the floor wriggling and kicking in excitement or pleasure like an infant. English = wriggle, writhe.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of any experience, to be extremely enjoyable and pleasant.; (As a Verb or Adjective) Of food, to have a very pleasant taste. English = (be) delicious.

wrist.description: (As a Noun) The part of your body between your hand and your arm which bends when you move your hand. English = wrist.

wristwatch.description: (As a Noun) A small clock that you wear on a strap on your wrist. English = watch, wristwatch.; (As a Noun) A specific point in time which can be stated in hours and minutes and is shown on clocks and watches. English = time.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To measure the amount of time that something takes to happen. English = time.

write.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To write a list.

write%20down.description: (As a Noun) A sheet of paper or a document that has a lot of writing, printing or information on it. English = document, text, written information.; (As a Noun) Instructions for preparing any type of food. It will have a list of ingredients, and describe the steps to prepare and combine them. English = recipe.×To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser thatsupports HTML5 video; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put a large amount of written information onto a document. English = write down, type.

write%20off.description: (As a Noun) A car that is so badly damaged in an accident that it is considered by you (or your insurance company) to be worthless because it cannot be fixed or it would be too expensive to fix. Idiomatic English = write off.; (As a Noun) An amount of money that you accept that you have lost (through bad business, misfortune, etc.) and that you accept you will not get back. Idiomatic English = write off.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To judge a car to be worthless or beyond repair because it is so badly damaged. Idiomatic English = write off.

writing.description: (General Definition) The action of holding something small and using it to mark a surface of some kind or any action or any thing associated with this in context.; (As a Noun) The act or result of using a pen or pencil to produce words, letters, or numbers. English = writing.; (As a Noun) A long thin object which you use to write in ink. English = pen.

stupid me.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To feel guilty or embarrassed because someone has discovered you doing something wrong or foolish.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To feel embarrassed or ashamed because of something which has happened to you.; (Interactive) Used alone to express regret at having done something wrong or stupid. English = 'How stupid of me!', 'How could I have done that!'

x.description: (As a Noun) The letter X in the one-handed manual alphabets.

x-ray.description: (As a Noun) X-RAYS are a type of radiation that can pass through most solid materials. X-RAYS are used by doctors to take a picture and examine the bones or organs inside your body.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To X-RAY means to use a special machine to pass x-rays through parts of a person’s body to make a picture of the bones or organs inside.; (Note) There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for X-RAY. If you know a sign for X-RAY used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

x%20(value%20of%20%22x%22).description: (As a Noun) In mathematics and algebra, the letter "x" is often used to mean a value that is not yet known. It is called a "variable" or sometimes an "unknown". When referring to ‘the value of “x”’ in discussing mathematics and algebra, this sign is used for “x”.

y.description: (As a Noun) The letter Y in the one-handed manual alphabets.

yacht.description: (As a Noun) A boat with sails used for racing or for pleasure trips. English = yacht.; (As a Noun) The sport or activity of sailing a yacht. English = yachting.; (As a Noun) A large piece of material attached to a mast of a ship. The wind blows against the material and pushes the ship along. English = sail.

yarn%20(story).description: (As a Noun) A story that someone tells, often a true story with added details which they have invented to make it more interesting. English = tale, yarn, story.; (As a Noun) A person who talks a lot. English = chatterbox.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To tell a story; to tell a tale (often exaggerated or only partially true). Idiomatic English = spin a yarn.

yawn.description: (As a Noun) The act of opening your mouth wide and breathing in more air than usual. You often do this when you are tired or bored. English = yawn.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To open your mouth wide and breath in more air than usual, often because you are tired or bored. English = yawn.

year.description: (As a Noun) A period of 365 or 366 days, beginning on the first of January and ending on the thirty-first of December. It is made up of twelve months. English = year.

year%20(for%20a%20year).description: (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence or next to a verb to show that the action or situation happens throughout the year or lasts an entire year. English = year round, year long, for a year.

year%20(last%20year).description: (As a Noun) A period of a year before the time of talking. English = the past year.; (As a Noun) A period of one year before some reference time in the past. English = the previous year, the year before that.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence to mean the action took place sometime during the previous twelve months or year. English = in the past year, during the past year.

year%20long.description: (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence or next to a verb to show that the action or situation happens throughout the year or lasts an entire year. English = year round, year long, for a year.

yearning.description: (As a Noun) The deep feeling of unhappiness you have when you want something very much that you cannot yet have, especially the return of someone who has gone away. English = longing, yearning.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To want something very much that you cannot yet have, especially the return of someone who has gone away. English = miss someone. Idiomatic English = long for someone, pine for someone, yearn for someone.

year%20(next%20year).description: (As a Noun) A period of a year after the time of talking. English = the next year.; (As a Noun) A period of one year after some reference time in the past. English = the following year, the year after that.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence to mean the action takes place sometime during the following twelve months or year; or after at least a year. English = in the next year, during the next year; in a year's time.

year%20(one%20year).description: (As a Noun) For a period of one year. English = one year.; (Note) This is really a blend of ONE/YEAR and is used when talking about how long something lasted or will last. You can extend one or two more fingers for ‘two years’ or ‘three years’ but for numbers of years larger than three you make two clearly separate signs: first the number, then the sign for YEAR.

year%20round.description: (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence or next to a verb to show that the action or situation happens throughout the year or lasts an entire year. English = year round, year long, for a year.

years.description: (As a Noun) Periods of 365 or 366 days, beginning on the first of January and ending on the thirty-first of December. They are made up of twelve months. English = years.

year%20(this%20past%20year).description: (As a Noun) A recurring period of time (such as a week, month or year) before the time of speaking. The unit of time has already been mentioned. English = this week, this month, this year, etc.; (As a Noun) The used up or elapsed time within the unit of time (week, month, year, etc.) being talked about; this past week, this past month, this past year, etc.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence, or immediately next to a verb, to mean the action takes place sometime during the previous unit of time being talked about, or before some other reference time.

year%20(this%20year).description: (As a Noun) A recurring period of time (such as a week, month or year) the unit of which has already been mentioned and which the signer is in at the time of speaking. English = this week, this month, this year, etc.; (As a Noun) The remaining time within the unit of time (week, month, year, etc.) being talked about; the rest of this week, this month, this year, etc.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning or end of a sentence, or immediately next to a verb, to mean the action takes place sometime during the following unit of time being talked about (week, month, year, etc.), or after some other time reference point. English = during this week (month, year), during that week (month, year), this time.

yell.description: (As a Noun) A loud shout given by someone who is excited, afraid, or in pain. English = yell.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To shout loudly, usually because you are excited, angry, or in pain. English = yell.

yellow.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To be the colour of lemons or egg yolks. English = (be) yellow.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To become yellow. English = yellow, turn yellow.

yes.description: (Interactive) Used alone to signify agreement, to accept something or to say that something is true. English = 'Yes.'

yesterday.description: (As a Noun) The day before today. English = yesterday.; (As a Noun) The day before any given day; the previous day.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be the most recent period of time, event, or thing. Used immediately before a time sign such as 'night', 'week', 'month', 'year', or before event sign such as 'birthday', 'marriage'. English = (be) last.

yesteryear.description: (As a Noun) The year before this year; last year; yesteryear.; (As a Noun) The year before a given or particular other year; the previous year.; (As Modifier) Used at the beginning of a sentence or next to a verb to mean the action in that sentence took place one year before the current year, or one year before the year being talked about. English = last year, the previous year, the year before that.

yet%20(not%20yet).description: (Interactive) Used in response to a question about when something should happen or be done to mean that you think it should not be done now, although it will have to be done at a later time. English = 'Not yet.'; (As Modifier) Used immediately next to a verb to mean the action has not happened up to the present time. English = not yet.

yield%20(surrender).description: (General Definition) The action of throwing something up in the air, such as a ball, or any thing or action directly or indirectly associated with this, such as the action of throwing up your hands or arms as a gesture of 'giving up'.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To stop doing or having something. English = give up.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To admit that you cannot do something and stop trying to do it. English = give up.

yonder%20(very%20far).description: (As a Noun) The amount of space between two places. English = distance.; (As a Noun) The distance between two places, especially when that distance is considerable; a long way.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To be located at a great distance away. English = (be) far, (be) far away, (be) distant.

you.description: (Interactive) Used to refer to one of several addressees. English = you there.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used to refer to the person the signer is addressing. English = you.; (As a Pointing Sign) Can be used to refer to the location of the addressee. English = there.

you%20first.description: (Interactive) Used alone to mean to the person it is directed at that you think they are next to do something, when you are both waiting to do the same thing, but that you are after them. English = 'I'm after you!', 'You then me!'

you%20know.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To know someone or something because you have seen or heard them before or because someone has described them to you. English = recognise.; (Interactive) Use alone to seek confirmation that your conversational partner knows who or what you are talking about.; (As Modifier) Used to introduce a topic of conversation, just before you name the person or the thing, as in "You know John, well....", "You know that new smoking law, well...".

you%20(plural).description: (As a Pointing Sign) Used to refer to people the signer is talking to. English = you. Informal English = yous, youse, you lot, you-all, all of you.; (Note) The two flat hand variants can be more polite and formal and are especially used when signing to a large crowd of people or giving a speech.; (Note) The sign is usually used immediately next to a verb and can mean the people do the action or that the action is done to them (because another person or thing does the action). The interpretation depends on a number of factors, such as the type of verb and the number of other people or things talked about in the sentence or which of them are relevant in the context.

your.description: (As a Pointing Sign) Used to mean something is owned or possessed by the person the sign is addressing. You put it before or after a noun sign to say what is possessed. English = your.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used alone to mean something is owned or possessed by the person the signer is addressing. Used alone without saying what is possessed if it is clear from context or because someone has mentioned it before. English = yours.

your%20(not%20your).description: (As a Pointing Sign) Used to mean something is NOT owned or possessed by the person the signer is addressing. You put it before or after a noun sign to say what is possessed. English = not your.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used to mean something is NOT owned or possessed by the person the signer is addressing. Used alone without saying what is NOT possessed if it is clear from context or because someone has mentioned it before. English = not yours.; (Note) Like the pointing signs for ‘I/me’, ‘you’, ‘he/him’, ‘she/her’, ‘it’, ‘we/us’ and ‘they/them’ this sign points in a particular direction. Also, like the possessive pointing signs ‘my/mine’, ‘your/yours’, etc., the sign points or indicates with the palm. It points in the direction of the thing or person it is referring to (in this case the addressee, i.e., ‘you’). Similarly, the other possessive signs in this dictionary can add the final negative  open handshape to mean ‘not mine’, ‘not its’, ‘not his’, ‘not hers’, ‘not ours’ and ‘not theirs’.

your%20(plural).description: (As a Pointing Sign) This sign is placed before or after a noun sign, though usually before it, to mean the thing is owned or possessed by people the signer is addressing. English = your.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used to mean something is owned or possessed by people the signer is addressing. Used alone without saying what is possessed if it is clear from context or because someone has mentioned it before. English = yours.

yourself.description: (As a Pointing Sign) The sign is used immediately before or after a verb to mean the person the signer is addressing did the action of the verb alone (i.e., without anyone else present) or without the help of anyone else (i.e., the person is responsible for the action). English = yourself.; (As a Pointing Sign) The sign can be used immediately before or after a verb (but usually after) to mean the action of the verb was done by the person the signer is addressing to the very same person and not by anyone or anything else, i.e., it makes the verb reflexive. English = yourself.

yourselves.description: (As a Pointing Sign) Used immediately before or after a verb to mean more than one  person (when the signer is addressing two or more other people), but not the signer, did the action of the verb without the help of yet other people. The signer sweeps the sign past the people being addressed. English = yourselves.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used immediately before or after a verb to mean more than one  person, but not the signer, did the action of the verb to the very same people, i.e., it makes the verb reflexive. The signer sweeps the sign past the people being addressed. English = yourselves.

yours%20(not%20yours).description: (As a Pointing Sign) Used to mean something is NOT owned or possessed by the person the signer is addressing. You put it before or after a noun sign to say what is possessed. English = not your.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used to mean something is NOT owned or possessed by the person the signer is addressing. Used alone without saying what is NOT possessed if it is clear from context or because someone has mentioned it before. English = not yours.; (Note) Like the pointing signs for ‘I/me’, ‘you’, ‘he/him’, ‘she/her’, ‘it’, ‘we/us’ and ‘they/them’ this sign points in a particular direction. Also, like the possessive pointing signs ‘my/mine’, ‘your/yours’, etc., the sign points or indicates with the palm. It points in the direction of the thing or person it is referring to (in this case the addressee, i.e., ‘you’). Similarly, the other possessive signs in this dictionary can add the final negative  open handshape to mean ‘not mine’, ‘not its’, ‘not his’, ‘not hers’, ‘not ours’ and ‘not theirs’.

yours%20(plural).description: (As a Pointing Sign) This sign is placed before or after a noun sign, though usually before it, to mean the thing is owned or possessed by people the signer is addressing. English = your.; (As a Pointing Sign) Used to mean something is owned or possessed by people the signer is addressing. Used alone without saying what is possessed if it is clear from context or because someone has mentioned it before. English = yours.

yugoslavia.description: (As a Noun) A former republic in south eastern Europe, between Italy and Greece. English Yugoslavia.; (As a Noun) A person from Yugoslavia. English = Yugoslav, Yugoslavian.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To come from or relate to Yugoslavia. English = (be) Yugoslav, (be) Yugoslavian.

z.description: (As a Noun) The letter Z in the Irish and American one-handed alphabets.

zebra.description: (General Definition) Anything with stripes, strips or straps on it, such as striped clothing or a harness, or any thing, animal or action that can be associated with this in context, especially a zebra.; (As a Noun) An African wild animal which looks like a horse with black and white stripes on its body. English = zebra.

zest.description: (As a Noun) The ZEST is the outer skin of citrus fruit, used as a garnish or flavouring.; (Note) The signer in the video is giving an Auslan explanation of the English keyword ZEST. There appears to be no commonly used Auslan sign for ZEST (but some signers represent this visually using depicting signs, once they have established the topic).  If you know a sign for ZEST used by you or other Auslan users (deaf people or interpreters) please go to "Report missing sign" and supply details. Thank you.

zion.description: (As a Noun) In the Bible, the hill or mount at Jerusalem, the site of the Temple. English = Zion.

zip.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To fasten an item of clothing using a zipper. English = zip, zip up.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put on an item of clothing worn on the torso that has a zip up front such as a jacket, a windcheater, or a track suit top.

zip%20open.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To unfasten an item of clothing using a zipper. English = unzip.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To take off an item of clothing worn on the torso that has a zip up front such as a jacket, a windcheater, or a track suit top.

zipper%20(trousers).description: (As a Noun) The front opening on a pair of trousers. English = fly, zipper.; (As a Noun) A pair of pants or trousers that has a fly, especially a pair of jeans.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put on a pair of trousers, pants or jeans that has a fly.

zip%20up.description: (As a Verb or Adjective) To fasten an item of clothing using a zipper. English = zip, zip up.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To put on an item of clothing worn on the torso that has a zip up front such as a jacket, a windcheater, or a track suit top.

zoo.description: (As a Noun) A park where wild animals are kept so that people can look at them. English = zoo.

zoom.description: (As a Noun) The brand name of an internet-based communication software platform that combines video conferencing, online meetings, chat, and mobile collaboration. English = Zoom.

zoom%20off%20(speed).description: (As a Noun) The process of something becoming unable to be seen and disappearing by moving away into the distance at speed.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To disappear by moving away into the distance at speed. Idomatic English = disappear from sight, vanish from sight.; (As a Verb or Adjective) To leave a place quickly or suddenly. Idiomatic English = dash off, zoom off.
